subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Bruce Scott, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

It is almost 80 years since an armistice restored peace after the war that the entire world thought would end all wars. Sadly, peace did not last. However, the Australian repatriation system, born at the same time to care for those who returned from the Great War, has not only endured but evolved to meet the ever changing needs of the veteran community. Today, we remain true to the goals of repatriation. More importantly, after eighty years we continue to improve the benefits provided to those Australians whose service deserves our ongoing recognition and practical assistance. This bill contains the most significant expansion of veterans' benefits for many years.

From 1 January 1999, eligibility for a Repatriation Health CardâFor All Conditions, better known as a gold card, will be extended to Australian veterans aged 70 or over who faced danger from hostile forces of the enemy during World War II. This will provide these veterans with the certainty and comfort that comes with knowing that their health needs will always be met. Full health care benefits were extended to World War I veterans 55 years after the end of that conflict. In providing this further extension of the gold card, Australian World War II veterans aged 70 years and over with World War II qualifying service will receive the same benefit 54 years after the end of that war.

The criterion on which this extension of eligibility is based, is the `incurred danger' test, formally known as `qualifying service'. This qualifying service must have occurred during the `period of hostilities' as defined in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. This covers the period from 3 September 1939 to 29 October 1945 inclusive. Qualifying service is also a criterion for service pension. Service pension was introduced in 1936 for those veterans who served in a theatre of war. It was intended to recognise that these veterans faced danger from hostile forces of the enemy and endured the deprivations, horror and hardship of war.

World War II veterans with qualifying service are now an average age of 76. Their health care is a very high priority for this government. This initiative extends to an estimated additional 50,000 veterans a comprehensive range of health care services, including private patient hospital care. Other health services provided through the gold card include: choice of doctor; pharmaceuticals at a concessional rate; optical care; physiotherapy; dental care; podiatry care and products; and chiropractic services. Eligible veterans, that is, those aged 70 or over with World War II qualifying service, will be eligible for these benefits regardless of their level of income or assets and irrespective of whether they have war-caused disabilities or conditions.

They will join an estimated 260,000 veterans who already have a gold card. Of the 50,000 additional veterans expected to become newly eligible for a gold card, approximately 17,000 are current holders of a white cardâthat is they are only eligible for health treatment for their war-caused disabilities and conditions. This initiative, costing around $500 million over four years, is an important means of recognising the willing sacrifice made by veterans in Australia's time of need and of expressing our profound gratitude for their courage and dedication.

Extension of the gold card has been a top priority of the government and also of the Returned and Services League and other ex-service organisations. I am pleased that this initiative fulfils yet another coalition election commitment and further demonstrates the government's commitment to providing older Australians with greater security and stability. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1998)
Customs Proposal No. 4 (1998)

The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1995. Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 (1998) and Customs Tariff Proposal No. 4 (1998) formally place before parliament, as required by law, proposed reductions in the excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline (avgas) which were notified in Commonwealth Gazette No. S225 on 21 May 1998 during the recent recess of parliament.

The alterations contained in these proposals implement the reduction of 2.6 cents per litre in the rate of excise and customs duty on avgas with effect from 25 May 1998, as previously announced by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon. Mark Vaile MP. This will deliver significant savings in operating costs to the general aviation sector, as part of the federal government's plan to abolish the Airservices Australia component of the excise and customs duty on avgas.

This reduction is the second instalment of Airservices Australia's pricing reforms and removes the element of the avgas duty relating to the provision of en-route services. The first instalment was delivered in 1997 with the introduction of location specific charges for rescue and fire fighting services.

A proposed third instalment would see the removal of the remaining avgas duty directed to Airservices Australiaâ13.092 cents per litreâin conjunction with the introduction of location specific pricing for terminal navigation services from 1 July 1998. This is in line with the government's commitment to implement a fair and equitable system for recover ing the costs of providing air traffic services to the industry.

The general aviation sector now pays about $17 million per year through the avgas levy for services that they do not necessarily use. By removing this tax, the government is ensuring that there is a transparency in the charges collected by Airservices Australia. The users who will benefit include private aircraft owners, sport aviation participants, flying training school operators, agricultural aircraft operators and smaller charter operators. The cut in fuel costs will mean real benefits to the private pilots and small operators. The government expects the reduction in duty to be passed on to consumers almost immediately through an equivalent drop in the price of avgas.
Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the house.
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

Constitution Place is the small park on the eastern end of the gardens around Old Parliament House. It is a match for Magna Carta Place, on the western end. subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 June, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âWhen my presentation on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998 was interrupted last night, I had just begun to comment on record keeping relief for benefits of no more than $5,000 for fringe benefits tax purposes. I had said that at first blush the amendments read quite well. However, they will at best have a very limited practical application, according to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry WA, because the $5,000 threshold equates to `little more than one modest motor vehicle' and will therefore exclude the majority of small businesses.

speech.para: Given that small businesses paid more than $1,475 million on motor vehicle benefits in the 1997 FBT tax year and the government's commitment to implement only those small business task force reforms which would not adversely affect the revenue, it is no wonder that it has opted for a threshold amount that will benefit only the smallest of small enterprises. But even those small business proprietors who will benefit from the exemption would be wise to heed the advice of those tax and accounting professionals who have expressed their concern about the nature of this exemption.

The CCIWA has made clear its position that the failure of a small business operator to maintain accurate records `would constitute imprudent risk taking for most businesses'. Small business owners must understand that, regardless of whether they are required to submit FBT records to the tax office, the onus of proof will remain with the taxpayer to advise of any changes to levels of benefits provided. In other words, the administrative burden on small business owners will remain unchanged.

These provisions do not achieve their stated purpose. Penalties for non-disclosure will continue and, if recent ATO audit practices are anything to go by, the tax office will be watching small businesses very carefully indeed. In the 16 April 1996 edition of the Australian Financial Review, Mr Ian Langford-Brown, Director of Taxation at the Institute of Chartered Accountants, noted that the Australian Taxation Office imposed almost $3 million in penalties on businesses for filing incorrect FBT returns in the previous year. It would be an act of commercial folly for a small business proprietor to fail to maintain current FBT record keeping standards despite government invitations to do the opposite.

Also, as the Taxation Institute of Australia, the TIA, makes clear, while section 135H gives employers the right to `choose' how to work out the aggregate FBT amount, there are no parameters guiding them in their choices. No mention is made in either the bill or the explanatory memorandum of the time frame in which the choices could be made, how the choice should be made and if, once made, the choice can be varied. This is entirely unsatisfactory. I call on the responsible minister to explain how the government intends to correct this. Another point of concern for the Taxation Institute of Australia is section 135C(b), which provides that an employer will not have a base year if the FBT return was lodged late. The TIA insists that there should be no deferential treatment on the grounds of timing of lodgement.

Schedule 13 of the bill provides for further changes in the franking of dividends by exempting companies and former exempting companies. The government has already sought to effect significant changes to dividend streaming and the franking of credits in a separate tax bill debated in this place earlier this year. The criticisms I have noted in respect of this schedule relate generally to a lack of clarity of definition in both the bill and the accompanying explanatory memorandum. As if tax professionals and taxpayers generally do not have a hard enough task in understanding and applying the terms of the existing taxation acts, their job is being made harder by new legislative measures like this one which are ambiguous and undermine certainty.

The Taxation Institute of Australia has expressed its concern about the definition of what the government deems to be an exempting company and queries why the definition outlined in the explanatory memorandum fails to closely mirror the description of companies that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced in his May 1996 press release. The institute also suggests that the concepts of accountable shares, accountable interests and prescribed persons remain too broad and require clarification. As I see it, the government has two choices. It can make the necessary corrections now and improve the certainty of the measure or it can wait and be forced to bring on another technical corrections bill into this place further down the track. Surely the first option is the more sensible.

While the coalition draftsmen are at it, they may care to address an inherent bias in the schedule. The government's support for a reform of the taxation system is premised on its being unnecessarily complicated, inefficient and inequitableâand it is right on every count. I take this opportunity to point out to the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) (Mr Miles) an in-built inequity in this measure.

As it stands, a majority non-resident shareholder in a company will be entitled to a withholding tax exemption in respect of franking dividends. In contrast, a resident minority shareholderâthat is, someone with five per cent of the total sharesâis excluded from the benefits of franking credits on franked dividends simply because 95 per cent of the shares in the company of which it is a shareholder are held by a non-resident. The TIA argues that this inequity is `inexplicable' and that such an anomaly requires correction before the passage of this bill. I call on the government to commit itself to make the necessary corrections.

The retrospective nature of the concessional treatment of exempted dividends also warrants closer inspection by the Treasurer and his junior ministers and parliamentary secretary. As the TIA correctly observes, while a reference was made by the minister in his May 1996 press release about the distribution of exempting credits to continuing non-resident shareholders by a former exempting company, it was not elaborated on. The TIA therefore believes it to be fair that the concessional treatment for exempted dividends be applied prospectively and the bill amended accordingly. My opposition to retrospective taxation measures is well recorded in this place and I concur with the TIA in their push for the prospective application of schedule 13.

The government suggests that the objective behind these changes to the imputation system is to prevent tax minimisation by limiting the source of franking credits. However, it fails now, as it did in the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997 to provide even the most basic of information on the financial impact of this initiative, and that is surely unacceptable. According to the explanatory memorandum, the effect of these changes to the franking of dividends by exempting and former exempting companies will result in `unquantifiable revenue gains to the extent of existing tax minimisation'.

I am a little curious to understand how this might be so. It is now more than 12 months after the delivery of the 1997-98 budget measures, which saw the first tranche of changes in imputation, and the coalition is yet to provide any evidence to back up its claim that abuses in the imputation system undermine national revenue. I take this opportunity to remind members that imputation was introduced principally to improve the efficiency of our domestic capital market. The fact that up to 35 per cent of franking credits in Australia are not used implies that the Australian market is only two-thirds as efficient as it could be. Up to 35 per cent of franking credits remain unused because the shareholders receiving them are taxed at a low rate, are tax exempt or are non-residents, suggesting that companies are already limited in the manner in which they can provide franking credits.

And yet the government claims that these changes are required to limit the circumstances in which companies which are effectively wholly owned by non-residents or tax-exempts can utilise franking credits. The argument simply does not hold water. If the government wants to be taken seriously on this issue then it needs to start providing some serious facts and figures to back up its claims of abuse.

As recently as the day before yesterday, in an answer during question time, the Treasurer talked at length about the protective measures employed to combat rorts and tax minimisation schemes. Sadly, this entirely honourable pursuit outlined by the Treasurer is undermined by the continued failure of his government to satisfactorily substantiate claims of abuse.

I conclude by observing that I find the approach of the Labor Party in opposition to legislation such as this curious. In his opening address on this bill on behalf of the Labor Party, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) said that the reservations he holds for the legislation will be dealt with in the Senate. In other words, we are using the House of Representatives as a clearing house. The opposition is not able, equipped or willing to debate the legislation in this place, to make its concerns known in detail or to propose any amendments it may have. Instead it is leaving it to its colleagues in the Senate. I find that a rather curious approachâif it is not demeaning of the House it certainly shows a lack of either confidence or ability to deliberate on legislation, complicated as it might be and indeed as it nearly always is in taxation matters.

talk.start.para: âThe Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998 is a catch-all bill and it makes various amendments in relation to taxation provisions. The particular provision about which I want to speak is schedule 5, which provides for donations of $2 or more to the Menzies Research Centre to be deductible if made after 2 April 1998. It in fact puts into effect the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 10 October 1996 that donations of $2 or more would be deductible. Indeed, it was in the Treasurer's defence of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in another censure motion against the Prime Minister for misleading this House that I was reminded of the background to this particular provision. The Treasurer was very kind to remind us that last Monday was not the first time the Prime Minister had deceived the public and withheld from the public domain that which should have been before it. The Treasurer also helpfully stated, in relation to the Prime Minister's three-year memory lapse:

speech.para: Isn't it convenient to have a memory that only goes back three years?

Obviously he has not been in the country for the past week to hear the Prime Minister foundering on his definition of `never, ever'âa definition which the Prime Minister now says lasts only for three years. Again the Treasurer helpfully reminded us that it is convenient to have a memory that goes back only three years.

We are not opposed to the deductibility amendment but I want to take the opportunity to highlight the sorry history behind this amendment. Again, it is a history of the Prime Minister in deceit, cover-ups, another conflict of interestâthis time by the Prime Ministerâand a betrayal of trust. It involves a Prime Minister who was a director of a company and did not disclose it; a Prime Minister who, as a director of that company, presided over a cabinet decision which benefited that company and did not declare his interest at the cabinet meeting; and a Prime Minister who, when he was caught outâwhen he realised that he should have declaredâdid not fess up but resigned secretly from the position that he held.

We need to be reminded of the background of the Prime Minister's unctuous heralding of a new era in politics were he to be elected as Prime Minister. In his campaign launch speech prior to the 1996 election he said, according to a story in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 February, that the thing he most wanted was:
`a covenant or understanding' with the people; a covenant of trust, in which, in return for the voters' decision to make him Prime Minister, he would deliver honest and faithful government.
`The most important thing any government can do is to build a sense of trust, a sense of integrity, a sense of honesty and a sense of commitment to the Australian people.'

Two years after that statement the Prime Minister has failed utterly to build any sense of trust, any sense of integrity, any honesty or any commitment. This is a Prime Minister who said, also prior to the last election, that the coalition would `never ever introduce a GST'. Now the tax that he said he would never ever introduce he wants us to believe will never ever go up. Also, he will not tell the Australian publicâwhom he wants this covenant of trust withâthe details of this new tax, even though he has been promising for 12 months that the details would be available `soon'.

This is a Prime Minister who misled the parliament when asked if it were true that the government members tax consultative task force on taxation was told not to make recommendations to the government. The Prime Minister, in a rather out of character show of decisiveness, answered: `No, no, no' to that questionâan emphatic `No' to the proposition that this committee had been asked by the government not to make recommendations to it. That defies belief. He must have known because the chairman of the committee knew. The Treasurer told him. He gave instructions, and not only to the chairman of the committee, Mr Brian Gibson, one of the Prime Minister's fallen seven so far, not to make recommendations; all members, it would seem, who participated in that committee were fully aware of it.

We have not seen the report but I bet, if it were available, that we would not see the `R' word anywhereâ`It is recommended that' or `Recommendations to the government'. Why? Because they were muzzled beforehand. And who muzzled them? The government muzzled them, with the Prime Minister's knowledge. Yet he came into this House and said he knew nothing of that muzzling. That defies belief. We have seen him spend the last week scurrying about in an effort to avoid the fallout from misleading the House over it.

He says he did not know, and he expects us to believe him. The problem with this Prime Minister is that he is a serial offender in deceiving and in hiding the truth. The only covenant or understanding this Prime Minister has succeeded in establishing with the Australian people is the following: whenever he opens his mouth, whenever he makes a promise, people understand that he simply cannot be believed. A shining example of this is the Prime Minister's much vaunted code of conduct. The Prime Minister has now ripped up that code of conduct, most graphically over the Warwick Parer affair. The minister for coal who owns a coal mine did not tell the parliament that he had shares in a coal mine. The Prime Minister says `Oh, he only has 16 shares.' The problem is that those 16 shares were worth $2 million and produced a dividend stream over the course of four years of $800,000. Nice if you can get into it! Is this the tax reform the Prime Minister has in mind for the Australian battler? No, only for his flatmate, Warwick Parer.

He has torn up the code of conduct in relation to Warwick Parer because, he said, we have actually got to show him with his fingers in the till. But that is not a breach of a code of conduct; that is corruption. So the Prime Minister is saying: `I no longer have a code of conduct. You have to prove corruption.' If we prove corruption, it would not be in here that the Prime Minister would be grilled. It would be in the courts of law that the likes of the people accused of corruption would be tried. It is a ridiculous proposition. The Prime Minister has torn up his code of conduct.

But it is not only in relation to his ministers that he has torn up the code of conduct. His own actions in relation to the Menzies Research Centre, the subject of this bill, also involved the Prime Minister breaching his own code of conduct. It is the one example where he has not just breached his ministerial code of conduct but has also breached the requirements of disclosure to this House. In other words, he has misled this House and again he has let down that covenant, that trust, that he says he wants with the Australian people.
Let us just remind ourselves of what that code of conduct says.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. It is not a habit of mine to frequently take points of order, as you are aware, but I do think that by any measure the member for Hotham is straying from the purpose of the bill. If he believes that the Prime Minister has misled the House, there are other forms of the House that he should use for such an allegation.

âThere are two points to the point of order the honourable member has raised that I will deal with. I am sure that the honourable member for Hotham realises that he must couch his terms very carefully when making allegations regarding the behaviour of the Prime Minister. To the second point about relevance, I was about to investigate how wide ranging the debate had been. Apparently it has been wide ranging. The honourable member for Hotham is now coming around directly to one aspect of the bill and I am sure that he will keep in mind that he needs to be relevant to the legislation before us.

âAbsolutely, Mr Deputy Speaker, because what I have said is that this relates to the Menzies centre, a foundation which benefited from a decision of the government and of the cabinet over which the Prime Minister presided but which he did not tell the Australian public about. That is a breach of his code of conduct. It is a breach of the requirements in this House and it is related precisely to why we have a piece of legislation in this House. Do you understand the connection? Well, I will continue with it. What does the Prime Minister's code of conduct state? It states that ministers are requiredâ

âOn the previous point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I presume you understand the connection because the ques tion was directed to me and I would have thought that of itself was unparliamentary conduct.
âI would remind the member for Hotham to direct his remarks through the chair.

âI would be delighted to direct them through you and I thank the Chief Government Whip for drawing my attention to that dreadful indiscretionânever done on that side of the parliament! The Prime Minister's own code of conduct states:

speech.para: Ministers are required to resign directorships in public companies.

John Winston Howard, Prime Minister of Australia, was appointed a director of the Menzies Research Centre Ltd on 29 September 1995. The centre is a company limited by guarantee. He therefore should have resigned his directorship of that public company. He remained a director of the centre after becoming Prime Minister and only resigned secretly on 15 October 1996, interestingly enough just days after the resignations of Senator Short and Senator Gibson for breaching the Prime Minister's code of conduct for not disclosing and after the Prime Minister had said directly to them, `You need to know what your obligations are under my code.' We believe, having admonished his frontbench, he realised himself he was in trouble and so he weaseled his way out. He resigned secretly.
What was the means by which he tried to justify this? He relied, in this parliament, on a dictionary definition of what a public company was.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. You have asked the member for Hotham to come back to the topic. This is not part of the legislation and I would ask youâ
âIt is part of the legislation.
âNo, the Menzies centre deductibility is. That is okay.
âWell, how did it get it?

âWe will come to the Evatt Foundation and all the rest of it later. I am just putting it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the material that is now being put is just going on and on. It is repetition and I do not think it is relevant to this Taxation Laws Amendment Bill at all. I ask you to bring him back to the topic.

âI am sure the honourable member for Hotham realises the need for relevance. He has, at this point in time, outlined that he is speaking to schedule 5. He is speaking to matters related to the issues that are contained in schedule 5. I might add that the parliamentary secretary has already indicated in his point of order one of the ways in which this debate has probably developed and will be rebutted. If there were other issues that were brought in, the fact that this debate has developed into such a wide ranging one would allow that course of action.

âThe Prime Minister tried to rely on the fact that this was not a public company. He tried to use a dictionary definition that a public company was one which offered shares to the public. But this is the Prime Minister, a lawyer by training and a man primarily responsible for all Commonwealth law. The law over which he presides makes it clear that a company limited by guarantee is a public company. The point I am making is that he tried to weasel his way out through a dictionary definition because he knew he was caught by his own code of conduct. The mere fact that the company does not trade in shares is immaterial.

speech.para: The Prime Minister's other desperate argument in relation to the centre was that it was a not for profit company and that he was really not involved in the running of the company. That is also spurious because, in the case of the Commonwealth of Australia v. Friedrich, the court found there was nothing in company law to suggest that the standard expected of a part-time non-executive director of a company not for profit was different from the standard expected of any director of a profit making company.

Despite the semantic gymnastics of the Prime Minister, the case against him is clear. He did not resign the directorship of the Menzies Research Centre when he became Prime Minister, and he should have. How can the Australian public have any faith in a man who flagrantly breaches his own guidelines on integrity and honesty? I was very interested in the dictionary defence in relation to this matter. He did not use the dictionary in relation to `never ever'.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I again raise the point of order in respect of relevance. This is very repetitious. I am not sure how many times I have heard this; it is probably 30 or 40 times now. I do not believe it is relevant to this legislation and I would ask that you draw him back to the debate which is in hand.

âThe honourable member for Hotham is relating his comments to schedule 5. Perhaps he is overly dwelling on the matters that led up to the decision to create this schedule 5 element but I am sure that, in his concluding few minutes, he will make sure that he is relevant to the bill.

âThe relevance is this: we are debating in this parliament a bill to give deductibility. We are not against the deductibility, but the process that led to it: a Prime Ministerâa director of a companyâmaking a decision in a cabinet to benefit that company. So we have a piece of legislation before the parliament that, in the process of coming here, involved a breach of the Prime Minister's own code of conduct. The point I am making is that it is a conflict of interest. The Prime Minister tried to argue in defence that it was not a conflict of interest because this was not a company. But in saying it wasn't a company, he relied on a shonky dictionary definition. When we asked him in the parliament what the dictionary definition of `never ever' was, he said `not for three years'. If you look at the same dictionary that he relied upon, you will see that the definition of `never ever' says:

speech.para: At no time. On no occasion. Not ever. As an emphatic negative. Not at all.

He also redefined the definition of `regular' when he said the cabinet would have regular regional cabinet meetings. They have had them three times in two years. He redefined the word `soon' when he said, `I'm going to Newcastle soon.' Remember when they closed the Newcastle steelworks? `Soon' means `not before I've been to the second test at Lords'. He also redefined the word `immediate' when he said that they would introduce the car tariff legislation immediately. Twelve months on, we still do not have a bill. He redefined the dictionary definition of `continued funding' when he said that he would continue regional development funding, but then cut the funds and abolished the department. He also redefined the word `preference'â`to like better', `to promote or advance a thing preferred', `giving or receiving a favour'â

talk.start.para: âOrder! The honourable member for Hotham should go back to the processes rather than the definitions.

âI will do that; I just have to finish this point on `preference'. What is his new definition of `preference'? `We don't like One Nation, but we will put them ahead of Labor.' This is a Prime Minister who has lost trust. This is a Prime Minister who has breached his covenant. If, in fact, he is going to give tax deductibility to the Menzies Research Centre out of this program, maybe one of the first tasks he should give it is to rewrite the Concise Oxford Dictionary because he has redefined it in this place. If the Menzies Research Centre is to continue to receive the benefits from thisâwhich we do not opposeâwe want to know why the Prime Minister did not fess up; why the Prime Minister has broken his covenant with the Australian public; why the Prime Minister has continued to be deceitful; why the Prime Minister has twisted the truth; and why the Prime Minister has changed definitions. That is what we want to know, and we want to know the true circumstances that led to this bill coming before the House. (Time expired)

âThe Australian public are getting used to the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) griping, whingeing and whining. It happens in question time where they see the aggressive antics of the member for Hotham, and we have heard it againâjust taking up the time of parliament and wasting time. As I said, I have probably heard what he said 30 or 40 times. This is not a constructive way of continuing debate about important legislation like the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998 .

speech.para: I want to rebut a couple of things he said, since the debate has been allowed to continue in that way. The honourable member for Hotham is well known throughout Australia for his R&D syndicatesâwhere billions of dollars were being used. He was looking after his rich mates. He is accusing the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in regard to the Menzies Centre. The implication is that somehow the Prime Minister was going to get some financial benefit. There are no tradeable shares in that company. Yet the member for Hotham protected his rich mates in regard to R&D syndicates in this country, which was costing other taxpayers billions of dollars. It is the height of hypocrisy for the member for Hotham to come in here and waste time, split hairs and be so pharisaical in his approach over the issue of the Menzies Centre.

It is very interesting that we are giving tax deductibility to the Menzies Centre in exactly the same way as there is tax deductibility for the Evatt Foundation. In other words, the Labor side of politicsâthe Evatt Foundationâis getting the same tax deductibility. What do we know about the history of this? Who gave that tax deductibility? It was given by the now Prime Minister back in 1981 when he was Treasurer. He granted tax deductibility status by way of legislation in exactly the same way as tax deductibility is being provided for the Menzies Centre. We have heard 20 minutes of nonsense from the member for Hotham, but that is not new. I guess we are going to hear a lot more nonsense from the member for Hotham who likes wasting the time of the parliament on some of these matters.

There is no doubt that this country, in electing John Howard to the position of Prime Minister, elected a person who is very straightforward and honest. He is a man of integrity and he can be trusted. His commitment to the Australian people is very clear. There is no doubt that the Australian people know of the decency and honesty of John Howard. They have seen that over the 20-odd years or more that he has been in this parliament, and they will continue to see it. I rebut entirely everything the member for Hotham has said in that regard. As somebody who works very closely with him, I see him as one of the most decent, honest people in this country. Certainly compared with some of the people represented on the other side of politics, he stands out.

This bill covers a large number of measures. Firstly, it delivers further on the government's commitment to reduce compliance costs for small business by implementing the fringe benefits tax record keeping exemption in response to a recommendation by the Bell task force. Other FBT reforms designed to reduce compliance costs for small business are contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1997, which is awaiting debate in the Senate.

These measures include an FBT exemption for employee taxi travel to cover travel to and from work at any time of the day, an FBT exemption from 1 July 1997 for car parking on small business premises, and simplification of the range of provisions. The small business recording keeping exemptions may benefit up to half of the small businesses in Australia paying FBT and will come at a cost of $70 million over four years. The record keeping exemption targets those employers whose fringe benefits tax does not exceed an indexed threshold amount and who do not significantly alter the fringe benefits provided in later years. Eligible employers will not be required to keep fringe benefit records and will have their FBT liability in future years determined from base year taxable benefits. The benefit threshold for the 1996-97 FBT year is $5,000. The measure applies to benefits provided from the date of royal assent and to FBT liabilities from the 1998-99 year.

Secondly, the bill implements a number of important 1997-98 budget measures. The first is part of a package of measures relating to preventing franking credit trading and dividend streaming. This bill introduces a rule to limit the source of franking credits available for franking credit trading. The Senate recently passed Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1998 which contains the general anti-avoidance rules. The second budget measure relates to depreciation of plant previously owned by exempt entities. The bill sets a common base for the depreciation deductions for plant that can be claimed by exempt entities which become taxable and by taxable entities which purchase plant from an exempt entity in connection with the acquisition of a business. The measure is designed to align the treatment of asset sales with the treatment of sales of shares in the entity.

The third measure amends the tax law to prevent taxpayers obtaining deductions for capital expenditure in excess of their actual outlays. Where the expenditure has been financed by hire purchase or limited recourse finance, an associated amendment will treat taxpayers who finance assets by hire purchase as the owners of those assets for purposes of applying the various capital allowance deductions.

In addition, the bill amends the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to rectify defects in the current law, thereby ensuring that sales tax exemption for goods incorporated into properties owned by or leased to always exempt persons or the government of a foreign country is only available for the purchase of goods principally for their own use or for use by organisations conducting the business of always exempt persons or the government of a foreign country. This measure applies to any dealing from the date of the introduction of the bill into the parliament.

The bill also demonstrates the government's commitment to dealing promptly with technical areas which occur in the rewrite of the Income Assessment Tax 1936 by the tax law improvement project. The bill also amends the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to include the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission within the definition of a law enforcement agency for the purpose of obtaining access to taxation information.

I want to make a few brief points about some comments made during the debate. The member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) made comments regarding the amendments to the sales tax law and the erosion of the PAYE base. In relation to his comments on the sales tax, the amendments apply to dealings on or after 2 April 1998âthe date the bill was introduced into the House. The measure is not retrospective. Where a contract has been entered into on the basis of that, sales tax exemption will apply. Section 128 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 allows the contract price to be altered as a result of a change to the sales tax law which directly causes an increase in the cost of the party complying with the contract. As the member for Wills should know, increases in sales are generally applied from the date of announcement.

The other point I would make is that, following the introduction of the bill into the parliament, advertisements were placed in the national papers advising of the proposed change. The advertisements made clear that the sales tax does not need to be remitted to the tax office until 28 days after the bill receives royal assent. The member for Wills also made comments about leakage from the PAYE tax system. Despite its apparent concern about this issue, Labor had not passed its legislation to amend the PAYE laws before it was thrown from office on 2 March 1996, and Labor never issued the promised discussion paper, although the budget documents of May 1995 said the paper would be issued `shortly'. If we are going to have the member for Hotham in here debating definitions, the word `shortly', in regard to the previous Labor government, ought to be clearly addressed. I suspect that this splitting of hairs does not get the country any further ahead and I suggest to the opposition that the best way to proceed in the future might be to ignore these silly nit-picking debates.

Let me reassure you that the government believes that all taxpayers should pay their fair share of tax. However, small businesses were highly critical of Labor's proposed changes to the PAYE provisions. We received representations that the proposed changes would in some circumstances have brought payments to independent contractors within the PAYE provisions. In response to those representations, the government decided not to proceed with the legislative changes introduced into the parliament by Labor.

However, the Commissioner of Taxation is continuing to take steps to safeguard the operation of the law and, in relation to alienation of personal services income, we have asked the commissioner to ensure he continues to apply existing provisions including the anti-avoidance provisions of part IVA to ensure that taxpayers do not avoid paying tax on personal services income through the use of interposed entities. To this end the tax office is currently conducting compliance projects that are dealing with personal service incomeâthe PAYE enhancement project and the alienation of personal services income project.

The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) made a number of comments about schedule 13, that is, limiting the source of franking credits available for trading. In particular, he suggested that there is an anomaly in the provisions because whereas minority non-resident shareholders in companies effectively wholly owned by the non-residents can benefit from the franking credits of the company, minority resident shareholders cannot, and the government has not provided revenue figures for the measure.

In regard to the alleged anomaly, it is not anomalous to allow minority non-resident shareholders to gain the benefit from franking credits in the form of an exemption from dividend withholding tax while denying franking rebates to resident minority shareholders. This is a necessary consequence of the provisions if they are to be effective in preventing such companies selling off their franking credits to franking credit buyers. That is the very mischief the measure is designed to prevent.

In regard to revenue, while it is not possible to provide an exact estimate of the revenue lost that already existed from franking credit trading and dividend streaming, $130 million a year is now being factored into the forward estimates for 1998-99 and subsequent years to take account of the effect of the measures on existing activities. This revenue effect will be reflected in the explanatory memorandum for Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) introducing the 45-day rule. I commend the legislation to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Miles) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe legislation which is currently before the Houseâthe Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998âis currently being considered by a Senate committee. The Senate committee is not expected to report until, I think, 22 June. It becomes rather difficult for the House of Representatives to consider these matters when the public inquiry which is being conducted by the Senate and the report which is expected from that Senate committee are not in the public domain. But that is perhaps typical of the process by which the government has pursued this particular legislation. I will say a bit more about that later.

speech.para: I begin by saying that, just as the last parliament and this parliament spent a lot of time working out the right series of measures that needed to be put into the Telecommunications Act to open up the telecommunications market to full and open competition, there is a similar number of very complex issues which need to be dealt with in considering the transition from analog to digital broadcasting in Australia. In telecommunications there were a whole series of issues that placed many of the different stakeholders at each other's throats; a whole series of issues that needed to be weighed up. Many decisions had to be made, each one of which determined the final impact of telecommunications on the Australian public for many years to come. In the same way in broadcasting, this legislation deals with many complex issues; issues on which a considered judgment needs to be made about what is in the public interest.

In some ways, I am reminded of a book that I read over the Christmas break called Longitude. It portrays the history of the development of accurate chronometers that allowed sailors to determine their longitude so that they did not hit hidden reefs and allowed them to accurately plot their position on the globe. Actually, a competition was established by an act of the British parliament to encourage timepiece makers to develop accurate chronometers. The chronometers ended up being massive machines which had many different working parts and many different springs and metal objects to try to ensure that, whatever the changes in temperature, however rough the sea, they maintained their time. In some ways it is the same in broadcasting. With this legislation we have the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) weighing up the many compromises and decisions that need to be made to try to ensure that, when we look at the future of broadcasting in Australia, we protect the public interest.

Despite the views of many of my constituents, I think we currently do have reasonably good quality television in Australia. I am reminded of that old comment by Winston Churchill that democracy is the worst way to run a government, except for all the alternatives. In some ways in Australia our television, despite its faults, is perhaps one of the worst, except for all the alternative forms of television which are available in every other country. In Australia we do have a very healthy mix of national broadcasters and commercial broadcasters. When we make a comparison with Britain and Europe, we see that they do tend to have a much stronger public system and often a much weaker commercial broadcasting sector. Whereas, in the United States there isâas is the case in so many other areas, such as healthâa minuscule public broadcasting system and a very strong, dominant commercial broadcasting sector.

I think that our healthy combination of public broadcasting and commercial broadcasting, with a dash of community broadcasting on top, means that we do tend to get some of the best of the programming that is available in other countries. But we have also seen over the last 20 to 25 yearsâsince the Whitlam government yearsâa healthy increase in the level of quality Australian content on television. We have local content quotas which ensure that we have quality Australian material, particularly drama, on our TV screens at prime time. I am pleased to say that not only does it get high ratings in Australia but also it is earning export dollars for Australia in export sales to other countries.

We are recognised around the world for producing some of the best quality children's television programs. It is often not shown at prime time, but we do have many children who know when quality children's programming is put to air. I am sure that the recognition Australia receives around the world is testament to another policy success in getting that balance between ensuring that commercial broadcasting is profitable in Australia but that commercial broadcasters have certain obligations to the public. They get to use the spectrum, they get to operate as free to air broadcasters, they get a piece of paper with a television broadcasting licence which allows them to make a lot of money out of free to air broadcasting.

In return, the Australian public, through the Australian Broadcasting Authority, puts obligations on them to make sure that they meet minimum Australian content rules, that they have a certain amount of new Australian drama, new children's television and new documentaries going to air each year. That is part of the balance. There is a very complex machine that is Australian television, that compromise between how many public broadcasters, how many community broadcasters, how many commercial broadcasters to have in each capital city market. You look at the profitability of the commercial broadcasters. What are the public obligations you place on them. What is the competition for advertising revenue between commercial television, radio, newspapers and magazines. All of these things comprise a very complex machine. We have to make sure that we get the balance right, otherwise we could end up with a television broadcasting system that does not deliver the level of quality we have today. If we make the wrong decisions on digital television, we could end up with a broadcasting regime that does not allow us to maintain the current standards of broadcasting in Australia.

With those preliminary comments, I turn to the legislation. I would like to briefly remind the House of why I think we have this piece of legislation before us today. This is a piece of legislation which the government is already on record as saying that it is determined to see rammed through the parliament before the end of the next two sitting weeks. We all suspect that there might be an election called before the parliament resumes in August. I think it will be very unfortunate if the parliament does not get sufficient time to consider the implications of this bill because of the government's election timetable.

Why is the government trying to ram this legislation through in the next two weeks? Let me remind the House that when the current broadcasting bill was before the parliament, I think way back in 1991 and 1992, the Minister for Family Services, the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), introduced a second reading amendment to this particular legislation. In those days he was the coalition spokesman on communications. He was responsible for an amendment moved to the broadcasting bill in the Senate which required the then Labor government to conduct an inquiry into whether or not it was in the public interest to have a fourth commercial television network in Australia. When I had the honour of being Minister for Communications and the Arts, we tossed around whether to have another commercial network, an open university channel, a channel which provided for community broadcasters in each of the capital cities and regional areas or a family channel.

There were a number of people in the Labor Party who were pushing very strongly for a channel perhaps similar to some of the specialised channels on some of the pay TV networks where parents could be assured that there would be less violence and, if there were news services, that they would not have as much graphic footage about disturbing images.

talk.start.para: âAbout parliament.

âAbout parliament perhaps on certain days. Certainly there was a view that in those days on the coalition side we needed to look at the possibility of extra competition in commercial television broadcasting.

speech.para: Having moved this amendment way back in 1991, it was in the legislation that this inquiry be conducted before 30 June 1996 or 1997. During the period that this government has been in office it has stopped an inquiry. The Australian Broadcasting Authority had a reference from the former Labor government to conduct an inquiry into whether or not there should be a fourth commercial television network. The Liberal Party stopped that inquiry. They have taken no action whatsoever to look at whether or not it is in the public interest to have an open university channel, a family channel or a commercial broadcasting channel network. Accordingly, we have not had that full debate which certainly the member for Bass thought we needed a few years ago.

That is a minor offence compared to the undertakings which the government gave before the last election to conduct a full public inquiry into the cross-media ownership rules. Some people might ask, `What has that got to do with digital television?' We on this side of the House believe it has everything to do with why this legislation is being rammed through the parliament before the next election by the Howard government. Before the last election, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised a full public inquiry into the cross-media ownership rules. As soon as he was elected, the government announced that it had scrapped the need for a full public inquiry and that instead it would simply hold a private, in camera departmental review.

Not surprisingly, when that review was completed the government was given the recommendation it asked for: a recommendation to water down or abolish the cross-media ownership rules. There was a public outcry at the Prime Minister's intentions to abolish the cross-media ownership rules, which would have allowed Mr Murdoch to purchase Channel 7 in addition to owning his Australian newspapers, which would have allowed Mr Packer to purchase the Fairfax newspaper group in addition to owning Channel 9, which would have allowed Channel 10 to purchase radio stations in addition to owning its television networks. It would have meant that we would have had an even greater concentration of ownership in the Australian media than we have today.

I am pleased to acknowledge that a number of government backbenchers spoke out with many of us on this side of the House about the dangers posed by that greater concentration of media ownership under the Prime Minister's plans. The next speakerâand I hope I do not put a hex on himâwas one of those who was reported within the Liberal Party to have spoken out strongly against the Prime Minister's changes. We acknowledge the courage of the government members who were prepared to speak out on what I consider still to be one of the most important decisions that the Howard government has made to date. Thank God the Prime Minister was rolled on that one.

Having denied the media proprietors the watering down of the cross-media ownership rules, we then have digital television placed on the agenda. Instead of having the long debate that all of us believe is necessary, unfortunately we have the government commissioning reports from the Australian Broadcasting Authorityâreports that we on the opposition side believe did not consider all of the issues as thoroughly as was required. It is pretty rare for the Broadcasting Authority to do thisâin the past it has had a pretty good record in its work on producing reports on broadcastingâbut we believe on digital television the ABA has tended to be very strongly influenced by the free to air broadcasters. I am disappointed that the government has not been prepared to ensure that there is a wider debate about many of the consequences of these issues.
The Minister for Family Services, the member for Bass, who introduced the legislation, said:

. . . we need to ensure broadcasters have clear signposts along the road to digital television, and are able to embark along the risky conversion process with a degree of certainty about government policy.

That sounds like a motherhood statement. The concern we have is that the legislation does not contain clear signposts along the road and does not give the degree of certainty that stakeholders are entitled to have. This legislation leaves the minister with enormous powers to give directions to the Australian Broadcasting Authority to determine how digital television will be introduced. There certainly are not clear signposts; there is actually a sign which says, `Watch this space for what the minister will do after the election.' It certainly does not allow us to reach any firm conclusions about whether the minister has set all of the levers and knobs on this complex machine to the right settings. We think that, in those circumstances, the minister cannot claim that this legislation is providing the certainty that is needed.

The legislation seeks to allow digital television broadcasting to commence on 1 January 2001; it also claims that all areas will have digital coverage by 1 January 2004 and that, if any regional television broadcaster drags its feet, it will be required to surrender its digital licences.

One question I would like to put to the minister who sums up at the end of this debate is: is the government prepared to give a guarantee that anyone who currently receives analog television channels will receive all of the digital channels that will be broadcast? We all know that the transition from analog mobile telephony to digital mobile telephony has seen many areas where there have been holes in the coverage of digital mobile telephones, and, where the Broadcasting Authority has moved analog broadcasters from the VHF to the UHF band, there have been occasions when the broadcasting authorities have not been able to ensure that every person who used to receive a signal receives a signal from the new translator or the new antenna. So we seek some guarantee from the government that, if we are going to see a switch from analog to digital, after the year 2008, after the period of simulcast when the current analog stations shut down, anyone who currently receives the analog channel will have access to a digital channel.

talk.start.para: âBetter quality.

âThe member interjects and says, `Better quality.' I seem to remember that we were promised better quality when we moved to digital mobile phones, but I am not sure we actually have delivered better quality on digital mobile phones.
âThat is your fault.

âHe says that is our fault. I think we have to sometimes question whether the so-called experts in these areas do know as much about what will happen as they claim, and on digital broadcasting I think we are entitled to ask whether anyone who currently receives analog television channels will be able to receive digital television channels. If there are areas where people live in valleys or in places with difficult terrain, if there are places where they will not receive digital television, who is going to meet the cost of putting in translators to make sure that they then get access?

speech.para: Normally in commercial television broadcasting it is up to the commercial television channels to decide whether they will spend extra money to put in additional translators to improve their signal. If this government is going to leave it up to the Seven, Nine and Ten networks to decide how many of their viewers will get access to digital television, then I suggest that there is a danger that many of their current viewers who now get analog channels 7, 9 and 10 may not get digital 7, 9 and 10 and all of the other digital services that are coming.

For the people in the gallery and the people listening, the other message the government has not told you very clearly is that you will have to purchase a new digital television which may cost quite a considerable sum of money. It is difficult at the moment to accu rately estimate how much the new digital televisions will cost, but you can imagine the cost to the community when every television which now operates in Australia will not be able to pick up signals when the current analog signals cease in 2008 or later. It is quite a dramatic cost to ordinary families, and we certainly need some guarantee that the signal will work in all the current areas where people are receiving signals.

As for the phase-in period, the Labor Party has indicated in-principle support for the simulcasting time line, that is, for commencing the digital broadcasting in 2001, and for the period of simulcasting to proceed at least until the year 2008. We support that particular time line.

We have indicated our in principle support for the free loan to the free to air broadcasters of a second block of seven megahertz of spectrum to allow them to simultaneously broadcast the new digital service and their old analog service.

We have also indicated our in principle support for a ban on multi-channelling. This was one of the requests or demands that the free to air broadcasters put on the table during the debate. Basically it would mean that channels 7, 9 and 10 could have converted their single analog channel into five or seven different digital channelsânot high-definition television, but into a number of different channels.

Basically today in Australia, instead of having our three commercial broadcasters, if we had enough spectrum for 15 commercial broadcasters, I think very few people would think it would be fair to allocate all of those new channels to the existing broadcasters, to allow the current three networks to maintain their monopoly of the Australian television broadcasting market. Quite rightly, the government is saying that the commercial broadcasters will not be allowed to introduce multi-channelling.

We are a bit quizzical about the government's decision to allow the ABC and SBS to engage in multi-channelling broadcasting. The reason I am a bit quizzical about that is that I think it will be very difficult for the government to allow public broadcasters to introduce multi-channelling but to prohibit commercial broadcasters from bringing in multi-channelling. I suspect that this might be the government deliberately allowing the free to air broadcasters to put a foot in the door for multi-channelling or, in fact, for the commercial broadcasters to see the ABC and SBS foot in the door so as to perhaps allow the commercial broadcasters to come back at some future date and seek to have multi-channelling options.

The debate in Australia started off in the same way as the debate in the United States. Free to air television said that this was all about delivering high definition television to Australian viewers. What they said was, `If you give us this extra quantity of spectrum, this seven megahertz of spectrum' which, by the way, blocks out any other new competitors, `then we will move towards high definition television that will give cinema-quality pictures to Australian viewers around the country.'

In the United States, exactly the same argument was used when they went through this debate but, having received the spectrum, the US broadcasters are now saying that they have no speedy plans to introduce large quantities of high definition television broadcasting. They are into multi-channelling as much as they can. They are into making sure that they do not do what they said they would do, which was to introduce high definition TV. It is all about trying to maximise their revenue rather than delivering an improved service to their viewers.

I think we have to be very sceptical about whether the government will in fact set up a regime that will deliver high definition television to Australian viewers. I suspect that the demands for multi-channelling will still be not far from the top of the list of objectives of the free to air broadcasters.

On the restriction on new licences, we have the government saying that there will be no new commercial television licences allowed before 2008. That is one of the few specific clauses that are hard and fast and not given over to the discretion of the minister. As I say, that contrasts quite dramatically with the views of the member for Bass when he was the opposition spokesman on communications earlier this decade and was arguing for a public inquiry into whether or not we needed a fourth commercial television network. The Labor Party has said that we will be considering amendments to this period of exclusivity which goes all the way to 2008. Our final decision on that will be made clear once we have seen the outcome of that Senate inquiry.

There are several other issues which we believe are worthy of consideration. They include the question of industry development. The Labor Party believes that it is important for the legislation to explicitly recognise the industry development obligations and the opportunities that will arise for Australian manufacturers and those who are involved in software development through digitalisation. We think it would be helpful for the government to require industry development plans in the same way as in telecommunications where the major carriers are required to develop plans to maximise the opportunities for Australian manufacturers and software developers. We would also like to see digital broadcasting offering new and innovative opportunities for information service providers in rural and regional areas. Many of these, we believe, are worthy of consideration.

For these reasons, we have concerns about the government's attempts to ram this through in the next two weeks. We are concerned that the government has not got the settings right on all of the knobs and levers in this complex machine known as broadcasting in Australia. We believe that, unless the government gives this greater thought and consideration, then there is a risk that we will not have as high a quality Australian television as we have today. Therefore, I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that further consideration of the Bill should be deferred, for the following reasons:
(1) the Government has provided insufficient time and opportunity for a wide public consultation process to examine the impact of the introduction of digital broadcasting into Australia;

(2) the Government has introduced this Bill with undue haste which is reflected by the fact that it was necessary to circulate substantial amend ments even before the resumption of the second reading debate;

(3) the Australian Broadcasting Authority provided advice that indicated that legislation could be tabled in Parliament in October 1998 providing for a digital broadcasting commencement date of 1 January 2000, and the Government has given no reasons for ignoring this advice;

(4) given that the Government received the digital broadcasting report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority in July 1997 and then took over eight months to make a public announcement on its proposed framework for digital broadcasting, its claim that the legislation needs to be dealt with as a matter of urgency is disingenuous;

(5) the Senate is conducting an inquiry into the legislation, and although the inquiry has been given insufficient time to report by the Government, it is likely that evidence and recommendations will emerge from that inquiry which would assist the House in giving proper consideration to the Bill;

(6) the Government's legislation does not address the enormous potential that is presented for industry development in Australia through the migration into a digital broadcasting environmentâopportunities will exist for Australian manufacturing and software development industries and the contribution this can make to Australian employment and export earnings should be recognised and supported in the legislation;

(7) the Government's legislation does not provide sufficient recognition for the particular infrastructure issues faced throughout regional areas, and just as digital broadcasting provides special opportunities for access to new services in rural and regional Australia, disproportionate expenditure will be required to ensure that the capacity exists for the development of appropriate infrastructure;

(8) the Parliament's consideration of this Bill must place paramount importance on the interests of the broader Australian community and consumers, and given the impact that digital broadcasting will have on the delivery and reception of television and other broadband and online services, any attempt to hasten the legislative process without proper parliamentary scrutiny, public debate and discussion, could jeopardise those interests".

talk.start.para: âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âThe Australian Labor Party have proved yet again that for them the information superhighway should be torn up and turned into a dirt track. The Australian Democrats have a view that is slightly different: it should not just be a dirt track; it should also be a toll road. Anyway, we will let them work that out as time goes on.

speech.para: I think the bottom line is that in Australia we have the very best television in the world. We have free to air terrestrial television that the rest of the world could only envy, with three commercial operators offset by a very effective public system of the ABC and SBS providing an effective range of views and access to programs. This has been supplemented in recent years by an emerging cable sector. With a strong public sector, a strong private sector and an emerging cable television sector, Australia is very well served.

We have been strong adaptors of technology over the years. Television started in time for the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne and colour TV seemed to be hinged more around the Commonwealth Games of 1974âor was it the Olympics of 1976? We have seen Australians over a long period of time readily take up technology and readily accept the need to be part of what is new and what is also to their benefit as far as entertainment and information access are concerned. We have a successful quality and quantity of Australian content.

All of this comes as a result of quite deliberate action by government over the yearsâdeliberate action to require the telecasters of such programs to provide Australian content through a carrot and a stick approach and also deliberate action because one of the few things that we can claim is directly underpinned from the 1901 version of the constitution is management of the spectrum. As a result, we can quite legitimately legislate in this place, and in no other place in Australia, those rules and regulations which govern the access to the spectrum, the basis on which television and telecommunications signals are sent. Commercial channels sell access to the spectrum, which governments make it possible for them to access by licensing arrangements.

As a result of those licensing arrangements, we can set and demand certain outcomes. In that regard, the bill before us today is consistent with everything that has ever been passed in broadcast or television policy since whenever. After all, we have a set of regulations and requirements and a set of outcomes that are well specified, and we have a set of deliberate actions that we want those who want to have access to digital television to meet, otherwise they will not have the access.

It is important to address a couple of the matters mentioned by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), a former minister for communications in the Keating government. I think it is important for him to know that no-one on this side will allow digital television to become the technological stalking horse for the cross-media ownership debate. I can assure you that that matter has been well addressed by the government's communications and the arts backbench policy committee.

talk.start.para: âWhat about the next term?

âWe are certain that, whether it is in this term or the next term, doors are not going to be left open to allow those sorts of things to occur. In fact, quite the opposite: the doors are left open to a range of possibilities as far as the use of this technology is concerned, but there are mechanisms contained within this bill which will ensure open inquiry and accountability for the decisions which are made. We have to make sure we do get specified in this bill the outcomes we want. We have to make sure also the industry itself is given some very clear guidelines as to the timetable it needs to embark upon. I am concerned the Australian Labor Party and their cohorts in crime, in a metaphoric sense, in the Senate are very much hell-bent on the delay of this bill. They want to drag it out and drag it out for no apparent reason other than simply blatant opposition for opposition's sake.

speech.para: What is at stake? It is an industry in which I once worked and in which, I know, the member for Calare (Mr Andren), who will be speaking as well this morning, also worked. An industry such as this, like any industry, needs to understand where they are going, how they can invest and what they have to invest in, and what are the rules and regulations governing such investment. Queued up all around this country at the moment, from the smallest country town to the biggest city like Sydney, are television operators waiting for this bill to be passed to bring some certainty to their actions. They want to get on with the job of purchasing the equipment and getting in place the technical side of things so the new digital age can be realised. And we have the Australian Labor Party professing delay, which I think is anchored in the basis of opposition for opposition's sake.

In my own electorate people in the suburbs of Wishart, Upper Mount Gravatt, Mount Gravatt, Holland Park West, Wellers Hill and Tarragindi and people up Weller Road find that they get a poor quality analog signal now. They are getting ghosting and scratching because of the physical intrusion of Mount Gravatt. To address one of the matters raised by the member for Dobell, in the digital regime the clear signal which is available close to the transmitter will be available in those sorts of scratchy areas.

It is a technical fact that digital transmission is more robust than analog. The signal is resistant to electrical interference and to ghosting. Ghosting is something which happens when the signal cannot distinguish between some physical interruption and the place where it is supposed to go, so hills, buildings and so forth cause problems. Being digital, the signal cannot readily contain additional data which allows the receiver to correct errors caused by this interference. In most instances, as a result of digital transmissions, a perfect copy of the signal is transmitted. This information was given to me, I confess, by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, but if they are prepared to put this in writing, then I am prepared to relate it in the parliament. I think this in itself is a mechanism of accountability for such an organisation and for the members it represents to actually deliver on it.

For those constituents of the member for Dobell, of the member for Calareâand, I think, yours as well, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehlâwho are on the edges of the transmission area and get a scratchy signal, digital will produce a clear signal right to the edge of the scratchiness we currently get with analog. To delay this bill longer means constituents of mine, of yours and of other members in this place will continue to experience the poor quality transmissions they are currently suffering.

If the Australian Labor Party want to continue to delay the bill, this sort of problem is going to continue for a long time. They are actually threatening the gentle balance which exists in this industry, a balance which has the potential for high profits but which also returns profits into the employment of people through the creation of Australian content television productions and so forth. Delays will interrupt such an investment regime and the process of logical planning for what is to come, I think the Australian Labor Party should get out of the way so we can get on with the job we are supposed to do. Far from ramming this through, the government is recognising the need for Australia to be part of what is happening in the world. In November of this year the United States is switching on to digital television, and the Australian Labor Party are professing delays to keep Australia further behind. There is no need for it.

What is the consumer going to get out of this? They are going to get higher quality pictures, CD quality sound and access, for a lot of their programming, to cinema quality broad screen pictures on their television sets. Yes, they will have to purchase new television sets, but Australians have never been afraid of buying into new technology. As more Australians purchase into this new technology, they will find the costs will continue to decline, as they have with mobile phones. For those who purchased a mobile phone very early onâand I certainly was not one of them, because I could not afford it 10 years agoâthe cost was around $1,000. They are now down to $49, and I suspect the same thing will happen when it comes to digital television.

At the end of the day, it is not just about television programs and the hedonistic experience of enjoying your favourite showâthe member for Moore (Mr Filing) perhaps like Neighbours or similar shows; it is also about access to the information superhighway, because digital television contains within it the prospect for the television set to be accessed by computer and data content, a bit like the movie Back to the Future. People will be able to receive phone messages, access the Internet and all these sorts of things, all from the comfort of their loungeroom.

Those matters are not going to be an automatic right for the current free to air carriers because the government has quite rightly said that is beyond the basic job they currently do. This bill specifies, as is the case with all these sorts of matters, clear understandings and clear obligations on the free to air channels to gain access, in a loan sense, to spectrum, provided they do the job they are supposed to do.

talk.start.para: âIt's a free gift.

âThere is no sense of giving away anything here because, after all, giving access to the spectrum for digital to operate in a simulcast with analog in the transition period of about eight years is an additional cost to those involved in television transmission, because they have two sets of transmitters to maintain.
