One will be that a limited but different regime may apply to the ABC and the SBS in so far as those particular networks conform to their charter. The ABC may well be allowed to use multi-channelling if, for example, it wished to show its educational programs or perhaps some of its arts programsâsimilarly with the SBS.

In summary, the government has mandated that we will have the best high definition television in the worldâwith high definition video picture and with CD quality soundâwith the continuing free to air broadcasters, two public broadcasters and three commercial broadcasters; that there will be special arrangements for the ABC; that there will not be multi-channelling; that there will be a regime in provincial Australia which allows those particular channels three years in which to install their digital technology; and, finally, that all of the channels will have an eight-year period in which they must broadcast both in digital and analog.

We should not underestimate the cost of this to free to air broadcasters. This is another reason why the spectrum is being lent to the free to air broadcasters in that, during this co-transmission period, there will be a cost somewhere of the order of $20 million to $30 million a year to those broadcasters. So it is a big ask for them.

I think the government has done an excellent job in putting this legislation together. The government's backbench committee fully supports the measure. It is a visionary concept that will put Australia at the front of the pack and will increase the quality of entertainment and quality of life for many Australians, both in capital cities and in provincial areas.

talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure to speak on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 . I am very glad to see the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) in the chamber, some of whom will be following with, no doubt, some excellent speeches after mine.

speech.para: Australia has an excellent record in introducing new technology. We were the world leaders in taking up such new technology as the Internet and mobile telephones, as two examples. Australian television already compares well with its overseas counterparts. In Europe state broadcasters dominate the sector whilst in the United States the commercial sector rules. In Australia we have a very good balance between the commercial stations and the ABC and the SBS.

Television came to Australia in the 1950s. A quarter of century later we got colour television. Now, a quarter of a century on, we are getting digital TV. Digital TV is as big a change as colour was. Viewers will get movie quality pictures and CD quality sound. It will also make new services, including interactive services, available to all Australians. The government is committed to ensuring all Australians can share in the benefits of the new technology as soon as possible.

In order to achieve this we will need to provide prospective digital TV broadcasters a degree of certainty so they can make the very large investment needed for converting from analog to digital. This Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill is the first step in providing that certainty. Commercial and national broadcasters will submit implementation plans to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and to the minister for communications. The bill provides extra channels to existing broadcasters so that they can begin digital broadcasting in parallel to analog services. The government chose the right policy to allow the free to air providers to have that access now because of the huge capital investment that they are currently providing and that they will have to provide, as well as the software.

The start date for digital TV for Australia is 1 January 2001 for the cities and 1 January 2004 for regional Australia. The difference takes into account the huge investment required to upgrade services in rural areas. Broadcasters which fail to meet these deadlines will lose their licence. Broadcasters will have to simulcast analog and digital TV services for up to eight years to allow consumers time to switch over. They will then return one of the channels to the Commonwealth.

Digital TV allows for multi-channelling. Commercial stations will not be allowed to multi-channel, but this option may be open to the ABC and SBS. I certainly hope that that happens with the ABC. Unused channels will be put out to tender for datacasting. The charge for datacasting is part of the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 , which the House is considering concurrently with the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill.

Importantly, the needs of regional Australia and the people in my electorate of Richmond are addressed in this bill. There is, as I mentioned, a three-year period to allow broadcasters to set up in the bush. The government will also review whether any laws need to be changed to ensure that all regional areas get three commercial services as do the metropolitan areas. This is similar to what happened with aggregation back in the 1980s, but I do believe it will provide a far more secure and safe regime for those free to air providers, particularly in non-metropolitan areas. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) for his warm introduction. The Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 is the most significant broadcasting bill that has come before this House for a generation. It is so because this bill provides us with new technology and new access to technology, particularly for the millions of television consumers in Australia. From a technical point of view, we are providing seven megahertz to each free to air television station, of which probably around 5Â½ to six megahertz will be available for high definition TV, which means that the average consumer in Australia will have access to cinema quality television and CD quality sound. But, more importantly, it opens up a whole new access regime. When we go to what is called digital terrestrial television broadcasting, DTTB, we will be using the available spectrum more efficiently than is the case with the existing terrestrial analog coverage. And that means that, for the current amount of spectrum that is used for the signal you receive at your home now, you will get high quality television and the signal that is coming across will be able to be used for other services such as data broadcasting or perhaps even multi-channelling.

speech.para: There are a number of key points about this legislation that I would like to bring to the attention of the House and then I will talk about the ramifications of this legislation, which will be of more significant interest to the House. Firstly, this legislation provides for a start-up date for the introduction of digital terrestrial television broadcasting of 1 January 2001. That is for major licences in metropolitan areas. They will need to use it, within certain constraints, for high definition TV and, at the same time, they will have the opportunity to use the leftover spectrum for databroadcasting. There will be an eight-year period for simulcast, which means that the average punter at home will have the opportunity to retain the signal on their normal television set until 1 January 2009. So do not rush out and sell your TV sets. The opportunity here is that with the development of new technology you will be able to put a set-top box on your existing television set and receive the digital signal and digital quality sound but you will not get high definition television coming through your screen because your old TV set is quite constrained.

The next point about it is the opportunity to provide datacasting, and that is important. Datacasting is a vital part of the new technology era. As one of my colleagues, the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), said a little earlier, datacasting means that you can be watching the football and you can use the computer icon control, which is in your hand, to place the icon on the player and up will come the player's home page and you will have the opportunity to buy boots from Rocca or visit the player's mum's kitchen and get the best recipe available from, say, the Richmond football club team. There will be a lot of opportunities to enter distant home pages on the World Wide Web. This is just the beginning of the opportunities with high definition television.

There is a further provision in this bill which I would like to see changedâthe prohibition on multi-channelling. As I said, with the spectrum that high definition TV uses, you can either run high definition TV so that you see Brian Henderson on Channel 9 news in full colourâevery dot and creased out wrinkleâor you can have the opportunity to have perhaps six other TV channels in the normal analog coverage which you have now.

The combination is this: currently, with the signal that we are getting at the moment at home, we can divide Channel 9 into six separate TV stations so you will have 9A, 9B, 9C, 9D, 9E and perhaps even 9F. On one station you might have Brian Henderson and on another station you might have A Current Affair and on another station you might have Max Walker and Wide World of Sport. So, all of a sudden, we have got an opportunity to turn our TV sets from being receivers of five free to air stations into receivers of up to 30, or perhaps even more, free to air TV stations.

We have said they cannot do that. We have said they have got to use this new spectrum for high definition TV. And our major concern is that if Channel 9 can have a 9A, 9B, 9C, 9D, 9E then they will start to charge consumers for access to 9D, which might have 24-hour cricket, and of course that starts to impinge on the development of pay television services in Australia.

Finally, and this is where I have a reservation as well, there are no new entrants until December 2008. I will be quite honest to this house and say that I would like to see a further new competitor in free to air television. However, I recognise that there are huge investments by the major television corporations in free to air television in Australia. Channel 9, Channel 10 and Channel 7 have between $1 billion and $5 billion of capital invested in free to air television stations, not to mention the extensive interests of the ABC and SBS. All of them seem to have a presence in my electorate and I am very aware of that. But, at the same time, I also recognise that with that significant capital investment there are future capital investments required and with the advent of digital televisionâhigh definition TVâthe major metro stations are going to have to spend up to $700 million on new equipment, up to $50 million a year. I must add, though, that the proof of the pudding out of the United States, where high definition is preferred as opposed to the multi-channelling in Europe, is that the original estimates of the costs of the upgrade of the equipment were too high and the equipment is proving a little cheaper.

What are the ramifications of this bill? The first point is that here is the greatest single effort to converge technology. All of a sudden you are going to have one unit in the house that will provide you with CD quality sound, that will provide you with a computer database and access to the World Wide Web and that will give you free to air television. And what that means is it will be the third most significant investment for every family in Australia after the houseâthe family homeâand the car. That is what it means. So this is going to have a significant impact on consumer spending in Australia over the next few years.

The other major ramification is in relation to cross-media ownership and ownership regulations. This bill makes cross-media laws and foreign ownership laws in Australia redundant. Why? Because you are seeing it come out now. For example, Channel 9 has entered into a strategic partnership with Microsoftâninemsn, as they are promoting it. That is Channel 9 entering into a joint venture for datacasting or data information with a foreign owned company. That, of itself, shows that the spirit of the foreign ownership laws is made redundant.

Secondly, in relation to cross-media arrangements, why can't Channel 7 enter into an agreement with Fairfax to provide data services so that once a story comes up on the news with Anne Sanders you can click the icon on the story and you get a full web page or two web pages or three web pages about that particular news item that came from Fairfax press. This is convergent technology; it is going to mean that within the next three years Australia's media ownership laws will become redundant. I am a great advocate for free trade in relation to media ownership. I believe you cannot just change one part of the media laws and not another. You have to change it holus-bolus. In this case it is a perfect opportunity, through market forces, to change media laws.

The final point I want to make is in relation to content, particularly in relation to censorship. The World Wide Web is not censored, nor should it be. But we need to look at ourselves very carefully and ask ourselves the question: is it appropriate for us to try and regulate nudity and a range of other sexually related activities on television sets when you can watch Predator, with Arnold Schwarzenegger, where there are the most grotesque and humiliating and horrific scenes on television, and they remain unregulated? What sort of message are we trying to send our kids? It's okay to kill people in the most horrific and grotesque way but it's not okay to participate in what are meant to be natural activities. I think there is a strong message about content here and we need to be very careful in this new age of convergence not to regulate ourselves out of opportunities, but, more importantly, not to get carried away with censorship as it is currently being propounded.

In conclusion, I would like to pay tribute to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. This has been an extremely difficult area of policy reformâa hugely difficult areaâand he has negotiated through it quite correctly. I think the policy is good. If I had my druthers it would be a free and open market, but that was not to be the case. In this case we are making the most significant investment in free to air television in Australian history. I strongly support the bill. I strongly support the policy principles as laid down by the minister for communications, and I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt is with great pleasure that I speak on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 . It is a bill which, through amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 and the Radiocommunications Act 1992, will see Australia enter not only a new millennium but also the digital era of broadcasting. The long awaited introduction of digital terrestrial television broadcasting and the provision of high definition television pictures to make, amongst other things, the TV set become the one-stop shop in every home, covering every aspect from entertainment through to modern learning, information and financial services, has been heralded as a brave new world.

speech.para: But rather than continue to promote the pros of digital TVâand clearly they are as immense as the technology is dynamicâI want to outline to this House my desire and downright determination to see regional broadcasters, quality broadcasters, of the mould of NBN, Prime and Telecasters Australia Ltd get a fair and equitable deal to continue to service their audiences. All three regional telecasters operate within the Hunter and mid-north New South Wales coast as a part of that aggregated market. In particular, NBN and Prime in the Hunter place great emphasis on producing substantial TV hours per week of local content, be it news, coverage of key cultural and social events, through to local sport and providing community announcementsâsimply by being an integral part of our community.

The local programs screened in the Hunter, under NBN, include one hour of local news and network news five days a week and 30 minutes on Saturday and Sunday; This Morning, which is about Hunter entertainment and infotainment; our own local Romper Room with Miss Kim and Big Dog, a preschool program; Community Noticeboard; sports telecasts from the Newcastle Knights, Newcastle Falcons and Surfest; the NBN tele thonâsome will remember a young friend of mine, Hayley Tull, a cancer victimâwhich raised over $3 million this year; and local documentaries.

Prime dedicates 30 minutes purely to local news five days a week, and on weekends they do a local news and network news mixture. It provides Regional News Australia, a 30-minute weekly program every Saturday; Our sporting country, which is 30 minutes of weekly regional based sporting activities; Community Noticeboard; regional TV specials; and, of course, one that we all know well, the Country Music Awards at Tamworth. These companies invest tens of millions of dollars in our local community by promoting our local community. All three Hunter telecasters actively promote and sponsor major sport, cultural and leisure events, plus charities within the community.

In my meetings with both Denis Ledbury and his management team at NBN, along with Brad Jones and David Carr from Prime Television, the delivery of digital services to regional Australia and for regional broadcasters brings a lot of promise but also plenty of challenges and costs. Their thoughts on the matter extend further to the issue of retransmission of free to air TV services, which in the near future will also be brought before this House. That is a matter I have taken very much on board, having personally addressed the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) on it.

My main aim as a part of this new digital ball game is to ensure regional television remains dynamic and continues to have a rock-solid commitment to local news and programming and be as much a vital part of the communities in the next century as they are now, and also to be a financially viable business in the process, employing local people and investing in local communities.

I take on board the statement made by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, in their submission to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Committee just last month, which succinctly outlined the position that I am taking in relation to this bill and the real benefits that can and should bring to the people of the Hunter. That submission said in part:
Itâ
meaning digital transmission technologyâ

is not a new service which requires fundamentally new rules, it is a replacement technology which poses some difficult transmission problems because of the need to replace transmission equipment and replace or convert domestic receivers for digital reception.
That is a very important point to make. It is a point my government has already taken on board to a large degree and it is a point that we will continue to push.

Back on 24 March this year, when the minister, Richard Alston, unveiled the new digital era, there was a special place at the digital TV table for regional TV broadcastersâbroadcasters acting either independently or within an aggregate market, which services 35 per cent or approximately 6.4 million Australians with a high quality, high Australian, high local content TV product. This is about listening to the people of regional and rural Australia.

Prime Television, NBN and Telecasters Australia will face without question much higher costs per viewer to install digital transmission equipment. For instance, Prime Television, through its current analog service in northern New South Wales, has seven transmitters and 39 translators. In my own electorate, we have one transmitter at Mount Sugarloaf and then nine translators that take that signal.

When I listened to my colleague and friend the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) talking about the benefits, quite simply in the bush we just want every house to be able to receive TV. We are not interested in all the fancy stuff. All they have to do in Sydney is put up one transmitter, compared with the seven transmitters and 39 translators just to service the small area of northern New South Wales.

That is why this government's policy stance has the backing of regional broadcasters. Regional broadcasters, amongst other things, will have to meet a requirement to commence DTTB services by 1 January 2004, three years after metropolitan stations. They have a free of charge spectrum, no allowance of new players in the market until the year 2008 and, further, the government will consider whether additional support to regional broadcasters, such as licence rebates, is required when planning is complete and the costs of transmission to digital are known. This is the very least that they need.

FACTS estimates that in 1997 the cost of digital TV was $96 million for operations and $90 million for transmission to regional broadcasters in aggregated markets. As a comparison, metropolitan stations faced only a cost of $22 million for transmission. More recent figures are blunt: $245 million could be the bill for transmission to aggregated regional players collectively, including Prime Newcastle and NBN. At least 75 per cent of the total free to air TV industry investment in transmission facilities will be made by regional aggregated market operators.

Quite simply put, NBN, Prime and Telecasters Australia, the regional TV players from Newcastle to the Tweed border, must be given special consideration by the government towards helping them meet the financial burden. To put it another way, it is the equivalent of placing 15 years of expenditure into five financial years. It could, of course, come in the form of a licence fee rebate or tax relief on infrastructure inputs, in other words, sales tax reliefâtwo clear-cut areas where regional telecasters pay substantial money to this Commonwealth government.

Television licence fees for regional broadcasters paid to the Commonwealth during 1997 totalled $30 million. A more glaring statistic taken overall across the free to air television industry is that, collectively, 1997 licence fees as a proportion of revenue have reached eight per centâthe highest it has ever been, according to FACTS. A further point that illustrates that a helping hand for regional broadcasters is genuinely needed is that the revenue from advertising for regional telecasters runs at $511 million, equating to 21.5 per cent of all TV revenue generated in Australia.

The mathematics are quite simple: 75 per cent of the costs of restructuring the industry for digital is funded by 21.5 per cent of the income revenue for regional telecasters. Needless to say, 35.4 per cent of the Australian population serviced by regional broadcasters were within the New South Wales market and in particular the Hunter, which is the most difficult terrain for adequate transmission in all of Australia because of its unique topography. As I said, my aim is not for all the whiz-bangs; my aim is for each house to receive television.

Over an eight-year period, with the delivery of aggregation within regional television markets, FACTS has produced figures which outline that $147 million was provided in capital assistance. Whilst not a benchmark, the point needs to be reinforcedâin support of my three Hunter and northern New South Wales coast based regional telecasters, to retain their market share influenceâthat this debate is beyond the whiz-bang technology; it is all about hardware.

The capital expenditure involved is estimated to be $500 to $750 million in the first five years of the simulcast period including all commercial networks, regional affiliates and smaller regional independent operators. The government has taken this all on board, a matter both I and a number of my colleagues have pushed. This is not a debate about a free ride for the free to airsâit is nothing of the sort. As outlined to the minister in its submission and given carriage to me by Prime, NBN, Telecasters Australia, WIN and Southern Cross, `a digital television policy solution which fails to deliver a substantial equivalent standard of service in regional and metro Australia is no solution at all'. That is food for thought when we marry modern technology with modern financial and commercial reality. As I said, put simply, this is not about a free ride for regional telecasters or any such consideration. This is about delivering quality broadcast services for all Australians, not just those who choose to live in the city.
I support this bill, as would all of my constituents in Paterson including those who do not currently receive television broadcasts now but hope to in the future.

talk.start.para: âWe will call a division on this matter. We reject the amendment proposed by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), the shadow spokesman for communications.

speech.para: I sum up on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 today on behalf of my colleague, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, who is currently overseas. I am acting on his behalf this week. When I introduced this legislation some time ago, I indicated in the second reading speechâand several speakers today have indicated this in their speechesâthat we have a record of a very strong free to air terrestrial television broadcasting system in Australia. It started in the 1950s, going through to the introduction of colour television in 1975. We have certainly built a very good and strong free to air system in its publicly funded formâthe ABC and the SBSâand also commercial broadcasters. It has a substantial level of Australian quality content.

As we move forward in the new millennium we do stand on the threshold of new and exciting opportunities and the arrival of new technology. As the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) indicated in his speechâhe is always very eloquentâthis is a debate about a piece of legislation that is fundamental to the everyday lives of Australians. It is about television, where we get so much of our entertainment and so much of our information.

The opportunities that are provided by digital broadcasting are now apparent. We are grapplingâand this legislation provides the opportunity to deal with it in a constructive wayâto deliver digital broadcasting to this nation, to maintain all the qualities that we have come to expect and have seen in the delivery of the free to air systems in this country. Digital television is a huge quantum leap. Viewers will have the option of viewing high definition pictures of extremely enhanced clarity to what they enjoy now and with CD quality surround sound. Many colleagues today have talked about the impact of that technology.

I thank honourable members from both sides: the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave), the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the member for North Sydney, the member for Paterson (Mr Baldwin), who has just spoken, who indicated his key concern about regional television and making sure that digitalisation is going to be available to all areas of Australiaâand this legislation achieves thatâand the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), who was concerned about consumers, as we all are. The fundamental point about this legislation is that it is designed to provide a migration path to the utilisation of this new digital technology to make sure that consumers get the benefit of that new technology regardless of where they might liveâand I think that is particularly important.

In summing up, there are some amendments that the government will move but we will deal with the opposition's amendment first and then I will make a few brief remarks about the nature of our amendments. They are broadly technical in nature and there is no dispute about them, but I will deal with those after we have dealt with this matter.

Given that the shadow minister and former minister for communications is here, it is only right and proper that I should deal with his amendment. Can I say to him, firstly, that we do not accept the amendment. The fundamental point that you are making, as I read your amendment, is that there is some desire on the part of the governmentâindeed, there isâto enable this legislation to become law at the soonest possible time.

We did do a review. The Australian Broadcasting Authority did do a review last year, in July. There was wide public consultation about high definition television, about digital conversions. It recommended simulcasting, which is the very centrepiece of this legislation. This allows for existing analog technology, which is the delivery mechanism of the TV signals, to be simultaneously broadcast with the arrival of digital technology. By its very nature, it is done at the same time. That is what the authority recommended and that is what this legislation does. It sets time periods for that to be able to take place.

We are quite concerned, because of the level of investment that is required to establish digital television, that the soonest possible resolution of the legal position by way of the legislation take place, and that is why we would want this matter to proceed at the soonest possible time. To meet the dates that are proposed in the legislation, obviously we would need to get those decisions through the parliament as soon as we can.

You will recall that the ABA in its report recommended that the start date be 1 January 2000. In fact, this legislation proposes that for metro areas the start date be 2001 and in regional areas 2004, with some leeway to go a little further out if that is necessary. Of course, that will be subject, in the regional areas, to the completion by the ABA of implementation plans. Implementation plans are extremely important in this legislative package because, broadly speaking, the legislation establishes the legal framework, the policy objectives. It leaves in place the prospect of a flexible scheme. We have statutory reviews, which have been the feature of earlier broadcasting legislation, where the resulting regulations are disallowable within the parliament so there is ongoing opportunity for the community through its representatives to scrutinise this process.

But it is absolutely essential, when we look at those implementation plans, look at how many repeaters and installations are required, that we take cognisance of the need in regional areas. We would obviously consider licence rebates but that comes after looking at the overall implementation plans. The concerns that are raised by the opposition on that score are met in the body of the legislation and by statements previously made by my colleague Senator Alston and certainly by me.

Another point that is raised in your amendment is about the need for industry plans. Quite frankly, there is a role for Australian industry to participate in the digital provision of hardware and broadcasting equipment and so on, but that is not appropriate for this legislation. That is rightly a matter to be dealt with in broad industry policy.

I understand the Senate will give the product of its deliberations on 22 June, and obviously we would take account of those. As we have seen the hearings that have been proceeding, we still believe that we must meet that 2001 date and, as I say, provide legal certainty in the bill to enable investments to proceed.

In your final point you said you want more time for public debate. There has been an enormous amount of public debate about these issues. I think you use the word `disingenuous' in your amendment. I suspect that this second reading amendment is of itself and of its nature somewhat disingenuous. You do know, as a former minister, that we have had in this country endless discussions about how we are going to implement digitisation of television to benefit consumers, to make sure consumers are at the forefront of our considerations. Indeed, this legislation does that.

There are obviously other issues that members have raised and I will not be able to do justice to them, other than to make one particular point: as simulcasting takes place and you are sitting there with an analog TV set, you will of course be able to have a down converter on your set for a couple of hundred dollars and convert to digital reception. Then there will be enhancements available and multi-viewing will become available. That is allowable under the arrangements.

On balance, the government believes that this is an eminently sensible way to proceed to protect consumers, to give a clear and identifiable migration path for Australia to engage new technologies, to enhance for the viewing audience the clarity of the picture and to extend the sound capacityâand do that in a way in which the existing providers of free to air television, which have done so well for us over so many years, are able to be accommodated and become part of this new exciting industry.

Of course, we are dealing with a finite resource. We are dealing with spectrum. This is a finite resource that belongs to the people, and we have a responsibility in public policy terms to use it sensibly, to use it in a way that can enhance the community's enjoyment of that spectrum. And television being the pre-eminent way so many of us get our entertainment and our information, we believe that the public policy objectives that we have set in this legislation, the legal framework that we have put in place, is the sensible way to go.

I suspect that, had you been in government, the package that you would be presenting would be very similar to what is being provided here. This is an enormously interesting and intricate technology. It has public policy clashes, and we have seen plenty of evidence of that. There are competing commercial interests, all of which have to be considered. But in the end, we must make public policy decisions for the needs of all Australians wherever they live, and do it in a fair and reasonable way. We believe that this legislative package does that. Mr Speaker, I indicate again that the government does not accept the member for Dobell's second reading amendment.

âI thank the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). It is very charitable. I know that a lot of people who are having their lunch will be very grateful that he has taken consideration of their needs.

I present a supplementary memorandum to the bill. These amendments are detailed in the explanatory memorandum. They relate to a range of technical issues. They bring the planning objective for digital conversion schemes for metropolitan areas into line with the regional areas. They also require the schemes to be directed towards the objective that, as soon as practicable after the start of a simulcast period, the digital transmission of a television broadcasting service in both metropolitan and regional areas achieves the same level of coverage and potential reception quality as is achieved by the analog transmission of that service.

Indeed, that point was made during the course of the debate this morning and I assure members that that is an objective of the legislation which I feel sure will be achieved because there is quite a deal of difference technically between an analog mobile phone system as against an analog television system and a digital television system. Some people were surmising that there may be similar difficulties but, in fact, there will not be.

It will enable the digital conversion schemes to allow temporary test transmissions of digital broadcasting services before the commencement of the simulcast period and enable the ABA to formulate and implement a different digital conversion scheme for the transmission of broadcasting services to remote areas, taking into account the special circumstances which apply to the delivery of a television service to these areas.

It provides that the simulcast requirements do not apply to advertising, transmission arrangements or individual programs where the ABA is satisfied that the digital version of the broadcasting service will be substantially the same as the analog version of the broadcasting service. It increases consultation provisions on the formulation and implementation of the television conversion schemes and the access regime under the bill. It exempts advertising and sponsorship announcements from the closed captioning obligations.

We require digital television transmission standards and datacasting standards to be directed towards the objective of having open conditional access systems. These amendments and other minor technical government amendments have been drafted following industry consultation on the bill as introduced into the House. I take the opportunity to thank all those within the industry for their substantial submissions on this matter. Obviously, many have made submissions to the Senate. The minister has taken account of these matters and those matters are reflected in these amendments. I have taken the opportunity to explain in short form what they are and therefore proceed to commend the amendments to the House.

As I understand it, SBS offered that opportunity to commercial broadcasters free of charge. They offered to the other networks the right to on-broadcast the World Cup games free of charge. talk.start.para: âAt the outset I indicate to the government that, whilst we have some reservations about increasing the departure tax on passengers leaving Australia, the opposition will not be opposing this particular measure as it has been caught up in the budget process. Also, the way in which this has been introducedâincreasing the so-called passenger movement charge, which is a departure tax, by $3 up to $30âis a clear example of this government's breaking yet another promise to the Australian people, that is, in the first term of a Howard government there would be no increases in taxes and no introduction of new taxes. Clearly, this is a promise that has been broken. It has now slumped into the category of a non-core promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Once again, it is going to be the outbound tourists leaving Australia, both Australians travelling overseas for holidays and those tourists that have come from overseas and then are departing to go home, that will be slugged the extra $3.

speech.para: I read with interest that it is proposed that this measure commence on 1 January 1999, so it is some six or so months away, although interestingly, according to the explanatory memorandum, it was actually to start on 1 January 1998. That has been conveniently crossed out and somebody has written in `1999'. Whether that was a printer's error or whether the government was again going back on one of its long-cherished beliefs when it comes to legislation and its effects on the Australian peopleâthat is, introducing an element of retrospectivityâwe will not know, because this bill, when it is finally passed, will not come into effect until 1 January 1999.

It has been sold also as a measure to reap some benefit for Australia, for the government, in the year 2000 as a result of the Olympic Games. The fact is that Australia stands to benefit from an enormous influx of people, certainly commencing next year in 1999 and in the year 2000, as people come to this nation, both as athletes and also as visitors, to participate in what is clearly every four years one of the premier sporting activities in the world. The Olympics will provide an opportunity for people to see first-hand the world's athletes; they will see at first-hand in Sydney facilities which have been purpose built and which I think will stand the test of time as being amongst the best, if not the best, ever constructed for that purpose. Certainly that was the view of Juan Antonio Samaranch when he was here a few months ago to look at progress on the site.

As I have indicated, the departure tax increase that we are discussing today will be implemented by way of a bill. There had been some thought that it would be implemented simply by regulation, but that has proven not to be the case.

There is a severe budgetary implication for government with the introduction of this tax increase, not in a negative sense but certainly in a positive sense. Based on the budget measures outlined in Budget Paper No. 2 1998-99 and looking into the next four years, you can see that the take by the government from increasing the departure tax alone on visitors leaving this country by air is going to reap at best estimatesâand I think these are conservativeâ$78 million.

I will continue my remarks on this issue a little later today because I want to expose some of the hypocrisy of the government in respect of implementing these sorts of measuresâbreaking, Prime Minister, yet again, that promise.

âCan the Treasurer inform the House of the March quarter national accounts. Furthermore, are the figures consistent with budget forecasts?

âI thank the honourable member for her question. Today's national accounts confirm that the Australian economy is growing strongly. In the March quarter the national accounts recorded 1.3 per cent growth, and over the course of the year 4.9 per cent growth in the Australian economy. A 4.9 per cent growth in the Australian economy puts Australia probably at the highest of the OECD, with possible exceptions in Finland and Mexico, but certainly higher than all of the G-7 economies.

answer.para: Although the national accounts are always subject to revision, and care has to be taken in interpreting any particular quarter, one can see that this is totally consistent with the budget forecasts of growth in 1997-98 of 3Â¾ per centâindeed, at the moment considerably exceeding those forecasts. On the back of strong growth in this quarter those forecasts will be realised.

Although today's national accounts showed that domestic demand was flat, other indicators, such as employment growth, job vacancies, building approvals, credit growth, import growth and continued strength in trading performance and business surveys all support strong domestic demand continuing. Although today's accounts also show a build-up in private stocks allowing for a trend decline in the stock to sales ratio, there was a low stock to sales ratio. Indeed, it appears that the build-up in public marketing authority stocks, particularly by the Australian Wheat Board, indicates that the Wheat Board was holding commodities such as wheat, barley and sugarâcommodities which have now been sold and which will become exports in the next quarter and contribute to export growth in the final quarter of 1997-98.

More recent building approvals numbers showing growth of 8.3 per cent in April and 19.5 per cent over the year indicate good investment in the economy. Business investment will be underpinned by continuing growth in corporate profits, which grew 3.5 per cent in March to be 7.5 per cent higher than a year earlier.

These figures are consistent with an economy which is showing low inflation, enjoying the lowest interest rates in generations and enjoying a government which has put the budget back in the black and is now reducing Commonwealth debt, and which has had remarkably strong growth up until March of this year, at 4.9 per cent.

talk.start.para: âWhat about the current account?

âI think most Australians will welcome strong growth in the Australian economy. I think even the frontbench of the Labor Party would say that the important decisions of getting Australia's budget back in the black, of locking in low inflation and of giving Australia low interest rates were important markers to get to this position.

answer.para: Whilst an external downturn in Asia will affect the Australian economy and mark down growth in 1998-99 from the levels that it has been in 1997-98, we can say without qualification that it was the decisions of the government to turn around the haemorrhaging deficit and debt strategy of Labor, to reduce inflation and to bring down interest rates that strengthened the Australian economy at a time of external challenge. No-one would want to be running the Australian economy if it were still running a $10 billion deficit now in the face of an external challenge of the dimension that we now have. Now is not the time to turn our backs on good economic policy; now is the time to continue it, to continue to strengthen the Australian economy against external challenge and to bring the benefits of low inflation and low interest rates to small businesses and home buyers in this country.

answer.para: The growth rate in Australia is probablyâwith the exception of China and Chinese Taipeiâthe highest growth rate in the Asian region. answer.para: It is very easy when you have an Australian industry under a bit of economic pressure as a result of imports to run around the country saying, `The answer to the problem is to choke off imports.' Unfortunately, most of the imports in this particular instanceâunfortunately for the honourable member's argumentâare coming from Canada. It so happens that we have something like an eight or nine to one trade balance against Canada. If we were to be so short-sighted as to chop off imports from a country in respect of which we have a trade balance of about nine to one, we would in fact be cutting off our nose to spite our face. That would be a very unwise thing to do.

The international economic reality is that when it comes to a trading nation like Australia, we need markets. We need people to buy the goods and services we produce. If we do not buy the goods and services other people produce, they will not buy what we produce. That is a constant of international trade. I say this very deliberately because the honourable member has been running around the place saying that it is all very easy to solve these problems by chopping off imports. If you chop off imports in the wrong place, you will chop off Australian jobs. If you do that you will chop off Australian jobs.

I therefore say to those people in the pig industryâand I am sympathetic to their position; I listened very carefully to what they had to say, just as I am sympathetic to any industry that is under import pressureâthat, if you chop off imports from one source and there is retaliation, you will end up doing up far more damage to your country, you will destroy more jobs and you will destroy more industry than if you had not taken that action.

It is about time that all of us who are interested in a sensible debate and all of us who are interested in the future of Australian industry face the reality of this and stop running around uttering and mouthing populist one-liners offering simplistic solutions that would in fact damage the situation and leave us with fewer jobs, weaker industry and a far more impoverished trade situation.

In regard to diversification, I want to make two additional points. Japan is the world's second largest economy. Yes, it is hovering around zero growth, and that is a matter of concern. But, if you are the second largest economy in the world, even at zero growth you still need a lot of Australian intermediate goods, including coal and iron ore. And thank God they do. Hence, our intermediate goods exports have contributed to the fact that in the first 10 months of this financial year our exports to Japan are up 15.4 per cent, our exports to Taiwan are up 16.7 per cent, and our exports to China are up 9.4 per cent.

In other words, what we have done is help facilitate our export effort, help diversify our export effort, help demand and encourage demand, particularly with regard to our intermediate goods, and help with some hard edged trade negotiations at the bilateral, the regional and the multilateral levels.

The modernisation of Australian agriculture under the leadership provided by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has helped in that regard. The Australian government will do all it can to facilitate a diversified trade effort to the world, exports to every market opportunity in the world. We recognise there is no such thing as a level playing field, and we will work hard to further provide sensible support within the parameters of the World Trade Organisation to ensure that our exporters continue to create even more jobs.

Amongst those statements is included oneâand the member for Braddon will correct me if I am wrongâfrom the mayor of one of the local shires or municipalities who is a member of the Australian Labor Partyâin fact, he may even be a candidate for the Australian Labor Party in the forthcoming election.

answer.para: On Friday, the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Minister for Social Security, at my request, will both be going to Burnie to meet community representatives. They will be discussing the implications of the closure, and they will be discussing with community leaders various responses that might responsibly be undertaken. Against the background of those discussions, the government will be making some announcement and giving consideration to a further series of responses. I take this opportunity to point out that, despite the intense disappointment the government feels about the decision to close the pulp mill and the concern we have for the welfare of the 150 to 200 men and women and their families who will be affected by the closure,â

talk.start.para: âWorse work practices than the MUA.
âThe member for Denison will remain silent.
âWorse work practices than the MUA.
âI warn the member for Denison.

âIt is worthwhile pointing out that in the year to April 1998 there were 2,900 new jobs created in north-west Tasmania and the unemployment rate over that period in that region has fallen by 1.3 per cent. So the overall employment direction in north-west Tasmania, despite the adverse circumstances of the pulp mill, has been very positive. I remind the House that, since being elected, the government has put in place a number of very positive employment measures for the people of north-west Tasmania. There was the regional forest agreement, which was criticised by the member for Denison; the regional forest agreement that represented a very generous provision and which was put in place by the federal government. It is not only pro-environment but also pro-employment. And there was, of course, the Bass Strait vehicle subsidy, which has led to a strengthening of the tourist industry in Tasmania.

answer.para: I again say what I told the House yesterday, about the great employment opportunity of a generation for north-west Tasmaniansâthe Wesley Vale pulp millâbeing sacrificed on the altar of the Labor Party pursuing the agenda of a sectional interest. The rejection of the Wesley Vale pulp mill represented the height of the determination of the Labor Party to pay court to sectional interests at the expense of its traditional working-class base. I notice the member for Lalor, the National President of the Labor Party, is nodding his agreement.

talk.start.para: âNo, I am not! I did not.

âHe is nodding his agreement because in 1989 you had this classic example. I applaud the candour of the National President of the Australian Labor Party because once again he has reminded the House that, when Labor was in government, Labor was driven by sectional interests.

âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. What I was attempting to do was to interject to say that the main complainants were the fishermenâthe fishing industry was being destroyed in the area. The Prime Minister has completely misrepresented the situation.
âI know the member for Lalor always has something interesting to say, but he is not making a relevant point of order.

âWhat happened in Wesley Vale was that the Labor Party faced a choice between giving blue-collar workers in north-west Tasmania a job, a future and some hope, or placating the greeniesâand they chose the latter. They chose the green option and they threw the blue-collar workers to the wolves. Nothing that Labor has said since or nothing that Labor might say to try to exploit the Burnie situation at present can alter the fact that when you were in government you sacrificed the jobs of hundreds, if not thousands, of blue-collar workers in order to meet your green agenda. You did it with Wesley Vale; you did it all over the country. It was a deliberate tactic to serve the sectional interests of the Australian Labor Party, and that is one of the reasons why, in their hundreds of thousands, blue-collar workers all over the nation deserted you in 1996.
âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Has his attention been drawn to the statement by Professor Neil Warren on ABC television on 18 May, who said:

question.para: People are saying the GST will solve all our ills. I mean, the GST will not, and I think it is a mistake that it is going to cure our foreign debt and create thousands of jobs. It is just not going to do that.

I also ask the Prime Minister: is that the same Neil Warren who last September estimated that a 10 per cent GST would increase inflation by up to 5.2 per cent after repealing the wholesale sales tax? Does the Prime Minister still think that Neil Warren is one of the greatest tax experts in Australia?

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker!
âPrime Minister, you have a point of order behind you.
âHe hasn't been on TV for a while. Give him a go.
âIf the member for Banks will permit the House to hear, we can hear the member for Parramatta.

âOn a point of order, Mr Speaker: there are three brief points. Firstly, you have already warned the opposition about lengthy quotes from media statements. Secondly, standing orders specifically suggest that, where a media statement is allowed to be quoted, it must not contain comment, argument or opinion or material otherwise out of order. Finally, I would suggest that there is not a shred of that question which is capable of satisfying standing order 142. The comments of anyone external to the House are not the responsibility of the Prime Minister or any other minister, and the question should be ruled out of order.

âIf the members of the opposition had remained silent, we all could have heard the point of order. In fact, the question was directed towards the credentials of Dr Neil Warren, whose name has been presented before the House. Consequently, it is in order and I call on the Prime Minister to respond.

âThe answer to the question asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is yes, I still do have a great deal of respect for Dr Warren and I regard him as one of the foremost tax experts in Australia. You ask me do I agree with his statement that a GST will not solve every imaginable ill, or words to that effect; of course I do. I have never asserted that it would. I take the opportunity afforded me by the very convenient question of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to say that, in order to build even greater security for the Australian economy, what you need is reform on a number of fronts. Reforming the taxation system is the next logical thing Australia must do in order to further strengthen the Australian economy.

answer.para: We have the budget into balance, indeed into surplus. We have business investment running strongly. We have reformed the industrial relations system. We have many other micro-economic reforms under way and the next thing we have to do, not in a revolutionary but in a sensible evolutionary way, is to reform the Australian taxation system. Looking at the indirect taxation system is part of it.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked me a question about speeches made by Dr Warren. When you trawl around for speeches made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, it is interesting what you come up against. One of the things that I came up against was a compilation of speeches and statements made, which are available. There is a very interesting document entitled Speeches and statements available on the Labor Party's Internet site. Going through it, this is what a search reveals. The ALP Internet site has a section called `Speeches and policy statements'. It contains, so it says, a list of major speeches and policy statements by the leadership group. That sounds impressive.

For the years 1997 and 1998 the site lists the following: 48 speeches and statements by Kim Beazley; three by Cheryl Kernot; three by Mark Latham, and a book; two by Simon Crean; one by Paul Keating called `A prospect of Europe'; one by Martin Ferguson; one by Nick Bolkus; one by Martyn Evans; and one by Bob McMullan. There is a strange omissionâthere are none from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. In the whole of 1997 and 1998, there was none.

So it is apparent that the Leader of the Opposition's injunction at the doorstop this morning has had retrospective effect and that all of the speeches of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have been deleted. I address a heartfelt plea to the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Gary Gray: please can we have Gareth's speeches, because we love them?

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In recent days has Mr Christopher Skase applied for another Australian passport? If so, what is your reaction to that application?

âI thank the honourable member for Fadden for his question. I recognise that the honourable member for Fadden is one of all of the members on this side of the House who want to see Mr Skase brought back to Australia to face chargesâunlike some of the people over there, apparently.

answer.para: We have been trying to clean up this problem which was left for us by, above all, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. As the House knows, I cancelled Mr Skase's last Australian passport on 29 April last year. That passport has now been returned to Australia by the Spanish authorities. They confiscated it when Mr Skase applied to renew his residence permit in Majorca which expired on 13 May this year.

On 27 Mayâthat is, last Wednesdayâa lawyer representing Mr Christopher Skase wrote to the Australian Embassy in Madrid seeking a new Australian passport for Mr Skase. Mr Skase claimed he needed a new passport because he now has no identification documents. I can inform the House that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will not be issuing Mr Skase with a new passport. That is the policy of this government. We have informed Mr Skase's lawyer, through our embassy in Madrid, that his application for a new passport has been rejected and that he will not receive a passport.

Immediately after question time, I will be meeting with the Spanish Minister for Industry and Energy, Mr Pique. During our discussions, I will be taking the opportunity to ask that the Spanish government not renew Mr Skase's residency in Spain. Whilst the Australian government will not be issuing Mr Skase with a new passport, we are prepared to do one thing for him; that is, to issue him with a travel document to enable him to return to Australia. And that's it.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the terms of reference to the waterfront consultancy tabled in the Senate on 23 October last year. Is the Prime Minister aware that part of the document containing a direct reference to another attachment setting out the role of the Prime Minister and his staffer Arthur Sinodinos was deliberately deleted? Prime Minister, did you or your office have any role in the decision to delete that reference?
âI cannot recall the circumstances of that. I will have a look, and if there is anything useful I can tell the House I will.

âI address my question to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Can the minister inform the House what role detention policy has played in maintaining the integrity of Australia's borders? What has the coalition government done to ensure that Australia's detention centres provide an acceptable standard of detention?

âI thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for his question in relation to the maintenance of the integrity of our borders. It is a particularly relevant issue to the Northern Territory, as in the past it has been one of the places where people have clandestinely attempted to enter Australia. An important aspect of dealing with the issue of the extent to which people seek to circumvent our very reasonable immigration requirements is the issue of how you manage the entry of people who seek to come clandestinely. We know that in the early 1990s hundreds and hundreds of people arrived by boat, and this year we expect something of the order of 1,700 unauthorised arrivals by air. We have seen very significant trafficking and people making large amounts of money out of smuggling people from one country to another and exploiting people's vulnerability.

answer.para: Some of the people who seek to access Australia may have legitimate claims for refugee status for protection. That is a matter for which we have proper regard. We do accept our international obligations and we do allow those people who have proper claims to access Australia promptly. But, in relation to those people who arrive with no authority, often without any identification or documentation, who have deliberately disguised the way in which they are trying to enter Australia, you need to have a framework of law to deal with that situation. The framework of law has to be complemented by a range of measures to deal with those initiatives.

That does not seem to be well understood by some members of the human rights bodies that we have, by some well-meaning people who argue that when people arrive clandestinely they ought to be released into the community immediately or shortly after. The fact is that if you are going to ensure the integrity of the borders you need to have a system in place in which people are detained and, if they have no claims, are available for removal. You need to have a situation in which you are able to effectively administer that arrangement, and detention complements that regime. It is not an end in itself, but without it our ability to remove people in a timely way would not occur.

It is important to know that over a period of time we have been able to effectively reform the way in which this task is being undertaken. Today, protection visa applications are dealt with, for those in detention, in 51 days. The average length of detention for unauthorised boat arrivals in November 1995 was 417 days, compared with the average length of detention for all unauthorised arrivalsâthat includes boat and air arrivalsâof 174 days. There has been a very effective removal of people, such that we have only 13 boat arrivals presently in Australia, and one is seeking to resolve their situation as quickly as possible. Those who refuse to cooperate, those who refuse to pursue their applications, can often be held for times longer than we would like.

Finally, in relation to the question of the way in which people are maintained in Australia, let me say that there had been, I think, except for the purchase of the Port Hedland detention centre, no activity by the former government in looking at the way in which accommodation was provided. In the time that we have been in office, some $12.5 million has been spent on upgrading the Port Hedland detention centre, and in the most recent budget provision has been made for a $35 million project to upgrade the Villawood detention centre. They are important developments, ensuring that we do detain people in humane conditions and appropriate conditionsâ

talk.start.para: âIt says something about your government.
âThat is right. Tell the full story. We were looking for alternative sites.
âThe member for Reid and the member for Banks will remain silentâand so will members of the government.

âThe full story, for the honourable member for Banks, is that there was an abysmal record that led to large numbers of people seeking to enter Australia clandestinely. They did over time. We have turned that around, and we do not hold people in detention for the sorts of periods that brought Australia into disrepute before international human rights bodies. I have been defending Australia in relation to your record. If you want to raise your record, put it up every time and I will compare it with ours.

âMy question is to the Prime Minister, and it follows that by my colleague the member for Melbourne. Prime Minister, can you assure the House that, prior to 23 October, you had no knowledge of or involvement in the development of a government strategy involving the prospect of industrial action that would give stevedores the option of dismissing their employees and rehiring new people under different arrangements?

âI can assure the House that, from the time I became Prime Minister, in relation to the Australian waterfront I had one single aim, and that was to bring about reform of the Australian waterfront. Can I say that that remains my attitude. I want to praise the work of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business in relation to that.
âAnother non-answer.
âAnswer the question.
âI raise a point of order.

âThe Prime Minister will resume his seat. If the members from the opposition persist in interjecting, they will not be in the House to do so for long. The honourable member for Canberra on a point of order.

âMy point of order is on the very fundamental question of relevance. The question specifically wanted to know the Prime Minister's level of knowledge or involvement in the development of a particular strategy, and that generalised blah is not a response to that question.

âThe level of knowledge is not specifically a subject for questioning in parliament, but the Prime Minister is answering. I suggest that the question was in general in order and I ask the Prime Minister to respond.

âI repeat that from the time I became Prime Minister I had the aim in relation to the waterfront of bringing about reform. I specifically instructed the two ministers in my government who are responsible, the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development and the member for Hume and the current Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Naturally, in the course of that many options and many proposals were discussed. Those discussions and examination of those proposals proceeded upon the basis that we wanted a reformed, competitive waterfront and that change should occur to achieve those objectives, and upon the understanding always that change should be in accordance with the laws of Australia. I have always said that I would support efforts by anybody to reform the Australian waterfront provided those efforts were in accordance with the laws of Australia. That was my view, it is my view and it will remain my view, and I am very proud it.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister inform the House what policy initiatives are currently being implemented in his portfolio? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals?
âThat question is getting very close to being out of order. I will ask the minister to respond, but I suggest you look at the framing of those questions a little more carefully.

âI thank the honourable member for Herbert for his question. The member for Herbert, who is a very good representative for North Queensland, is always lobbying for assistance for his area from all government ministers. A couple of items of note that have taken place out of my portfolio in his area are the upgrading of the national highway system on the Bruce Highway and the upgrading of Wilcox Street in Townsville, which was a $21 million project which was promised by Labor for 13 years but never undertaken. It was one of those 14th year commitments: `We were gunna do it.' The coalition government has just brought down a very good budget which produced a $2.7 billion surplusâa turnaround of $13 billion from what we inherited from Labor.
âAnd cut the national highway again.
âAs part of that budget, the road fundingâI will come to the interjection of the member for Melbourne in a minuteâwas $1.62 billion.
âYou will address the question and not come to the honourable member for Melbourne.
âYou can, mr Speaker; let him go for it!
âThe member for Melbourne.

âThe last budget that the Labor Party brought down was $1.594 billion for roads, so it was an increase on that. We also had a $250 million allocation for rail and $3.5 billion worth of programs for regional Australia. The coalition knows the direction in which it wants to take Australia. We have a very clear view of where we are going. That contrasts greatly with the Australian Labor Party, which seems to be in a bit of a quandary as to the direction they want to go in. With the leadership up front here, it is whether they want to take the middle road, and with the young and the restless on the other end there is one wanting to take off to the right and the other wanting to take off to the left.

answer.para: I was interested to note an article in yesterday's Age written by the member for Melbourne, entitled `Why Labor Must Take a New Road.' He said in that article:
At the recent Victorian ALP Conference, John Brumby urged delegates to embrace the politics of the Third Way.
Not the first way or the second wayâthe third way.
He went on to say:
Why are leading Labor politicians in Australia starting to identify it as a potential source of policy inspiration?
They are plagiarising the policies of New Labour in the United Kingdom. They do not have any policies for Australia. He went on to say:
Without such principles New Labour risks being no more than a group of well-intentioned men and women making it up as they go along.
That is exactly what the Labor Party are doing. They are making it up as they go along. The penultimate line in this article is the last one, where he saidâ

talk.start.para: âA point of order, Mr Speaker!
âI point out to the minister that he is stretching a bit far from his portfolio at the moment.

âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not think I need to point out to you that this is entirely irrelevant to the question that was asked. It has nothing to do with road funding or with anything in the minister's portfolio. He should be made to sit down.

âThe member for Calwell will resume his seat. The question itself was so wide, it was within the parameter of the question but it is quite outside the minister's portfolio and I suggest he resumes answering the question, relating to issues within his portfolio and within the question.
âThe question was about the policy initiatives of our government and alternative proposals, and the member for Melbourne has put up some alternative proposals. He said:

answer.para: Labor must look beyond seductive slogans like the Third Way and understand the significance of the economic transformation.

We can only presume that he is talking about the significance of the economic transformation that the coalition government has introduced over the last 2Â½ years in fixing up the structural deficiencies of the Australian economy that we inherited from the Australian Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âThe minister will conclude his answer.
âIt is only the coalition government that has a view to the future of Australia. The Labor Party does not know which direction it is going in.
âThe minister will resume his seat.
âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to raise this with you but in this segment of the parliament we cannot participate in the affairs of the parliament because we cannot hear.

âThe honourable member for Hinkler has raised a matter that I have been endeavouring to address. The acoustics are still appalling. I know it is hard but I ask all members to take note of the fact that each of the members has an equal right to be heard and to hear in this place.

âDoes the Treasurer agree with the Business Coalition for Tax Reform that reforming the vertical fiscal imbalance in Commonwealth-state finances should be a fundamental element of any serious tax reform package?

âI thank the honourable member for Moore for his question. When the Prime Minister announced that the government was serious about tax reform and would take a policy to the next election for tax reform, he laid down five principles. The five principles included broad based indirect tax, significant personal income tax cuts, compensation for those in need, and the fifth was addressing Commonwealth-state financial relations.
âWhat was the fourth?
âI cannot remember the fourth for the moment, but there is a fourth.

answer.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âMembers of the opposition will remain silent.

âThe fifth was addressing Commonwealth-state relations, and that is the basis upon which we approach tax reform. One of the difficulties where you are putting together a tax reform packageâand we have sought to engage the states in this discussionâis that not all of the states have the same view. The meeting that we had with state premiers to discuss issues was very productive, and I think a majority of the state premiers are significantly committed to tax reform. But there is, of course, one Labor Premier. That Labor Premierâalthough I believe he will say privately that he agrees with tax reformâis being heavied by the leadership of the Australian Labor Party, for political opportunist reasons, not to engage in it.

answer.para: I think Premier Carr if he had his druthersâhe is quite an intelligent manâwould join the movement for tax reform.

talk.start.para: âBut what about your mate, Jeff? He has done so much toâ
âThe member for Batman has been warned. I ask him to leave the House under 304A for an hour.

para.inline: The honourable member for Batman thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

talk.start.para: âIt will not reduce the IQ of the Labor frontbench.
âThe Treasurer will resume his answer and refrain from personal innuendo.

âThe Premier of New South Wales, I believe, would be interested in tax reform. One must remember that, when the government first announced that it was going to engage in tax reform, we got support from the federal leadership of the Labor Party. The deputy leader of the Labor Party said on Radio 3LO on 19 May 1997:

answer.para: If the business community and the welfare community can get together and come up with some proposal that makes some kind of sense on all these fronts, that genuinely meets the concerns that people had about equity of attacks on consumption or expenditure and it meets the needs of the larger economy, then of course we would have to look at any such proposal.

So the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was prepared to join the tax reform, and then of course Labor, for completely opportunistic reasons, ruled itself out of the tax debate. In ruling federal Labor out of the tax debate, all the state branches were automatically ruled out, and as a result Premier Carr is unable to agree.

This puts us into a difficult position, doesn't it, because you have the Premier of the largest state who, whatever his private views, has been blackballed from the tax reform debate by Beazley, who has also blackballed Evans. This is, of course, giving a difficulty to discussing Commonwealth-state relations, but we are seeking to make progress in relation to it, and addressing vertical fiscal imbalance is one of the significant areas of doing that.

Can I assure the honourable member for Moore that, as the government progresses these things, it progresses in relation to all five principles that the Prime Minister had mentionedâbroad based indirect tax, lower personal income taxes, compensation for those that would be otherwise disadvantaged, no increase in the overall tax to GDP position and Commonwealth-state relations; all five principles that the Prime Minister outlined.

What do these results indicate about the coalition government's approach to balancing the migration program?

âYou got them in.

The fact is that independent migrants have had a very positive impact upon our economy, upon employment and government finances. The survey shows that three years after arrival they have a labour market participationâ

talk.start.para: âThere is far too high a level of conversation in the chamber. I would ask members to please remain silent.

âThis survey shows that three years after arrival independent migrants exhibit these characteristics: they have a labour market participation rate of more than 90 per cent, their unemployment rate is well below the Australian average at five per cent, the majority have obtained employment which is commensurate with their employment experience prior to migration and they earn on average over $40,000 per year.
âThe member for Prospect has been warned. You are talking far too loudly. I ask you to leave the House under standing order 304A.

para.inline: The honourable member for Prospect thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

talk.start.para: âIn other words, what this survey demonstrates is that those migrants create more jobs than they fill. This has to, I think, be characterised against the sort of program that we saw before we came to officeâone that was lacking balance.
