This government, by enhancing skill, age and English language requirements for skilled migrants, has ensured that all Australians benefit significantly as a result of the entry of skilled migrants.

answer.para: This contrasts with the position that the Labor Party is taking. The Labor leader made it clear last week in the article he wrote for the Australia-Israel Review that it is intent on increasing the family reunion stream without changing the total program numbers. The impact of that would be to increase family reunion entrants at the expense of skilled migrants. In other words, it would increase the number of people who are highly welfare dependentâthose people who are very often non bona fideâbecause if you look at the family reunion program as it was conducted by our predecessorsâ
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âUnderstand this: most of the family reunion program is for spouses, de facto partners and fiances.
âYou are keeping spouses out.
âThe member for Calwell! The member for Calwell will remain silent!
âI warn the member for Calwell.

âThose people who have bona fide applications access Australia. It is demand driven. If you want to increase it, the only way you will increase it is by introducing more people in sham relationshipsâmore people who are non bona fide.
âThat is rubbish.

âThat is the only way you are going to get up: if all the spouse applicants who are bona fide are able to access Australia. If it is demand driven, the only way to increase it is to get non bona fide applicants.
âA point of order!
âThe minister will resume his seat. He should have in mind he should not respond to interjections. The member for Calwell on a point of order.
âMr Speaker, the minister is misleading the House on the situation of the spouses in this country.
âThat is not a point of order.
âMany are being held up for up to 18 months before they can comeâ
âThe member for Calwell will resume his seat! That is not a point of order. There are ways by which he can raise his point of view if he should wish to do so. That is not one of them.

âLet me move on from the point I was making to the only substantial area in family reunion, which is in relation to parents. They can be parents who are aged or working age. The fact is that we have put a cap on those numbers. We do not apologise for that; we have done it very deliberately. The longitudinal survey demonstrated why that was necessary. The position with family reunion entrants is that generally the labour participation rate is only 20 per centâI am sorryâthis is in relation to the parent category; let me make it clear.
âAre they bogus parents?
âNo, I am not suggesting that they are bogus parents.
âThe minister will respond to the question, not to interjections.

âI am simply saying that in the parent category they have a labour participation rate of only 20 per cent and that includes working age parents. The unemployment rate is more than 60 per cent. They earn on average just over $10,000 per year. In other words, the positive economic outcomes of skilled migration would be lost if you were to shift the balance back to family reunion. That is the point that needs to be understood by the opposition and the Australian community. The Labor Party wants to turn the clock back to the point where the Australian community would have absolutely no confidence in the way the program was being conducted.

âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, isn't it true that your government was on notice about the Burnie closure but it still dragged its feet on anti-dumping and has done nothing to bring forward a value-added strategy for the industry as part of the RFA process which you spoke about just recently? Will you undertake to personally visit Burnie to see the devastating impact this closure will have on the community and will you also undertake to immediately develop an industry plan for the forest products industry and personally talk to Amcor about opportunities for new investment in the Burnie region?
âI wonder where the member for Lyons was, and I wonder what he said, when Graham Richardson said on 8 September 1989
âA point of order!
âoh, we will come to you in a minute too.
âOn a point of order: the Prime Minister's absolute contempt for the environment is well known. But, if he could get on with hisâ

âOrder! That is not a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat. If the member for Denison wishes to make a point of order he can do so. Engaging in debate during question time is totally contrary to the standing orders, as the honourable member knows.

âThe sensitivity of the Australian Labor Party to the special interest group politics that it played at the expense of blue-collar workersâand continues to play at the expense of blue-collar workersâis demonstrated by the actions of the Carr Labor government in New South Wales where it is selling out interests of blue-collar workers in the timber industry in the coastal regions of New South Wales.
âA point of order!

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, access to services is a major priority for people living in regional and rural Australia, including those in my electorate of Capricornia. Given that one-third of the veteran community lives outside major metropolitan areas, can you tell the House what the government has done to improve services for veterans and war widows in regional areas? In particular, what has been done to provide veterans with access to information about their entitlements?

âToday is the 56th anniversary of the great naval battle of Midway in the Pacific during the Second World War. I acknowledge the great support that the member for Capricornia gives to the veteran community in his electorate. There is no doubt that our veterans and war widows, wherever they live, need access to good services, particularly if they can be found in their home town or region.

answer.para: Since coming to government it has been a priority of the government not only to focus on the needs of our veterans who live in urban areas but also, because one-third of our veterans and war widows live outside urban Australia, it has been important to make sure that those in regional and rural areas have access to information services. This is an area of government service that was not delivered under the Labor Party when they were in government for 13 years.

It is important, too, that veterans do not have to rely solely on telephone access for this valuable service or information. Since coming to government less than two and a quarter years ago, we have not only introduced new services for veterans in rural Australia, including psychiatric services, podiatry services and more easily accessed transport services, but one of our most important improvements is that we have made it easier for veterans to gain information about their entitlements. Only recently in Rockhampton, the member for Capricornia's town, the TPI Association through the joint venture scheme was successful in gaining $3,500 for transport services for its TPI members and $4,500 for other services for its association.

Since coming to government we have opened up veterans affairs network offices in Bendigo, Maroochydore and Toowoomba. We have also established information services for veterans throughout New South Wales through the New South Wales government access centres in Gilgandra, in Grenfell, in Oberon; and through the Queensland government agents program, in Biloela, Cunnamulla, Blackall and Julia Creek. We have established information services through Centrelink in Orange, in the member for Calare's electorate, in your own electorate, Mr Speaker, in Tamworth; in Wagga Wagga, and in Rockhampton in the member for Capricornia's electorate. Soon we will be doing it in Mount Gambier in South Australia.

Contracted information services have also been established at Roma and Emerald, in Queensland. We have contracted community development services in Mildura and in Darwin. We have also assisted the veteran community to establish veteran information centres in Alice Springs, Port Lincoln and Murray Bridge. We are currently negotiating with the Tasmanian state government for information services to be provided in Smithton and also in Queenstown.

This is the way the government is acknowledging that one-third of veterans live outside of metropolitan Australia. The information that these offices provide is invaluable to our veteran community. We have established 22 information services locations throughout Australia since coming to government and there are more to come. This is acknowledgment of our veteran community and the very special place they hold not only in urban Australia but also in rural and remote parts of our nation.

talk.start.para: âToday's announcement that the Amcor pulp mill in Burnie will close by the end of the year is yet another savage blow to the economy of north-west Tasmania. And what do we see? We see the government not only ignoring their plight but also scurrying out of the chamber.

speech.para: The closure will mean the loss of at least 200 jobs directly associated with the mill and many others in the north-west community. The decision to import pulp rather than to produce it at Burnie is a harsh and callous act against the mill workers and their families, who have acted loyally for the company and for their region. Over the last few years these people have done everything asked of them to lift the efficiency of the millâto cooperate with the management, to work as a teamâand yet they find out about their redundancy by a leak in a newspaper. When they turned up at the meeting today to be given the news directly, they were given no detailed information as to what was involved or what their future could hold. The closure of this mill will further worsen our already deteriorating current account.

We fixed a regional forest agreement for Tasmania and established that area which could be logged. What this closure does is to move away from processing that which is logged so that more will now go out as woodchips. How can that logic be understood? It is not only a hit to the workers themselvesâbecause they have no futureâbut also completely contrary to the direction in which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) today said he was trying to head the nationâthat is, value added activity. This is reversing the direction. It is going back to woodchip exports.

What is the government doing about this? Nothing to date. Today's announcement of the intended closure has seen the government lift not one finger to try to stop it. We now know from the decision today that this closure will not occur until October. Given that the government has done nothing to date, it at least has the opportunity now to do something between this announcement and October to try to preserve and secure those jobs which otherwise will be lost in Burnie. The Prime Minister must personally intervene. His member of parliament for that seat has been totally ineffective. The acting minister for industry, Mr Truss, has ended up insulting the workers and blaming them for their own fate. And where is the real Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore)? He has gone to Paris. There are a few casinos in Paris. But he will not go to Burnie to save the workers or their future.

This requires the Prime Minister to personally intervene. He should telephone Amcor's chair, Stan Wallis, and talk about what is needed to safeguard the jobs of the Burnie workers. He should go himself to Burnie immediately to see first-hand the problems facing the region and to meet the workers and the management of the mill. His government must develop a comprehensive industry development strategy for that industry based on the forest agreements; not just secure a forest agreementâwhich was the legacy that Labor leftâbut actually intertwine it with an industry development strategy that drives value adding. That is what this government should be doing. He also should be talking to Amcor about alternative investment opportunities in the Burnie region based upon such a strategy. That is what that government should be doing. It is what Labor would have been doing well before now.

Again we are saying to the government: we will cooperate in talking with the work force, talking with the region, about what we can do collectively to secure an expansion, not a decline, in the region. But this is a government that turns its back on any suggestion of bipartisan approaches to industry policy and turns its back on getting involved in any activity that can secure the future of workers. In short, the Prime Minister has to involve himself. He needs to lead. That is what he claims to be: the leader of the nation. But he cannot lead on this issue because he has got no interest in doing so.

Yesterday, in question time, the opposition called on the Prime Minister, before this announcement was made today to the Burnie workers, to actually telephone Stan Wallis, the chair of that company. We know that he has the telephone number of Stan Wallis because it is Stan Wallis who is always appearing whenever the Prime Minister needs to be bolstered on the call for tax reform. It is Stan Wallis who says, `Take the taxes off business and shift them to the punters, shift them to the workers,' and, `Prime Minister, we are behind you all the way.'

But can the Prime Minister have the simple conversation with Stan Wallis about securing the jobs of the workers, the people who without jobs will not be paying any tax because they will be unemployed? That is the question and the issue that the Prime Minister should be engaging himself in. He refused to answer that yesterday in the parliament, so I take it he has not made that call. He refused to say whether he would make it. He refused to say again today whether he would even visit the mill.

Who is he sending down? His Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman). Why would you be sending the Minister for Social Security if it was not to look at the circumstances of unemployment benefits? Why not send the minister for industry? Why not send the person sitting at the table deputising for the minister for industry, who has gone to Paris, Minister `Blackjack' Moore who would not go to Newcastle when the Newcastle works closed but went to the opening of the casino? Now he has gone to Paris. He is putting baguettes before Burnie because he does not care about them. Where are you as acting minister? You get up and insult the work force in this place.

We also had, in the context of the BHP closure, the Prime Minister offering to go to Newcastle `soon'. Soon? Do you know where he had to go before he went to Newcastle? To the Second Test at Lords! He could not even drag himself to that place he loves to go, that same motel room this ordinary Prime Minister has been going to for the past 15 years at Hawks Nest. Do you know where Newcastle is, Prime Minister? It is the smokestacks a bit further south from Hawks Nest. This is where the Prime Minister was. He could not go to Newcastle, but he could go to the test at Lords. And it was a wash-out! What he is now presiding over is a wipe-out in terms of Burnie. What we have got here is another case of the Newcastle syndrome. He will not confront the workers that he has abandoned.

But he has made a call over the dispute, we understand. He has telephoned Premier Rundle with an offer of $3 million from the Natural Heritage Fund. What are we going to do: have parks and walkways created? That is cold comfort for the sacked Burnie workers. Three million dollarsâthis is the offer out of the Natural Heritage Fund. He is not even prepared to look realistically at a reconstruction package which we forced him to embrace, together with Bob Carr in New South Wales, in relation to the Newcastle closure. This is a Prime Minister who is not even consistent.

What we have got, if the Minister for Social Security is going down there and if he has rung Premier Rundle to offer him some funds from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, is an admission of defeatâan admission that he is not prepared to do anything to stop the sackings. All he can do is come in after the event shaking his head, twitching his shoulder and say, `There is nothing that could have been done.'

Do not expect an apology from this Prime Minister. Do not expect an appearance. He does not care. `Sorry' is not in his dictionary. One look at the Prime Minister's past involvement with the Burnie mill would give you no hope for believing that he was on the workers' side. After all, in the 1992 dispute, he was the one unctuously in this parliament saying that government should keep out of industrial relations but privately telling Peter Wade of North Broken Hill, who then owned the mill down there, `Go your hardest.' He even got himself thrown out of the parliament because of his passion and belief in saying that the government should be involved in sacking workers.

What about the acting minister at the table, Mr Truss, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, the minister representing the minister for industry? The threat of the mill and its closure was raised with him on 30 January this year. He was down there in Burnie and, according to a report in the Advocate at the time, he said `he did not believe the mills were near closing; if and when they were, his only commitment was that the government would look at the situation "in the light of events at that time."' Those events are now occurring, Minister. What are you doing? Amcor proposes to close this mill in October. It needs more than you looking at the situation; it requires some actionâa concrete plan.

But, instead, what did we get from you? You launched a vitriolic attack on the workers at risk of losing their jobs by blaming them. The headline that you got in the paper down there was `Minister slams doomed workers'. A shameful headline. Let us hear what you said. This is from the Hansard of yesterday. This is what the minister at the table, Mr Truss, said:

But let us look at the core of the problem. Many of the problems of that plant and indeed other manufacturing industries in Australia can fairly go back to the industrial relations practices of the Labor government . . .
Indeed some of the things that were going on in that plant made the MUA look like a work gang.

This is what you said. There were people in this chamber who saw the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) nodding and even saying, `Too right!' in response to that assertion by you. This is what you believe. You believe that the company has untrammelled rights to do what it likes, to keep the workers in the dark and not consult them, then you come along and blame the workers. You did not lift a hand. It would seem from today's answers in the parliamentâincluding those of the Prime Ministerâthat you are not prepared to lift a hand to do anything for them.

The member for Braddon must be one of the most pathetic members in this chamber in terms of representing his constituency. The Prime Minister boasted yesterday that the member had spent a large part of yesterday morning in Melbourne meeting senior Amcor executives trying to persuade them to delay the closure. He was not trying to safeguard the workers' jobs; he was merely trying to delay the closure. Again, he was simply accepting defeat. He was not fighting for their survival, not fighting for a growth strategy, but running up the white flag. The member for Braddon spoke on ABC radio this morning. This is a beautyâthis is how good he is at representing his constituents. He said:
After my meeting with the company yesterday I believe that they are going to go ahead with closing down the pulp mill section.

It must have been some fantastic set of representations. Here he is. He makes a special rush to Melbourne. He suggests to them, `Don't stop closing. Let's sit down and talk, but just delay it,' and they even knock him back on that!

What is the point of having him? Why not get someone like Sid Sidebottom down there who can actually represent these workers; someone who has got a commitment to their future and to that of the region? Sid Sidebottom, if you have not heard it before, Minister, will be the one hounding you. He will be the one reminding those workers of your callous disregard, your propensity to blame them rather than find solutions. He is the person we need in this chamber to represent the workers of Braddon. They are not getting it from the current member.
When the member for Braddon was asked what the company's response was to his request that the closure should only occur within 18 months, he said:
Well they were not impressed with that idea.

Here he is. He has run up the white flag. He put forward a suggestion for delay and he could not score on either proposition. In those circumstances, if you think you are going to be knocked back you at least go in and have a fight. You go in and represent your constituency. You do not run up the white flag, as this member has done.

Chris Miles, the member for Braddon, is not the person we want representing Burnie in this place. The local mayor does not want himâthe local mayor whom the Prime Minister wanted to quote today. He said:

Well, I think there has been a lot of concern with the member of parliament up here, Chris Miles, that Chris hasn't done very much for the area, considering his position as a parliamentary secretary to the Prime Minister.
The Mayor of Burnie wants Chris Miles out.

What we want is a government committed to securing these jobs, a government prepared to work in partnership with industry and the work forceâa work force that has demonstrated its willingness and preparedness to embrace change. But we want a strategy that gives us value adding, a strategy that gives a future for the region, a strategy that a government should be behindâbut this one will not get behind such a strategy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAt last we have the matter of public importanceâthe one that Labor care so passionately about that yesterday they forgot to put it in. They care so much about the workers of Tasmania that they forgot to get their MPI in. They forgot about it. They care so little about the situation in Burnie that, when they had an opportunity to raise it in the parliament, they simply forgot. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) did not get around to it. Today in question time we saw the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) bouncing up trying to get a question on this subject to demonstrate Labor's concern. But he was always interrupted by other peopleâhis mates in the front got in the way because they had other matters that were more important to them.

speech.para: The workers of Tasmania rated last in the Labor Party's questions today. They have no concern whatever about dealing effectively with these issues or asking questions about the facts. It took this side of the House to have the matter raised in question time today so the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) could respond in a positive and sympathetic way to the concerns of the workers in Burnie. He indicated the government's determination to address the direct and immediate issues that are associated with the lifestyle and the future of the workers at that plant and indeed the people of Burnie. But more comprehensively the government will put in place a plan for the future of northern Tasmania; a plan that we would not have had to put in place had it not been for the neglect of this industry over many years by those opposite.

I referred yesterday in the House to unsatisfactory work practices in this plant and indeed in many other workplaces around Australiaâworkplaces that were aided, abetted and supported by the member for Hotham when he was ACTU president. He agreed with and supported workers in work practices they knew were unsustainable. Only this morning one of the union representatives acknowledged that those days have to be behind us. Those days must be behind us. In fairness to the workers, the employees at that plant and the management, over the last couple of years they have worked hard to improve their productivity. They looked at the sorts of practices that were destroying the profitability of their company and therefore also their own jobs, and they were willing to work systematically towards improving the profitability of their company.

I said in my answer yesterdayâwhich I might add was acknowledged in the Davenport Advocate and many other Tasmanian papers but sadly not in the Hobart Mercuryâthat the company should acknowledge the contribution that has been made by workers and seek to find solutions to the problems which would secure their employment. The Hobart Mercury called my office today and acknowledged that that headline in the paper was a misrepresentation of the substance of my answer to the question. I find it most disappointing that a Tasmanian newspaper would seek to use the jobs of workers of Tasmania in such a political way.

If we look back at the root cause of the problems that have been confronting the workers of northern Tasmania, I think the Prime Minister summed up the problems quite admirably on a number of occasions when he referred to the disgraceful deal done by the ALP and the Greens in Tasmania to destroy the Wesley Vale pulp mill project. Had that project proceeded, the workers of Burnie today would be working in one of the most modern state-of-the-art pulp plants in the world. Their jobs would not be at risk. Their jobs would be secure. They would be providing pulp to an expanding Australian paper industry that would have the capacity to export around the world. Instead of our paper industry declining and suffering serious competition, it would have had the opportunity to deliver best practice technology and meaningful and lasting jobs for northern Tasmanian workers.

The Labor Party, when confronted with this opportunity for one of the biggest projects in Australian history, preferred to do a deal with Christine Milne and the Greens to secure preferences. The honourable member for Hotham was one of those who wanted the Green preferences because he was about to run for parliament for the first time in Melbourne. He preferred Green preferences to the jobs of the workers of northern Tasmania. In their determination to try to hang onto government, Senator Richardson and Mr Hawke, with the leadership no doubt in support of the member for Hotham and others, did a deal to wreck this project, to destroy the long-term viability of the paper industry of northern Tasmania. The member for Hotham preferred Green preferences in Melbourne to the jobs of the workers of Burnie in northern Tasmania.

The member for Hotham a decade ago was prepared to back unsatisfactory work practices which he must have known were putting at risk the jobs of the people in this plant and in other plants around Australia. He preferred to allow those sorts of rorts to continue rather than confront the productivity improvements which were always going to be essential if we were to have a modern and progressive paper industry in this country. The workers of that plant in northern Tasmania know that now. They know they have a contribution to make towards securing their jobs. They know, as do the paper workers in Maryvale, Shoalhaven and a whole stack of other places, that they must work with their management to ensure that their industry is secure, that their jobs remain viable.

Sadly, that realisation came far too late for the member for Hotham. It came far too late for the Labor Party. In 13 years they did nothing to address these critical productivity issues, and sadly the workers of that paper mill in Burnie are now paying the price for that indolence. Labor failed to do anything to secure the kind of industrial relations climate that was necessary, the kind of investment climate that would have been essential to secure the necessary investment to keep this plant operating effectively and to secure the future of the paper industry for Australia. Sadly, too much damage was done under 13 years of Labor for the workers of TasPEAC and others to correct that damage in the last couple of years.

Sadly, those sorts of things have left the paper mill and the management of Amcor with the view that this mill can no longer continue to operate profitably. I am very disappointed that they have made that decision. I believe that considerable progress was being made to improve the productivity of the plant. It is true, as the company has indicated, that the plant is now quite old. In fact, it is more than 60 years old. It was working with outdated technology. There was a plan to get rid of that outdated technology to build a new mill of world class standard at Wesley Vale. Labor destroyed that possibility. Labor did a deal with the Greens to destroy that possibility. The inevitable consequence of that was that a small, inefficient, old, outdated technology plant at Burnie was put at risk and the jobs of those workers were put at risk.

The company has been spending a considerable amount of money at Burnie and Wesley Valeâits other plantâto try to update the technology to make that plant competitive. But, ultimately, I am sure all will acknowledge that the company can only continue to make investments if they believe those investments are likely to be profitable. They also need to protect their investments in other parts of Australia. The big new plant at Maryvale will obviously substantially increase their production capability. They also have a plant at Shoalhaven that produces speciality papers which have a particular place in the market.

The key thing is that the company, in making this announcement, has reaffirmed its commitments to producing base paper at Burnie and in other places around Australia. Its coated and film coated offset production at Wesley Vale will continue, and it is investing $49 million to increase the company's 20 per cent share of the coated paper market. So there is still a commitment to paper making in Australia. I think we have that commitment only because of the policies of this government. If Labor's antiquated anti-dumping mechanisms were still in place, if the old measures introduced by the previous government which failed dismally to provide the sort of protection that the Australian paper industry needed from unfair and subsidised products were still in place, if there was not in sight a likelihood that reforming legislation would soon go through the parliament to give us the fastest and fairest anti-dumping mechanisms in the world, if the government had not made that commitment, I doubt whether we would see this long-term involvement by Amcor in the paper making industry in Australia.

They sought this protection from me and from the government, and we are providing it. The old measuresâthe slow cumbersome measures, the anti-dumping measures that Labor left in place, that Labor introduced in the first place but failed to do anything about, that the member for Hotham occasionally goes to Tasmania to criticise but never acknowledges he was a party to putting them in place in the first place and did nothing about correcting in his term in governmentâleft us with the residue of his failed anti-dumping protection measures.

We have acted spontaneously and quickly to bring those measures into place. We have responded to the needs of that industry and our action has been warmly appreciated not just by Amcor, the paper investors and the manufacturing industry but also by the workers of northern Tasmania. If you would like me to, I would be happy to produce letters from the unions and the workers of northern Tasmania congratulating me and the government on our actions in introducing these measures.

But it is not just that alone. If you look at the kind of economic climate that Labor had left the major investors in which to make decisions about whether they should expand their operations in Australia, you will see where Labor really failed Australian industry for 13 years. Under Labor, business investment declined to its lowest level on record, and that was a clear demonstration of the failure of their policies. Under Labor, Australian productivity improvement was just 0.9 per cent per yearâhalf the world average for this century. Under Labor, business expenditure on R&D as a share of GDP was 25 per cent lower than the OECD average. Under Labor, the manufacturing trade deficit blew out from $7.7 billion in 1982 to $27.5 billion in 1995. Under Labor, the manufacturing sector shed some 200,000 jobs.

Contrast that to what has happened under this government: there has been jobs growthâeven in northern Tasmania, which we acknowledge has gone through some difficult times. The Prime Minister mentioned in question time today that nearly 3,000 new jobs were created in the Mersey-Lyell region. That is indeed a record of achievementâthe unemployment rate substantially lower than when Labor left office. This government has indeed been working hard, in cooperation with the paper manufacturing industry and indeed industry throughout Australia, to try to create the kind of environment which encourages investment and which rewards those who in this country have the imagination to ensure that our industry is able to grow and expand, to provide jobs for Australians, to boost our exports and to replace some of the products that have been coming into this country.

Only under a coalition government would this sort of economic turnaround be possible. Only under a coalition government can you achieve the industrial relations reform, the economic reform. Only under a coalition government can you achieve the sort of measures that are necessary to protect Australian industry from unfair dumping or unfair subsidisation. Only under this government can you have the kind of turnaround that establishes the sort of environment that encourages investment in the paper industry.

We will not rush off and do secret deals with the Greens to knock off projects just to gain a few preferences. The Greens, I gather, are at it again. There are a number of major new projects being proposed for northern Tasmania and the Greens are once again threatening to block them. Will Labor once again do a secret deal with the Greens, as they regularly do in Queensland prior to the state electionsâsecret deals that we learn about months laterâto try to extract Green preferences?

The Labor Party were prepared to trade the jobs of northern Tasmanians for a few Green preferences. They are now prepared to trade the economic welfare of the people of Burnie in Tasmania for a few cheap political points. The member for Hotham will rush down and criticise and give plenty of advice from the side, but the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has been in there fighting for his industry, effectively representing it and ensuring that this government will respond positively and effectively to the problems confronting Tasmanian workers to ensure that that industry prospers in the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is very interesting that the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss), who has just spoken, did not give us one point on what this government is going to do for Burnieânot one point on how we can achieve anything to assist Burnie. After being advised that Australian Paper have decided to close the pulp mill, which is a part of the Burnie operation in north-west Tasmania, they have also advised that the two paper machines at Burnie will stay and the Wesley Vale mill will continue its operation.

speech.para: This closure is another terrible blow for Tasmania. Once these jobs go from the pulp works at Amcor, it will take Burnie's unemployment rate from 10.6 per cent to well over 13 per cent. This has been one of the highest in the country and will be extremely difficult for the Burnie people. Burnie already has great difficulty in finding employment for much of its population, since many other businesses in this region have closed since this government has been in power.

Not only have 180 jobs been lost here at the mill but there will also be support employees lost, maintenance employees lost and job losses for those who supply the wood to the mill and those in the community whose jobs are tied up with the production of pulp. This is an enormous impact in this very close-knit communityâone that has over 35 per cent youth unemployment.

talk.start.para: âHow much?

âThere is over 35 per cent youth unemployment throughout the Burnie municipality. Some of the blame has to lie at the feet of the federal minister for customs, Warren Truss, for taking such an inordinately long time to deal with the anti-dumping legislation. The federal member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has done very little to make sure that the work has been done to cope with the ability of the businesses there to compete. These ministers have the hide to blame the workers for the closuresâand that really angers me. They have attacked the workers there for the last 20 years, saying, `It's your fault. If you are unemployed now, it's your fault.' Blame the victim; it is a typical tactic started by Malcolm Fraser back in the 1970s.

speech.para: It is this government's incompetence that has caused the company to close its doors, and it hangs around this government's neck. The federal government has failed Tasmania. It fails to provide a safety net when these disasters happen and it failed to assist Tasmania in its last budget. The state is suffering enormous difficulties and the federal government has written us off, as it did in its last budget.

There are times when decisions need to be made swiftly and this is one of them. The simple fact that Burnie has been under threat for some time from the expense of making paper in an ageing mill versus the new up-to-date technology at Maryvale has been too difficult for the company to overcome. Some assistance should have been forthcoming from the government. The loss of research and development funds has made companies look at ways of reducing costs by closing plants rather than ways in which plants could be used in further downstream processing or upgrading of processing. That is a product of this government.The Maryvale mill could have been at Burnie if there had been incentives when the company was making those sorts of decisions. If the member for Braddon had got stuck in there, he might have achieved that.

We have had long delays in getting the regional forest agreements signed. The Labor Party had it almost finished in 1995, yet it was only signed off by the federal government late last year. There still has not been the necessary legislationâpointing to the governmentâto underpin the RFA process. The RFA process allowed us to build an industry plan to utilise forestry in developing value added products, creating more jobs and export from our forest industries. But this government has not sought to develop an industry plan or long-term strategy to ensure that this industry can be one of the leaders in the world. They are more interested in getting the raw product out of the state either as chips or as whole logs and as soon as possible. No value adding has been doneâunless you consider chipping to be value adding.

The last Labor government had an industry planâthe wood and paper industry strategy. They had an overall philosophy to support the development of a forest industry as a major sunrise industry for Tasmania, to compete on world terms with forest practices and timber development. This has all gone out the window since this government has been in power. The government has failed to drive this agenda. It has said that it would have legislation in parliament by 30 June this year to underpin the RFA. We have not seen any detail of this and 30 June is fast approaching. Will it be like the signing off of the RFA, with a two-year wait and dozens of local people still waiting to receive some sort of assistance because of the terms of the RFA? Legislation is needed to drive the industry development in Australia. We cannot afford this `quarry and export at all costs' mentality that afflicts this government. We need jobs, we need research and we need a strategy plan to follow in order to build and encourage other industries to develop.

Amcor is very conscious of the difficulties this decision will cause Burnie. They have told me that they are accelerating the launch of their new film-coated offset grades to be produced in Tasmania and they are proceeding with the commissioning of the paper coated upgrade at Wesley Vale, supported by the supply of base sheet from Burnie. So there is a need to put in place incentives to make them remain in Tasmania and also to assist in the continuation of the Wesley Vale mill. The further development of the RFA is one way of dealing with this.

I call upon this government to take some specific action, not just mouth the words we heard from the minister. I call upon this government to compensate the people of Burnie by supporting in kind the magnesium site mine being proposed by Crest Resources Australia so that they are assisted to put this processing plant in Burnie rather than on the mainland. The federal government will need to help the state to ensure it can carry out the necessary approvals and environmental studies in the shortest time possible. I call upon them to immediately start negotiations and clear the way for the company to invest in Burnie.

I also ask the federal government to keep discussions going with Amcor to ensure that they do not pull out of Burnie. These jobs are vital for the north west and the government's actions should not be put in the way to jeopardise these industries. By this I mean the anti-dumping legislation must be quickly finalised and incentives developed through a long-term strategy for the forestry industry in Tasmania.

We also need to know whether there is anything that can be done to utilise the plant which would otherwise remain idle. Can it be used for something else besides pulp? What are the options for manufacturing pulp besides going into fine paper? What work has been done on this? The federal government ought to be asking those sorts of questions and seeking to look for other avenues. This is what the member for Braddon should have done ages ago and that is what he should do now. It is time to act. Something has to be done.

The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Mr Truss, today slammed the workers of the past 20 or 30 years at this mill, the people who are now retired and live in Burnie and surrounding districts. They should all feel pretty well kicked by this minister who said it was their fault that the mill has closed. He ought to apologise to them. He did not mention that the industrial relations environment before 1993 had a little bit to do with management and that that is why there was some disruption taking placeâwe remember that dispute. He did not bother saying that at the other end of my electorate down on the Derwent River, ANM's management went down a totally different path, had a totally different restructuring process and achieved major results.

The workers in this mill have set up a consultative process. They have a health and safety program which has reduced accidents. Since 1993, 600 jobs have gone, the maintenance contract has been settled and signed, productivity has increased and workers have worked together on the anti-dumping situation. There has been a lot of work done since 1993, but a part of this mill is still going to go. A lot more work could have been done and the member for Braddon stands condemned for not defending the mill workers over the last 20 or 30 years who now live in his electorate. They have been attacked by Warren Truss in a very unfair and unjust way. He should have put a statement out defending those workers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday is a day of shame for the Labor Party. They stand absolutely naked on this issue, and I can tell you they are totally exposed on this issue. Political nudity by the Labor Party in this case cuts a very tragic figure in Burnie. Let us go back to the genesis of what is happening in Burnie today. I put this on a very square footing in regard to the situation that occurred in 1989. We have all accepted that the Wesley Vale mill went down the tubeâ
âWe are in 1998 today, Sunshine.

âYes, I will come to that. I suggest you stay and listen. You live in Canberra and you would not understand a worker if you came across him. You would not know what it is to get dirt under your fingernails and you would not know what it is to get grease in your hair. But I understand the Burnie mill workers and I know exactly what it takes to do hard work.

speech.para: Let us go back to the details of this issue. It was the Labor Party which prevented new technology coming into this industry in Tasmania. They prevented it. This is what Graham Richardson said about the mill going down on 8 September 1989 in a letter to me:

There is absolutely no reason for me to apologise to anyone over the Government's handling of the Wesley Vale proposal. Rather, I am proud to be part of a Government which is prepared to take . . . decisions when proposed developments clearly threaten the environment.

Let us have a look at the record. I quote what the CSIR0 scientists said on 1 August 1990. The pre-eminent scientists in Australia said that it was not about the environment; there was not a factor in regard to the environment. I will quote both of them. Chris Fandry said:
What the CSIR0 report in relation to the Wesley Vale project says is that there is no known scientific evidenceâ
none at allâ
. . . that there will be any long term detrimental effect of pulp mills.
What did Bob Johannes, a senior CSIR0 scientist, say on the same day? He said:
. . . I reiterate, we have no scientific evidence to suggest that there will be any known environmental impact or effect on fish.

Who did we have in here today saying it was going to affect the fish? The former President of the Australian Labor Partyâtrying to keep that line going. Here we have the top scientists in Australia totally rejecting that there was any scientific evidence to do away with new technology in the pulp mills in Tasmania. Yet Graham Richardson and the Labor Party were proud to do a deal with the Greens to scuttle new technology in Wesley Vale. Therefore, today we have this announcement by Amcor of the loss of 150 jobs, but it will not be that: it will be about 280 and will flow on to about 500. This is in industry that has a history of 60 years. Preparation should have been made for investment by companies to make sure there was money there for a new mill.

Quite contrary to what the Labor Party is saying here today, I have been in the forefront of people wanting a new technology mill in northern Tasmania. I put it to Amcor even early on Tuesday morning of this week that they should consider building a new quality mill in that area. Again they rejected it. Of course, the unions now are getting on the coat-tails of that comment to say that they are out there fighting for a new industry in this area. Yesâcoming after my representation to the mill. There is nobody in this parliament who has fought more for the forest industries through thick and thin so that the workers in Burnie and north-west Tasmania would have jobs. For the Labor Party to come in here and talk about being supportive of the mill workers in Burnie is absolute codswallop. There is no substance to their arguments at all.

We have seen the record of their dealing with the Greens to skittle new technology. They did not want new technology. No, they just wanted a few votes in Sydney and Melbourne. That is what they were about. In Tasmania under their administration during their 13 years there were 17 inquiries into Tasmaniaâand no outcomes at all. There were the Helsham inquiry, the Lemonthyme national estate and the 1986 memorandum of understanding with the state government. What did they do with that? They walked away from that to buy votes from the Greens. What did they do in 1989? We know about the Wesley Vale mill debacle. Labor sent that down the tube. Then in 1992 they decided they would actually do something with the regional forestry agreement. By 1996 there was not even one agreement signedânot even one, four years on.

talk.start.para: âThey were going to do it.

âYes, in the 14th or 15th year. There were 13 years of Labor and nothing was done with the regional forestry agreement. It got into a debate there with Minister Beddall. Keating, of course, opposed what he was doing. Then they said, `We are going to take certain coupes out of Tasmania.' When I went to the grid and had look at what they were talking about, do you know where those forest coupes were? They were out in Bass Strait. That is how much interest they had in Tasmania and the mill workers.

speech.para: What have we done? This is the record in two years. The degraded-forest licences were put into place. The amount of woodchips now being produced in the region behind Burnie has gone from 450,000 to 700,000 tonnes. That created 30 jobs and saved 110 jobs in the Burnie region. When it comes to the regional forestry agreement, this is going to create 1,000 new jobs. Under Labor we were shedding jobs in the forest industries. Under Labor in 1992 even the Burnie mill shed jobs, going from 1,324 down to less than 500. Seven hundred in one year went under Labor out of the Burnie mill. What have they got to say about that? Not one word, of course.

They come in here today in such an unctuous mood and do not actually suggest one dollar of support to Burnieânot one dollar, not one proposal. Their idea is to throw money at these projects and that will sort it out. That is what the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) would do, and we would have another DuPont, I suppose. They threw $60 million into Victoria and that project got closed down. They wasted $60 million. Throw money at it and get the political monkey off our back but don't care about the workersâthat is Labor's approach. Of course, the DuPont project went down the tube.

I am saying to the company in Burnie that they ought to be giving a lot more time for the closure of this mill, and it is outrageous that they are closing it three months before Christmas. How outrageous! They should be making sure that these people have jobs past Christmas.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party have done nothing. There is no record whatsoever in regard to the Labor Party on this particular issue. There should be retraining programs for these people, and I am delighted that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has taken up my suggestion about having ministers go down to the electorate. We will listen to the mill workers down there. Remember, the Labor Party did not suggest one dollar of help to the Burnie people todayânot one dollarâjust unctuous words and yapping about the issue and not really addressing the needs of the Burnie pulp mill. If Labor had been in government, there is no way that they would have been able to do anything. They had a $10 billion deficit and it would have prevented them from doing anything. But our government has got rid of that deficit and we are in a position to do things which will benefit Australia.
âDo it then.
âWe will do it in our time, not in the Labor Party's time. Labor's approach is deficit, debt and high interest rates.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYes, we will go down there and talk with the families of that community and listen to their needs andâ
âSympathy cards.
âNo, there will be a package for Braddon; I can assure you of that. We will listen very intently on Friday morning. (Time expired)

âOnce again we see political grandstanding in this House with neither party having anything to congratulate itself on. I am interested in this debate because I live in the midst of the biggest dry sclerophyll forest in the world, from which we hope we can develop exports to the value of $300 million. I hope that can proceed very shortly, with high value added products.

speech.para: To go back to Wesley Vale, there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that the Labor Party pandered to the Greens. There was concern about the fisheries but, without the advent of the atomic spectrum analysis machine, it would have been impossible to pick up any of the elements they said were going to be detrimental, because they are in such minute quantities. It simply was a bogus argument from the start, and it is quite clear that the Labor Party was pandering to Richardson, who was in turn pandering to the Greens. It is my view that Richardson is second only to Keating in the damage he has done to the Labor Party.

This is an industry of enormous value to Australia. It is an industry that should be exporting $4 billion worth of paper product and not importing. When Labor closed down the industry in this country they drove it off to South-East Asia, where it has been burning ever since. They drove it off to countries where there is no control whatsoeverâno semblance of management. The truth is that not one square inch of forest has been lost to forestry in this country. It has overwhelmingly been lost to farming and to rural sprawl. That is where the forests went, and that has to be considered.

talk.start.para: âThere have been no species lost.

âIn terms of species lost, that certainly has not occurred in forestry. In fact, in Western Australia they are planting 25,000 hectares a year. Whereas it took 50 years to plant the first 100,000 hectares, it will now be done in four years, and it is going to be very successful. The truth is that the forest agreements between the states and the Commonwealth are a nonsense. This is an area where the Commonwealth should get right out because it has no expertise. It is being driven by zealots with other agendas. The expertise in forests resides with the states, and Tasmania had a very good record in forest management.

speech.para: When the Labor Party was busy pandering to the Greens and closing down those forests in Tasmania, we were assured that workers need not worry because there would be jobs for them in tourism. You simply cannot transfer blue-collar workers to the tourist industry. But, in any case, once they had got rid of that industry, the Greens turned on the tourist industry. Their agenda was simply to stop anything happening in Tasmania and in forests in Australia generally.

There was talk of anti-dumping, and it makes me sick. The anti-dumping position of this government is no better than that of the previous government and it is no good at all. We need a much quicker response and we need governments that look after the interests of our people, not after the interests of multinationals. I know this is a digression but it happens everywhere. It happens in the forest industry.

In terms of pig imports into Australia, the pig is not coming from Canada; it is coming from ConAgra in the United States. It goes to ConAgra plants in Canada and comes to ConAgra agents in Australia. The government is backing multinationals against the interests of Australians. It is happening in the timber industry too, and for the government to look after the interests of people in Australia is long overdue.

But what is to be done? We cannot go on blaming each other. Something has to be done for Tasmania. I think Tasmania has been neglected. The truth is that without a return to a manufacturing industry there is no future for Tasmania, nor is there any future for Melbourneâfor a casino-led recovery will not last foreverâand there is no future for South Australia.

We get a lot of people from Tasmania, particularly from the Burnie area, coming to the electorate of Kalgoorlie seeking work. They are very welcome. If we could somehow reduce the flow of New Zealanders, we could take more Tasmanians. Let us just consider this: if Tasmania were to be given subsidies equal to those provided to the Northern Territory, you could pay for a new mill. There would certainly be more than enough money there to pay off a mill. It is quite clear that in the future we are going to be a big player in the paper industry. It would not be a waste of money if the government were to get involved in this. It is long overdue that Tasmania got some of the consideration that is heaped onto and poured into the Northern Territory.

The situation will not be helped by what has been said by either party. I think the company has been very neglectful. It clearly has not put much store by the chaos that is going to occur. This problem has not just arisen for the company; it must have seen it coming, and I think it should have made provisions beforehand. But governments have to pick up very often where the private sector fails. I think the government should give real consideration to doing something constructive for Tasmania.

We have had the minister who was previously at the tableâthe Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles)âbabbling about industrial relations and other factors. The truth is they are largely irrelevant. We need a regime where Australian industry can thrive. It will not thrive under a policy of economic rationalism. It simply cannot, because economic rationalism is not an economic policy; it is a political ideology. It is the ideology of big business, mainly American big businesses that control world trade. While the Labor Party and the government are hooked on this myth there can be no real hope.

We, as Australians, cannot abide a situation where Tasmania, one of our earliest areas of colonisation, is allowed to wither on the vine. For those of us who have been to Tasmania, it is very sad to see the depressed areas of the state. I think governments have an absolute responsibility to take Tasmania with us, not to abandon it. I believe that every effort should be made by whatever means necessary to get industries into Tasmania.

I suspect there is a lot of money to be made by value-adding timber in Tasmania just as there is in the Goldfields. We are looking now at markets in Europe for speciality timbers. There is a big market there for parquetry. I suspect that eucalyptus globulus would fetch far more money as a hardwood flooring in Europe and North America than it does as pulp. We now have the techniques for drying it satisfactorily. Indeed, we import it into Australia as Chilean oak. If we were to spend money on marketing this, I am sure we could find markets for it in Europe, where there is a preference for light-coloured timber.

Many of the other Tasmanian timbers would find ready markets in Europe. Just the hobby market aloneâthe woodturning marketâis a vast market. In my looks at the forests in Tasmania I saw many timbers which should be exploited to those ends. Those are the things that we should do. We should be assisting people by very generous help, by whatever means is necessary, to make sure that we can get some value-adding into the timber in Tasmania. In conclusion, it gives me no pleasure to continue to rise in this House to point out that the policies of both sides have the same end consequences for the people.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The discussion is concluded.

debate.para: That the following bills be referred to the Main Committee for further consideration:
Taxation Laws Amendment (Farm Management Deposits) Bill 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âAs I was saying some three hours ago in respect of the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 , the opposition will not be opposing the legislation but we do have some concerns about the way in which the government has broken yet another promise in respect of taxation.

speech.para: I just remind the House once again that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when Leader of the Opposition, said that `there will be no increases in existing taxes' nor would there be an introduction of any new taxes under his government. Clearly this is a broken promise because the departure tax is being increased. It is being increased by $3 from $27 to $30. The justification which the government is using suggests that it is to meet additional costs associated with the transit of people and equipment for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The measure, accordingly, is going to take effect from 1 July 1999.

This is one of two sneaky issues which were introduced in the course of the budget of a couple of weeks ago. Both go hand in glove. The second was, of course, the introduction of a new visitor visa charge. That is breaking the promise again because a new tax has been introduced to complement this increase in the departure tax. We will be saying more about that particular element when we examine whether a disallowance motion will be introduced into this House in respect of that new visitor visa charge. I foreshadow that the opposition is giving serious consideration to that element now, but as we are concerned about the departure tax I will confine my comments specifically to that.

In the budget of two weeks ago we saw the government stand in this place and triumphantly say that we have given $50 million extra to the Australian Tourism Commission to promote Australia overseasâspecifically, $41 million to ATC to promote Australia in new and also tried and true markets for foreign tourists and $9 million to continue promotion for the 2000 Olympics. They stood in this place and said, and the Minister for Sport and Tourism (Mr Andrew Thomson) has been out and about saying, `We actually listened to what people in the tourist industry were saying and we finally came to this conclusion'âa conclusion which the opposition had been putting forward for a number months, as had been the tourism task force and the Tourism Council of Australia, both peak organisations representing tourism interests in this country. The government have said that finally they listened.

Late last year when the Asian economic crisis was first gathering momentum, it was suggested by those organisations to which I have referred that the first signs of trouble in Australia were being experienced in the tourist industry. As Christmas rolled around and we saw airlines such as Qantas and Ansett decide to no longer fly into Korea because there had been a 77 per cent drop in Korean tourists coming into this country and Asiana Airlines and Malaysian Airlines decide to no longer fly into Cairns, you would have thought that the penny would have dropped with this minister for tourism and with the Prime Minister and they would have found some money to put into the Australian tourism industry to enable it to promote Australia as a destination in new and emerging markets and to try to reinforce it in some of our old tried and true markets.

The numbers coming from Asia dropped off. As I have said, in the case of Korea they simply collapsed. In the case of Japan, one of our best tourism markets, the last figures I have seen show something like a 17 per cent drop in the number of tourists coming here. As those markets dropped, the Prime Minister's response was, `We are not going to have any knee-jerk reaction in the way in which we'll respond to this crisis. And in the case of tourism they can simply switch markets. They can simply get out of Japan or Korea or South-East Asia. We will take the tourism dollars and switch markets and advertise in the UK, Europe or the United States.'

Anybody who knows anything about marketing arrangements or the way in which budgets for organisations like the Australian Tourism Commission are set could not help but see the ridiculousness of those sorts of comments. You simply cannot switch the markets just like that. You simply cannot go in and say, `We'll take our dollars and we'll look at advertising to promote more into Europe and the United States than into our tried and true markets of Asia.' It was an issue that the tourism industry came and saw the minister about and knocked on the Prime Minister's door about, but continued to be rebuffed.

If it had not been for pressure from those organisations and, dare I say, modestly, from the opposition, we may not have seen extra funds injected in this last budget to try to overcome those difficulties, because there is, regrettably, a belief in the Australian communityâand it is certainly mirrored in the minds of the present minister for tourism and of the Prime Ministerâthat tourism does not create real jobs in this country. It is an abso lute disgrace that that view is around and that the people who purport to lead this nation do not accept that one in nine jobs in Australia now is in the tourism and hospitality area. It is a disgrace that people do not recognise that $16 billion annually is raised through export earnings due directly to tourists coming into this country and that $65 billion is contributed to the gross domestic product of Australia through the tourism and hospitality industry.

There is unfortunately a view around that unless somebody is dressed in a blue singlet, safety boots and shorts they are not really a worker and they are not really in an industry that means something. This completely puts to one side the view that small business is dependent on tourism and that many of the organisations and businesses that are in tourism are small businesses. It completely puts to one side our friends in the Australian Customs Service, who play an integral role in the promotion of tourism into this country. It puts to one side all those airline employees, people who do the maintenance, bus drivers, chefs, front office receptionists, cleaners in hotels and people who run bungie jumping operations, yachts up on the Whitsunday Islands, cruises out to the Great Barrier Reef and operations at Uluru National Park. All of those people are contributing to the tourism infrastructure and employment of this nation. Therefore, it smacks somewhat strange to some of us that the government that would purport to say that it finally recognised that tourism is in a little bit of trouble is going to put $50 millionâor more properly $41 millionâinto extra funding for the ATC.

Members with a little bit of a memory can go back to the budget of two years ago, the first budget brought down by Peter Costello. He cut $18 million out of the budget for the Australian Tourism Commission. This is an industry which, as I have said, plays a significant role as an employer in this nation. Yet, $18 million was offered up as savings to the bottom line in the budget of two years ago. And belatedly we have seen $41 million being put back. As I have said, the Labor opposition and me specifically, as our spokesperson on tourism, absolutely welcome the fact that money is being put back. But there are, as ever, a couple of hooks in this.

When you go to the budget papersâand I was making some mention of this a little earlierâand specifically Budget Paper No. 2, the 1998-99 budget measures, and look over the four years commencing with this financial year and going forward, you see that in 1998-99 it is expected that there will be a $10 million increase in the passenger movement charge, and for that read `departure tax', generated for the government. In 1999-2000, a $21 million increase in the departure tax will be generated and in the year 2000-01 a $23 million increase, climbing in the year 2001-02 to $24 million. This makes a grand total of $78 million extra that will be generated by this $3 increase in the departure tax.

You reconcile these figures and you see that the government is saying: `We are going to put $41 million extra into promoting over those four years Australia as a tourist destination in new and emerging markets and to reinforce that view in other markets,' but the government is making $78 million over that same time. So clearly an additional contribution is being made by this increase in the departure tax. That increase is being offered up to the coffers of the government.

And it gets worse. As I said a little earlier, the other side of this insidious approach to the Australian tourism industry is that the imposition of a new visitor visa charge of $50 per head in those countries where there is no electronic travel authority processing system is going to impact on our new and emerging markets. We had the Minister for Tourism, after he had been to Nagano, head into China, then on to India and then come home. When he came back, having met with tourism officials in those countries, he proudly announced to the Australian community, and particularly those in tourism, some very welcome news. He announced that China had granted Australia preferred destination status in terms of tourists.

In a still fairly heavily planned economy, nations seek out that status, particularly from a tourism perspective. We went in and were actively lobbying to get that status so that we could take advantage of that new market, with the increasing affluence of China, particularly southern China, where the economy is booming. As China was prepared to let Chinese tourists come into overseas destinations we were actively out there seeking that status as a nation. And we got it. So what did we do to say thanks to the Chinese for that? We said: `When you come you are going to have to pay $50 now for a visa charge which was not there previously.' Then we said to them: `Oh, and by the way, when you go it is now going to cost you $30 instead of $27.'

Some thanks to the Chinese government for giving us the status that we had been actively lobbying for. Some thanks it was to say to them: `Thanks very much, but by the way it is going to cost all of those people coming here.' If there is one thing this country does not need in times of economic crisis it is more disincentives in the tourism industry. It is bad enough that this government has imposed a 400 per cent increase in the reef tax in tropical Far North Queensland. It is bad enough that now we are going to see a $3 increase in the departure tax. But to also slug tourists coming into the place out of the new and emerging markets that we are trying to cultivate, like China and India, $50 a time for a visa fee which had never been there in the past is absolute nonsense.

Is it any wonder that people like Bruce Baird, the Managing Director of the Tourism Council of Australia, is jumping up and down on behalf of his organisation about this, and has made representations to the minister? Is it any wonder that Mr Baird rightly is a touch put out because his mate in government, the Minister for Tourism, forgot to tell him about it? The Minister for Immigration (Mr Ruddock) forgot to tell him about it. They have dressed it up as a way they are supposedly keeping illegals out of Australia.

To be fair, has anyone ever heard of anything more ridiculous than saying that putting a $50 visa charge on somebody who has the intention of coming here and then staying illegally is going to keep them away? How nonsensical is that! It is a straight out revenue raising measure. Whilst I said that the measure we are debating today to increase the departure tax will raise an additional $78 million over four years, the proposal to increase by $50 per head the visa charges will raise $167 million extra. That brings it to a grand total of $245 million that will be raised by this government over the next four years by charging $50 for visas and by increasing the departure taxâbreaking two promises of John Howard's. The sum of $245 million and what are they going to spend?â$41 million.

Even the economic geniuses on the other side would have to recognise that this means they will have a little bit left over. And wouldn't we all like to think that the money is going to be spent on some of the projects that are necessary, such as boosting the Australian Customs Service, providing it with a few more sniffer dogs and other equipment to detect some of the less important items people try to bring into this country, drugs or anything else. But it is not. It is just going to come straight off the bottom line of this government. That is where the money is going to go. So that Peter Costello can stand up in here and say: `Isn't it wonderful that we have delivered some sort of a surplus?' Yet it is being delivered off the back of the very industry that we are trying to encourage.

It was also interesting, when looking at this issue, that on 1 August 1996 the Australian National Audit Office provided some information and also tabled an audit report on the passenger movement charge and the way in which the departure tax was administered, because two things emerged from that. Firstly, legal advice which was provided to Customs and to the Australian National Audit Office indicated that, in legal terms, that passenger movement charge was a tax. We all knew it was, but there were a few smartypants around trying to say, `No, it is a passenger movement charge. That is code for "tax" but we are not allowed to say "tax".' Secondly, as I have repeated in here on a number of occasions this afternoon, the Prime Minister was very positive and very `core' in his promise that there would be no increases in existing taxes and no introduction of new taxes. Both of those are out the window when we are talking about these two measures here. So it was established that it was a tax.

Based on estimates that were provided by agencies, the National Audit Office assessed that departure tax collections in 1995-96 exceeded by approximately $19.1 million customs, immigration and quarantine processing costs and short-term visa issuing costs. What does that mean? It means that the National Audit Office did a check and found out that there was overcharging, if you like, or certainly that what it was costing these organisations to carry out these processes was giving a net benefit in revenue terms to the government even then. This overrecovery arose for two reasons. One was that the customs, immigration and quarantine costs and the passenger processing cost of issuing short-term visas actually were lower than the $27 per departure originally estimated, and that was back in 1996. It is not me saying this, it is the audit office, which carried out this particular inquiry. The second reason was that the rate of growth and the number of departures had been higher than expected, adding more to the departure tax collections than to the passenger processing costs. If anyone doubts that, go and have a look at the audit office report entitled Passenger movement charge: Australian Customs Service published on 1 August 1996 and, for references, have a look at pages 8 and xiv. That will give you the references to those.

Here we have, even in 1996, the audit office saying that what it costs to process the departure tax in Australia was giving the government a net revenue boost. What we are seeing now is that that departure tax has been increased by $3 a head for the reason that the government wants to pick up all of those additional people coming in for the year 2000 games and beyond. So they are going to get even more money. As we have established already, just on Treasurer Costello's own budget figures, the departure tax alone will give this government an extra $78 million. I think that is underestimating it, quite frankly.

I know that the member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who has a continuing and substantial interest and knowledge in the tourism industry, will substantiate those viewsâthat there are likely to be increased numbers of people coming, certainly in the lead-up to 2000 and, we would all hope, beyond. We would all hope that the year 2000 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games will showcase this nation like never before and that we will see an enormous increase in visitors coming to this country in subsequent years. Whilst that will be great for employment opportunities in this country, it is also going to be great for the government because, on their own estimates, not only will they make that $245 million but I suspect they will be making a lot more.

Whilst we find it a little sneaky to have done this and whilst it is disturbing that the government has gone about reaping more money from Australia's important industry of tourism, what we find even more staggering is the fact that they have hamstrung the Australian Tourist Commission. Why do I say this? It is interesting. In the Senate estimates committee hearing yesterday, the Australian Tourist Commission were there giving evidence. I had asked Senator Cook to ask a few questions of the ATC as to how this increased funding that they had been given and that the government had made so much of a fuss about was going to be spent.

As I said to you, they are getting an extra $41 million over four years and in next year's terms I think the appropriation was to be $14.1 million. When questioned as to how that might be spent, in what markets and what value would there be for spending that money, it came to pass that the Australian Tourist Commission measured and estimated that the number of bangs they were going to get for their bucks in the United States was on the basis that the Australian dollar was worth 68 cents to the United States dollar. I do not know about you but I cannot remember the last time the Australian dollar was actually at 68 cents. I think at the minute it is something like 61 cents. Some of the estimates I have seen from economists in the papers today suggest it might go to 55 cents.

If the Australian Tourist Commission in the United States is given, in Australian dollar terms, $14 million to spend and they are basing their advertising campaigns on a value of 68 cents in the dollar, they are going to be mightily short-changed. If they are talking about advertising in Europe or, specifically, in the United Kingdom, I think the UK currency is down to about 38 or 39 pence at the minute to the Australian dollar. So that is not going to buy you too much in terms of advertising either.

I had the opportunity a few weeks ago to meet with the Australian Tourist Commission's managing director for Europe and the United Kingdom. We talked about this very problem and he said to me, `We keep on getting the funds that the ATC makes available to us for advertising in Australian dollars and when you convert it down you simply lose that advertising ability.' I think this is an issue the government needs to consider. Unlike our people who work in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, for example, or in Immigration, who are in outposts overseas and get compensation for the cost of living in those particular locations, they are paid their salary in Australian dollars. When they convert it to the currency of the country in which they are living they simply do not get an equivalent amount of money which enables them to live appropriately.
