Maybe the same sort of factor for correction needs to be put in here because, sadly, as was pointed out yesterday in the Senate estimates committee hearing that was looking at the Australian Tourist Commission, what it means is that that $14.1 million, based on the value of the dollar at the minute, is probably going to buy about $10 million or maybe even less than $10 million worth of advertising. I think that is sad. Simply because of currency fluctuations, the opportunity for us to advertise overseas is going to be lost. I hope the member for Fadden will have a few comments to make about that as well because he does have a great knowledge of the Australian tourist industry and would have made a great minister for tourism. It is unfortunate that he never got that opportunity.

I think it is rather sad that when we come into this place to debate a broken promise by the governmentâan increase in the departure taxâwe find that they have not been entirely honest with the Australian people and the Australian tourist industry when they did not tell them that even at the present rates, according to the Australian National Audit Office, they are actually covering their costs and having some left over already. Why couldn't that be put towards improving the advertising of the Australian tourist industry in other destinations? I think it is rather sad as well that, by increasing this, they are making a large slab of money which will not be directed at tourism but will simply come off the bottom line of Peter Costello's budget.
I again put on the record, to quote directly from Labor's platform, that:

Labor acknowledges that tourism is the fastest growing employment sector in Australia, particularly for young people. It is Australia's second highest export income earner and generates immense goodwill for Australia with overseas visitors. The advent of the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000 will add further emphasis to the important role tourism will play in promoting Australia internationally.

What the Australian tourism industry need is continuing assistance through these difficult times. They are not asking for handouts; they are just asking for a fair go. Unfortunately, the money that has been injected, whilst welcome, will not meet that objective, and the way in which it is to be collectedâby the broken promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made with respect to increasing taxesâwill not be welcomed by those people in the tourism industry. Nevertheless, it is a budget measure. For that reasonâand for that sole reasonâthe opposition will not delay passage of this legislation.

talk.start.para: âI am not quite sure on how many occasions during my time in this place I have spoken about passenger movement charge amendment bills or departure tax amendment bills. I always feel somewhat guilty because the introduction of the departure tax came as a result of one of the first recommendations of the House of Representatives select committee in 1978, which I chaired. That first recommendation was that we introduce a departure tax and the money raised be used in the promotion of tourism. The then government were very enthusiastic about that recommendation, and it was the very first one they instituted.

speech.para: Going back over the years, we have quite an interesting history on this particular charge. There was great trauma and drama within the industry in the early 1980s when the depar ture tax, which was then $10, went to $20. A few years later, it was dropped back to $10. The amount has varied since that time. At $30, which the passenger movement charge will be after the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 comes into force, it is in about the middle range of passenger movement charges around the world.

In that respect, I would remind the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) that, when you look at the on-charges for the tourists coming to Australia and leaving Australia, it is far more expensive for a Japanese tourist to go to the United Kingdom where the passenger handling charge at Heathrow airport is, I understand, Â£45. If you go to an airport like Denver in the United States the effective tax there is around $US40. These things get lost a little bit in the haze. I do not think that that is necessarily going to be the thing that turns people off coming to Australia.

I do not disagree with him saying that the tourist industry is very price sensitive in that international market, and it is price sensitive in terms of developing some of those new emerging markets. But, at the end of the day, it is not always these charges that make the difference. You usually find it is the key components of what the airfare charges might be and, indeed, what the accommodation charges might be that determine whether or not people come to Australia. I would suggest that the member for Cunningham might look at some of the core faresâthe tour basing faresâthat presently exist between Tokyo and Australia and Tokyo and Honolulu. If you check the mileage of the distance between Tokyo and Cairns, it is 15 miles shorter than the distance between Tokyo and Honolulu.

talk.start.para: âAnd the same time zone.

âAnd the same time zone. The last time I checked, the tour basing fareâand I have not checked this for some timeâfrom Australia was about $990. The tour basing fare that was operating into Honolulu was about $530. That is where the real difficulty is. While we can talk about these things and the disincentives that are there, in actual fact there are a number of components that make up the cost of a holiday and determine wheth er or not Australia is going to benefit from the visits that people are going to make.

speech.para: The member for Cunningham mentioned the tremendous impact that tourism has had on Australian employment, and that is true, with more than 600,000 people now employed in the industry. He mentioned the impressions that people have of Australia as a result of their visits and how that helps us around the world. But the tourism industry has more than thatâwe have a new export industry. In debates like this, we fail to mention not only the investment that has been made in hotels and the infrastructure of Australia but also the investments that have been made in education and the tremendous quality of the graduates of our TAFEs and our tourism and hospitality collegesâboth in the private and public sectorsâand what that is doing.

I read an article just the other day which said that it is now estimated that there is in excess of 350 Australian chefs who are working in London. We have, in fact, developed an export market. Take the hotel chains like Ramada and Sheraton. Years ago, I used to get up here in the House and complain that every hotel manager in Australia seemed to have the name of Fritz or Heinz. In actual fact, if you go overseas now you find that the hotel managers have the name of Blue or Jack or Bill or Dick. The Australian impression that has been made in the international hotel industry has been enormous.

I had some experience of this a couple of years ago when I was in the United States and stayed at a hotel in Washington. The young lass behind the desk was an Australian and I started chatting to her. She told me that the food and beverage manager of that hotel was an Australian, the general manager was an Australian, and her other friend on the reception desk was an Australian.

One of the real difficulties we have is that a number of these international operators are sitting outside the doors of Australian education establishments. They are waiting to take these young people out and put them in the world. That is fineâI think it is wonderfulâbut it does not necessarily mean that we are always getting the best out of our investment in terms of what is happening within Australia.

I will get back to this bill and the money that is going to be raised. It is true that a lot of money will be raised. I agree with the honourable member for Cunninghamâthe fact that we have the Olympic Games coming up means that the revenue we are going to get in will probably be far in excess of expectations. It is also fair to say that investments have to be made in looking after the Olympic Games and in looking at the increased flow of traffic coming in.

I have taken a particular interest in airport security in recent times. I knowâobviously I am not going to mention it here in any technical senseâthat the investment for airport security for the Olympic Games will be very extensive and very good. We are looking at some of the great state-of-the-art materialâthe post-Lockerbie materialâthat is available overseas now. We are going to make these investments and they are not going to be cheap. There is going to have to be a very real investment in the employment of further staff in areas such as Customs and the rest of it. I am not totally convinced that the money that we have indicated will be raisedâand some of the extraâwill benefit Australia in the long term and, most importantly, benefit the Australian image overseas.

It is exciting when we talk about the increased flow of tourism at the Olympic Games that we are not talking about any significant numbers in the two weeks of the games. We are already seeingâtwo years outâthe start of the movement as the advance parties move in. As more and more teams establish themselves hereâand they will be established in Australia for quite some time leading up to the gamesâfriends and families will start to move in and out of the country, building to an ultimate crescendo during the two weeks of the games.

The great thing about the investment in the Olympic Games is that it is a long-term investment in tourism; we are going to get that build-up in tourism before the two weeks of the games. If we have half a brain, we will do exactly what overseas countries have done. It always amuses me that visitors to Munich on package tours have almost a compulsory visit to the 1972 Olympic Games site. Munich still attracts that attention. It still uses it 25 or 26 years later as a major tourism stimulus. That is where Australia has got this chance.

Although I am a parochial Queenslander, I believe the decision to take it to Sydney was ideal. I hope that people realise the real potential for the promotion of Australia that that is going to bring. Can you just imagine the opening credits of the telecasts every day? If I had the rights to the telecast, I would make sure that I had a camera up in a helicopter and a camera out at the Heads somewhere. I reckon that the opening scene every day should be a big zoom-in straight down the harbour, through the bridge and into the Olympic site. That is going to do absolute marvels in bringing this image of Australia to millions of people around the world. That is where the real investment of the Olympic Games is going to play such a tremendous role in the future and provide so much wealth for Australia, and indeed long-term jobs.

Another thing which has been raised in this debate and which was raised yesterday in the Main Committee in another debate is the decline of Asian tourist numbers. The member for Cunningham was quite right. I followed the figures leading up to the end of the year and I think I am right in saying that for December last year the arrivals figures were only down about 2Â½ per cent on the figures of the year before. They were about 17 per cent higher than the December figures for 1995. It did come as a rush, as the numbers dropped out of Seoul and Bangkok. They declined a little out of Hong Kong. Japan stayed there. What concerns me now is that in recent months we are starting to see a decline in the Japanese figures. I understand that the latest figures would indicate that we are down about 14 or 15 per cent. They were pretty stable until the early months of this year but now they are starting to move down.

I do not say this as any great criticism of the industry, or indeed the Australian Tourist Commission or governments of any administration, but a lot of time and effort were put into the development of the Asian tourist markets, and rightly so. For the period I was with the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation, we concentrated very heavily on Japan. We made that infrastructure and it built quite well. The pilots dispute came along in 1989 and the market went bad. We went in again and we put tremendous concentration into that Asian market.

In the 1980s we had some interest out of the United States, and those figures were quite good. We also saw the emergence of some quite unlikely markets out of Europe. For a while we were the flavour of the month out of Denmark and Sweden; that has gone down a little. The French started to pick us up as an international destination. We had some quite good figures out of Italy, and Spain was starting to develop. Since the recovery after the pilots dispute we have got a bit lazy in the intelligence we were gathering and the efforts we were making in developing new markets. Those new markets were not just China. I think we are fortunate that China has made us a preferred destination. Frankly, I do not think that we are going to make piles of money out of the Chinese market. It is pretty basic tourism and in terms of yield I do not think it is going to be as great as some people indicate. I think the Indian market certainly has potential. We have never really focused much beyond Asia, except for a couple of those traditional areas.

One of the interesting markets that has been emerging for the last decade has been the South American market. It was interesting that during the time of the apartheid regime in South Africa, the Argentinians, and to a degree the Brazilians, were moving into South Africa in big numbers. They then switched into Europe and then started moving to the United States. The next move was obviously into Asia or into Australasia.

We have never really seriously looked at trying to develop that market. Part of the problem was that there were no air links and, as far as the old Qantas regime is concerned, enough said. We just could not get them interested in looking at developing new markets at all. I think we have missed the boat to a degree on that South American marketâthey have started to look at going to other places. There might still be some hope, I think, with the tremendous relationship between Australia and Chile, for example, but we can build that up. That is an emerging market that is quite exciting.

The other market that is really just starting to move is the market out of the Middle East, and that Middle East market is high yield. The stories we hear about the sheikh coming on board and taking over the entire first-class section of an aircraft with a cast of thousands behind him and taking over a couple of floors in a luxury hotel are quite correct. It does happen. I would hope that whoever may be in charge of the tourism portfolio and whoever may be in charge of the Australian Tourist Commission would look at developing markets such as that; not to get our focus away from Asia, but so that we do not become quite as complacent as we were about the way the Asian market started to develop and come forward. So there are some great challenges to the industry at the moment.

It is good that the numbers from the United States and Europe have increased. Unfortunately, those numbers do not necessarily go into the places that need the help. We are feeling a bit of hurt in Surfers Parade and in Cairns in particular because of the downturns in the Asian numbers, and the European and the American markets are not necessarily going there in force. So it is going to be a challenge to make sure that we know what we are doing there. But it is a challenge that the industry have faced before; they have had their downturns in the past. I think it is a magnificent challenge. I just hope that the extra funds that will be raised from the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 will go some way toward developing those new markets and making sure tourism remains one of our great export industries and the greatest generator of employment in Australia.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI begin by thanking the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) and the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) for their contributions to the debate on the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 . It is always interesting to listen to the member for Fadden talk about travel issues and tourism issues. I am sure he is without peer in this place as a member with an understanding of these issues and the airline industry in particular. I have enjoyed his company on travels from time to time and his knowledge is truly outstanding. I also thank the member for Cunningham for his contribution and for the indication that the opposition will be supporting this legislation.

speech.para: This legislation implements the decision announced by the government in the 1998 budget to increase the existing passenger movement charge from $27 to $30 with a date of effect from 1 January 1999. The increase was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and will help to meet the additional costs associated with the transit of people during the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The rate of the charge is fixed at an amount that covers the overall cost of customs, immigration and quarantine processing of international travellers.

I noted the comments of the member for Cunningham when he queried, as a result of an audit report, whether or not there had been an over-collection of moneys. Subsequent discussions in relation to that audit report suggest that the system used to calculate the figures is open to question. The accounting system was not the usual one used for these sorts of circumstances, and that figure is, to put it mildly, open to question.

The charge is imposed on the departure of a person from Australia. It is collected by airlines and shipping companies at the time of ticket sales and remitted to the Commonwealth in accordance with the arrangements entered into under the Passenger Movement Charge Collection Act. I think these arrangements have worked very well for all stakeholders and passengers have appreciated the fact that they no longer have to line up in a queue to buy departure stamps. The cost of their departure is covered by means of this new mechanism. The current arrangements with the airlines are due to expire on 30 June 1998, and the government is finalising negotiations with interested parties for new arrangements to apply from 1 July 1998 to 30 June 2001.

The reason the bill is being brought forward at this time is so that these negotiations can proceed smoothly and also so that clear notice can be given to the industry of the increased charges to avoid the embarrassment of trying to collect additional amounts at a later time. I thank the House for the smooth passage of this matter and commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI have been saying for a while now that, as sure as night follows day, if this government is re-elected the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Howard) will axe Medicare. Tonight the axe hits another part of Medicare.
âHow can you say that with a straight face?

âThe member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) interjects and says, `How can you say that?' Tonight an axe wielded with David Foster like power will smash into the trunk of Medicare because in the next 90 minutes we will debate the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 , a bill which I believe is the beginning of the end of Medicare. It is the beginning of the end of Medicare because this bill means that, for the first time in Australia since Medicare was established, we will not have the five-year Medicare agreements with each of the statesâthe five-year guarantee that Medicare in public hospitals is there as the safety net for every public patient, wherever they may live, whatever their circumstances.

speech.para: This is a $29 billion bill which pays for hospital services, and it represents the complete failure of the Howard government to reach Medicare agreements with the states. Apparently the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) can negotiate health care agreements with New Zealand and Ireland but cannot negotiate health care agreements with his own Liberal and National party colleagues in the states. He certainly cannot negotiate a Medicare agreement with the state of New South Wales.

The acting minister gave us a 20-line second reading speech for a bill that is to allocate $29 billion to the states. It is clear to anyone that this government does not care about public hospitals; public hospitals that serve two out of three Australians for most surgery and almost every Australian for emergency care. As we pointed out in the last couple of weeks, the budget provided not one extra dollar for public hospitals that was not on the table when the Premiers walked out of the Premiers Conference two months ago. It seems that this government has come to the conclusion that it does not want Medicare agreements. It hates Medicare so much that it cannot even stand to have the name `Medicare' in the title of this legislation. That is why we know that, if this government is re-elected, as sure as night follows day, this mob will axe Medicare. It wants to go to the election without having signed any Medicare agreements, and it wants to have a free hand afterwards. That should send a chill down the spine of every member of this House.

We have had a few indications lately about what the government really thinks about Medicare and public hospitals. On 21 May the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said that he thought people getting treatment in public hospitals was a problem. The Treasurer said that he thought a good public hospital system is some place where people who cannot afford to get medical care should go. That is not what we on this side of the House think of public hospitals. We think public hospitals are the safety net for Australians, no matter what their circumstances. It is the safety net that two-thirds of Australians are placing their faith in.

talk.start.para: âIt was one-third before you guys got into power.
âIt is the government of which you are a member that has cut the federal funding for public hospitals by $800 million.
âThat is rubbish.

âYou go and talk to the people at the Blue Mountains hospital or the Nepean hospital or the Hawkesbury River hospital about the pressure that their hospital is under because of the federal cutbacks that your government has made. You come into this House and vote for cuts that have affected the hospitals in your own electorate, and you cannot walk away from your own personal responsibility for supporting these cuts in federal funding for public hospitals. That is why Maggie Deahm will be the next member for Macquarie. She will be re-elected as the member for Macquarie at the next election because you have failed in your responsibility to speak up for your constituents.
âOrder! I ask the member to direct his remarks through the chair.

âWe on this side of the House believe that the government has a responsibility to make sure that the public hospital system is looking after those public patients. The Howard government wants to leave the way clear to impose up-front hospital charges at public hospitals if they get re-elected, and this bill allows them to do it. We are not prepared to let that happen, and we do not trust this minister to stop it. We will be moving an amendment to the bill in the consideration in detail stage to ensure that that cannot happen. I am quite happy for copies of that amendment to now be circulated in the chamber. I foreshadow that that amendment will be moved when we get to the consideration in detail stage.

speech.para: If the government is not prepared to accept the amendment, they will have made it clear that their intention is to allow a re-elected Howard government to introduce compulsory charges for public patients in public hospitals. We know that the Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong, has always hated Medicare. We know it is something that he has always opposed. Let me remind the House of some of his most famous utterances on Medicare:

Medicare has been an unmitigated disaster . . . Radical surgery will be performed on Medicare . . . The second thing we'll do is get rid of the bulk-billing system. It's an absolute rort . . . We'll pull it right apart.
That is what the member for Bennelong said about Medicare.

talk.start.para: âWas that 1985?
âIt was only two weeks ago that Peter Costello said that he intends to re-engineer the health care system. We have the Prime Minister saying that he wants to pull it right apartâ
âOrder! I would ask the honourable member for Dobell to direct his remarks through the chair, and I would ask the minister not to aggravate the honourable member for Dobell.

âThank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. As recently as two weeks ago, we had the Treasurer saying that he would re-engineer the entire health care system. We had the Treasurer saying that he wants to introduce a system of no claim bonuses in private health insurance. In some way he thinks that human being's bodies are the same as motor vehicles. The elderly and the chronically ill are the greatest users of the health care system. They will be the ones hardest hit by the Treasurer's intention to introduce no claim bonuses into private health insurance.

speech.para: At the end of the day this bill, in allocating $29 billion, is providing inadequate funding for the Australian public hospital system. It is not just the Labor Party that is saying that; the states in their submissions to the Senate inquiry into the Medicare agreement stated that 1.4 million patients are not funded over the five-year agreement of the offer. We have the AMA stating that it is quite clear that there will be a doubling in the waiting lists. Let me remind the House of what the AMA had to say. According to Dr Robert Hodge, one of the AMA's federal councillors:
Public hospital waiting lists will double in a few short years unless the Commonwealth dramatically lifts its funding offer . . .
He further stated:
If no more money is offered, hospital waiting lists will blow out and the quality of care doctors are able to provide will be compromised.
Some 116,000 Australians are on hospital waiting listsâthis is likely to double over the next few years unless a better deal is struck.
Consultations with colleagues in all states over the past few weeks has demonstrated a deep and unprecedented level of concern among surgeons working in public hospitals.
People are waiting in corridors to get access to hospital beds, less and less elective surgery is being undertaken and teaching and research is being lost, particularly in out-patient departments.

So it is quite clear that the AMA has very serious concerns about the government's inadequate offer. We have a former leader of the Liberal Party, Dr John Hewson, completely dismissing the government's claims that this offer represents a 15 per cent increase in hospital funding. Dr Hewson was quoted on The World Today on 13 May as saying:

Well it's true, on the numbers there's a 15 per cent increase, but if you allow for things like population, if you allow for the aging of the population, if you allow for the service delivery considerations, that 15 per cent shrinks to 1 per cent, and that is why the states are screaming.
That is why public patients are going to be hurt by this government's inadequate federal funding for public hospitals. On the Face to Face program of 17 May we have the minister for health stating:
If you take age out; if you take population out; if you take any drop in private health insurance out; the increase is 1.5% per year, so that's 7.5% over 5 years . . .

We have the minister for health disputing the Prime Minister's claims that it is a 15 per cent increase. The minister for health pulls the rug out from underneath his own claims that this is a 15 per cent real offer. It is clear that the minister's press secretary winds the minister for health up every day and then sends him out for his doorstops. Is it any wonder that the minister is getting into so much trouble when we have comments such as this one reported by the ABC, who ran a story on Tuesday, 5 May, which stated:
The office of Federal Health Minister Michael Wooldridge now says that Government's patience may run out and it could change its offer of payment.

We have the health minister making it clear that one of the weapons he intends to use to bludgeon the states, to take the axe to Medicare, is to actually cut the amount which is currently out there on offer to each of the states. This is despite the fact that on 23 March the Prime Minister said:
. . . I make it very clear to the patients of Australia and to the public of Australia: you will not suffer because of the petulance of the Premiersâ
this is when they walked out. He continued:
Every single dollar contained in the offer that we made will be delivered in full and on time.

The minister for health's press secretary winds him up like a sort of clockwork toy and sends him out. The minister for health and his office is out there saying that the offer to the states is going to be cut because this minister for health has lost patience with the states. So we have the press secretary to the minister for health overruling the Prime Minister's guarantee that every single dollar of the offer would be provided to the states.

One of our concerns is that this very bill does not comply with the Prime Minister's undertakings. We had the Prime Minister stating that every single dollar of that offer would be delivered. This bill does not meet the Prime Minister's offer. The Prime Minister said that the payments to the states would be indexed according to a whole number of factors, including declines in private health insurance. This bill is a lump sum each year. There is no indexation; the offer that the Prime Minister made that every single dollar would be provided to the states in full and on time is not provided for in this piece of legislation.

Someone is misleading the Australian people and someone is misleading the health ministers of each of the states and the territories. We know who that person is: it is the Prime Minister, John Howard, the member for Bennelong, who at the Premiers Conference said that every single dollar would be delivered. But the bill that has been introduced into the House does not comply with the undertaking that the Prime Minister has given.

If you look in detail at the offer, it is ludicrous for the government to claim that there is a massive increase in funding. They have got dodgy figures all through this package. They have double counted the funding for mental health and palliative care; they know that there is $479 million for mental health and palliative care in this offer and they know that this area was not included in the last Medicare agreement. They claim that there is a substantial increase in the new Medicare agreement because they have brought mental health and palliative care funding into the tent. It is a clear demonstration of that old saying that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. This government's claim that there is a 15 per cent real increase in federal funding for public hospitals is worse than a damned lie; it is quite clear that they have doubled counted the funding for mental health and palliative care.

Veterans' Affairs funding has also not been in the Medicare agreements before, and only 45 per cent of veterans currently use public hospitals. We have had the massive cuts to federal funding of public hospitals in the last two budgetsâ$800 million in 1996 from the forward estimates, and another $400 million from the state health budgets and the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program. It is very clear that the government has abandoned the Medicare agreements to give it the flexibility to take the axe to Medicare if it is re-elected.

The real concern is that this government's inability to sign agreements with each of the states and territories before 1 July leaves Medicare and the protection for public patients in public hospitals completely at risk. Because there is no binding agreement with the states, there is no certainty whatsoever. The only limit in the bill is in the maximum amount the Commonwealth can pay the states. There is no minimum amount which this minister can provide each of the states and territories under the legislation before the House.

Every year, each of the state health ministers will be at the whim of the federal minister for health. He has already shown he has no intention of keeping the Prime Minister's promise about making sure every dollar is delivered on time. So every year we will get the same round of bickering and acrimonious negotiations, which are not just bad for the public health system but disastrous for planning for public hospitals and a nightmare for patients, who are the ones that really suffer at the end of the day.

This minister has run the length and breadth of the country claiming that this package is about reform in health, but there is no reform in this bill at all. One part of the minister's reform plan was the national development plan. This was supposed to be capital funding for structural reform, but the minister sold out his own plan when he gave Queensland a pre-election bribe and turned this money into recurrent fundingâcompletely contradicting his own guidelines for submission based project funding.

Because this minister has been unable to negotiate, his fancy talk about reform has come to nothing. He cannot bring about change in health unilaterally. The minister should soon start to learn that you can only negotiate these things in a rational and trusting way, not in a way that seeks to bludgeon the states to the negotiating table.

I would now like to turn to the three Medicare principles which have been put into this piece of legislation. They have been rewritten in such a way that a strict literal reading of them would make it impossible for any state to comply with any of them, ever. For example, principle 1 states:

Eligible persons are to be given the choice to receive, free of charge as public patients, health and emergency services of a kind or kinds that are currently, or were historically, provided by hospitals.

What is an example of a service which was never so provided? I would like the minister to tell us when he sums up. Give me an example of some medical service that has never been provided at some stage by hospitals. There is no time limit on this. How far back are we going to go to look at the role of hospitals in each of the states and territories? If you compare it with the previous principle in the former Medicare agreement, it states much more simply:
Eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients.
Turning to the second principle, the minister's new version in the bill states:
Access to such services by public patients free of charge is to be on the basis of clinical need and within a clinically appropriate period.
I do not think anyone has met that particular principle yet. The new version of principle 3 states:
Arrangements are to be in place to ensure equitable access to such services for all eligible persons, regardless of their geographic location.
That is also so wide ranging that I doubt any state health system meets that principle either. Compare that with the old principle 3, which stated as follows:
To the maximum practicable extent, a state will ensure the provision of public hospital services equitably to all eligible persons regardless of their geographic location.

What they have deliberately done is to broaden the principles in such a manner as to make them meaningless. The effect of these new principles is that the minister can choose himself whether or not to pay who he likes and when he likes. This legislation therefore has no meaning whatsoever. It is no guarantee to the states or to the people who are out there working in the public hospital system that federal funding will be maintained. It leaves the way completely open, if this government is re-elected, for the radical surgery that the Prime Minister proposed for Medicare back in 1987.

The old Medicare principles were less general and less open to ministerial fiat and ministerial interpretation. The government has deliberately broadened the principles to such a ridiculous extent that, as I say, they are trying to render them meaningless. Once again, this applies to up-front hospital charges as well and we believe that there is no guar antee whatsoever on that. That is why we will be moving our amendments in the consideration in detail stage, to try to ensure that public patients have a guarantee that they will not be hit by compulsory charges no matter what this government seeks to do.

For those reasons, we believe that this legislation is an outrage. The future of Medicare is to be decided in a 90-minute debate in the House of Representatives, a 90-minute debate that is going to commit the Australian taxpayer to spend $29 billion. For all the people out there who know that their local public hospital is under pressure, this is what this government thinks of you and your local hospital: 90 minutes on a Wednesday night; 90 minutes to allow all of those concerns to be dealt with by the national parliament; 90 minutes to determine whether or not their inadequate and measly $29 billion is going to address the pressures and concerns that are out there due to the crisis in the Australian public hospital system.

Come the next election, members of the government will each individually be held accountable for their neglect of public hospitals, for their attacks on the public hospital system, for their obsession with private health insurance, for wasting $1.7 billion on private health insurance while the public hospital system lurches from crisis to crisis. They are the people who will be held responsible for the fact that the Australian public hospital system is not going to receive the funding that it so desperately needs.

talk.start.para: âThe hypocrisy and deceit of the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) is astounding, even by Labor Party standards. I think he spent too long reading the Labor Party campaign manual and not enough time researching the facts. I suggest the member for Dobell might take a look at the budget papers to correct some of the rubbish he has just sprouted about supposed cuts in health care funding.

speech.para: Let me inform him of these facts. In the last year of the Labor government, Commonwealth government funding on hospitals was $5.49 billion. In the first year of the coalition government, it rose to $5.61 billion, in the second year to $6 billion and in this recent budget to $6.7 billion. That is an increase of $600 million over the first two years or, counting this next year, an increase of $1,244 million in Commonwealth government funding to public hospitals.

If you look at the total health care budget, the rise is even more significant. In Labor's last year, Labor spent $18,633 million. In the coalition's first year, it was raised to $19,294 million, in the second year to $20,734 million and in this year's budget to $22,273 million. That is an increase over those three years of $3.6 billion.

Even the member for Dobell should know the difference between an increase and a decrease. If it rises in three years by $3.6 billion, it goes up, not down. That, for the member for Dobell, is an increase, not a decrease; it is an addition, not a cut. I am sure even the member for Dobell would understand that an increase of $3.6 billion is a significant increase in government funding for the health care system.

The Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 is necessary because of the Premiers' refusal earlier in the year to accept the Commonwealth's five-year health care agreement. It delivers in full the health funding offer made at the Premiers Conference in March. As the Commonwealth is unwilling to wait any longer to ensure the continuity of funding for state hospitals, it is necessary to introduce this supplementary legislation. In other words, the government has to introduce extra legislation to overcome the petulance of the state Premiers and to ensure adequate funding for public hospitals, in spite of the stunt of the Premiers and in spite of the stunt of the member for Dobell.

Two main points need to be made in this context. Firstly, contrary to the deceit of the opposition, this government is committed to maintaining the integrity of the health care system and of the public health system. This involves both maintaining Medicare and ensuring a workable private health system. It is imperative that all Australians, regardless of means and regardless of circumstances, have access to quality hospital services. The coalition is committed to exactly that. It is committed to maintaining Medicare. I say again for the members of the opposition: the government is committed to maintaining Medicare.

The government is committed to ensuring universally available acute health care services. This supplementary legislation before the house demonstrates that commitment, in spite of the lack of cooperation of most of the state governments and in spite of the posturing of the opposition. The bill includes a prerequisite, for the states to receive funding under this bill, that they adhere to the principles of ensuring universal access to health and emergency services free of charge on the basis of clinical need and within clinically appropriate periods, regardless of the patient's location.

It is worth again noting the details of the five-year Medicare offer that was rejected by the Premiers and that was just criticised inaccurately and incorrectly by the member for Dobell. This offer was a very fair and very reasonable one. The offer was for $30.17 billion over the next five years, up from $24.99 billion in the previous agreement. That is an increase of 15 per cent in real terms over Labor's forward estimates. This is a significant point: not only was it an increase over the past agreement, not only was it an increase over what Labor last negotiated, but also it was an increase over Labor's own forward estimates. Those were estimates they could not have met themselves, but they are estimates which we are not only meeting but in fact exceeding.

The offer includes an 11 per cent increase in the base level funding. It also includes significantly an indexation factor to cover increasing costs. This is important in light of the distortions by the member for Dobell. This indexation covers factors such as the growth and ageing of the population, the increasing costs of hospital services and, importantly, any reductions in private health insurance. It also includes, on top of that increase in the base level of funding, $500 million for mental health and palliative care. In addition to that, it includes another $750 million to fund veteran health care at full cost over the next five years. Not only is this a great boost to the veteran community, includ ing the extension of the gold health card to another 50,000 World War II veterans, but also it takes some of the pressure off the public hospital system. The package also included $500 million for projects aimed at restructuring the health care system.

I note that the Queensland and ACT governments have accepted the $23 million offered under the critical and urgent treatment waiting list scheme of the $120 million offered. The needy in the other states are missing out. Yet the member for Dobell would encourage the other Premiers to stand firm and encourage them not to accept that offer and encourage them to maintain the lengthy waiting lists and encourage them not to accept this extra $120 million that the Commonwealth government is offering to immediately reduce the waiting lists in state public hospitals.

The second point that needs to be made is that a quality and affordable health care system requires also a viable private health care system. I am sure that even the member for Dobell would accept that without it there is an unsustainable burden on the public health care system. Before Labor came into office in 1983, Australia had a good health system, a workable combination of private health insurance and free public hospitals. It was based on the right principle: if you can look after yourself then you take some responsibility to do so; if you cannot then the public hospital system is there. Both the private and the public system were of high qualityâhigh quality public hospital care and affordable private health insurance.

Then the Labor vandals and wreckers got their hands on Australia's health care system. Thirteen years of Labor saw a steady assault on the quality of our health system. In 1983, over 63 per cent of Australians had private health insurance. By 1996, when Labor was thrown out of office, that figure had declined to close to 32 per cent. This disastrous decline was a result of a number of policy disasters, enacted either out of sheer ignorance by the Labor Party or else in a premeditated desire to destroy the private health system. Early in its time in government, Labor removed the tax rebate on private health insurance pre miums, thereby significantly increasing the real cost of premiums and causing an exodus from private health insurance. I note Labor's desire to remove the current $450 private health insurance rebate and thereby accelerate the decline in private health insurance numbers. Other decisions in those disastrous 13 years, such as a withdrawal of the bed day subsidy and the withdrawal of the reinsurance pool contribution, also added to the cost of private health cover and hastened its decline.

The ideologically blinkered approach may have warmed the hearts of the Labor Left but put growing pressure on the public health care system. There is an estimated rise of $100 million a year on the cost of running the public hospital system for each one per cent drop-out in private health insurance cover. Thus, Labor's failure over their 13 yearsâin spite of the warnings by their former health minister, Graham Richardson, that something had to be done to address that declineâto halt the decline in membership from 63 per cent to 32 per cent has added $3.1 billion a year to the cost of running the public hospital system. Because of the ideological obsession of the Labor Party, they have added such an unsustainable burden on the public system that it is costing the public system an extra $3.1 billion a year to cater for the extra numbers in the public health care system.

A number of state health ministersâincluding, significantly, Dr Refshaugeâhave admitted in recent weeks that this decline in private health insurance has been one of the problems. They acknowledge that the decline in private health membership has placed an intolerable strain on the public system. We have Dr Refshauge on one hand admitting that we need to prop up the private health system to reduce the strain on the public system and we have the member for Dobell on the other hand trying to tear it up. This is typical of the member for Dobell and his colleagues. They are out to destroy the private health system completely and to exacerbate the growing pressures on the public hospital system. They are more interested in ideological purity than in the health care of the Australian community.

This is a demonstration of their shameful ignorance and incompetence. On this issue, as with many others, Labor is driven more by point scoring than by genuine policy debate; driven more by ideological obsession than by sound policy; driven more by political ambition than by any concern for the common good. This government is committed to Medicare. It is committed to ensuring health care for all the needy and it is committed to building a health care system that is workable. This government's commitment stands in sharp contrast to the hypocrisy and nonsense that we have heard from the other side.

talk.start.para: âWe now know the truth about this government's commitment to Medicare. It does not exist. As the previous speaker, the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett), has quite clearly indicated to the House, he wants to go back to the system we had pre-Medicareâpre-1983âwhen two million Australians were without any health insurance coverage whatsoever. The member for Macquarie has made it quite plain to the House that the government wants to go back to a system where we had to rely on private health insurance, and public care was available only for the needy. I think that is how he put it at the end of his statement: public hospital care should be available only for the needy. We on this side of the House do not think that is the sort of health system we should have in this country. That is the system they have in the United States, and what is the situation there? They have 40 million people without any health insurance coverage, and it costs that country twice as much for health care as it does here in Australia. Labor is committed to Medicare and we want to see it strengthened; we do not want to see it whittled away.

speech.para: We do not share this government's obsessionâand I would have to say that there is no other word for itâwith private health insurance. The job of the health minister should be to make sure that Medicare works and that people can get hospital care when they need itânot have an obsession with private health insurance. That is not the main game. The main game is making sure that there is sufficient funding for patient care, not wasting taxpayers' money on private health insurance subsidies, which their very own Jeff Kennett has called `money down the drain'.

This is the question the member for Macquarie should be able to answer: why is it that every previous Medicare agreement has been signed but this time the Premiers know that the amount of money being put forward is just not enough to make public hospitals pay? With all previous Medicare agreements, the states signed up, but not this time. It is not by any means the case that all the state Premiers are Labor. It is the Victorian Premier who has been very outspoken, along with his Liberal colleagues.

I do not want to let the state governments off the hook, because the states do carry a significant responsibility to fund their public hospitals properly. The Kennett government did significantly cut public hospital funding in Victoria when it first came into office, but that does not mean that we should have a situation which leads us to debating this bill tonight. We are debating this bill because this government is incapable of getting the states to sign Medicare agreements. For hospitals like the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre, which was technically bankrupt earlier this year because of the cuts of the Howard and Kennett governments, in my electorate, it will mean that they have no security about their future funding.

There are two things I would say to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in the context of this legislation. If it is the case that we are not going to have Medicare agreements but just have hospital funding paid directly to the states without the states signing agreements, what is this government going to do to stop the massive privatisation of public hospitals that is going on around the country? Let us have a look at the real impacts of the privatisation of these hospitals. In Western Australia we saw the privatisation of a public hospital, the Joondalup Hospital. Less than two weeks after it was officially opened, it was decided to cancel elective surgery for public patients. What did this government, which says it is so committed to public patients, do to the Western Australian government to make sure that this closure did not affect public patients? Absolutely nothing. As the memo from this hospital shows, the closure of wards was to affect only public patients. The government did absolutely nothing to make sure that public patients would retain their access to this hospital. This is the first indication of the development of a two-tiered health system in this country.

This move is going ahead in leaps and bounds in my own state of Victoria. An article in the Age on 7 May this year reported that doctors from Sale, Maffra and Heyfield hospitals were writing to the state minister saying that they are very concerned about those hospitals having to reduce medical services so that the privatised Latrobe Regional Hospital could make enough money. The state government has given the private owner of the Latrobe hospitalâAustralian Hospital Care Pty Ltdâa 20-year monopoly on public health services in this area. The doctors in Sale, Maffra and Heyfield are very concerned that public hospital access to essential services in those towns is going to be reduced.

In my own electorate, the biggest privatisation of all is taking place. The Victorian government recently advertised for a registration of capability for the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Hospitalâthe proposed basis of private sector involvement to build, own and operate that hospital. We in the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne are very concerned at that change. What I would like to know from the minister is how he intends to stop the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre so that the people of the north-eastern suburbsâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I move that the question be now put.
âYou can't do it in the middle of a speech. It is customary to let someone finish their speech first.

âI will put two questions to the minister. What is the minister going to do to stop the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre so that the people of the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne can continue to get public hospital care when they need it? I would like to call on the minister to make a decent offer to the states so that the Medicare agreements can in fact be signed, so that public patients in all of our hospitals, particularly those public hospitals that are being privatised in Western Australia and in Victoria, will know that they will not be charged for essential health care. Without Medicare agreements no public patient can be guaranteed that they will not face charges. This government seems as if it is just going to sit on its hands and watch major teaching hospitals being privatised around this country to the absolute detriment of essential health care.
âMr Deputy Speakerâ

âMr Deputy Speaker, I have moved that the question be put. On the basis of good manners, the opposition speaker was allowed to complete her few sentences, but I had already moved that the question be put.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I have the call. The only option open to the parliamentary secretary is to move that I be no longer heard. You have given me the callâwith great respect, sir.
âYou are quite right.

âThe 1998 OECD Economic Surveys report into the wellbeing of the Australian economy made two important observations about the state of our domestic health care system. The report indicated that the two factors which had brought about persistent increases in health expenditure over the past decade were the lack of incentives for public hospitals to improve the efficiency of service delivery and the steep decline in the number of Australians covered by private health insurance. It is in the context of these issues that I wish to discuss the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 .

speech.para: This bill seeks to earmark more than $29.5 billion over the next five years towards the cost of health and emergency services in the states and territories. This represents an increase of 15 per cent in real funding over the life of the yet to be renegotiated Medicare agreement. Given the coalition's current fiscal consolidation program, this should be judged to be both fair and an attractive offer.

Despite this, state government leaders in attendance at the March 1998 Premiers Conference deemed it appropriate to walk out on discussions with the Commonwealth government because they were not satisfied with the amount on offer. They did so believing their bargaining power to be at a peak, owing to the imminent federal election, and they demonstrated that they intend to behave no differently from their predecessors when it comes to haggling over the terms of Medicare agreements.

The states variously profess an aversion to tied grants and yet, whenever these grants come up for renewal, state leaders always argue for more than is being proposed. This is possibly in some cases because previously the offers were always less than was actually available. It is my view that we live in a federal system that has many of the disadvantages and few of the benefits normally attributed to a federal system of government. Despite the fact that we are gearing up to celebrate the centenary of Federation, we are no closer than we were nearly 100 years ago to enjoying the benefits of responsibility and accountability that should flow from having three distinct and competitive levels of government.

subdebate.1.para: Billâby leaveâtaken as a whole.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2:

speech.para: (1) Clause 6, page 3, at the end of subclause (1), add:
and is observing the condition set out in subsection (3).
(2) Clause 6, page 4 (after line 12), at the end of the clause, add:
(3) It shall be a condition of the grant that a State not impose compulsory hospital charges for inpatient care on eligible persons who elect to be treated as public patients.

I will not spend a lot of time speaking in the debate so that other colleagues will get a chance to speak. I simply make the point that the amendments that we are proposing seek to make it absolutely clear-cut that any state that receives funding under the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 will not be able to impose compulsory hospital charges for in-patient care on eligible personsâthat is, anyone who has a Medicare cardâwho elect to be treated as public patients. This is the belt and braces protection for public patients that state governments do not impose new compulsory charges on public patients in public hospitals.

talk.start.para: âThe amendments of the opposition go to the heart of my perspective that the now highly centralised system of revenue raising in Australia means that successive Commonwealth governments have been able to increasingly impose their will on other levels of government. What is proposed by the opposition is merely an extension of that.

speech.para: The states have played their part in this fiscal centralisation process by failing to take responsibility for raising their own revenues over the years. The lack of economic discipline that has characterised so many recent state government administrations is a direct consequence of their inability to implement adequate and efficient taxing measures.
The analysis of our health care system by the OECD in the report I mentioned earlier found that:

Efforts to contain spending pressures through a cap on budgets for public-sector hospitals had undermined efficiency as restraint has been imposed where capped budgets made it possible, not necessarily where resources (are) being used least effectively.

What an indictment of the manner in which our state and territory governments run their hospital systems. This observation also reflects badly on the Commonwealth, which perpetuates arrangements that allow this to happen. If the state leaders were to be held politically accountable by their electors for the way in which they administer their public hospitals, it is certain they would manage their affairs in a much more efficient and accountable way. The only reason they can get away with inefficient and redundant practices in the public hospital system is that these can be easily masked by way of cost shifting.

The fact that the majority of state and territory leaders refused the Commonwealth offer, which I referred to earlier in the second reading debate, which would have given the former more flexibility but fewer opportunities for cost shifting, revealed their continued reluctance to be truly responsible managers of our public hospitals. Until such time as both the consumers and the providers of our health system have reason to be directly concerned with the cost of health care, I cannot see there being much change in the status quo.

As I have already indicated, the OECD survey noted the correlation between declining private health membership numbers and rising costs in the public health system. Despite increases in the Medicare levy on supposed high income earners who fail to take out private health cover and the extension of incentive payments to low and middle income earners who do not maintain private health insurance, the coalition has not been able to stem the flow out of private health insurance facilities. The new Medicare agreement recognises this and intends to automatically compensate the states for increased hospital costs resulting from falling private health insurance levels. Despite this, the states continue to assert that the agreement is not generous enough. The haemorrhaging from private health insurance is:
. . . the creation of a compulsory tax-financed public system (which) has limited private insurance to (little more than) a top up role.

These are not my words. I have quoted directly from the 1998 OECD report, which correctly lays the responsibility for the scheme at the feet of the government which introduced an almost open-ended system of unlimited access to so-called `free' medical care, otherwise known as Medicare. I am referring, of course, to a former Labor government. From the start, the Medicare levy misrepresented the true cost of funding our public health care system. Instead of injecting a degree of honesty into the Medicare levy by setting it at a rate that reflected the real costs of Medicare, the Hawke government created and perpetuated an arrangement in which taxpayers received subsidised health care in return for what looks like a nominal levy on their income. Despite a 24 per cent increase in the Medicare levy from around $3.3 billion in 1995-96 to an estimated $4.1 billion in 1998-99, the revenue raised from this impost continues to fall far short of the cost of federal funding for our public health system. According to the 1998-99 budget, the cost to the Commonwealth to fund hospital services for the coming financial year is somewhere in the vicinity of $6.7 billion. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThese amendments are completely unnecessary and shows that the Labor Party and the two shadow ministers have not bothered to read the legislation that we have put into the parliament. The Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 states very clearly on page 3, clause 6(1):

speech.para: A grant of financial assistance under section 4 is not payable to a State unless the Minister is satisfied that the State is adhering to the principles set out in subsection (2).
Clause 6(2) then goes on to say:

Eligible persons are to be given the choice to receive, free of charge as public patients, health and emergency services of a kind or kinds that are currently, or were historically, provided by hospitals.

So that is totally provided for in the legislation. The second point is that not only is it redundant but it is destructive and shows again that the opposition does not understand health. The section in the amendments which refers to clause 6, page 4 says:
It shall be a condition of the grant that a State not impose compulsory hospital charges for inpatient care on eligible persons . . .

That totally is counter to everything that is happening in the health system at the moment. The fact is that there is a shift from in-hospital to out-of-hospital services, there is increased use of hospital in the home, and this clause has been put in so that people who in the future have services in the community that are currently being provided in the home are not disadvantaged. To limit this amendment, as the opposition does, to just in-patient services leaves the way open for people in the future who are having community based services to be charged, which is completely the opposite of what it is intending to do.

There is only one reason for this amendment: the opposition wants to put out a tawdry little press release at the end of this saying, `The government voted against ruling out charges for hospitals.' We will vote against it for two reasons. Firstly, it is already in the legislation. Secondly, these amendments are positively harmful. We have actually beaten you to it. We have put a press release out around the gallery saying that you are a goose, that you do not understand the legislation, that you have not read it, that it is already in there and that you do not understand what is happening in hospitals. Along with your confusion the other day over what happened with the PBS and its demand effects, this is another example showing that you do not understand the health system.

I could reply to each and every one of the inaccuracies that exist in this legislation, but the suspension for dinner is coming up and it would take far more time than I have. In terms of the opposition's misrepresentation, no amount of scaring, no amount of misquoting the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and no amount of misrepresenting the situation will allow you to scare people because the fact is we have covered the bases. We have no desire to see people charged. We have covered it completely by having it in the legislation. This is just a further example of your not understanding the complexities of health and of your trying to make cheap political points out of this health care agreement. As a government, we have no intention of allowing you to do it. Quite frankly, this is too important an area in which to play politics. The government has made a fair dinkum attempt here. It is a generous one and it should be supported.

talk.start.para: âI will be very brief. My response to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is that, first of all, you are asking us to trust you. The Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 says in clause 6(1):

speech.para: A grant of financial assistance under section 4 is not payable to a State unless the Minister is satisfied that the State is adhering to the principles . . .

Minister, we do not trust you. That is the message here tonight. We do not trust you, and the public patients in Australian hospitals do not trust you. We know that, as sure as night follows day, if this mob are re-elected they will take the axe to Medicare. That is why we are putting in this new clause: if the states accept the Commonwealth funding for public hospitals, they will have to accept the new condition that they not impose compulsory hospital charges for in-patient care on eligible persons who elect to be treated as public patients.

If you want to make sure there are no charges on public patients in public hospitals, vote for the amendment. If you want to leave open the possibility and want only to trust this minister for health that there will be no charges in public hospitals, vote the Labor Party amendment down. I know what the public patients out there want: they want the belt and braces protection that your mates cannot impose these new hospital fees.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Lee's ) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: âThe Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 is not the sort of bill that should be being rammed through in the last days of the sitting. This is a very bad bill. It is the sort of bill that is the root cause of the loss of faith in the party political system and in the two major parties that is feeding the growth of increased support for minor parties and Independentsâthe flight to the minor parties. The most recent Morgan poll showed the two major parties' vote at 83 per cent. That flight is much more stark in other countries, so we ought not over-interpret the significance of it, but we know that it is happening. You can see it in this House. You can certainly see it in the Senate. You can see it in the results in almost all the states. You can see it in the opinion polls and you can hear it in the attitude and discussion of people.

speech.para: It is not just that the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are losing support amongst Australians. At the end of the day that does not matter. We live in a democracy. If someone else comes up and takes the support, that is what happens. That is the electoral outcome. But if people lose faith in the capacity of the political process properly to resolve their problems, at the end of the day it is very bad for the whole democratic process.

We have a bill here which is about putting $45 million over three years into the coffers of political parties from taxpayers. If it were passed, some of that money would go to my partyâprobably not a very big proportion, but some. We would be better off. We would have some more money for fighting elections. We would have some more money for the administration of the party. But the body politic would be worse off. When I say $45 million, that is not the amount of extra money the political parties will have; that is the cost to the taxpayer of this bill according to the explanatory memorandum. There would be a slight variation from year to year, which I assume is based on some assumption about when the elections are going to be, but over the three years the cost to the taxpayers of extending this political donation tax deductibility will be $45 million.

Some of that money will be from corporate donations, some from private donations. You assume that somewhere between $100 million and $130 million of donations will be going to political parties through this systemâa minority of that sum to the Labor Party, most to the Liberal Party and the National Party. The one thing I agree with about the bill is that it would extend to Independents the opportunity to have tax deductible donations made to them. If there are going to be such donations, it is proper that they should be extended to those people.

But why the urgency of dealing with this bill? We have a serious problem in our electoral laws, a serious loophole, which to its credit the government has said it is going to close, but we are not seeing any urgency about that. That is the so-called Greenfields loophole through which donations are made to the Liberal Party without any disclosure. That is very serious. That loophole does require closing before the next election because it is a major loophole. I welcome the fact that the government is committed to closing it. That is a good thing. It should have closed it already. You could say there is some urgency; we should move to close this loophole before the election. But we see no action on that. Here, where we see that there is massive financial advantage, we suddenly see urgency. We are being pressed to make special arrangements to ensure that this bill will be passed, but it will not be passed with our support. With only a month between the introduction of this bill into the House of Representatives and when it is proposed to commence you wonder what the urgency is. I did not realise the Liberal Party was in such financial difficulties, myself.

It is a fundamentally flawed proposal. I know and I understand whyâI disagreed but understood at the timeâthe Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters supported this proposal. I did not criticise them then, although I disagreed, and I do not criticise them now, although I disagree. You can understand why at first glance the idea of extending this $100 to $1,500 does not look terrible. For some individuals it will be perfectly reasonable. I am not suggesting that it is about dishonesty. I am very criticalâand I have been critical in here beforeâabout Greenfields. I thought and think that is a rort. I do not think there is anything of that avoidance of the law, of that impropriety, here. I just think it is wrong in principle. Here we are in parliamentâ148 here, 76 up thereâsaying: `We think the organisations that send us here ought to get more support from the taxpayer.'

I would like to go out in the street and ask people what they think, and say: `We have here a proposal to spend an extra $15 million a year of your money. What is the most important way you would like to spend it? You have a few options. One of them is you could help out the Labor Party and the Liberal Party with some big tax deductibility.' I have to say, I do not think that is a winner. I am not talking about a winner in terms of votes on either side because if it is passed we both benefit. What I mean is in terms of the respect people have for the way we as politicians and parliamentarians conduct ourselves and the democratic process; the priorities we setâwhether we are a government for their interests or for ours. That is the issue that I think is in contention here.

How is this in the public interest? I can see how it is in the Liberal Party's interest, I can see how it is in the National Party's and I can even seeâand no-one knowing my background will be surprisedâhow it is in the Labor Party's interest. What I cannot see is how it is in the national interest and, at the end of the day, that is what we are here for. That is our fundamental obligation.

What this bill does is increase the maximum annual tax deductibility threshold for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500. I never agreed with $100, but there is no mischief in it. It costs almost nothing and, by definition, there are no big donations and there are no big cashflows under it. In principle, I never agreed with it and I am not normally a thin end of the wedge person. People criticised it at the time as thin end of the wedge and I did not think it was, so I did not say much about it. Perhaps I should have and I am as guilty as anybody. But what we have is just in time for the next election, from 1 July this yearâa major change to the tax laws with a cost to the revenue of $45 million over three years, and the only beneficiaries are the political parties and Independent candidates.

I repeat that, if it is going to happen, I agree with the extension of it to Independents. If we are going to do it, that should be a part of it. I do not think we should do it at all but, certainly, if we are going to do it we should do it in that way. But we are rushing this through and there has been no public scrutiny. I know there was a joint select committee and that is the proper way to go about changing these laws. I support that process. The previous Labor government started it, this government continues it and that is good. A lot of very good agreed changes to the electoral laws come out of that and it does put the process of each election under the sort of scrutiny that it should have. I support all that.

I know that the committee and my Labor colleagues supported this. As I said, neither they nor the Liberal Party and other party people on that committeeâI do not any longer know the detail of the composition; I do not reflect on those individualsâare going to get any money in their pockets out of this. Whether Labor, National, Independent or whoever, they are not going to be personally advantaged by this. They are not acting in wrongful self-interest, but I think that they have made a mistake which is serious and should not be allowed to recur.

This is also going to extend the right of this tax deductibility to corporations from individuals, and I do not agree with that either. Of course, it did not apply when the limit was $100 but it did not matter. It matters now and it should not happen. If this has any rationaleâand I think I understand the rationale people put for itâit is about an attempt to empower individuals to say, `What we want is a large number of more small donations instead of a small number of large donations as a diffusion of political power and influence.' I think that is the honest rationale. The secondary rationale is, `Boy, isn't this a lot of money that is going to come into our party coffers.'

But underlying that is that legitimate argument and that is why members of the committeeâfrom all partiesâsupported it. I understand that but I think that gets swamped by the secondary motivation about the dollar signs ringing over there in Blackall Street at the Liberal Party headquarters, about $45 million of tax deductibility and more than $100 million of donations flowing through this tax deductibility, predominantly going to the conservative parties but, I repeat, not only to them.

We are not literally changing the electoral laws we are changing the tax act, but we are changing the laws that relate to the way we conduct our political system and our elections rather than closing the egregious loophole that has been pointed out. That is a serious reflection on the priorities of the government. It is a very sad day but, more importantly, it is a very sad day for our political process. We all not only have the national interest to defend but we also come here with an obligation to speak for, act for and defend the standing of the legitimacy of the political process.

We all do things that do not help that, most often at question time. I am as guilty as anybody and I do not want to stand here and pretend it is everybody else and not me. Of course we are all here and we are all shouting and doing things.

talk.start.para: âNot as guilty as everybodyâafter all, Duncan's here!

âMaybe not as guilty as everybody but I am in there anyway. If you want to have a competition about who is the most guilty, I am prepared to enter it. I probably would not win it but I would not come last. We are all into that and, afterwards, are we sometimes proud of it? No. Does it happen in the theatre of the place every day? Yes, it does and it is a very contagious event.

speech.para: I do not want to pretend everybody is in here every day doing everything with high principles about the long-term impact on people's views about the standing of the parliament, et cetera. We know that sometimes kids come in here. The teachers must have a hell of a hard time keeping discipline in the school after they have all seen us in here. But a lot of times a lot of really great things happen in here too. People get up and make really important speeches about little things and big things that they care passionately about and the cut and thrust of debate takes place. The arguments that are raging in our society are reflected in our parliament and we are able to bring about political, social and economic change peacefully through the democratic process. That is the great thing about our society. Most members, most of the time, apply most of their activity to doing those things and that is good.

This bill, if it becomes a part of our taxation laws and part of our structure of funding political parties, will undermine all that good effort by all the members on all sides.
