It is not a Labor, a Liberal, an Independent or a National thing; we will all suffer. The system will be the worse for all of us if that is to be the case. The public are not stupid. They are much better informed these days. One of the achievements of the previous government of which it was proud was that it made a very significant increase in year 12 retention rates. Why do I mention that in this context? While we were proud of that achievement, we underestimated some of the corollaries of itâmany of them not relevant hereâwith respect to the types of jobs people want and all those sorts of things about aspirations. It changed our society. The constituencies are different.

The expectations of young Australians about the political process, their politicians, their government and their governance are very different. They have more access to information. They have more information and they have more education to help them assess and analyse that information. They are not smarter than previous generations, but they are better informed, better educated and they have better access to information. All those things are healthy, but they are a bit demanding sometimes when you are out on the hustings, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, relaxed as you look about this forthcoming electionâmore than previous ones, if I judge correctly. Nevertheless, having held a marginal seat for a long time, you would know that the voters are getting more demanding. I am sure that is not why you are leaving, Mr Deputy Speaker.

talk.start.para: âYou're not leaving, are you, Mr Deputy Speaker?

âI was not reflecting on his chances of being re-elected. I do not think my facts are inaccurate there, Mr Deputy Speaker, are they? I did not mean in any way to reflect that. We are all facing that, and they will want to know when it becomes public, as it inevitably will, that we saw this as a priority, that we gathered here together at their expense and decided that this was the thing that we particularly wanted to doâso much so that we had a special sitting to deal with it. We would not normally be sitting now, but this bill is listed because it is so important. Some others that the government listed originally that it wanted to pass have dropped off the list
âThe ones that would have saved Burnie.

âSome that are very important for reasons to do with the city of Burnie, according to my colleague the member for Denison. All sorts of bills have dropped off the list, and that always happens. We all make comments about how badly the other side administers the program, but it always happens that there are more bills you want to pass than there is time for, and at the end of the day you have to set some priorities. You have to say, `We wanted to pass X number of bills. We now realise we can only have something less than X, and we therefore have to set some priorities.'

speech.para: Amongst all the bills, the government has chosen the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 . We have not chosen it, and if we had been askedâand it would not be a surprise to know that we never areâwe would have said that this is not something that we give priority to. This is not one that we would have put at the top of the list, but it is the government's right to determine what comes into this show. The government has the powers of executive government. It has the right to introduce legislation and to set priorities about what is introduced. We have the right to debate it, to try to change it and, where the numbers give us the opportunity, to try to defeat it if we are opposed to it. But it is a reflection of the government's priorities that they chose this bill.

My concern is that, if this bill is passed, there will be a profound adverse reaction in the community. Maybe I should not worry about it, because it will probably be mainly targeted at the government, but that is not my point. No, the election is not going to be won or lost on this bill. No-one is going to change their voteâwhenever the election isâbecause of this, but I think the process will suffer. The party political system will be adversely affected. The standing of the major parties will suffer a setback. The flight to the minors will be enhanced and exaggerated, and that will not be a good thing. If the voters choose to vote for minor parties, that is of course their democratic right, but it is not a healthy sign if they do it because of disillusionment and protest.

Those are the things that cause me concern about this bill. The opposition will be opposing this legislation. My colleagues can put their own arguments and express their own approach to this. Many of them have given it a lot of consideration. Many of them served on the committee that made the recommendations, and they will wish to get up and espouse their own case. This is an important bill that we need to deal with. I regard it as an important bill. Therefore, on behalf of the opposition, I make it clear that we will be opposing this bill when, as I assume, we formally vote on it tomorrow morning.

talk.start.para: âI must admit that listening to the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) was an interesting exercise. He traversed through a heap of stuff which I did not even know was relevant. I am sure he meant well. Even though he was being very vague, and they tell me he is a very nice fellow when you get to know himâ
âThat's very patronising.

âHe was a Western Australian originally, so there is a chance of him being half decent. There is a little bit of hope for him. The speech by the member for Canberra was very waffly. I know he was trying to fill in his whole 25 or 30 minutes, but thank God he didn't!

speech.para: I am pleased to speak on this Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 , but I am going to be brief, because I am not going to cover that vast territory. That is not necessary. The aim of this bill is to expand the existing tax deductibility provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The first aspect of the expansion of the provisions of the act, reflected in this bill, that I will talk about will enable tax deductible donations to be made to Independent candidates and all other members on a similar basis. As the member for Canberra said, he is sure that this has made it even fairerâIndependent and minor party candidates can be party to this bill.

Under this bill Independent candidates and members will be able to receive, for the first time, small to medium tax deductible donations from the public. We do know that $100 was just a farce. This is more realistic. We know that there are many people who donate small amounts of money to candidates and political parties, but we also know that there are people who would like to donate more, and the carrot is that there is some form of defraying the cost of doing so.

Deductibility is one aspect which demonstrates that this government is serious about transparency. That is the whole key to this issue: the transparency, the accountability and the honesty which this government gives through this bill. Because Independents will benefit enormously from this bill, it also demonstrates that the government is being fair and demonstrates the equity with which it treats all partiesânot just its own, not just the major parties, but smaller parties and Independents. It represents equality of opportunity.

Another aspect of this bill is the provision to raise the tax deductibility ceiling, as I have also mentioned, to a sensible level. I am sure that even the member for Canberra, in his sadness about the message that it will send, will say that the general public will realise that this is sensible compared with the $100 which was just a token gesture, because we know that people are willing to donate a lot more. I will move on to that shortly. This is a significant amendment. Clearly, in the past, lower tax deductibility did not encourage individuals to donate financially to their political party of choice. But the ability to donate was always open to unions and in particular to the corporate sectorâso we are being balancedâwhich is larger and has more funds.

We are not saying that either party has a mortgage on who donates. We do know that the corporate sector is, by and large, the supporter of the conservative side of government, and we do know that the unions provide enormous amounts of money to the Labor Party. It is a fact of life. But for the individual to donate money to a political party simply was not a viable option, except perhaps for the more comfortably off who were not going to miss large amounts of money. This is where the public gets the perception that donating to political parties is somehow an activity which is not completely desirable or above board because it is almost limited to the larger sectors or the wealthier sectors. The individual was almost left out. It is little wonder that a large section of the public thinks that political donations are the province of the unions and the wealthyâthat they have a monopoly and somehow get an advantage out of this.

The fact that an individual will now receive more attractive tax treatment with this bill should not be seen as an attempt to buy votes from either side or buy favour from anybody involved but an attempt to level off the playing field. That is the point that needs to made: it does produce this more level situation for all involved.

By creating more of an incentive, or, rather, by removing a disincentive to donate, the bill spreads donations by the community far wider amongst individuals, corporations and, do not forget, as I said, the unionsâthe great collectors on behalf of those sitting opposite. It will also stop the reliance upon unions and business for money. This can only be a good thing for the perception of the public. We are talking about the member for Canberra's perception, so it is not just going to be in the province of those two people; it will encourage and involve more people in the public and the community.

This bill is a demonstration of the government's commitment to honesty in government, as we have seen before in the charter of budget honesty. You might recall that the opposition opposed this bill some time ago as they do not appear to be very supportive of bills which give credibility to the government's activities and restore the public's faith in the government's accountability. The member for Canberra said this is not in the national interest. I would have thought anything that was more open and more transparent was in the national interest. It was in that interest to see that fair play and equality were being displayed. I am quite surprisedâI must say I am very surprised in factâand the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) is not paying attention. He is a member of the joint committee which examined this matter and brought forward this recommendation.

The unbelievable thing is that this was a unanimous decision from that committee and now the member for Reid and his fellow members of the Labor Party have been rolled by the echelons of the Labor Party on this. They have been done. I think it is highly unusual for a committee to come up with recommendations, to support them unanimously and to walk into this chamber and get rolled. It just shows you where the power is in the party, and it is certainly not with the member for Reid. I am sure he would prefer to be down at the Grange tonight rather than here, but I am sure he is going to stand up and support his people who have told him which way to vote.

Anyway, what I find quite unusual is that the Labor candidate for Swan and Labor candidates all around Australia have been putting out in their mail: `Please donate to us to help us fight these elections.' What the opposition are now going to do is to say to the people who may donate to their candidates, `Look, sorry old son, we were going to support you to help ease the burden of you donating to this particular person, but because the member for Reid and his mates got rolled we cannot help you anymore, because we do not agree with the principle for some reason.' The principle that was being espoused by the member for Canberra was quite fallacious. There was not any substance to it, and he was talking about messages being sent to the public. I think the message being sent to the public is that the opposition flip-flop on these issues, depending on who is in chargeâwho has got to them at the last moment.

In this case, it seems to be an absolutely crazy sort of situation in that the opposition had one position a month or two ago, but we find out here tonight from the member for Canberra that they are not going to support it. The rest of the community will soon be able to decide who is being transparent and sensible here.

What I find interestingâand I oppose thisâis that I believe that the Labor Party is going around at the moment asking for $200 donations on behalf of their members, putting the money into the Labor Party and then giving it back to the wharfies. I ask the member for Reid: is that right? Are you collecting money on behalf of the wharfies? Will this be tax deductible? Will the opposition be ruling out the tax deductibility of this money? They are collecting money on behalf of the wharfies to prop up these poor people on $70,000 to $90,000 a year. Now they are saying, `Oh, this might not be able to be claimed because we are channelling it through the Labor Party and it might not be tax deductible now.' I am sure that the constituents of the member for Reid will not appreciate that.

talk.start.para: âIt's not deductible for that; you know that.
âYou are donating it to the Labor Partyâ
âOrder! The honourable member for Swan should make his remarks through the chair.

âThrough the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, they are donating these $200 donations to the Labor Party, and we know that they actually want to give it to the wharfies. I am a bit worried about the tax deductibility of the money they are talking about. As I said, by putting it through the taxation system it is transparent because it has an audit route and people can see what is happening to their funds. This government will not be targeting this practice because, as the member for Canberra said, all members, including opposition members, were supportive of it. The minor parties and the Independents were also supportive of it. They will be interested in receiving the funds that follow.

speech.para: I find it unusual that the Labor Party now say that they are not going to support something that is decent and open to the Australian public. Naturally, I support the bill because it is something that had all-party support. I believe it is something that we could take to the people of Australia and say, `This is open and transparent. You can see that it is a sensible graduation in terms of time moving on and the amounts of money being collected in political campaigns these days.'

talk.start.para: âI rise, as a member of the Labor opposition, to oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 . In doing so, I suggest to the House that this bill is about making it even easier for the Liberal Party to line their own pockets and get money from business. It is being pushed through now to give the Liberal Party an even bigger and more unfair advantage in the coming election campaign than it already has.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I am very reluctant to do this but the suggestion has been made that members of the Liberal Party, which presumably includes people in this House, propose to line their pockets with this bill. This is obviously not the intention of the bill. I suspect that, if the member for Batman thought through his remarks, that would not be the intention of his comments. But that is what he said, and I really do take some objection to it. I think it should be rephrased.
âFrom the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Batman, I did not read that into it. But I will listen very carefully to the honourable member for Batman.

âI appreciate that you are following the debate, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I think it is a very important debate. I understand why the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) is a bit sensitive about these issues.

speech.para: The recent disclosures to the Australian Electoral Commission by political parties of the donations which they have received makes for very interesting reading. The disclosures show that the coalition received $13.4 million in donations in the financial year 1996-1997. This is nearly 50 per cent more than the ALP received. What is interesting about the list of top donors to the coalition is that the source of this money is deliberately hidden. I must say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I think it is about time we had a bit of accountability with respect to donations by big business to the coalition government.

When you are in government you have to make decisions that affect the community and, more often than not, have an impact on the business activities of a range of companies both within Australia and beyond. I think in any normal democracy it is more than appropriate that transparency apply to donations to political parties. Otherwise, suggestions can be made that all is not above board and that particular companies are being given a rails run on some government decisions and, more importantly, not only might they potentially be given a rails run, but they may have made a secret donation in a clandestine way to the political coffers of the government of the day.

These issues are, I believe, the crux of the debate this evening. In that context, I refer to the fact that the three biggest donors to the coalition are associated entities. There are clandestine ways of hiding the donations which are given hand over fist by some in the business community, encouraged and support edâdoors opened in the processâby the Liberal Party's Treasurer, one Mr Ron Walker of Hudson Conway.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The honourable member for Batman is straying from the text of the bill, which relates to tax deductibility of donations and the limit of $1,500.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The issues I raise go straight to the crux of the bill: the question of tax deductibility, accountability and transparency. I think that is more than abundantly clear to anyone who is listening to the debate in an objective way. In that context, can I say that the clubs and foundations to which some of these donations might be made are being set up by the Liberal Party explicitly to enable individuals and companies to channel money to the Liberal Party in secret. This is the nature of the fundraising regime operating under so-called Honest John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia. The Liberal Party is deliberately and deceitfully exploiting loopholes in the Electoral Act. I can understand why the parliamentary secretary has tried so much to shut me up in respect of these issues.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the matters of which the member for Batman complains took place under the regime established by the former government. For him to bring in the Prime Minister and to make such allegations about conduct, firstly, I think offends standing orders 75 and 76 and, secondly, as you suggested earlier, seems to be quite outside the scope of this bill and, therefore, irrelevant to the debate and out of order.
âI ask the honourable member for Batman to direct his attention to the bill.

âI am, very much so, Mr Deputy Speaker. I remind the House that, when the Labor Party developed legislation aimed at ensuring such accountability, the coalition was found wanting when it came to supporting such initiatives. The current Prime Minister was part of the coalition government that made those treacherous decisions with respect to the Australian public. In that context, I believe the real intent of the government with respect to some potential changes and watering down of some of the current provisions is to try to assist in the laundering of funds. I suggest that it is deliberately setting out to thwart that act's intentions to make political donations transparent and subject to tight disclosure laws.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The standing orders prevent offensive statements. They prevent the casting of aspersions on motivations of members and so on. The member has suggested that this is about money laundering. Money laundering is a very serious accusation to make. It is a criminal offence under all sorts of statutes. This is what he is accusing the government of. I think it is quite out of order and should not be allowed.
âI did note the use of the word `laundering'. I am not quite certain which member that was directed at, but I ask the member for Batman to direct his attention specifically to the bill.

âI do not think what I said was directed at any member of the House. I talked about the Liberal Party as an entity being engaged in trying to facilitate laundering of funds, not individual members. I would ask that the parliamentary secretary listen to what is being said rather than imagine that I am in other than a proper way trying to expose potentially what might have gone on in the past or what they want to facilitate in the future.

speech.para: As I have said, the Liberal Party never has had and continues not to have any interest in keeping Australia's national government above a sense of accountability and removing it from any potential accusations of corruption with respect to the funding of elections. Its deceit does not end with the $500 club, the Cormack Foundation and the Free Enterprise Foundation. There is now a new body on the scene. Maybe the problem with the parliamentary secretary is that he has not been invited into the inner realms of that new body. I refer to the mysterious so-called Greenfields Foundation. Maybe the parliamentary secretary can enlighten me by making a contribution as to the background and the intent of the Greenfields Foundation. Or maybe you can enlighten me, Mr Deputy Speaker, as a member of the Liberal Party, even though you are a member of the Liberal Party on the way out.

The Greenfields Foundation is closely intertwined with known Liberal Party identities. The Greenfields Foundation has very generously given a massive $4.65 million loan to the Liberal Party in 1996-97. I would like to know what the going interest rate is with respect to that loan. The Australian public does not know the true source of this huge sum of money. It is quite a considerable amount of moneyâ$4.65 million, perhaps on the never neverâto the Liberal Party from a so-called Greenfields Foundation. They do, however, know that the loan enabled the Liberal Party to pay off its debts to the National Australia Bank for the cost of the 1996 election campaign. I wonder what other pay-offs have been involved in these transactions, with the Greenfields Foundation, the clubs and the other foundations because of the unwillingness of the Liberal Party to ensure transparency, accountability and public scrutiny of these secret operations.

The disclosure of this $4.65 million loan from unknown donors certainly caused a public scandal, with a range of newspapers reporting on it. For example, the Australian Financial Review had a range of articles entitled `Secret foundation look at taking donations'; `Liberals receive a $4.6 million secret loan'; `Liberals use $4.6 million loan to pay off NAB debt'. In the Canberra Times the headlines read `Minister won't detail Greenfields Foundation $4.6 million loan to Libs' and `Beazley slates Libs on use of donations loopholes'. I could go on, but the real intent of the media and the Australian publicâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! I do not think it would be within the standing orders to pursue that line. The bill, as is quite rightly addressed on the front of the bill, is a bill for an act to amend the law relating to taxation. The honourable member for Batman should speak to the bill.
âYes, Mr Deputy Speaker, it does go to the question of taxation, but it is also in the context of a broader debate which occurred with respect to accountability of donations to political parties.
âAnd its tax deductibility.

âAnd its tax deductibility, which is the point I made following your request to make sure that I focus on those issues. It was the very point I made in responding to you: the all important point of tax deductibility.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have thought in that context that the next piece of legislation concerning electoral donations and tax deductibility would have tried to reduce the potential for hidden private donations. Tax deductibility potentially means a loss of revenue for other government activities. We should not lose sight of that. It is not just a question of donations and of whether or not they are publicly accountable; tax deductibility also means that we are losing potential revenue for other government activities, such as employment services, health, education, the building of roads and railways, our international standing, our capacity to represent Australia overseas in important World Trade Organisation debates and negotiations about access to companies.

I would not have thought that the next piece of legislation would increase the scope for business to unduly influence the democratic process even more. Sadly, increasing the power of private interests to unduly influence the public process is exactly what the bill before the House does. The bill proposes amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. It would increase the maximum annual tax deductibility thresholds for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500. That I suppose pales into insignificance when you compare it with the loan by the Greenfields Foundation of $4.65 million to the Liberal Party in 1996-1997. But, for a lot of ordinary Australians, $1,500 is a considerable amount of money, especially for those on the growing queue of the long-term unemployed or the growing queue of unemployed youth in Australia at the moment.

The changes would allow companies to make tax deductible donations and would broaden the definition of donations to cover contributions as well as gifts. I assume that the parliamentary secretary understands the importance of that.

Yesterday in this place, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) ranted and raved about the fact that some trade unions make donations to the Australian Labor Party. The problem was that, in making that contribution, he failed to point out that these donations are up-front, fully, honestly and frankly disclosed under some of the most rigorous accounting requirements in place throughout the length and breadth of Australiaâvery rigorous accountability requirements and accounting processes set in place by legislation of this parliament. That is in contrast, despite the debate about tax deductibility, to the much larger hidden sums paid by shadowy sources into the parliamentary secretary's party's coffers.

The minister also failed to point out that no trade union contributes large enough funds to make the top 50 donors to Australian political parties. The ALPâand it is fairly important when you consider the potential impact of this change with respect to the tax deductibility of donationsâattracted only 10 per cent of the largest financial contributions made to political parties in 1996-97.

It is clear who the big winners are from unaccountable, undemocratic loopholes in the laws governing political donations. I do not think the changes with respect to the tax deductibility embodied in the bill before us this night are actually going to facilitate overcoming those hidden opportunities. I suppose that is why the Liberal Party is, as it has always been, the party overwhelmingly supported by capital. It is certainly no friend to the battler. It is beholden to big business, as its support of the GST shows. I wonder about the impact of tax deductibility, for example, on a major company such as Amcor, whose chairman, one Mr Stan Wallis, is currently very intimately involved with the federal government.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I do not know that the member is speaking to the bill in this respect.
âI am going to some of the donations and the potential impact of this change in tax deductibility on these corporate donationsâtotally in order.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This bill gives tax deductibility on donations up to $1,500. How can the statement that we anticipate the member for Batman will make on this subject possibly be within the standing orders? It has nothing to do with the $1,500 tax deductibility limit that is under consideration.
âI will be directing my attention to the remarks that the honourable member for Batman makes in respect of the statement he just made. I will be listening carefully to it.

âAs I understand it, there is some concern in the corporate world that the $1,500 tax deductibility limit is not as high as they wanted. That is evident when you actually look at some of those donations. For example, with respect to Amcorâof which Mr Stan Wallis is out there currently rallying up big business support to back financially the GST campaign of the Prime Ministerâ$1,500 would be a bit short when you consider the following donations. In 1992-93, for example, Amcor donated $100,000 to the coalition, and to the Australian Labor Party it donated $30,000.
âThe member for Batman is going well outside the limit of the bill, which speaks of a $1,500 limit on deductions.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It must be in order to argue whether or not a measure in a bill is appropriate. It may be inappropriate because of its being set at too high or too low a level. What the member is doing is exploring why this particular proposal does not deserve the support of this House and giving instances of issues that are relevant to it.
âThe honourable member for Batman should direct his attention to the content of the bill, which is very precise in its undertaking and its administration.

âI want to explore the potential impact of this bill in a wide-ranging way because the Australian public is listening to this debate and they are concerned about the potential impact of the bill. They know that there is nothing whatsoever wrong with supporting a demand that the opposition actually demand accountability with respect to donations to the government of the day. That is why I suggest to the House that this bill clearly proves that the coalition parties have made no commitment to cleaning up the Electoral Act.

speech.para: I can assure the House that the Labor Party has this commitment. We will continue our campaign to close the loopholes in the law which are now being exploited by the unscrupulous coalition government. For example, take Amcor's 1996-97 donation to the coalition of $135,000 against its donation to the Australian Labor Party of $40,000. I think the coalition ought to properly explain whether or not any other donations by a company such as Amcor are given through some of those other secret arrangements they have in place such as the Greenfields Foundation.

For that very reason, we will continue our campaign to close the loopholes. We will endeavour to stop the Liberal Party flouting the electoral disclosure laws. We will ensure tight and transparent laws regulating disclosure of political donations rather than opening the floodgates further, as this bill seeks to do.

I understand the need for accountability. It is not just donations to political parties that concern the Australian public but also, I suppose, discounts given to politicians and whether or not those discounts are potentially tax deductible. I refer to an interesting article on page 6 of the Herald Sun of 7 May 1996 which reports on a $43,000 discount given by Hudson Conway to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. It also reports that not long after that discount was given the actual apartment was worth $75,000 moreâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The member for Batman is straying well outside the terms of this legislation.

âThank you for drawing my attention to ensuring that there is full accountability and disclosure in this House, the people's house, with respect not only to tax deductibility of donations but also to secret discounts given to ministers of the government. As I said, the bill is attracting a lot of public attention. It is not just about tax deductibility; it is about accountability. It is about ensuring that secret donations become fully accountable and transparent to the Australian public.

speech.para: The Australian public has had enough of secret arrangements in foundations such as the Greenfields Foundation or the free enterprise club. They want to know that what is on the table is there for the public to see, that there are no secret donations and secret arrangementsânods and winksâby which people will benefit. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) made a curious speech, but it had nothing to do with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 and it certainly had almost nothing to do with the reality of donations to political parties in this country.

speech.para: I am reminded of Bob Menzies' final press conference where he was asked by a cheeky journalist, `What do you have to say, Prime Minister, about the powerful interests which have controlled you through your political career?' and he said, `How dare you bring my wife into this.' Listening to the member for Batman, one would think that the Liberal Party was being manipulated by some kind of shadowy business interests. It is not true, it never has been true and it certainly is not going to be true whilst ever I have anything to do with the Liberal Party.

This bill is about increasing the tax deductibility of political donations from $100 a year to $1,500. It is not about vast corporate donations, absolutely not, and it is not about non-disclosure. The Liberal Partyâthis governmentâperfectly supports the disclosure principle and we are not seeking at all to increase the tax deductibility beyond $1,500. Sure, as the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) said, this measure will have the effect of increasing, in a sense, public subsidy towards political parties, but it will have the effect of supporting all political parties, as the member for Canberra had the grace and decency to accept in his speech.

What the member for Canberra neglected to point out was that it was the former Hawke Labor government which first brought in public funding for political parties. It was the Hawke Labor government which brought in a public funding regime which now, I think, ensures that about $40 million per election campaign go to the various political parties. What we have here is a serious attempt at double standards by members opposite.

The member for Canberra said with a degree of sincerity that measures like this bring the parliament and politicians into disrepute. I do not think measures like this bring the parliament into disrepute. I think what brings the parliament into disrepute is the kind of cheap smear that we have just had from the member for Batman. The member for Batman tried to suggest that politiciansâmembers of this parliament, ministers in this government and presumably ministers in governments generallyâare susceptible to improper influence from people who buy that influence by making donations to political parties. That simply is not true. Members opposite who have been members of governments know that donations are made from all sorts of sources.

talk.start.para: âYou live in cloud cuckoo land.
âThe honourable member for Banks shall cease interjecting.

âAnd it does not, in any way, compromise the integrity of governmental processes. The member for Batman pointed out that Amcor donated $135,000 to the Liberal Party in the last electoral cycle and he also pointed out that that self-same company donated $40,000 to the Labor Partyâthe Labor government. Is the member for Batman suggesting that that $40,000 bought government decisions? I hope he is not. I do not suggest that it did, but if the $40,000 which Amcor gave to the Labor Party did not buy government decisions, why is the member for Batman degrading and debasing this House and his colleagues in this House by suggesting that $135,000 does buy the Liberal Party? It just is not true. The member for Batman knows it and he demeans himself by making these sorts of statements.

speech.para: As the member for Banks has been interjecting across the table, democracy does not come cheap. Any of us who have been involved in election campaigns know just how dearly bought democracy is these days. It probably costs upwards of $20 million for the major political parties to run their campaigns. In a marginal seat, it probably costs something like $100,000 to $200,000 to run a campaign. It is an enormous amount of money which has to be raised from somewhere. Let's face it, healthy political parties are the muscle and sinew of an effective Westminster style democracy. This bill is designed to ensure that all political parties have the wherewithal with which to continue.

Let us consider for a moment what may well be the real motivation behind some of the contributions of members opposite. Why are they so hostile to this whole idea of tax deductibility of donations to political parties? The simple truth is that the Labor Party receives vast amounts of money from the trade union movement. The trade union movement, as far as I am aware, is essentially organised on a not for profit basis and therefore the union movement does not pay tax. In other words, the Labor Party's donors do not pay tax; the Liberal Party's donors, by and large, do pay tax. This is a simple measure on the part of members opposite to try to hamstring one side of politics. It is quite transparent in that sense. If members opposite want to object to this bill, by all means let them do so, but let them be open and up front. Let them be as transparent about their motivations as they wish donations to political parties to be.

ALP members of the standing committee that made this recommendation got it right. They understand how politics really works. They know the need for incentives to be given to people to donate to political parties. They understand that this measure is something which is necessary to benefit the politi cal process generally. They got it right. Why are members opposite now getting it so wrong? Why have members opposite abandoned the decency and the conscientious convictions of their colleagues on this committee? I can only assume that with an election imminent they are getting desperate.

talk.start.para: âAt the outset, I express my strong support for one ingredient of this legislation, and that is the funding for independent candidates. Unfortunately, as we are quite aware at the moment, the public is distrustful of politicians in general. Whilst I do not condone people leaving major parties out of self-interest rather than because of ideological or very fundamental policy differences, it has been inequitable and it has been unfair that funding has been allocated to the major political parties alone. If we are talking about democracy, if we are talking about the representation of people and giving them options in regard to democracy, it is more than reasonable that those candidates who are Independents receive funding. We know we have had some representatives, like the previous member for North Sydney, who have made fairly major contributions both at a federal and a state level in regard to the public knowledge of politicians and the exposure of some of the things that actually do concern the public. I want to very strongly support that ingredient of the legislation, because it is something that not only is necessary but also will give confidence to the Australian electorate that the system is not totally controlled by power brokers at the top and that funding is not totally at the behest of the self-interest of the major political parties.

speech.para: In regard to the overall thrust of this legislation, I think there is a very fundamental flaw in it. The nearest thing I can remember to this attempt is collusion between the Liberal, National and Labor parties in the state parliament of New South Wales in regard to increased superannuation payments when that was debated in the middle of the night. This legislation comes through at the end of the budget process, with a total focus upon that and the Queensland elections. It is being put in here today in the last days of this particular session and, quite frankly, it is of concern in a very real sense. I for one am very pleased, as a member of the relevant committee, that the party has been persuaded to oppose this legislation. We should have opposed it from the beginning. What has changed the focus in our party has been the revelations in regard to the Greenfields Foundation, which certainly became very public after the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

I should put on the public record that the figure of $1,500 was essentially a compromise. There has not been too much coverage by government speakers tonight of the original proposal of the government parties. They were not looking for $1,500; they looking for $10,000. That was the proposal of the parties opposite. Tonight when they say to us, `Oh well, $1,500 is not too much,' this is only the foot in the door.

talk.start.para: âYou guys made it $100.
âI am not disputing $100; I think it is quite reasonable.
âThat was the first foot in the door.

âThe smart comment over here is that there is some analogy, some comparison, between a person in this country giving $100 and a person in Granville, Guildford or Merrylands giving $10,000. There would not be a person in my electorate who would think about giving $1,000, let alone $10,000. To say that that $100 was basically a big step towards what the Liberal Party proposed is wrong. They proposed that corporationsâwe are extending it to companies hereâshould be able to deduct $10,000. I think that gives the lie to this thrust tonight that this is only a minor gradation or a minor increase, that you really do not have to be disturbed; it is not aimed at the corporate sector, it is not aimed at allowing heavy corporate inputs.

speech.para: Let us look at the pattern of donations. In an article entitled `The Big Tilt' in the magazine The American Prospect of May-June 1997 we see the reality of campaign funding. This applies to Australia as well as to the United States. It reads:

The 3 percent of the sample with family incomes over $125,000 are responsible for 4 percent of the votes, 5 percent of the protest, 6 percent of the contacts with members, 8 percent of the hours devoted to campaigning and fully 35 percent of the money contributed.
In other words, the wealthiest three per cent contribute 35 percent of election donations. It continues:

At the other end of the income scale are the 19 percent of the sample with family incomes under $15,000. They are responsible for only 14 percent of the votes, 13 percent of the hours volunteered in the campaigns and 12 percent each of the contacts and protests. And when it comes to making electoral contributions, they are barely visible, donating only 2 percent of campaign dollars.

So the fact of life is that the average person really does find it a struggle to make any contribution. I have not seen any comparative figures in this countryâI do not think they have been constructedâbut the poorest 19 per cent in America, a big percentage of the population, are giving two per cent of donations.

I referred in a previous contribution to an article in the Economist which says that a fundamental problem in regard to electoral funding is that it is always catch-up politics. Quite clearly, in this country we always have a problem of catch-up politics, catching up to the last conspiracy of the coalition parties. We know that we have constantly had to adjust electoral funding laws in this country. We had to go through the process of associated entities. We had to tackle the legislation, look at it again, because what they were doing was basically having a company or a foundation, call it what you will, over in left field that supposedly had nothing to do with the Liberal Party, regardless of how close the personnel were, how close the post office boxes were, how close the phone numbers were and regardless of people's careers previously in the Liberal Party. It was said to be just a coincidence that all these connections were there, that they had nothing to do with the Liberal Party, yet we find them making very substantial massive donations to the coalition and more particularly the Liberal Party.

There had to be reform of the legislation, there had to be changes and there had to be catch-up politics. This is the constant story in this country's electoral funding legislationâ once you close one loophole, they have found another way through. The latest thing is that they say that someone walked up to them and gave the Liberal Party a $4.6 million loan.It was nothing to do with Liberal Party, no connectionsâsomeone just gave them a loan.

Let's be serious. The Australian public knows that this is just the latest methodâthe latest manoeuvre, the latest subterfugeâto undermine public scrutiny of electoral funding in this country. This is a situation where the public wants to know if a party has a philosophy of subcontracting out or wants to sell out large sectors of government. This is supposedly driven by ideology, and when you get to these funding laws you question whether it is really ideology rather than an IOU. We hear about those kinds of government practices in the defence area every second day, where they want to basically sack people in the Australian defence forces and subcontract, sublet or contract out. One has to question whether part of this is driven by these unknown donors.

The only reason ever heard for thisâand it is quite surprising that there are not a few other reasonsâis that people are too scared to be made public. Supposedly they are going to be somehow victimised by the union movement or whatever. I do not know of any other reasons why it has to be so secretive. We have a minister hereâhe is a bit down in the dumps these daysâwho said that he changed the laws of this country on industrial relations so that industrial disputation would be reduced. Essentially it was all solved, everyone could have individual contracts and the power of the unions was broken. One has to question why, in the context of his major successes and his ability to clamp down on the union movement, they are still trying to have constant secrecy by setting up foundations and manoeuvres in a way that the Australian public can have no knowledge of who is donating to them.

Why is there such secrecy? Why can't we say if there is a decision about the Australian mineral industry or if parts of social security are going to be contracted out and the private operators brought in? Why can't we say that the labour hire companies are going to come in? Patrick Stevedores and the National Farmers Federation are going to basically come into the waterfront. Why can't the public know, in their consideration of this policy, this legislation and this government position, that there is a possibilityâeven though it may be erroneousâthat there was some influence brought to bear in relation to that decision making?

We are seeing a widening of the availability of people to donate very substantial amounts of money. We could see a scenario whereby large corporations allow a number of executives or people intimately connected with their company to go to dinners or other fundraising events and to claim it individually. Essentially we are talking about a series of indirect donations by the same entity. They are getting to a situation, with 10 of them, where they can deduct $15,000âeven more than what the Liberal Party intended in the first place. This is a sham attempt to get $10,000 deductible.

This legislation is very much a concern. If the government is losing too much sleep about the fact that some Labor Party members on this committee have got a different point of view as to when the matter was discussed, I put to you that the $1,500 was a compromise at that stage in regard to a government thrust for a preposterous level of $10,000.

The decision has to be seen in the context of the very public revelations about the Greenfields Foundation: that the opposition cannot trust this government in relation to electoral funding in this country. It is something that we should be able to sort out together. We should be able to say that the public has a right to know. It is going to further undermine public confidence, it is going to make people ask why this legislation was brought in, it is going to allow corporate donors to have a bigger say about policy and it is going to let them have a bigger impact in relation to both political parties. Let's be honest about it. There is a possibility they are going to be encouraged to give greater donations in this way.

Also, $15 million is going towards this, and this is in the context of the constant whingeing complaints of the government that they do not do this or that in this country any longer because they were left such a mess by the previous government. Here is a chance to avoid wasting $15 million on an exercise that is designed to increase the possibility of corporations calling the tune in a variety of policy areas. This money could be spent elsewhere. It is an undesirable move; it was part of a broader government thrust. When they bemoan the fact that Labor has moved off about this position, I want to remind the government members of this committee that, if we go back through the committee's proceedings, there are a lot of other very popular recommendations in regard to voluntary voting and other radical changes to our voting system which are aimed to cushion the government's electoral possibilities that they have abandoned in the light of day.

talk.start.para: âBefore I make my remarks on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 , I would like to advise the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) that, if the government really wanted to save money, it would abandon public funding of elections. If you added that to the $15 million, there would be something there.
âPublic funding is about honesty and integrity in office.

âIn that case, tax deductibility is another way of going about it and it might be said to be the same. This bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible contributions of $2 or more to registered political partiesâincluding those registered under state or territory legislationâup to a maximum level of $1,500 annually; to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible gifts to Independent candidates and membersâalso up to maximum level of $1,500 annuallyâand to allow deductibility for donations made by companies.

speech.para: These amendments will implement part of the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the JSCEM, on the 1996 federal election. The amendments are proposed to apply to contributions and gifts made from 1 July 1998.

As an Independent member of this House and an Independent candidate at the next election, Iâor, more accurately, donors to my campaignsâclearly have an interest in this bill. As the law stands, donations to my campaigns and to the campaigns of my Independent colleagues cannot be deducted for tax purposes. The same also applies to Independent members in state parliaments. They along with all other candidates at an election must surely, as a matter of justice and equity, be in the same position as their main opponents, who are usually drawn from the ranks of the major parties.

I have submitted to this House during other debates that it is a matter of simple equity that any donors to my campaignâprovided the donations do not exceed the limit stipulated for registered political parties, which is currently $100âshould benefit from tax deductibility. The present situation is something of an anachronism. It is understandable that, prior to the recommendation of the JSCEM and the introduction of this bill, it has not been in the minds of the major parties to ensure that donations to the campaigns of Independents should benefit from tax deductibility. I believe that, if the issue had not been pressed by me or by one of my Independent colleagues, it is likely thatâeven though what my colleagues and I submitted to the JSCEM and have urged before this House is fair and justâit would never have been dealt with in this place.

The present government certainly recognised the inequity, even though it took its time about rectifying it. On 20 October 1997, during question time I asked the Treasurer (Mr Costello) whether he agreed that an inequity existed in the treatment of tax deductibility for political donations. I then asked the Treasurer whether he concurred with the recommendation of the JSCEM that the inequity be rectified. The response of the honourable gentleman was to concede that I had what he described as a `conceptual point'. I differ with him on thatâit is far from conceptual. He said:
I suppose you could say at a conceptual level that there should be an equivalence of treatment.
I am pleased to see that the government's in-principle agreement has now taken solid form.

But a further inequity regarding Independent candidates persists. It is indistinguishable in the underlying logic from tax deductibility for donations to Independent candidates' campaign funds. Section 304A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provides that each candidate in an election shall disclose details of all gifts above a value of $200 that he or she has receivedâand substitute `campaigns' for that if you wishâduring the disclosure period for an election. For House of Representatives elections the same rules apply to all candidates, regardless of whether they are endorsed by a registered political party. So far, so fair.

However, gifts may of course also be made to registered political parties and not to individual candidates. At the end of a financial year, a registered political party must lodge a return setting out amounts received by the party during the previous year. However, if the total of all gifts received by the party from one person or organisation is less than $1,500, the party is not required to include the particulars of that donation in its return.

Clearly, a candidate who is endorsed by a registered political party does not really need to receive and account for campaign gifts in the same way that an Independent candidate does. Indeed, if a party candidate does receive a qualifying donation, the amount is usually not declarable because almost invariably the obligation to do that accrues to the relevant political party. Also, endorsed candidates will have money spent on their behalf by their party.

So it is that donations to Independents are required to be identifiable as being to individual campaigns whereas those who donate to the campaign funds of individual endorsed party candidates are not so identifiable, because the sums received are included in a consolidated return lodged by the respective party headquarters. Therefore, the source of a donation to an endorsed party candidate of up to $1,499 will not be identifiable as such and not even declared, but donations to Independent campaigns of $200 or more must be declared. Since the government has shown, through the words of the Treasurer and by its action in introducing this bill, that it is concerned about equivalence of treatment of endorsed and Independent candidates, I trust that it will take steps necessary to rectify this other anomaly.

It must be assumed that disclosure rules are there for a good reason. However, the source of a donation to an endorsed party candidate of up to $1,499 will not have to be declared, but donations of $200 or more to Independent campaigns must be. There is no reason why all candidates should not be treated equally in terms of the disclosure requirements. I suggest that either the threshold above which all candidates are required to disclose gifts should be raised from $200 to the $1,500 limit applying to political parties or the threshold for political parties should be lowered to the level imposed on donations to the campaign funds of Independent candidates. I suspect the latter would not find favour with the parties, but they cannot refute the equity of the principle involved.

In closing, I congratulate the government on the introduction of these changes to the tax deductibility for donations to the campaigns of Independents and I urge that very same government to consider commensurate measures to rectify the other inequities in the electoral laws to which I have referred. To that end, tax legislation is not the appropriate instrument. It would indeed be an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

talk.start.para: âI rise to oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 . But before I get into the detail of the bill I cannot help noticing that in this experiment with putting the Hansard reporters around the place they are in the far back row of the press gallery tonight. Frankly, Hansard are in a different position to the pressâthey report accurately. And they fix our mistakes; they do not amplify them. I look forward to the day when Hansard are in their proper place on the floor of the House, at the table where they should always beâwhere history and convention dictate they should be. I say that for the benefit of listeners.

speech.para: I come to this debate as someone who served on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters during my first six years in the parliamentâfrom 1990 to 1996. I enjoyed my time on that committee. I am not on the current parliamentary committee; I am on three other parliamentary committees and as shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs I have my hands full. But this debate is important and that is why I feel compelled to speak. The bill that we are debating is a scam. It is a scam on the taxpayers. It is a scam that was introduced very late into this parliamentary sessionâon 28 May 1998. If this bill goes through it is going to cost the taxpayers some $45 million dollars in the space of three yearsâ$18 million in 1999-2000, $12 million in 2000-01 and $15 million in 2001-02. Those figures are on page 1 of the explanatory memorandum in relation to this bill.

I can think of many better things to do with $45 million over three years. The money could certainly be spent in the area of indigenous health or education instead of lining the pockets of donors to political parties. I was on the parliamentary committee that recommended the current position, which is a vastly different position. It allows tax deductions to an annual level of $100. Some of us had reservations back when we were debating that, but one of the reasons we relented was that $100 is not a large amount. A $100 deduction may encourage people to join political parties. The membership of political parties can be tax deductible. That is part of the political process and it can be done at little cost to the public.

But this is a scam allowing tax deductibility to the amount of $1,500. It is interesting to note that before the parliamentary committee the Liberal Party recommended an amount of $10,000 be tax deductible. Frankly, this is a fundraising scam on the part of the government for their corporate mates. They have the Freedom Foundation and the 500 Club. We cannot even find out where the $4.5 million loan to pay off the NAB debt came from. Under this proposal they can get their corporate mates to pay $1,500 a head for dinner and not only do they get their feed and their speech from our ever diminishing Prime Minister (Mr Howard), but their $1,500 fee for the fundraiser is tax deductible. That is red hot.

I do not want the best politicians money can buy. I do not want to go down the American path or the Japanese road. There is corruption in those systems. Some might argue that this is an anti-corruption measure. It is not an anti-corruption measure. It is putting the weights on particular sections of the community to come along and cough up at taxpayers' expense. It is an arm twisting exercise for the apparatchiks and the bagmen.

Senator Minchin, the Special Minister of State, who has carriage of this matter, is one of the few competent ministers in this government. It is his ideology that worries me. In terms of the republic, he is the minister against the republic. In terms of native title, he is the minister to tear down native title. In this area he is the minister to get them re-elected. That is what this is about. It is a scam to apply from 1 July 1998 to allow the Liberal Party to get involved in a fund raising venture with their business mates at taxpayers' expense.

A better and more transparent way of doing it is in relation to what is happening at the moment. In the last parliament there were recommendations and the various political parties got funding to the level of the votes they receivedânot only in the House of Representatives but also in the Senateâand it was equitable. Lest it be thought this is a bean counting measure, I have no problem with the public funding of political campaigns provided there is transparency in the campaigns, consistency and principles. Donating to political parties is fine, but there should be disclosure mechanisms, not tax deductibility mechanisms. I have no problem with people donating whatever amount of money it is for political parties to follow their political philosophy. But those donations should not be made tax deductible to the extent that this government seeks to make them. I note with regard to my friend the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) that I was disappointed that even the ALP members had recommended this $1,500. But it was a compromise because the government was seeking $10,000 tax deductibility.

If you have a problem with funds let us have some transparency and uniformity. This is the way to do it: if you want to increase the amount by the price of a postage stamp, that is a more principled way of doing it. I do not want it said that we started this by allowing that figure of $100 to be a tax deduction. That is in a different league. In relation to membership fees it is a minuscule sort of amount that does allow Independents and other minor parties to do some fundraising.

But this is a scam. You could have a bit of intimidation of employees of large companies, your SES service and a whole range of things. In relation to this campaign you have whole levels of staffers, consultants and SES officers that you can exploit. In goes the $1,500 and it is tax deductible. So you have the whip-around. The party apparatchiks, by putting a levy of $1,500 on staffers, or whatever, can create a whole new scam that is underwritten by the taxpayer. That is how they do it. When they increase the size of donations before it is allowed to be disclosed, you spread the money. You get companies purchasing a series of tickets for their employees. That is why this is not the proper way to do it.

I do not think there is a shortfall for this government, because it attracts every spiv and carpetbagger and the white shoe brigade with its policies. We are flogging off our assets. Who is getting them? The poor old NAB helped the government write off its debt and what was going to happen? They were going to get access to the super funds but that hit the fence in the Senate the other week. That is what worries me about thisâthe self-interest of it. It is the best backed horse in the race for this government. It is about downsizing. It is the same here; it is for their mates. This is about tax deductibility for the mates of the tories. There will be a whip-around at the Melbourne Club and all the others. Frankly, if they have a commitment to the tories, then they can donate their fifteen hundred bucks without getting tax deductibility. I would rather that money go to the unemployed or to maintain child care.

I repeat: $45 million over three years, an average of $15 million a year of taxpayers' money, and that is just an estimate. It is untenable. That is why a bit of sanity prevailed here. When this matter came before the parliamentary party and the caucus we did not have any trouble saying: `We are not going to go along with this scam.' On a number of occasions there has been cross-party support in relation to electoral matters and we have copped criticism from the pressâsome right, some wrong. I think we probably have one of the better electoral systems in this country, with compulsory voting, public funding and a whole range of things. The Australian Electoral Commission is probably second to none. But there comes a time when enough is enough. This is the area where a line has to be drawn in the sand because it is pretty obvious that there is incrementalism with this government. We will go to $1,500, then it will be $10,000 or whatever.

If people want to kick in fifteen hundred bucks to the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, then let them do it at their expenseâno strings attached. The taxpayer already underwrites our electoral system in terms of funding. That is worked out on a proper formula and the Democrats, Independents and others are looked after. I support that system. I do not want to have to go cap in hand as a member of parliament around the labour movement or anywhere else to put the weights on to get the $1,500 for a special dinner or whatever. It is wrong. It is not necessary.

Indeed, that is what worries me about this government. They talk about transparency, they talk about value for the dollar, a whole range of things, but not when it comes to self-interest. And that is what this is about, self-interest for the big end of town, so they can have the whip-around with their mates because only their mates can come across with the $1,500. The labour movement is struggling to keep the jobs of its constituency at the moment. Those on the factory floor are losing their jobs. It is middle and senior management and the senior executive service whose salaries are going through the roofâthe bosses. This is a bosses' clause. It is a clause for the rich, who are so mean-spirited that they cannot kick in fifteen hundred bucks for the tories without the taxpayer turning it into a tax deduction. That is the problem with our tax system. All the spivs and carpetbaggers and family trusts are in there right up to their necks with this governmentâtax minimisation, tax avoidance. This is consistent with the philosophy of the tories.

talk.start.para: âWhat's this about? R&D syndication?

âThe minister at the tableâor the parliamentary secretary, I am sorry; he is not a real minister, he is a parliamentary secretary, who is entitled to the position as he is a pen pusher and signs his nameâtalks about R&D. I will tell you what R&D did. It encouraged investment. They are not the mates of the Labor Party. R&D is about jobs. There is no incentive. The government do not need tax deductibility if their policies are working for their side of town. They would be lining up to give them fifteen hundred bucks without tax deductibility. It shows how bad this government and this Prime Minister are going when they need the incentive of tax deductibility to get fifteen hundred bucks out of their mates. Because that is what this is about. Their mates are so mean-spirited and always looking to minimise tax that they are not prepared to kick in the fifteen hundred bucks. They want the taxpayer to underwrite itâsocialise your losses, the agrarian socialists in the National Party. It is just not consistent that a conservative government, worried about taxpayers' dollars, worried about transparency, says one thing and does another.
âThis was a unanimous report.

âThe parliamentary secretary at the table talks about a unanimous report. What is the position? Are we as a parliamentary party and as a caucus supposed to accept all the parliamentary reports? I listened to my good friend the member for Reid and he says it was basically a compromise. I know his views. I know my views. When I was on the parliamentary committee this would not have got past first base.

speech.para: The decision of the parliamentary party, which is the right one, is that we are not going along with this scam. And it is a scam. If you want your mates to donate $1,500 for your next election, then do not worry about getting the taxpayer to underwrite itâgo out and do the hard yards. If you go out there and tell them how good your policies are and do it on a policy basis, you will not need tax deductibility. But they need it because they have nothing to offer the electorate or their constituencies, except another scam to minimise tax.

talk.start.para: âLow interest rates, no debt.

âAgain, I will respond to the parliamentary secretary because he talks about low interest rates. They are a vote of no confidence in this government because they have comatosed the economy. Interest rates now have to go down because they have to breathe life into the corpse that this government has created. It is not about saying, `Look how great interest rates are.' You have to have a job to be able to have a mortgage to pay off a house. I would have thought unemployment would have been the big one.

speech.para: We have this feigned indignation by those on the other side of the House. This is $45 million of taxpayers' money. We had a scam of a special auditor for ATSIC because we had all of these allegations of indigenous organisations wasting the money or whatever. The Federal Court threw the special auditor out three-nil. But what did it show? That the overwhelming majority of those organisations were honest; there was no corruption there. They needed some assistance in training. There was a problem with red tape. But there is always a scam in it in terms of this government. You do not look at it on its merits. The parliamentary secretary is so effective that the Burnie workers lost their jobs today! That is how much the bosses listen to him.

It is a pleasure to get up and oppose this because this typifies the choice at the next election. Only a conservative government could bring this sort of stuff into the parliament with a straight face. We are engaged in a struggle, and it is a class struggle at the moment. It is only their supporters who can afford the $1,500 to kick in for the tax deduction. That is what it is aboutâtheir mates. This is a bill for their mates.

This country has a big choice at the next election and it really is about which direction we are taking our country in. We have an ever-diminishing Prime Minister. This is about this government using the advantage of office, attempting to use the tax system for their benefit. I say: if you want transparency in the arrangement then do it on a per voter basis. If you want to increase the level of donation to a political parties, do it. Test your strength in terms of the votes that you can attract. That is transparent, it is principled and it is uniform. But this backroom deal where we are going to give tax deductibility so that the party apparatchiks can go out and bend everyone's elbow to get them to kick in the $1,500 is all this will encourage. That is not transparent and that is not good for the system because it makes us, as parliamentary representatives, prisoners. That is why I believe in the principle of public funding because, as parliamentarians, we do not want the best parliamentarians that money can buy, and that is what this is about. Senator Minchin has been the architect of this. He is a competent minister but a party apparatchik whose brief is to get the government re-elected at minimum cost to the tories. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill is a sinister try-on and follows an ambit claim in the committee which considered it in the first place. I thought that the member for Banks (Mr Melham) covered the issues extremely well and set out in a very stark way the sorts of choices that are in front of us. But I did want to take issue with one of the points he was making. He was expressing the view that this shows that the rich are mean-spirited and too lousy to make a donation to the Liberal Party without the incentive of a tax deduction. I would suggest that it is really not so much a reflection on those who are well to do but rather a reflection on the Liberal Party that it is unable to attract donations on any other basis. Indeed, why would you? Why would you give them even a hundred dollars? But why would you give them $1,500 without the tax deductibility when you have a government which has been so incompetent and has made such a mess of the major issues confronting this nation that it has become a laughing stock?

speech.para: We have seen the nursing home accommodation fiasco, we have seen the way they have handled waterfront reform, we have seen the superannuation debacle with the government in there ringbarking the superannuation tree that Labor planted, we have seen a cabinet in disarray, we have seen the travel rorts, and we have seen more ministers go and more cabinet attrition than we have seen since the Stalin cabinet in the 1920s. So if you are a well-to-do person you might be excused, without the incentive of tax deductibility, for saying, `No, I do not think I will make a contribution to this government. I really do not think that it represents money well spent.'

This bill proposes a number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is intending to increase the maximum annual tax deductibility threshold for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500, a 15-fold increaseâa major increase by any yardstick. Secondly, and just as importantly, it proposes to allow companies to make tax deductible donations. You might think that it is no bad thing for individuals to make donations and to contribute to the democratic process, but the idea that companies contribute to the democratic process and that they have some interest which ought to be reflected by according them tax deductibility is not something that I can support.

The bill proposes to broaden the definition of `donation' to cover contributions as well as gifts. It proposes to bring donations to independent candidates in line with political parties and it proposes to allow for tax deductible donations to be made to political parties registered under state or territory electoral legislation. It is proposed to come into effect from 1 July this yearâvery soon, very quickly and very conveniently, one might suspect, from the point of view of a government which seems all too intent on a dash for the polls before too long.

As earlier speakers in the debate have made plain, this is an essentially political issue. The considerations which are at stake here are political ones. We have a government which is seeking to gain political advantage for itself. The bill has been introduced on the eve of an election. The government is endeavouring to ram it through on that election eve to assist it in its election efforts and for no other reason. Indeed, the government's second reading speech sums up why we ought to be opposing this bill. It makes reference to:

. . . an increase in the threshold will encourage small to medium donations, thereby increasing the number of Australiansâincluding companiesâinvolved in the democratic process and reducing a political party's reliance on a small number of large donations.
So the government's intention is absolutely plain. The government's intention is that the Liberal and National parties ought to be advantaged in the coming election.

The budget figures also give the game away. There are indications in the budget figures that this measure will cost $15 million. On a rough and ready assessment of that, the government is looking to have some $45 million donated via this processâvia the donations loophole which has opened through this processâat the expense of the taxpayer. It is always interesting to come in here and hear the government say, `Look, the tax system has had it. It's full of holes, so we've got to bring in a GST. Too bad for the poor old retired people who are going to have to pay more on their food and more on the essentials of life, but the tax system has had it. There are too many leaks; we can't plug them all,' and here it is opening up the loophole for tax deductibility for donations by companies.

Let us have a look at where the donations from companies, aided by a tax deductibility, might go. I refer to evidence brought forward for the 1996-97 financial year concerning donations. These were reported in a couple of places, including the Herald Sun and the Financial Review. The report in the Herald Sun was clear enoughâ`Corporate Australia has thrown its financial weight behind the Liberal Party'. Official figures released showed that the coalition attracted nearly $27 million in 1996-97 compared to the Labor Party's $19 million. When you look at a lot of the companies and trusts involved, the difference is very severe indeed. For example, the ANZ Bank donated $125,000 to the Liberal Party and $20,000 to the Labor Party. Amcor donated $130,000 to the Liberal Party and $40,000 to the Labor Party. Hoyts donated $51,000 to the Liberal Party and $12,5000 to the Labor Party. They were modest compared to Village Roadshow. Village Roadshow donated $202,850 to the Liberal Party and around 10 per cent of that, $23,000, to the Labor Party.

There were other companies that did not bother to engage in even token balancing. Santos donated $153,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing to the Labor Party. HIH Insurance donated $126,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing to the Labor Party. Coles Myer donated $110,000 to the Liberal Party. They made an offsetting donation to the Labor Party. Pratt Holdings donated $105,000 to the Liberal Party. Western Mining donated $103,000 to the Liberal Party. Grollo Australia donated $100,000 to the Liberal Party. None of them bothered to make offsetting donations to the Labor Party. It is pretty clear what the Liberal Party believes it will achieve through putting this bill through the House. The Liberal Party believes that it will be able to secure the financial benefit of that tax deductibilityâcertainly at the expense of Labor and also at the expense of the taxpayer.
