The member for Banks and other speakers were right to point to many of the attractive and desirable features of Australia's political and electoral system, but I think it is also fair to say that we have some problems in the way that our electoral system functions and, in particular, in the way that political donations function, particularly this prospect of secret foundations and trusts receiving donations, passing them on to the Liberal Party and not being accountable for them so that we do not know who the ultimate donors are. For example, earlier this year it was reported that the Liberal Party had received a $4,650,000 loan from a secret foundation. The lenderâthe Greenfields Foundationâhas strong links to the Liberal Party's former secret funding vehicleâthe Free Enterprise Foundation, which was caught through a 1995 crackdown on disclosure law. Up until that time, the Free Enterprise Foundation had donated large sums to the coalition but was not required to reveal the donations it received. So that circumvented the intent of the funding disclosure laws.

When we endeavoured to close that loophole, we found that the Greenfields Foundation was loaning rather than donating money to the Liberal Party and thereby maintaining that it was not obliged to provide any information to the Australian Electoral Commission. But, revealingly, the address that they use is the same Canberra post office box used by the Free Enterprise Foundation, and any inquiries that the Electoral Commission has made to the Greenfields Foundation have been answered by Mr Tony Bandle, who has been a trustee of the Free Enterprise Foundation since 1981. Indeed, when the Liberal Party was challenged on this, its federal director said, `Under the Electoral Act, anyone can lend money to a political party. All we are required to provide is a name and address. You can write to them.' So it was pretty clear that the Liberal Party had no intention of bringing the public into the know on where this money had come from and the purposes to which it was being put.

We see a circumstance where the main bankrollers of the Liberal Party are private trusts. We have things like the Cormack Foundation, Add Lib, the 500 Club, and I have already mentioned the Free Enterprise Foundation. We have seen high profile business people including John Elliott, Richard Pratt, Hugh Morgan from Santos, WMC, Coles Myer, Lion Nathan and Southcorp all pitching heavy donations in the direction of the coalition, but not Labor. We had the aviator Dick Smith donating more than $10,000 to the Liberal Party, including a special contribution for Prime Minister Howard's electorate of Bennelong. Dick Smith has done pretty well, let me say, from the change of government.

All of this occurs against a backdrop where this government had said it was going to raise political standards, but in fact it has taken no action to do that whatsoever. My feeling is that out there in the community there is a sense that political standards have been damaged and are progressively being diminished. For example, prior to the election we had a parliamentary inquiry talking about a ban on inaccurate and misleading political advertising, and all the inquiry's coalition members regarded this as a good thing, including the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin). But we now learn that the federal government has opposed or at least postponed plans to ban inaccurate or misleading political advertising so, in the colourful words of the Adelaide Advertiser, `politicians are likely to be free to tell blatant lies during the next federal election campaign'.

You can tell that the idea of greater election spending, more donations based on tax deductibility, very little in the way of restrictions on what can be said in the course of the election campaign, and all this advertising, mean that the coalition is intending to swamp the electorate with a glitzy campaign. There will be very little in the way of truth, very little in the way of detail, certainly on the big issues like GST, and very little in the way of detail on any of the other things on which the electorate will need to make up its mind on the election outcome. I regret to say that there is no doubt that in any political system influence can be bought and donations do have some effect. There is no getting around that; influence can be bought. We have seen, I think regrettably, some suggestion of that already in the last couple of years.

Interestingly, we had a quite spectacular outburst from Mr John Sweeney, the Chairman of the Trust Company of Australia, which had made a very substantial donation to the Liberal Party during the 1996 election. If I recall it correctly, they had donated some three floors of their offices for use as a campaign headquarters, so by any yardstick this was a very handsome donation in kind. Mr Sweeney, we understand, was approached by Ron Walker, the Liberal Party's federal treasurer about using their headquarters again. He said, `Let's do it againâthe same as we did last time.' We understand that Mr Sweeney replied, `Over my dead body' or words to that effect and he went on to describe the Liberal Party's actions over the Managed Investments Bill 1997 as `treacherous as Pearl Harbour'. Mr Sweeney cited the statements of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the board of the Trust Company in front of Andrew Robb that they would not support the Managed Investments Bill. Of course, this government has proceeded with the Managed Investments Bill, so you do not need to be Einstein to work out what has happened here. John Sweeney and co were done in.

I think one thing that we do need to say is, `Let the Liberal donor beware'âyou might not get what you think you are getting. It is often suggested that an honest politician is one who, when he is bought, stays bought. That apparently cannot be said of the Treasurer. Mr Sweeney has made it clear, on the record in a public fashion, that he is not prepared to support the Liberal Party because of the way they have behaved over the Managed Investments Bill.

We have also seen concerns expressed about the fundraising of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), who was unable to explain here or anywhere else just how it was that a donation from Ramsay Health was described as being care of his electorate office post box. We have had some queries about what has been occurring there.

I think, quite seriously, we have been seeing examples of the banks, which are unquestionably supporters of this government, being given rather privileged treatment in the way this government has gone about its conduct of government. For example, we have recently seen reported that the big banks' fee income has risen some $657 million in the past 12 months, yet we have had absolutely nothing coming from this government by way of criticism of those fees and charges; nothing of the sort of criticism that the previous Treasurer used to do to contain banks' fee and charges.

We have seen a situation where, during the half year to March, the big four banks earned nearly $3.5 billion in fee income. Last October and November all the banks restructured their fees and charges. The National Australia Bank doubled some of their over-the-counter fees to $2, Westpac reduced the number of fee free transactions, while the Commonwealth Bank introduced phone and Internet banking fees. Last September the federal government accepted the recommendations of the Wallis inquiry to allow banks to set their own fees and charges. As soon as that occurred the fees rose, but what did you get from this government? Absolutely nothing in the way of comment concerning that or any action to monitor those fees and charges.

It is interesting that this government has been taking the credit for lower mortgage interest rates, but the Westpac Chief Executive, Bob Joss, has stated on record that the trade-off for lower mortgage rates is higher bank fees and charges. So you have got to ask the government: do you also accept responsibility for the big four banks earning that $3.5 billion in fee income during the half year to Marchâthe $657 million increase over last year's figure? In relation to these issues, this government has been running absolutely dead.

The same applies to the issue of choice of superannuation fund. The member for Banks earlier referred to the fact that the banks, in supporting this government in the way they have, in bankrolling this government in the way they have, have an expectation that they will be able to get their hands on the superannuation income of ordinary workers. The government's choice of superannuation fund legislation is designed to give banks and other vested interests that advantage. Otherwise, why would it be before the parliament? There is no support for this coming from employees. There is no call for this. No-one is coming into our electorate offices demanding to have what is described as `choice of superannuation fund'. There is no support for this from employers, for whom this is a royal pain in the neck and will simply result in more red tape, more paper work, for them. There is no call for this from other areas of the superannuation industry. There is certainly no call for this from the industry funds and the likeâwhich have been doing a very good job, let me say, in looking after workers' superannuation.

The government's changes are designed to give the banks and other vested interests a leg-up into that superannuation area. There is a suspicion in my mind and in the minds of others that this represents a pretty crude trade-off for campaign donations. This is not the kind of influence which we want in this nation and in this parliament. Regrettably, if this billâthe Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 âis passed, we will see more of this sort of thing rather than less. We will see donations go up to $1,500 on the back of tax deductibility and a lot more in the way of corporate donations. That will be at the expense of the taxpayer and it will also be at the expense of good government, of decent, clean and honest government, in this country. We in the Labor opposition will be opposing this bill, and we will be urging others to do likewise in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âin replyâWe have heard a fair bit of grandstanding in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 . I just want to go through this very simply for those people who are listening to this debate. Somebody who, for example, donates $100 would, if they are a company, get back $36. If they donate $1,500, they would get $540 back. If they donate $10,000, they would get $540 back.
âNo, for $2,000 they get a third.

âNo, they get $540. If they go to $20,000, they would get $540. If they go up to $100,000, what do they get? They get $540. The member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) came in here and indicated that a number of people and companies had donated substantial amounts of money to political parties. The implication of course was that these guys were going to get great tax deductions. But on $100,000 they would get a $540 tax deduction. That is a great incentive, isn't it? Somebody who has got $100,000 will really be swayed by the fact that he will get back $540 in tax deductibility. That is the first thing to say about the sort of grandstanding that we have had going on here by the Labor Party. It is so much nonsense. That is the simple reality of it. I do not believe that, if those people contribute $30,000, $50,000 or $100,000 to a political party, they are going to be moved by tax deductibility.

speech.para: Of course, there are unions who donate to the Labor Party. They do not have to pay tax. The unions do not pay tax. They take money off Liberal Party voters and then filter it through to the Labor Partyâthat is how they do it. They take the dues from Liberal voters, National Party voters, Independent voters and Democrat voters and then, of course, they just siphon it through into the unions and back to the Labor Party. That is how the Labor Party do it.

The other thing about this piece of legislation which has been totally ignored by the Labor Party is the fact that it will give tax deductibility to Independents and anybody else who wants to put up their hand and participate in the democratic process without being involved in a big party. This legislation really does extend equity and fairness in this area. Of course, the Labor Party do not like that. They like to hunt in packs and just keep in groups. They are not individual or independently motivated people. They just hunt in packs. They hate people who are independent thinkers. They hate people who choose things, people of conscience or anyone like that. They are opposed to this.

They do not want an individual to be able to put up their hand and say, `Look, if anybody donates to me I'm going to have a run in the seat of Banks, just to stand, to participate in the election which is coming up.' The Labor Party do not want these people to be able to get tax deductibility. That is one of the reasons they are opposing thisâor the reason some of them are opposing it. I am not quite sure if they all oppose it or not. Some on the committee supported it. Was it Senator Conroy? The opposition shadow spokesman for veterans' affairs supported this to begin with, but obviously he must have been rolled in the party room or he has changed his view. But, then again, the Labor Party will do anything or say anything to get into government, so we can expect these sorts of things to happen.

There has been a lot of grandstanding here. The Labor Party do not want Independents or small parties to be able to participate and get a fair go. They just want to keep other taxpayer funded sorts of things for large parties and not allow individual people to get the same sorts of benefits. The Labor Party totally ignored that, and yet it is a major part of this legislation.

I just want to go over a few other points in this summing up speech. This bill implements the government's response to the tax related recommendations in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1996 election. The recommendations of the joint standing committee were unanimous. In other words, the committee included members of the Labor Party, the National Party and the Liberal Party, and the recommendations were totally unanimous. In the committee the people sat back and looked at the matters. They all believed that this was the best way to go, and of course that is what we are doing: we are implementing this unanimous decision by the joint standing committee.

Recommendation 61 provides that the tax law be amended so that the donations to a political party of up to $1,500 annually, whether from an individual or a corporation, are tax deductible. Currently the tax law allows contributions of $2 or more up to a maximum ceiling of $100 per annum to registered political parties under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to be tax deductible by individuals. The government agrees with the joint standing committee that an increase in the tax deductible threshold from $100 to $1,500 per annum will encourage small to medium donations. This will increase the number of Australians, including companies, involved in the democratic process and will reduce a political party's reliance on a small number of large donations.

Recommendation 62 provides that the tax laws be amended to provide that donations to an Independent candidate at a federal or state election are tax deductible at the same level as donations to registered parties. Currently such donations are not tax deductible. The bill also implements this recommendation. This provides an equivalence of treatment between Independent candidates and members and political parties. The bill also implements the government's decision to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible contributions to political parties that are registered under state or territory electoral legislation. This expansion complements the tax concession afforded to Independent candidates and members.

The members for Canberra (Mr McMullan) and Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) indicated that the Labor Party will oppose the bill. The effect of that is to retain the status quo. This means that Independent candidates and members do not receive equal treatment with registered political parties. That is clearly unfair and clearly inequitable. We did not hear anything about that from the Labor Party. They are not about equity. I have not heard any justification by the Labor Party in regard to this issue. More importantly, it demonstrates that the Labor members of the committeeâSenator Conroy, the deputy chair of committee, and Laurie Ferguson, the shadow minister for veterans affairsâhave been rolled totally and completely on this issue in the party. After full consideration in committee stages, listening and looking at the 1996 election, they decided in their judgment that this recommendation of $1,500 was a good, wise and sensible decision. Then they got to the party room and, as the Labor Party will do anything to get back into power, they were rolled, probably by the chiefs of the Labor Party such as their national secretary or somebody like that.

The bill has been given priority as the proposed amendments are to take effect from 1 July 1998. Australians wishing to make tax deductible donations to political parties and Independents under the new proposed arrangements will remain uncertain until the proposed legislation has been passed by the parliament. The Labor Party's justification for their stance on the bill simply does not add up. This bill very simply changes the tax law to do two things: to increase the threshold for tax deductibilityâas simple as thatâand to give equivalence of treatment between Independent candidates and members and political parties. It does no more than that. They are two very simple changes to the tax law. The Labor Party would like to make a lot of these changes but they are essentially two very simple changes: to increase the threshold for tax deductibility from $100 to $1,500 and to give equivalent treatment to allow more Australians to participate in the democratic processes in this country. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debateinfo.title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (LANDCARE AND WATER FACILITY TAX OFFSET) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âGiven the fact that this parliament seems to be coming to its end, I wish Mr Miles well, the former member for Braddon to be, in his future career. I begin the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Landcare and Water Facility Tax Offset) Bill 1998 by indicating that the opposition will be supporting this legislation but wishes to raise a number of matters which go to how effective it may be in its application. The first point is that there is truth in the proposition that low income farmers do not benefit equally from the opportunity to take advantage of tax deductions under section 387A and 387B of the tax act for Landcare activities. What that means is that there may be some disincentive for them relative to their more affluent counterparts to invest in repairs of rural lands.

speech.para: Both the former Labor government and the current government have put in place measures designed to facilitate and assist activities to address the terrible backlog of environmental damage that has been caused through bad planning and poor farming practices, often through no fault other than a lack of knowledge as to appropriate methods but nonetheless very significant damage that has been caused in the past. The mechanisms that have been used include the tax system, the Natural Heritage Trust and direct expenditures through programs such as the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. This particular measure fits in by giving a rebate to low income farmers whose incomes are less than $20,700. So the effective benefit for their expenditure on Landcare activities is worth to them 34c in the dollar.

The difficulty that we have with this proposition is not the principle of it but some of the estimates of how far it will be applicable and the degree to which it will be effective in reaching its intended beneficiaries. To begin with, I think it has to be said that farmers who do have taxable incomes below $20,700 are certainly not flush with cash. If you have an income below that, most of your expenditure is going to be committed to the struggle to survive and your capacity to find additional capital expenditure may be quite low. To the extent to which that is the fact, the capacity of farmers to draw down even on this rebate is to be severely doubted.

The government will finance this measure by appropriating some $80 million which it would have otherwise expended directly on landcare projects under the Natural Heritage Trust. So this, in a sense, does not represent new dollars committed to this sector but, rather, a different vehicle for its application. But, if you think through the mathematics of that application, the only way that $80 million can be drawn down is if there is additional expenditure on farm related landcare in aggregate of about $240 million. The reason for that is you only get the 34c in the dollar and, if the value in the estimates is $80 million, in order to access that $80 million there must be a multiple investment which adds up to $240 million.

It seems to me, at least on first sight, somewhat improbable that farmers whose incomes must be less than $20,700 are sufficiently numerous on the ground to be able to make investments collectively of that order. What this presages is the same kind of slow retreat from reality that we saw with the farm retirement package, where originally the government said it was putting forward a major initiative that would benefit some 10,000 Australian farmers to enable them to retire from subeconomic land. They revised that figure down some little while later to 4,000, or perhaps 5,000, and they now estimate that the uptake of that will actually be 1,500 farmers.

Of course, no-one hears much about the retreat. They hear the announcement, they see the fistful of dollars waved and they antici pate that they will be able to access those benefits. But, when the bitter truth emerges as to how difficult it is to access the programs, how difficult the guidelines are, those findings are not communicated in the blaze of publicity that attended the first announcement. With the present measure there was a blaze of publicity. I think it was the only mention of the environment, oblique though it may be, included in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Costello).

I suspect that what will happen is that there will be nowhere near the uptake of the $80 million. So what is being offered to the low-income farming community of Australia, to those rightly regarded to be in greatest need, is an illusion. The illusion is that they too can access funds of a substantial order to assist them in repairing their damaged agricultural lands. But the truth is they will be able to do it only if they can find, from the banks or from their own personal resources, the capital to expend in order to draw down that rebate.

As I indicated in my remarks previously, it seems highly improbable that that group of farmers whose taxable incomes are below $20,700 can collectively bring forward $240 million of additional capital expenditure. To put that in some context, last year the landcare component drew down some $120 million worth of funding under the Natural Heritage Trust. So, if this program actually draws on the full $80 million, it represents a doubling of farm commitment to landcare that would otherwise have occurred simply through the Natural Heritage Trust but funded by the lowest income earning farmers in Australia. I suspect the mathematics simply does not add up.

The other point that I think should be put on the record is that the drawdown is against the Natural Heritage Trust. The Natural Heritage Trust has become the equivalent of the magic pudding to the coalition. Maybe some in the gallery would know the story of The Magic Pudding, one of Australia's most well loved children's tales by C. J. Dennis.

talk.start.para: âNorman Lindsay.

âSorry, Lindsay, of course. But the pudding was available to be cut and come again. It was the mythical magic political solution where you could carve off a slice and then have another one from whence you carved the first. The magic pudding's political equivalent has become the Natural Heritage Trust. What was once touted as the most significant commitment to the environment and landcare in this nation's history has become debauched. It has become debauched for three reasons. Firstly, it has become debauched because of the manner of its administration. I do not want to retail here what I have retailed at length previously about the way in which nine out of every $10 that have thus far been expended in the early rounds of the fund went to coalition held seats.

speech.para: I do not need to retail how the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) intervened personally to overturn the recommendations provided to him by the so-called independent advisory bodies that were set up in each of the states and territories. I do not need to address all the issues which go to the political rorting of the scheme. Those are clearly on the public record. But what I do want to say is that there are further reasons why one should regard the scheme as having been thoroughly debauched.

The second reason to regard the scheme as thoroughly debauched is that one of the clear commitments of this government prior to the introduction of the trust was that it would be supplementary to the forward estimates of the Labor government. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave his absolute guarantee that not one dollar of those forward estimates would be removed. Of course, we know from the budget figures that that was simply a misleading and untruthful statement. What has occurred is that the forward estimates that apply to both expenditure through the Department of the Environment for recurrent environmental expenditure and expenditure in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have been reduced. So the value of the Natural Heritage Trust has been substantially diminished and funding withdrawn to apply to the normal recurrent purposes of the department, quite contrary to the pledges made to the Australian people when the Prime Minister went to the Sherbrooke Forest and set out on this misleading and deceitful course of conduct.

The third point that is important to realise is that not only have the recurrent expenditures of the government been reduced but the fund has been drawn on to meet expenditures which would have normally come as special appropriations. For example, in my own state of Tasmania, where does the funding for the reservation of private forest lands which were associated with the regional forest agreements come from? It certainly was not provided for in the budget. It comes out of the Natural Heritage Trust.

When you go up to Cape York and look at the CYPLUS agreement negotiated by the former Labor government, it cannot go ahead because this present government will not commit itself to it as a result of the intransigence of Borbidge. But some of the environmental concerns are to be addressed where from? Not from general expenditure in the forward estimates as we hadâno, another steal from the Natural Heritage Trust.

Tonight we see yet a further steal from the Natural Heritage Trust. We find that the fund has been reduced by $80 million to fund this tax initiative. Where else do you find a tax initiative being funded from a trust? You find that where people are deceitful and misleading. You find it when they say one thing before their election and do another afterwards.

This government lacks all credibility now. It politically rorted the Natural Heritage Trust fund, it misled the Australian public that it would not diminish the commitment into the forward estimates put forward by the former Labor government, it has stolen tranches of money to meet the proper commitments of government in the normal course of their business from the fund and now it is meeting its revenue shortfall on the tax side by another bite into the Natural Heritage Trust.

What we see in this measure is a good, well-crafted idea being debauched by two things: firstly, an overestimate of the number of beneficiaries, a misleading impression being left with the farming community that they will be able to draw down on this to their economic benefit when plainly those low income farmers will be struggling to meet the capital costs of moving into these fields. This, therefore, is unlikely to be as accessible to them as they would anticipate. It is the same kind of misleading that occurred with the farm retirement scheme. That is the first area where the Australian public are being set up for disappointment. The second reason is that it is just part of another process of using the Natural Heritage Trust as the magic pudding, which seems to be sliced and sliced again as if it keeps going. It does not keep going. It just means that the trust's real value to the Australian community is diminished.

What was put forward to the Australian community as the most important and principled commitment of an Australian government to land repair and to management of the environment has now stumbled into ignominy. When you have the Australian Conservation Foundation and groups right across Australia now speaking out about the appalling environmental record of this government, the Natural Heritage Trust no longer gives any cover. It has no credibility, and the failure of its credibility is sheeted home to this government that has so abused the confidence of the Australian public by deceitfully cheating on the three key underlying principles that they pledged before the last election with respect to that trust.

This is a government that deserves no trust. This is a government that has forfeited the right to trust. This is a government whose Prime Minister lacks any trust from the Australian community. This is a government whose funding of this tax arrangement would normally come straight from general revenue. If any of the opposition members who are cheerfully smiling can point to any other example where an appropriation of this nature has come from a specific appropriation of money, they are welcome to tell me. But no, all those nice members interjecting opposite are hypocrites because they cannot. The environment suffers as a consequence.

The opposition is happy to support this measure. It will help some low income farmers, but certainly not the numbers the government holds out the promise to, and at the cost of direct funding expenditure, the debauching of the Natural Heritage Trust, because of that squandering of the opportunity that was offered to the Australian community by the Prime Minister at the last election. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âWe have heard so much in the last few weeks about what is happening to our health system, and I would like to read a letter into Hansard to reflect what is happening to the health system in Tasmania. It reads:

speech.para: Dear Mr Harry Quick

I am writing in regards of this so-called Health System you parliamentary people all seem to have your finger in. Well I'm here to tell you it stinks. By my writing this letter it probably won't make an ounce of difference but at least you know how us average low income people are treated and expected to live, like second class citizens. The RSPCA don't treat animals like this. I am 22 years old, married and have three children. They are aged three and a half, two and a half and three months.

I recently went to my GP about this terrible pain I had been experiencing. He told me after several tests I had Gall stones. So then being referred to a surgeon who is meant to be the best. He tells me I need my gallstones removed but because of my age they would take the gallbladder out too. But there is approximately a 3 year waiting list to have this surgery performed at the Royal Hobart Hospital. Basically, he told me that unless I could pay just under $2000 to have this done or had private health cover I would just have to sit and wait. These people with private health cover or $2000 would have priority over me.
With stupid recommendations of stay away from fatty foods. So I stuck to a strict diet of fruit and vegesâfive small meals a day. Guaranteed they couldn't live like this.

Anyway, Monday 25th May I started experiencing terrible pain and put up with it knowing of this waiting list and the surgeon's attitude. Tuesday it was worse, so I rang him. He told me to go to the clinic between 9.30 and 10.00 am. When I arrived, after the usual wait, I was told to eat as I should. There wasn't anything they could do, I wasn't the only one in pain nor was I the only one on this waiting list.

Wednesday, 27th May: the pain is just so bad I am nearly doubled over and went to Accidents, Emergency at Royal Hobart Hospital. Not many questions asked but was I down for surgery? What had I eaten all day? My reply: one banana. They gave me a shot of pethidine and sent me home.

Thursday 28th: suffered all day again in terrible pain till I couldn't take any more and back to Royal Hobart Hospital. Again after a four hour wait a shot of pethidine, no questions asked and back home.

Friday 29th: arrived at Royal Hobart Hospital at approximately 10 am to sit in a waiting room for four hours in terrible pain after being called in and sat in a cubicle for a couple more hours. They prodded and poked, took me for ultrasound, took blood, offered me more pethidine which I rejected. After all this to be sent home being told even though I have suffered for a whole week I wouldn't be entitled to surgery, nor will I be moved up the list and if I come back they will admit me for drug relief.
So here it is, Monday, 1st June, seven days later and I am at home in terrible pain, with recommendations of taking Panamax every four hours.
Now tell me, animals don't suffer like thisâwhy should I? And I'm damn sure you big nobs wouldn't have to suffer like this. With three children I am not capable of looking after what do I do?
It's no good going to the Royal. Go in there with gall stones and come out a drug addict.
I am no different than these people with good jobs, on private health cover Just because I am unemployed I have to suffer.
Where's the justice!

So much for this so-called Health System. I don't really know what your job is, but aren't you there for the people of Gagebrook, Bridgewater. I shouldn't have to suffer any more just because I'm not one of the more fortunate people with money.
How can they deny me this operation for anything up to three years? And to top it all off the bloody nurses are on strikeâfabulous health system.
Whoever has done this to the system needs shooting, they shouldn't be able to play with people's lives like this. Ha! What a life mine is, spent in bed the majority of the time.
Please, what can you do to help? I'm desperate. By the way, in three weeks, through not being able to eat, I've lost seven kilograms. What will I be like in three years?
Yours sincerely
Kaylene Sturzaker.

And she is not the only one. You might laugh across the road, but these are real people. The health system in Tasmania is in crisis and something needs to be done instead of all the political grandstanding by all people in this House, on both sides of the House, because people like Kaylene are suffering.

talk.start.para: âToday is the 201st anniversary of the landing of the first merinos on Australian soil and, like some other members, I have got a symbol of the wool industry here on my lapel to celebrate that event. As a former wool grower of Corriedale sheep, well known for their meat and lustrous 25- to 30-micron wool, I have been very much part of this industry. There has been some confusion about the original importer, John Macarthur. His wife did much of the work with the original merino. He had certain roguish tendencies. My forebears were free settlers from Scotland. I would like to get that clearly on the record here in the parliament.

speech.para: But 3 June 1998 is a much more important occasion because we have in the gallery students from the schools of Lethbridge, Inverleigh, Meredith, Shelford, Anakie and Batesford, from the heartland of Corangamite, the premier wool growing area of Australia. The students are here to see the parliament in action, and they have seen some quite lively performances, both this evening and yesterday. They have visited the High Court. They have visited the House of Representatives. They have seen it in its usual active state with nobody there. They have seen the Japanese embassy and they have seen the Science and Technology Museum.

Members will be interested to know that the students had a mock parliament at Meredith where real democracy was in action, major issues were discussed and there was grassroots debating. The member for Corangamite was appointed Speaker without debate, and the legislation before the House was `No junk food to be consumed at the school'. The government had a view: they were against junk food being consumed. The Prime Minister was appointedâRebecca Smith, after a party room count. Sam Toulmin was appointed opposition leader. Strong speeches were made and there were a lot of interjections. No suspensions were undertaken by the Speaker and the Speaker was totally in control. I wish to draw to the House's attention that these young students started to behave like members of the House of Representatives.

The doors were locked, a vote was taken and the majority was on the government side. Opinions were expressed on both sides about the value of the debate, and there was some concern that some members on the opposition side were supporting the government. That does not happen in this place. There was a heated debate about the local issues, and they understood that it is a privilege here in Australia to debate matters freelyâunlike in Indonesia where troops, guns, nepotism and corruption have been the order of the day.

Lethbridge is a very fine little villageâover 100 years oldâin the Golden Plains Shire halfway between Bannockburn and Meredith. Inverleigh has a background in sheep and crops and is based on the Barwon River on the Hamilton Highway. McConachy's Family Store is also the local post office.

Shelford is the centre of a top merino wool-growing area. Anakie is near the You Yangs in the seat of Corio and the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) is the member representing that group. Batesford is on the Moorabool River, and Meredith is the centre of a fine wool-growing area. It has a great number of rabbit populations and increasing blue gum plantations, which the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who is at the table, would not understand. He has no understanding of matters like blue gum populations. Meredith was the home of Sir Henry Bolte, who was the Liberal Premier of Victoria from 1975 until 1972.

I thank the teachers who have helped bring the students here to Canberra: Rob Lamond from Lethbridge, Debra Stavenuiter from Inverleigh, Erica Baulch from Meredith, Michael Kinnane from Meredith and John Tantau from Lethbridge. They have given a lot of time, devotion and enthusiasm to this event. The students have been in the whip's office and they now have a clear understanding of democracy at work here in the House of Representatives. There may be a future Prime Minister from the heartland of Corangamite. They can see the freedom with which big issues are debated here, although the honourable member for Denison does not fully understand the issues of land care and the allocation of funds. As I said, the students understand the freedom that we have to debateânot at the point of a gun like in the Middle East, Cambodia or Indonesia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn indulgence, on behalf of the opposition, I extend the same welcome to your constituents and I wish them and you well.

âI wish to raise a matter which I believe is most serious within the portfolio of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). It concerns what I understand to be the letting by Comcare of a contract without competitive tender, at a price of $600,000, to a Chicago based American company called AON Corporation. I am advised that the contract has been let to gather information from every government entity with respect to their insurance requirements. From the nature of the information being sought, it would seem that an attempt is being made to change the direction of Comcare from a purely workers compensation based corporation into a form of captive insurance company dealing with every class of insurance.

speech.para: Obviously AON, being a commercial broker, will have a significant advantage over other competitive brokers, even if they do allow competition, having been instrumental in gathering the information together and having met with every government entity. The effect of this, if it occurs, will be to remove many millions of dollars from the Australian insurance industry, giving it to Comcare and then presumably into the hands of international reinsurance companies, unless the government is going to put significant additional capital into Comcare. The consultancy and the advice would be wholly at the behest of 100 per cent offshore-owned entities.

The potential for further losses of Australian jobs in the insurance industry is very real and many of those have disappeared in the last few years. As I indicated at the outset, my principal concern at this stage is that a contract of this scale could have been let by an organisation within the administration of the minister, without a competitive tender. I am also concerned that, without adequate investigation from independent expertise, the possibility of forming an all classes captive insurance company is being considered. It seems to me that, if this information is correct, it is an extraordinary breach of the minister's responsibilities in respect of his areas of administration, and I call on him, using this forum, to give a full explanation to the House.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on an issue for which I have grave concerns and which I feel very strongly about: the ever-pervading violence portrayed in the media, film, video games and the music industry within our society and which our children and young people are subjected to. Tonight I would like to refer to an article in yesterday's Australian by Ruth Ostrow, entitled `Proof of pleasure positive is in the viewing'. In this article Ms Ostrow outlines the concern she has for her daughter who, at the age of four, is already shooting down her dollies with a make-believe gunâher plastic Mr Banana shampoo bottleâwhile in the bathtub.

speech.para: I certainly do share with her those concerns. Ruth Ostrow makes comments about consenting adults, which she is entitled to, of course, but I would like to point out that we, as parents, must be ever vigilant as to what our children are exposed to and what we think is appropriate to be produced for entertainment. I would be most concerned if my four-year-old son were shooting at make-believe objects or if he were to be accidentally exposed to one of the sex shows on the radio or television, either in the car while strapped into his safety seat with the radio tuned to the wrong station or at home watching TV unsupervised.

I would be absolutely mortified and paralysed at the bathroom door if a four-year-old son of mine, while playing in the bathtub, decided to demonstrate sexual techniques to his dolly with his Mr Banana shampoo bottle or if I overheard him discussing with his kindy mates the advantages of multiple orgasms for women bound in leather. All of these, as some suggest, are truths about sexualityâand sex, as does violence, sells. For instance, a few years ago the publishers of the basketball magazine Jamming published pornography in the magazine that six- and seven-year-olds purchase.

I hope that my sons are not exposed in such a manner and that they respect women and grow up not to laugh at or degrade them but to have a wonderful, meaning and loving relationship with the women that they love. So, consenting adults, please by all means do what you like in the privacy of your own homeânot in public nor in front of the childrenâwhether it be sex or violence.

Having said that, I am not surprised that, at the tender age of four, Ruth Ostrow's daughter is already trying to shoot and killâin make-believe, of course. A cartoon I watched many years ago with my children while in the lounge room was a sadistic, violent portrayal of the Three Bears. Daddy Bear was continually verbally abusing Baby Bear, calling him stupid, dumb, useless, hopeless and no good while at the same time beating him around the head and body with a four-by-four, laughing all the time. It made me feel sick to the stomach to watch, so I turned it off so my children did not have to see it.

When I rang the manager of the television station to complain, all he did, in an amused manner, was to tell me to switch it off if I did not like it. I remarked, `That is fine for me, but what about children who aren't lucky enough to have their parent or caregiver sitting down watching with them?' His response was, `It's only a cartoon.'

My grave concern about the level of violence in the media and violence generally is the effect that it can have on our young people. Young people are our future. They hold the key to the future of Australia and the world. Many are generally very optimistic, vibrant and live life to the fullest. In an earlier speech on youth suicide, I stated that for some, however, the world seems to offer little hope or enjoyment and that many look for an escape, which is often death. Youth suicide is a tremendous problem in Australia.

The growing prevalence of violence in the media and on film suggests that violence is the way to solve problems and recent research suggests that a continuing stream of violence desensitises us as a society. I have previously remarked on comments by my eldest son, who at the time was 14 years old. He asked me whether you could die if you had coke poured in your ears. When I asked why he would want to know whether that was a way to die, his answer was that he had been listening to some music on the radio and the lyrics of a song were listing lots of different ways to commit suicide. Of concern to me is that not only do we have a diet of enforced violence portrayed constantly on our televisions and video games for even very young children through to adolescents but also our adolescents are constantly bombarded with violent and sadistic role models within the music industry.

Our society has a problem when games such as Mortal Combat, where the object of the game is to kill, destroy and maim in the most gruesome manner possible, are produced for entertainment. Or there is the game, Harvest, whereby you get the highest number of points for killing little innocent babies. In addition, we have the Necromunda Gangers game, whereby the object of the game is to kill and maim and to collect as many weaponsâsuch as knives, grenades, pistols and gunsâas one can for extra points. So what are we, as a community and a society, teaching our children? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday in the House I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when he was going to intervene to save the Australian pork industry. This industry is mostly made up of family farms and is perhaps one of the best examples of Australian farming as a small business. Unfortunately the years of hard work, personal and financial commitment and dogged determination have suffered at the hands of uncaring government policy. This industry is currently being devastated by subsidised pig meat from Canada and, although it is clear the Howard govern ment has the power to save this industry and the many Australian families reliant on its survival, it appears the government will not intervene.

speech.para: A study by the University of Queensland makes it clear foreign imports are destroying the Australian pork industry. It is equally clear the Howard government has the right, under article 19 of the World Trade Organisation Agreement, to suspend imports because of the demonstrable damage being done to this industry. When I asked the Prime Minister about this issue, his answer was one that would have given cold comfort to the dreadfully insecure families of pork farmers across Australia. The sacrifice of the pork industry on the altar of free trade is just one example. This international agenda must stop, and stop now. I call on the Howard government to reverse the rural decline and unemployment it is helping to sponsor.

Tonight on A Current Affair, I would have thought Ray Martin would have been professional enough to divorce himself from the bias you would expect from his close links with the Aboriginal industry and those who discredit decent Aboriginal Australians with their obvious and grubby grab for money. I was wrong. As I have said, the real objective is not reconciliation but remuneration.

On the subject of the dreadfully dangerous draft declaration of the rights of indigenous people and my parallel of the plans for Australia and the Canadian experience with Nunavut, I was somewhat taken aback that the indigenous nature of Nunavut could possibly be questioned. If Ray Martin has some communication from the Canadian government denying the true nature of Nunavut, then I suggest the people of this indigenous state are at odds with the Canadian government.

Any doubt of this position can be clarified by simply turning to the Internet and typing in the address for Nunavut. My staff will happily make this address available to anyone interested in the truthâor at least the truth according to the people of Nunavut. Here is an example of what you will find:
In 1999, the Inuit of the Nunavut area of Canada's Arctic will take on the responsibility of managing their own affairs, and those of the non-Inuit also living there.

It certainly sounds like the Inuit Eskimos are clear on where they stand. Does Ray Martin seriously believe the Canadian government just carved out 350,000 square kilometres of freehold land for just 24,000 people just for the fun of it?

As for Mr Jull, his involvement in these matters is also hard to deny, considering even just these snippets of available information: he was the research director of the Nunavut constitutional forum which negotiated the establishment of Nunavut; his work in the Office of Indigenous Affairs in Queensland; his association with the North Australian Research Unit; and the obvious use of his work by the Cape York Land Council. At the very least, Mr Jull's work has been the blueprint for the Aboriginal industry's plans for an indigenous state in Australia. There is much more, but this at least is enough to question the value of negotiating the draft declaration of the rights of indigenous people and its ramifications for other Australians.

talk.start.para: âSome members may recall that in May last year I paid tribute to two friends of mine, Lui and Theresa Suine of Griffith, who were at that time celebrating 65 years of devoted marriage. Earlier in that year Lui had celebrated 70 years of life in Australia, having come to this country in 1927. As I said in the House at that time, Lui and Theresa were typical of those Italian migrants who have come to Australia over the years and helped make it the great nation it is today.

speech.para: Lui and Theresa Suine's contribution was made in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and one of Lui's proud statements was that there were only three months of his life in Australia in which he could not find work and these included the years of the Great Depression.

Lui and Theresa were born in Cavaso in the beautiful Veneto region of northern Italy, not far from the city of Venice. They were married in Griffith in 1932 and the happy result for Australia was five children, 18 grandchildren and more than 20 great-grandchildren. I admired and respected the Suines and was deeply saddened when Theresa passed away nearly nine months ago.

The last nine months, to say the least, have been difficult for Lui. With the support of his lovely family he has tried to get on with his life and care for himself and his small dog, a terrier named Jemma. It is with sadness that I now inform the House that in the early hours of last Friday Lui passed away in his sleep and has now rejoined his beloved Theresa.

It was fitting that this great Australian of Italian heritage was buried yesterday, on the Italian national day. I offer my condolences to the extended Suine family and with them thank God for the lives of Lui and Theresa who contributed so much to the Riverina region in which I live and to this nation.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on a subject portrayed daily by the media. All ages and stages of our human race can be victims of its effect. It has crept into everyday life and in some ways is an integral feature of our everyday existence. If we are not affected by it ourselves, we know of others who have been affected by it personally and physically. We read about it, we see it on television, we hear about it, we talk about it and many actually carry it out.

speech.para: The subject to which I refer, of course, is violence. We recognise violence as socially unacceptable behaviour. Perpetrators end up in courts, gaol or die as a result of violent acts. Victims of violence lead a changed life, suffer consequentially for their part in the act and life is never, ever the same.

I talk here generally about physical violence. It has become a feature of our daily entertainment and it is this aspect of the entertainment industry that I believe is doing our society a great injustice. Obviously, we do not have everybody out there in the streets committing violent acts. The majority of people in our community are not violent and show restraint and self-control when it comes to choosing the appropriate action and reaction to situations.

What I am concerned about is the unrestricted diet of violence our children have foisted on them from the day their parents realise television can become the primary childminding tool. The seemingly harmless images of cartoons reinforce in a child's mind the painless depiction of violence: it is only pretend; it does not really hurt. It is worse where children view the videos hired by their parents rated R, Restricted, and M, Mature Audiences Only, which they are technically not supposed to view but in the confines of their family home do view, with parents not realising the consequences.

This is not a call for blanket censorship of those videos but a plea to parents to realise that they are responsible for their children and ultimately for ensuring their children's minds are not affected by intrusive acts of violence that are totally unnecessary and may lead to disturbing psychoses. We have seen the effects of such a continued diet of violent entertainment in recent weeksâwith real life examples of young killers who perpetrate violent acts with tragic circumstances. When you read the details, the effect is quite sickeningâthat a young person's life can be treated with such insensitivity and dispassion by others who are usually the same age or not much older. Police have revealed that they often find violent videos in the homes of criminals. It raises a question or two. Who's next? And why did they do this?

Parents need to monitor what their children watch as entertainment. Parents also really need to reflect on their own personal choice of violence as a form of entertainment. Actors in films that depict such violent behavioursâand I mean the really graphic scenesâshould also consider their part in this whole cultural acceptance of violence as a form of entertainment.

There are a couple of films out now that portray violence against women. While there is not the usual blood and guts or gratuitous violence, they almost re-enact criminal acts committed in real life. We all know the famous saying `We are what we eat'. Let us take that a step further by considering that we may become what we watch, and act accordingly. If we are fed a diet of television and violence, there is no telling what we are to become.

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to say a few words about a project in my own state of Tasmania which, unfortunately, has not been graced with any favours from this government. The project is a proposal for the construction of an AFL stadium. It has been advanced by a consortium which includes the business community and a union superannuation fund through the C+BUS scheme, so it would have substantial community support and the support of the Tasmanian government. It has been put forward for funding under the Centenary of Federation arrangements. Regrettably, although more than half the $1 billion that has been promised from the Centenary of Federation Fund had been thus far committed, not one dollar other than the amounts that have been allocated per electorateâthat is, the $200,000 per federal memberâhas yet been allocated to Tasmania. That contrasts with other states where every other state has received a very significant benefit.

speech.para: The cruelest blow was dealt on the weekend when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) went to the marginal Liberal seat of Robertson and announced that the federal government would be making a $12 million contribution to a multi-purpose stadiumâvirtually the mirror image of the AFL stadium proposal in Tasmania. It is a cruel blow because New South Wales is actually in the middle of a building boom. It is going to be hosting the Olympics. There are enormous construction projects under way. My own state is the most economically disadvantaged at the present time. There is no building boom under way. In fact, construction workers are languishing for want of work. The failure of the present Prime Minister even to receive a delegation from those putting forward the proposal when he can travel to Robertson and hand out $12 million is a matter of grave regret.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
