talk.start.para: âIn today's media there is a story about the final signing of an agreement on the Jabiluka mineâthe last step to allow the go-ahead. Last night I briefly mentioned my concern about this mine. The uranium mine at Jabiluka is not just an issue for this parliament; it is an issue about one of only 20 areas in the world that has world heritage listing for both its environmental and cultural significance.

speech.para: It would appear that the government does not really care about world heritage significance. This government prides itself on making decisions based purely on economics. Whether you look at land clearing, the Hinchinbrook development or the approval for the Jabiluka uranium mine on the edge of Kakadu National Park, they are all developments that make no efforts to conserve the biological diversity or respect the people who live there. We have to get serious about the way we value our environment and our community.

In the case of Jabiluka, both environmental groups and the traditional landowners are opposed to the mine. Ms Yvonne Margarula, the senior traditional owner of the Mirrar people, explained her people's opposition to the mine and opposition to the $210 million in royalties. She said:
Money come and go. Aboriginal people walk around a lot, but we always go back to (the) country where we (were) born. No matter where we go, we always go back to the same place.

In the recent budget, the government cut funding for the management of world heritage properties, which includes the Kakadu National Park. Not surprisingly, most of the moneys were cut from budget fundingâexactly 50 per cent. Natural Heritage Trust funding, which goes to specific projects in world heritage areas, has also been cut by eight per cent. If you add the budget and Natural Heritage Trust funding together, the government has cut 67 per cent or $14.5 million from world heritage funding. One has to ask: is this an indication of what the government's priorities are when it comes to the environment?

The government has plans to overturn the existing management of the Kakadu National Park. During the Fraser and Labor governments, the land was handed back to the traditional landowners. The traditional landowners gladly shared their land and culture with other Australians and with many overseas visitors. If this handover, the winding back of these arrangements, were to go ahead, this would be nothing short of yet another vicious assault on relations with traditional owners.

Other concerns about uranium mining go to the health of the workers. I would contend that as yet we have not had proper monitoring of health outcomes for past workers. There is not only the health of workers but also the health of the ecosystem. This mine that I am talking about would leave 20 million tonnes of radioactive tailings. These have a life of at least 250,000 years. That is not bad for a mine with a lifespan of only 28 years.

ERA is also considering an alternative option to mill the uranium on site at Jabiluka instead of at the existing Ranger mine nearby. They will be preparing a public environment report themselves for the consideration of the minister. Dr Peter Bridgewater, the Commonwealth Supervising Scientist, said:
If ERA were to proceed with the Jabiluka mill alternative, I would recommend in the strongest possible terms to the minister for the environment that ERA be required to prepare a new EIS.
Why has the minister ignored the advice of the Commonwealth's Supervising Scientist and allowed ERA to conduct their own reportâa report which, I might add, is less rigorous than the EIS process?

This mine will have a devastating environmental impact on the Kakadu National Park. Most Australians do not want it and the traditional owners do not want it. I would ask that the government consider these matters in trying to balance environmental values that surround this project and the economic value.

As I said, the direct funding off-budget for the management of the world heritage propertiesâand this is the line item that we are talking about that reduces from $10 million to $5 millionâincludes the management of the Tasmanian wilderness, Queensland Wet Tropics, Willandra Lakes, Australian fossil mammal sites and central eastern rainforest reserves. If we look at the last four, we will see that the funding to be contained in this year's budget reduces to zero. I hope there is some explanation about how these sums come about and that it is not an indication of the commitment of this government to those sites. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to make some brief observations about the allocations in the budget for the primary industry sector. Some of these are specific points; some of them are more general points. Let me go first of all to the specific points.

speech.para: There will be a lot of discussion between now and the next election about the government's AAA package. I will be continuing to make the point that we are supportive of all of the components of the AAA package, with the exception of the intergenerational transfer of the farm, which I will come to in a moment. They were previous Labor programs which were good policy and were funded at the levels that they have been funded at in these budget provisions.

If I remember correctly, on the day of the announcement of AAA, everybody, with great fanfare, announced their support for these programs and said what a fabulous figure $517 million was. By Monday, 24 hours later, even the National Farmers Federation was saying that there actually was hardly any extra money and there was nothing new. That is the fact: for all the cant that was preached about previous Labor government programs in this sector, the fact is that what the government produced with this integrated rural package was a rebadging of everything that was previously there and the funding levels were almost identical. Given that history, we are obviously quite comfortable with those programs and are committed to continuing them.

I take this opportunity to correct a mistake I made in the main chamber last night in the discussion on the intergenerational transfer bill. I quoted a figure which had come to me from the Senate that there were only 14 families who would be eligible to transfer, because the conditions were so stringent. You may remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the original estimate put out by the government on launch day was 10,000. That has been revised down quietly in comments in various Senate estimates committees between last September and now. As of last night, we were being told the figure is 2,100 and that it is likely that 500 families will be eligible under the criteria. That is the figure that was arrived at in the debate last night from the government side.

My point is not as colourful as it was when I thought the figure was 14, but it is still immensely valid, as that figure of 10,000 has been revised down now to effectively 500. I refer to the comment by the New South Wales Farmers Federation in January when they said they had yet to find anyone who qualified. The legislation will be through the Senate shortly. The real test will be to find out how many there are. If those figures are correct, then it has been exactly as I described itâa sad hoax, because the expectations were created on launch day of 10,000 and it is down to a much smaller number than that. But I do correct the error I made in the other chamber. The figure of 14 relates to re-establishment grants that have been qualified for under the flow-on from farm family restart and re-establishment.

I wish to make a broader point. I am not quite sure how the minister is intending to deal with this, because he has not won many budget battles around the table with the Treasurer (Mr Costello). I am of the viewâit is just a judgmentâthat the government has seriously underestimated the impact of the downturn in Asia. I am also of the view that the government may have underestimated the longer term flow-on of the climatic conditions we have been experiencing. If both those factors are correctâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will confine my remarks to as brief a program as I possibly can, although quite frankly I would like to take on some of these issues at great length. In relation to the comments this morning by the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), I remind him that the ALP platform was fully supportive of uranium mining until well into the 1970s. I think it might even have been the late 1970s or early 1980s when the loony left got hold of their program and put in place what can only be described as a totally absurd, intellectually dishonest and utterly indefensible so-called three minesâwhich was actually two minesâuranium mining policy approach.

speech.para: This has achieved nothing in terms of the national or international moral or even economic implications of uranium mining except to deny Australia some very urgently needed further contributions to our export performance. They were masters at ensuring that Australia had a very serious current account deficit. Their policy seemed to discriminate at every turn against exports over the 13 years that they were in government, yet they continued to hang on to such absurdities as what was in fact the two-mine uranium policy.

In relation to Jabiluka, I think it is worth noting that the Northern Territory minister for resource development, Eric Poole, yesterday issued a release which sums it up pretty well in terms of what has happened up there after 18 years since the grant of the leaseâ18 years. The time it takes to do things in this country makes us a laughing stock in some parts of the world. The release states:
Since the grant of the lease, this brings to fruition the Territory government's efforts to have another uranium mine on stream in the Territory, Mr Poole said. Although the path has been longâ
that is the understatement of the yearâ

every environmental matter has been carefully considered. The resultant project will provide enormous economic benefits to the nation as well as an economic boost and considerable employment to the local Aboriginal people without any unacceptable impact on the environment.
The release goes on, and if anyone is interested, they can look at it. I find it hard to question the thrust of what is being said.

In more general terms, the member questioned this government's commitment to the environment. It was really very noticeable, I think, that more could be said about the things that he omitted to refer to than those to which he chose to refer. He made utterly no reference to the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust which sees levels of expenditure in this country on environmental programs in vitally needed practical programs such as bushcare, which is worth well over $300 million, and represents a real effortânot the sort of billion trees program under which probably more trees have died than have actually been planted and survived to maturity under the Hawke programâto provide the resources, the incentive and the policy framework to ensure that we do retain valuable vegetation in this country and plant vast areas of new vegetation.

It sees virtually a doubling in funding for landcare. In fact, the landcare movement was stalling at the time that we came to government. The very group that won the Prime Minister's award for landcare in Western Australia in 1995 had gone into hibernation because they did not believe they could go anywhere at the time that we came to power. But we have seen an explosion in the number of landcare groups right across Australia because we are funding it in a far more realistic and, in dollar terms, large way.

We also see such other valuable programs as the national land and water resources audit, which will for the first time in this countryâand perhaps for the first time globallyâgive us absolutely impeccable information about the true state of our environment and the true state of our sustainable agricultural land use and other policies in a way that has simply not been worked through before. We see $70-odd million for river care as well as real funding for the coastal and clean seas program. And so it goes on. The record is quite outstanding.

It is undergirded by a philosophy that the Labor Party were never able to catch up with. They were locked into 1970s approaches to environmental management where it was assumed that industry and environmental values and those who pursued them were automatically at loggerheads. There was a `knock them down, drag them out' sort of approach which we saw reflected here this morning. They have been unable to move to where the modern world is on environmental management, which is essentially recognising that industry and the environment groups have to pursue these things together. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTo pick up where I left off, I was making the point that the government has underestimated the impact of the Asian downturn and I think the government may have underestimated the flow-on effects on farm incomes of El Nino and the general climatic situation, particularly down the east coast of Australia and elsewhere. If I am right about thatâand let us hope I am notâthen the $517 million that is made available in AAA for farm assistance and for income support will be substantially underestimated.

speech.para: That will mean the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) will have to go back to the budget table and seek a greater allocation. Given that we are going into an election campaign with our charter of budget honesty and with all of the surplus being used up with the tax cuts, we are going to have to face this issue of where the money comes from when the farm sector needs additional income support, if the government has underestimated these effects. I have no doubt that that will turn out to be the case. There has not been much success around that budget table against the Treasurer (Mr Costello). It is a question that I think the minister ought to be giving some thought to now. He ought to be preparing himself for the answers to those questions.

That takes us to another area that is a substantial component of the primary industry budget allocationâthe matching R&D grants. If there is a downturn in sales of the kind that may occur, it means there is not going to be the need to provide the same degree of matching grants because the levy revenue will be lower. I wonder whether the minister is able to put a commitment on the table now that, if those funds are not fully expended, they will not be siphoned off to somewhere else in the budgetâperhaps offered up as part of the tax cuts or whatever. These are questions to be considered. Can you keep them in the primary industry budget? Let us see where we will go.

We will have the tax debate as we go on. It will lead to discussion about the impact of the GST on the farm sector. I often hear the minister making the point in the parliament that anyone who opposes a GST must by definition be opposing farmers because it is impacting on their export income.

talk.start.para: âLike MUA.

âAn interesting observation. The only way I can work this out in the farm sector is by examining the benefits that will be proposed in the tax package. There will be tax cutsâwell, 70 per cent of farmers do not pay tax so they do not get any tax cuts. With regard to the reduction or removal of wholesale sales tax, farmers already have the wholesale sales tax exemption, so they do not get that. The petrol tax cuts have disappeared in the debate but, even if there were to be fuel tax cuts, the diesel fuel rebate already exists for farmers, so there is no gain there.

speech.para: What are we left with? What does happen to farmers? Of course, they get to pay the GST every time they wander into town to buy things. So, probably along with the very low income sector in the economy, this group of people will be paying more tax under a GST proposal. I do not know whether there will be some attempt to offset that in some of the provisions to be made in future budget programs. I just hope that those on the other side are not seriously deluding themselves that a tax reform package will somehow lead to an increase in income for farmers, because they will actually have substantially less disposable income and therefore will find themselves under more pressure for support under AAA and other support measures. These are things that we are going to be talking about during the next two, three, four or five months. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âBefore we proceed with the debate, I remind all members that this is not a second reading debate; it is the consideration in detail stage. Therefore, while in the second reading debate on the appropriations a very wide latitude is given regarding the matters discussed, the consideration in detail stage should deal with the content of the bill.

âI want to say in absolute seriousness that, in the interests of a decent debate about rural Australia, I really do hope that the member opposite, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), for whom I have a personal regard, will avail himself of my continual offers to secure some decent briefings from my department so he actually knows some of the raw truth about agriculture in Australia.

speech.para: He continually trots out this line that I have not won against the Treasurer (Mr Costello). Firstly, we work together. Secondly, if you have a look at the outlays, you will find that we have secured vast quantities of resources for rural Australia that your team did not. It is as simple as that. You ought to have a look at the raw reality because you confirm, apparently, that you just do not know what you are talking about when you issue those figures. I have to say that to you.

The fact of the matter is that, as a member of ERC, I was able to contribute to the most important thing of all for farmers of this country, which was getting the books back into order so we got interest rates down, saving farmers hundreds of millions of dollars a year, and we got a stable currency which ABARE estimates has also delivered more than just the interest rate cuts. In 13 years, you were not able to do that; we did it over the course of about 18 months. We had a total reform which has delivered enormous benefits for rural Australia.

Let me come very briefly to AAA. I am sorry I have got to rush through this. It is utter nonsense to say, firstly, that it is broadly the same as Labor's program and that it does not involve new money. It is a $517 million program taking the place of a $200 million program. It contains elements that simply did not exist before, that were not heard of beforeâlike farm family restart. There are hundreds of farm families having their urgent needs met under that program. It did not exist before. It was not there. You cannot say this is a dollying up of Labor Party programs. It did not exist, mate. It was not there. Now there is Farmbis. That was not there. You did not have Farmbis. You talk about IEDs. They have been not only restored to the quality they had before Senator Walsh gutted them, but made available through the private sector instead of through the government as well.

Then you come to programs which you seek to criticise, such as the retiring farmers benefit package. You never did anything like that at all. We have not taken anything away from farmers, let me add. They can still access the pension. But if they are in very necessitous circumstances, they may be eligible for a more generous arrangement. Over and above that, because unfortunately the member opposite has not understood this, exceptional circumstances are still available. It is needs driven, my friend. You obviously did not understand that; your speech made it obvious that you did not. If a need arises, the money will be there. Again you say I haven't won anything.

talk.start.para: âThe minister should address his remarks through the chair.

âThe fact of the matter is that we have doubled the recovery time following an exceptional circumstance over what Labor offered, and we have put something like $300 million over and above what was on the forward estimates into that program to meet real needs in states like Queensland that have been hard hit by drought.

speech.para: We retained such things as the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which was to go under Labor. They pulled it back just at the last moment prior to their last budgetâliterally almost the night beforeâbecause the then Prime Minister was worried about a backlash. Not only have we retained that in full, and retained R&D in full and so forth, but we have found that extra money. We have found money to double landcare and so forth and we have found such resources as the $130 million, I think, extra in total to rebuild AQIS, which was left technically insolvent by the previous regime when they were in power.

In addition to that, let me make some other more general remarks just to again come to grips with the superficiality of some of these attacks. He says we have not prepared for the Asian downturn. Every responsible and understanding economist I am aware of in this country today says that the country would have been exposed to far greater damage if we had been running the sort of economic parameters that your team left us with. It is a reality that we have, relatively speaking, managed to insulate the Australian economy. It is impossible to do it completely because commodity prices are down and we are in the Asian region. But if anyone seriously disputes that weâand our farmersâare much better off under the sort of economic parameters that are now in place in this country, they ought to go to cloud-cuckoo-land because that is the only place they will find anyone who agrees with them.

In terms of that provision for rural Australia, I come back to what I said a moment ago: the provisions are demand driven. When exceptional circumstances are tripped, the money will be found. It is not a question of having to win. Those things have been sorted out in a responsible way by a responsible government and farmers know full well how we have met those needs.

talk.start.para: âWe have struck a nerve here. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is very sensitive about some of these points. If we want to have a debate about whether the AAA package is just a rebadging of former Labor programs, or whether there is actually any real money, do not take my word for it. Take the NFF's word, as I said before. Within 24 hours of the launch, there they were saying, `We can only see at most $30 million of new money in a package of $517 million.' My figure on the day was $17 million. So two of us found that within 24 hours.

speech.para: Of course it has simply been a re-presentation of former programs. When we go to have a look at some of the components of it and we look at the take-up rate, we are going to find out that my figure was much more accurate even than the NFF's because the take-up rate is not there, because the criteria were much harsher than you led people to believe. You are supposed to understand the farm sector. You guys wander around the National Party telling everybody that you are the farm sector. You are supposed to understand these things, but you get them wrong. I just make that point. It is not just me. It is even the National Farmers Federation confirming what I am saying.

I chuckle at your observation about the diesel fuel rebate. Heaven's above, do we all remember the intense campaign run by the farming industry, the mining industry and the road transport industry about diesel fuel policy and, in the case of farming and mining, about retaining their rebate? We sat, newly in opposition, having been through the same campaign from them year after year, budget by budget, wondering how you could have got yourselves into this mess with your prime constituency. Then at the end, you had the farm sector saying, `Thanks very much for letting us keep our diesel fuel rebate,' for God's sake. `Thanks very much for letting us keep it.' God save me. What are you trying to say, Minister?

Let me go to your observations about the Natural Heritage Trust, environmental investment and landcare. At no point in the last three years have we opposed the investments in environment or landcare issues in the budget. The point we have made is that, again, it has been a sleight of hand trick, because the programs that were formally funded as ongoing items on budget, such as funding for the Murray-Darling Commission, funding for landcare, funding for a range of environmental programs, were simply collected together, rebadged and called the Natural Heritage Trust.

That is fine, but do not try to deceive people that you suddenly produced a great new dollop of money for environmental spending when what you have simply done is to consolidate a range of programs that had been there, called them something else and made great play of it.

talk.start.para: âAre you serious? Are you actually serious?

âI thought the Murray-Darling Commission was a classic one. I forget the actual figures. Something in the order of $200 million to the year 2000 was the allocation for them. Out you came, as part of your billion dollars, allocating the Murray-Darling Commission an extra $11 million, I think it was, calling it the grand year 2000 plan. Big deal! You did not cut their funding, but do not go out and try to tell them that they suddenly got this great new boost in funding, for heaven's sake. Just be straight about it. There is no problem with us about these things. We are very supportive of investment in environmental programs.
âThere's a big problem. You don't understand at all.
âOrder! The minister can have a go in a moment.

âI absolutely understand it. Let me say, though, that, in the current landcare tax incentive that you provided in the budget, which we will be supportingâthe 34c in the dollar rebate for low income farmersâyour $80 million budget allocation is predicated on these farmers spending something in the order of a quarter of a billion dollars over the next four years. I wonder whether that is feasible. I hope it can come to be so, but it may well be an amount that is quite an overestimate. (Time expired)

âI have to say again that I genuinely wish, in the interests of constructive debate in this country, that my opposite number, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), would acquaint himself with the facts and try to develop a real understanding of what we have done. By no stretch of any imagination can AgricultureâAdvancing Australia be described as a rebadging of existing programs. There are completely new programs with completely new incentives and objectives built into them that have obviously been completely and absolutely lost on my opposite number. I challenge him now: will you accept from me the offer of a full briefing from my department on AgricultureâAdvancing Australia?
âI don't need it, my friend.
âYou do need it. I asked a group of farmers the other day whether they knew who my opposite number was in this countryâ30 of themâand none of them could name him.
âThey were unsure who you were.
âI was just standing there right in front of them.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder!

âIt is interesting that you always resort to the class warfare. Mr Deputy Speaker, they resort to the oldest trick in the bookâthe class warfare stuffâat the drop of a hat. One of them makes cheap and gratuitous remarks about the fact that I do not wear double-breasted suitsâbecause I do not happen to particularly like themâwhile he was wearing one in the House the other day. It is trivial and pathetic beyond belief.

speech.para: I simply state as a matter of fact that it is perfectly obvious that my opposite number does not understand AgricultureâAdvancing Australia and that he would do very well indeed to have a briefing on it. I challenge him to accept from me a briefing from my department so that he has a reasonable understanding of it and he can actually look at the real new money in it.

talk.start.para: âYou'd better offer it to the NFF. It's not me, mate, it's the NFF.

âThe NFF were fully involved in its implementation and its design. My point stands. It is quite simple: my opposite number is not interested in an informed debate on this matter. He is not willing to acquaint himself with the reality of the detail of the AgricultureâAdvancing Australia policy. He stands condemned by his own refusal to look at the facts.

speech.para: When it comes to some of the other matters that he has raised, I really think much the same applies. I make the same general offer. I think that he would do very well indeed to go and secure for himself a full briefing from my departmental officers on the policies that we are implementing, the resources that we have allocated for rural Australia. At the same time, perhaps it would be useful to ensure that he has an understanding of the value of broad based economic reform to the farm sector, which is a price taker. Eighty per cent of agricultural product from this country is exported. It sells into markets where we have little or, in most cases, no control over prices received.

Therefore, the most important area that we can possibly hope to address in this country is input costs. Input costs involve everything from the broad economic parameters that the government operates and impacts on such things as inflation. Under Labor, inflation averaged 5.7 per cent for 13 years. Under us, we are now below two per cent and, at the moment, we are actually in a negative inflation environment. Interest rates cost the farm sector, with high levels of indebtedness, a great deal of money and restrict their opportunity to recover, pay off debt and re-invest. There is also the currency, which now finds itself genuinely floating when, as ABARE estimates indicate, in the Labor Party's term of office, because of the differential between our interest rates and American interest rates, speculation meant that the currency was always higher than it would otherwise have beenâagain, impacting negatively on farmers.

Plainly, my opposite number is also not aware of the impact of wholesale sales tax remaining, despite the so-called rebate arrangements for farmers. It cascades through the system. It is built into the cost of all of their inputsâinto transport in particular, where wholesale sales tax applies to virtually every piece of transport equipment in the country, not to mention fuel excise. These are important issues. They warrant quality debate, not trite, throwaway lines that reflect a genuine lack of understanding of farm policy.

talk.start.para: âIn respect of the question of whether there has been what I would describe as a hoax or an attempt to deceive farmers into thinking that they have something new and specialâand, again, in terms of the briefing that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is talking about, I suggest he needs to offer it to the NFF because they clearly have got it as wrong as I have in his eyesâlet us just take one classic case: the farm management deposit scheme, which is estimated as being worth $60 million in this set of allocations.

speech.para: The minister in his speechânot in that of the last five minutes, but in the one earlierâmade the claim that they have transformed and cleaned up Labor's mess in this particular field with the IEDs and the FMBs that were about. There is a very interesting question to ask the minister here. First of all, let us ask: what is new and different? Was there previously a scheme in place for farmers to average income from good years to poor years, and average out their tax liability as a result? The answer is: yes, there was, originally created in the form of income equalisation deposits with certain conditions.

I remember having discussions with the NFF during the late 1980s that led to modifications to IEDs and also the introduction of what was then called farm management bonds. The eligibility criteria and the way they worked are absolutely identical to the new farm deposit scheme now introduced by the government, with one exceptionâthat is, that you have privatised them. We are not opposing that. If they are being held in a private sector banking institution, that is fine. Previously they were managed by DPIE and Treasury. Big deal! But do not tell farmers that all of a sudden they have some new, whiz-bang income averaging deposit scheme or management bond that previously was not there which is estimated at $60 million in the budget.

On announcement day, one factor emerged that is critically different from what has now come out in the explanatory memorandum to the bill. On announcement day, there was no minimum qualifying period. That was the essential difference with Labor's programs. Labor's programs required that the funds had to be held in those deposit schemes for at least 12 months or, if they were to be taken out earlier, for the benefits to be obtained, there had to be hardship provisions.

The government has removed the criteria relating to the hardship provisions; it now has simply introduced the bill with a 12-month minimum qualifying period. So the funds have to stay there for 12 months. But the effect of the 20c in the dollar tax rate is identical and the income averaging component is identical. The only thing that is different is that you can hold it in a private sector institution and the interest earned on it will be fully tax chargeable. Under the former Labor program, because the funds were being held by DPIE and Treasury in their certificates, the tax was not part of the total interest earned because it was acknowledged that the interest component would be lower than the commercial rate.

So, if you go to the fine detail of this, the program is absolutely no different, the criteria hardly vary at all and the net result to the farmer is absolutely no different. If the minister wishes, he and I could go through the AAA component by component and he could tell me how wonderful Farmbiz is, for instance. We could then bring forward from the 1995 budget the comparative Labor program that did exactly the same task, it was called something different and it allocated exactly the same amount of funds. Some of them were even cut in your budget; in some of these areas Labor actually provided more. If you want to sit down and have a component by component, piece by piece debate with me about the bits and pieces of the AAA, let us have it. But you will get exactly the same result as you just got on IEDs: you will get a detailed analysis, and people will understand that what you are talking is tripe.

talk.start.para: âI think the point is clearly established: my opposite number, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) does not comprehend these packages. New money in AgricultureâAdvancing Australia, by the way, is $235 million. Since you frequently quote the National Farmers Federation as the authority on this, I make the point that, in relation to farm management deposits, that organisation made it very plain that we had introduced a workable and attractive scheme that would bring farmers back into itâbecause yours did not. So you quote the NFF; I quote them back at you.

speech.para: Again, I make my offer: I challenge you to accept a full briefing from my people on agricultural policy, in the interests of Australian farmers having a more informed debate and your making a contribution that must be taken seriously, which sees you seriously challenging and not simply making trite observations about agricultural policy in this country. I believe that would enable us to genuinely advance the interests of farmers in this country. I do not say those things lightly. Those around me know that it is an observation I have made many times during the time that you have been the shadow minister.

I am quite happy to have a detailed debate with you at any time, my friend, about AgricultureâAdvancing Australia. But I would suggest that we do not waste one another's time. You get a formal briefing from the Department of Primary Industries and Energyâthat is a generous offerâand then you might be in a position to be able to have an intelligent debate about it.

I thank those who have contributed to the debate for their observations. I simply make the offer that, if anyone else would like detailed information on any of the programs under EA or DPIE and the relevant expenditures, I would be more than happy to provide it.

talk.start.para: âI want to conclude some remarks I made earlier about the provision for the 34c in the dollar rebate for low income farmers who make expenditure on landcare. There are some principles involved here which we are happy to support, but they do involve expenditure from the Natural Heritage Trust, which in itself comes from the sale of one-third of Telstra. So the situation is that we have sold one-third of a major public asset, and we have put to the Australian people that the funds from the sale of that asset would be used to reduce debt or for public environmental expenditure. Those funds are now being made available as a tax rebate for farmers for works done on their properties. That is a further shift in the allocation of public funding principles. I am not opposing it but I am making it known that that is what is happening.

speech.para: The comment I made before about the $80 million budget estimate of that expenditure is one that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) should give some thought to. It is a 34c in the dollar tax rebate, and it is estimated that the cost to revenue will be $80 million. That assumes that low income farmers will be spending in the order of $240 million either in cash or in kind on what will be classified as eligible landcare expenditure.

This at least raises the question: how on earth will low income farmers be able to make $240 million worth of eligible landcare expenditure? Therefore, is this estimate just another attempt at deception about how big and wonderful this program is, or has the government got some view that somehow low income farmers are going to have more money than they have had up to date and will actually be able to make expenditure of that order? Or will we find, in two or three years time, that it was a gross overestimate? And that if it was a gross overestimate, then it did not work: and if it did not work, is there a better way of doing it?

I am not saying at this point that I know of any better way of encouraging low income farmers to expend more on their properties. But I am saying that I well understand why it is a 34c rebate, and that if it is given as a tax deduction when your income is as low as $20,000 then your marginal rate is well below 34c. I well understand that. I understand the point that it at least makes the tax effect for low income farmers equal to that of higher income farmers. But I do make the point that it is predicated on $240 million worth of eligible expenditure. I wonder where on earth one would draw that kind of estimate from.

To sum up my earlier contribution, I think the government has considerably underestimated both the long-term effects of the climate change conditions we are experiencing and the impact on agriculture in particular from the Asian downturn. I ask the minister to go back and look at the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the Australian Financial Review around September last year. When he was asked what would be the impact on the Australian economy if there were a downturn in agricultural demand from Asia, he answeredâand I think I can remember his exact wordsâ`Let's not get too excited about it. Agriculture is only three per cent of GDP.'

I think that statement reflects my starting point about the position round the budget table. You are going to need to give additional support to farmers over the next few years, if you are still in office, and you will need a lot more support from the Treasurer than that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âYesterday we heard allegations in the parliament that the Labor Party's foreign affairs document was supposedly borrowing from other documents. Again, in the grievance debate last evening similar claims were made. But if we look at the area of defence, we see that the Liberal Party, from their own statements, seem to have done a little of the same preparation that they allege the current opposition has done.

speech.para: One of the consistent claims from a variety of spokesmen when the coalition was in opposition was that Australia was in a situation where its defence forces were basically very undermanned. That was a consistent appeal to the Australian electorate and to people in the armed forces and it indicated that we were unable to defend ourselves and that we needed more personnel. It is quite interesting to note that in this budget we see a continuation of the reality that has followed the coalition's ascent to office.

All the rhetoric in the world about how they are going to make it more efficient, more agile and more able at the sharp end does not for one moment in any way answer the reality that we see another 1,713 full-time ADF positions earmarked to disappear in this budget. The coalition's cumulative reduction is forecast to reach 4,000 uniform positions. Essentially, 4,000 are going to disappear. Part of the reason for that is that the defence efficiency review panel was staffed almost totally by the corporate end of town.

It is all right to say in any organisation that there is value in getting outside analysis to question whether things are going in the right direction, because all groups get very cosy and very settled. But the reality of what is happening in this field is that it is driven by ideology. That is the dominant sentiment of what is happening in this portfolio and at other ends of the government. As I say, it starts at that essential point in that the people driving the inquiry really had a minimal input from defence personnel. A very minor number of those were actually doing the examination.

Under the current coalition government's plans, 4,700 uniform positions will disappear and another 7,000 are under execution orders. Also, 3,100 civilian personnel will disappear and another 5,900 are under review. Despite that very firm 1996 election commitment that one had to be very worried about the low staffing levels, what we have seen in reality under them is in actual fact in very stark contrastâsubstantial, continuing reductions. There is constant concern on the part of the personnel that their jobs are on the line and that they could go. There are also constant threats of outsourcing of virtually all sectors of the defence forces.

As I say, if we start having rhetoric in this parliament about a party not understanding where they were before coming into government, we see it in this field. In actual fact, there have been consistent reductions. The same goes for bases. Is it any wonder in Australian politics that One Nation is seriously eroding the National Party base when we see their total inability to question this ideologically driven policy of closing down significant bases around the country in areas such as Wagga and many other rural towns? It does not take much to speculate about the impact that those base closures will have in areas such as Queenscliffâand we know there is a lot of controversy about that in Victoriaâin Wagga, and in Point Cook in Victoria.

What we are seeing is a totally ideologically driven determination to reduce employment levels in the defence forces and to cause people concern as to where their future lies. People have skills which are, in some cases, transferable. We know that, but there are others who, because of their age, have minimal possibilities of getting employment in other sectors.

The next matter I want to turn to is the Defence Housing Authority. There has been no indication by the current government that this will not be privatised. There is no clarification in these budget papers. One of the realities is the continuing shift of people to WA, the Northern Territory and other areas more remote from the major capital cities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to talk a little bit about veterans' affairs. I do not know whether the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) is going to find his way here or not, but I will make one brief remark while the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) is here. We are dealing with these matters together, so I am not sure whether the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will appear, but I am happy to proceed on that basis. While the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) is here, I should make a point to the Minister for Defence. I had not intended to, but it seems to be the perfect opportunity to raise the issue of the Sydney Harbour foreshore and the intentions of the Department of Defence in respect of Georges Heights and Middle Head.

speech.para: I thought the member for Warringah might help a little if I raise this issue now; I am sure I would have his support. It is a matter on which the minister and I have not exactly seen eye to eye. I will not go through it all again. He is aware of my concerns. He has written me a rather unfriendly letter back, which is a little out of character, I would have to say, telling me that I did not know what I was talking about and that I should go back up to Middle Head and have another look. I have written back and said, `Thanks for the offer but I've got other things on my mind in the immediate future.'

I want to put on the record my continuing concerns. I am only reflecting the concerns of the residents there who, admittedly, I suppose, have a vested interest in it. The member for Warringah is aware of the issue. He may wish to make a contribution, as I said, because he should know more about it than I do. I only got into it because I went there, had a look and was concerned. As a member of the Defence Subcommittee, it was legitimate for me to be concerned. I then had a number of the residents, whom I actually knew from my former life, approach me about it. In my mind, those concerns are not yet totally allayed. They may well be in the mind of the member for Warringah. I am not trying to overstate it, and I do not know whether he wants to say something. But I think the concerns remain. While the Minister for Defence is here, that is the only issue I wanted to raise.

talk.start.para: âI have been invited to comment on a matter by my friend the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). I believe that the whole question of military lands on Sydney Harbour is in very good handsâthe hands of the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

âThe second issue is the question of the future of the Defence Housing Authority. We are aware of the dire circumstances of defence housing which preceded the 1987 establishment of this authority. In 1986 we had a situation where a little over 5,000 homes in this country in the defence sector could be classed as good quality, while a massive 18,300 were in contrast defined as below standard. Under both governments in the intervening period there has been a substantial, continuing improvement.

speech.para: In 1996 there were estimates that nearly 15,000 could be in the good quality class and, with the spread of leasing by the department, a further 5,200-odd were classed as good quality leased property. Only 600 houses were regarded as substandard or below standard. So there has been a substantial, continuing improvement in the housing available to defence personnel. I do not think many people here would dispute that housing is fundamental to the morale of service personnel and to retaining their families. Housing is a fundamental, central, basic part of their lifestyle. It needs to be of a good quality.

Mrs Sue Hamilton of the Office of the Status of Women, in her 1986 report entitled Supporting service families, said that the low standard of service housing was a significant contributor to poor family morale in the services. That is extremely accurate. But, once again, there seems a thrust by the government in this field to say, `If it is possible to sell anything in this country or to privatise it, then let us do itâlet us just do it for the sake of it.' In this case, I think we have to question whether the market forces are such that it will be to the advantage of defence personnel. I can say genuinely that both people in the forces and interest groupsâthose service groups outside that take up their cause, including veterans groupsâare very concerned that this matter has not been clarified, that it is dragging on, and that there is the possibility of the housing authority being sold.

In the markets these service personnel go intoâin towns where there is a base and where they have not previously livedâthere can be an extreme demand for housing and changing demands at the end of people's periods in the forces. People often do not have local knowledge; they may never have been to these towns; they do not have family there; they do not have the experience of the market; they do not know the availability of transport there; they do not know where services lie in these country towns. Even in regional centres one needs to have a fair base of knowledge, although I appreciate that the defence forces have tried to make sure that people are fairly cognisant of local conditions.

But the housing authority is there for a very defined purpose: to provide proper, decent, cheap housing for defence personnel. I do not have any confidence in the outcome if we allow the private sector to come into this area. Defence personnel have enough challenges to face in a new areaâestablishing new friends, becoming familiar with the services, and often with the spouse requiring employment in a new sector. On the matter of spouse employment, it is worth saying that one of the major thrusts of the employment policy of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) is going to drastically hit defence families.

A fact of life is that amongst the many groups now for the first time denied access to help in gaining employment are the spouses of defence personnel because they are not on benefits. They are not clients of the social security system. So when they go to these towns there is not going to be the previous free assistance. One has to treat this very seriously, because a family that has been used to two incomesâwhether in metropolitan Sydney or Melbourne, or out near Ingleburn, Richmond or whereverâis going to be in dire circumstances if the wife cannot gain a job in a new employment market and does not have government assistance.

We do express our concern, as do many other interest groups in this field, about the continuing failure of the government to clarify exactly where the Defence Housing Authority is going. Indisputably, this is a particular market. It is a select market. On occasion the market is in areas where there is not that much housing infrastructure. The government has to seriously question where it is going if privatisation is on the agenda. (Extension of time granted)

Finally, I want to deal with aspects relating to defence personnel. There has been a continuing series of reviews by the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop). The list is getting quite endless. At the end of this parliament, regardless who is elected, her three years in the portfolio will be clarified by one thingâand that is reviews. Let us go through those that I can readily recall, and I have no doubt the portfolio knowledge of the minister at the table, the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), is such that he will know a few others.

We have had the military compensation inquiry. The first review was announced on 30 October 1996 and a further review announced in June 1997. We have the corruption in the navy inquiry still ongoing. We have had the sexual harassment in the ADF inquiry. Then we turn to the review of military discipline tours at the defence correctional facility and the review of overseas service entitlements for veterans. In some cases, these inquiries have been going on and on with very little results, except that every three or four weeks a `zero tolerance of sexual harassment' press release comes out which gets a run for a day or two. Some leak occurs from one of these inquiries that someone got hit in the head somewhere, or some such thing, and that gives the minister another chance to say that she has zero tolerance. Not one of these reviews has resulted in a final report being presented to this parliamentâsome of them have been going for years on endâand no resulting action plan has been announced by the government.

Two of the current inquiries are the direct result of botched reviews that she conducted earlier. The military compensation scheme was reviewed after the Black Hawk accident, but this review was given such restrictive terms of reference that it was only able to propose changes that would benefit ADF personnel who sustained extremely severe injuries, such as quadriplegia and paraplegia, and the widows and dependent children of those who were killed. So it had only a narrow, restricted oversight. When the furore continued from the family, friends and service groups connected with other disabled servicemen, these complaints about the unresolved problems forced her to announce in June 1997 a further review to develop `a single self-contained military compensation scheme for peacetime service which covers only military personnel.' There has been very little coming out of that second review nearly a year later.

The further review of overseas service entitlements would not have been necessary if the coalition had honoured its 1996 election undertaking to resolve all outstanding anomalies in relation to both medals and repatriation benefits. Instead, it conducted an inadequate, bureaucratic exercise that engaged in no consultation with the ex-service community, ignored many episodes of service, and short-changed two groups whose cases were considered. Once again, both of those reviews are the result of the inflexible and narrow way in which the minister constructed those inquiries. Years later we still have not had the outcome.

I see that the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) is here. I noticed the other day one of his press releases from when he was a loyal coalition member. In 1996, believe it or not, he was out there telling his electorate that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) was basically doing something about disability pensioners to try to make sure the pension would not be counted for social security purposes. I admit that, in Senator Newman's case, this was probably a one-off exception. It is different for the other minister in this field; there are, as I said, six or seven inquiries going nowhere. In answer to a question on notice, Minister Bishop said:

The Government determined that other genuine anomalies brought to its attention, which are substantiated sufficiently to warrant further examination will also be reviewed. As a consequence, the following are currently under review; RAAF at Ubon, Thailand, during the Vietnam War; HMAS Parramatta, HMAS Sydney, HMAS Vampire and HMAS Yarra during the Indonesian Confrontation; RAN Communications Detachment in Singapore during the Malayan Emergencyâ

Et cetera. There is widespread concern in the veteran community that the situation of naval personnel who served with the Far Eastern Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency is not being reviewed, despite the Senate's vote on 22 October 1997 requesting that the government grant these veterans access to the service pension. We know that Senator Tambling, representing the government, indicated that the situation with the Far Eastern Strategic Reserve and Ubon would get serious consideration. Eight months later, we are told that it is a minor priority in the government, that they have not really allocated many resources to it and that it might eventually, one day in the future, have an outcome. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to address the matter raised earlier by the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) because it is a separate matter from the galaxy of matters raised by the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson). I know that the member for McPherson has been worried about the Sydney Harbour defence properties for some time. He knows that I have disagreed with his view on the matter and I have disagreed with the publicly expressed view of Premier Carr as well. The reason for that is that we do have a number of properties still residing under the auspices of the Department of Defence. There are a lot of them, but I think the ones that the member for McPherson is interested in are North Head, Middle Head, Georges Heights, Woolwich, Cockatoo Island and perhaps Garden Island, although the last two really come into a different category.

speech.para: In regard to Garden Island and Cockatoo Island, there are some remedial works to be done in both of those areas which need to be done in a hurry. I just have to say that there is no way on earth the New South Wales government would have the resources to deal with the Cockatoo Island pollution. Nobody is denying that the pollution has been there and has been formed over 100 years of shipbuilding, manufacturing and so forth, but there are some very serious matters to be dealt with and it is our estimate that it will cost somewhere between $40 million and $50 million.

The business of holding up remedial works that the Department of Defence ought to be doing in other parts of Sydney Harbour is not helping the Cockatoo Island situation as well. Quite frankly, I have expressed the view a number of times that, if we could fix Cockatoo Island before the Olympicsâor at least remedy the pollution problems and solve some of the other problemsâthat would be a good thing for the benefit of Sydney and Australia coming into that enormous event.

In regard to Middle Head, in 1979, the federal government gave back to the New South Wales government the end of the peninsula on Middle Head. Absolutely nothing has been done about that since. It is just sitting there with a fence across it in a degraded state. Our plan was to do something about the remediation of that degraded land which had been given back to the New South Wales government in 1979 and they were given a whole lot more land, which you might call foreshore land.

To do that, you needed to be able to extract some dollars out of that land which is already built on, and I am talking about Georges Heights of course. As the member for McPherson would have seen, no doubt, there are a lot of buildings that are old, and there are housing buildings and other buildings that should be pulled down. At the same time, there are some rather beautiful old stone buildings and other historical works that need to be put into very good order, and that was the part of the plan as well.

I have to say that I got an award for environmental remediation in the past and I am very concerned to make sure that we enhance all those values, but simply to say that they have got to go back to the people, or some generic phrase like that, does not necessarily produce the result that I know the honourable member wants. I wanted to raise that because I want the same result. Therefore, the foreshore area should be remediated and produced in a state which is in no way an eyesore and which beautifies Sydney Harbour again, but there are other areas and assets which have to produce the money to do that. I just wanted to say those things. I am very pleased to hear my colleague the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) say that the matter is in the very good hands of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Defence. For the first time for some time, I agree with him totally.

The member for Reid raised a couple of other subjects, the first being the undermanning of the Defence Force. In particular, he was talking about the army. He said that we are now coming down to an indicated target over time of 50,000 people in the Australian Defence Force, and that is true. (Extension of time granted) The reason for that, obviously, is that, over many years, we have been concerned about the under-resourcing of the Australian Defence Force. If you want an example, and I notice that graphs and graphics are all the rage these days in these parliamentary proceedingsâ

talk.start.para: âAt least it's not a map of Australia.

âNo, but this is a map of what you promised, in blue, and what you delivered in the Defence Force for every year in the first eight years that you were in governmentâpromise this, deliver less. That is exactly what you did when you were in government, and that is why we are under-resourced. We got to a situation where the money went down from 2.65 per cent of GDP to tip under 1.9 per cent now.

speech.para: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am telling you that the fact is that you under-resourced the defence department and we have to fix it up. That is why we conducted the defence efficiency review: to get rid of duplication, to get rid of waste and to get rid of inefficiency. We will save $1 billion in recurrent terms, which you were wasting. That is what we will save. The other point about this reduction of personnel is that you actually got rid of 13,500 people during your term.
âYou said it was undermanned.

âYou got rid of 13,500 people in your term. What is more, having done that, you had 42 per cent of them in combat or combat related positions. We are moving them to 65 per cent in combat or combat related positions. Just work that out. It might be a bit complicated. It would be too complicated for the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), but just work out what that gives you in effective ability to defend this country. It actually increases the ability to defend this country.

speech.para: However, the main point in all of this discussion is the matter of the waste that was produced by the Labor Party in producing assets that were, as described yesterday by my colleague the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop), for but not with. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), your leader, said in parliament yesterday, `But that's what you do in peacetime.' Work that out! When you want to go to the Gulf, you have some assets that you cannot send and you cannot fill them up because these days you cannot go down to the corner shop and order a bolt for a .303. We are not in that context at all; we are in the context of taking years to fill up the hollowness that we had in some of those assets. I do not want to go through all of those assets. You know them as well as I do. The theory behind your leader's interjection in the parliament was that in peacetime you do one thing and, when war is approaching, you do something else. That is fantastic, if you know when it is approaching. But, as it takes you four years to fill those assets up and make sure that they are current, how on earth are you going to do that? It is a nonsensical proposition.

Even you know now when you look at it that, if you look across the whole raft of assets in the Australian Defence Force, you could not contract them out, even if you had the money, and get them fixed in the time. It is not a possibility. So you have to make sure that, when you build an asset, you build an asset that is current to do what you want it to do at the time. You will still have other assets that get behind. There is no doubt about that because technology moves on, and technology is moving on faster. One dayâwe are not quite thereâpresumably with software improvements and so forth, you will be pulling a box out of here and putting another one back in. We have not got to that stage in most of these circumstances yet.

I have to say to the Australian Labor Party that, whatever you thought the circumstances were in the past, it is not the same now. We have a big catch-up job to do. We are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in the army alone just to get rid of the hollownessâlet alone buying ASLAVs, new equipment and what have you; just to get rid of the hollowness that you left. You do not have to ask me whether that was true or not. Your own report about the armyâit was written in your timeâwas the most self-scathing report that anybody could ever possibly read. Effectively, it said you had left the army 15 years behind the times. So that is the answer to your question. I could go on about the Anzacs and about a whole lot of other things as well. (Extension of time granted)

I will just finish on the subject of the DHA. There is a review going on in DHA, and there are other reviews going on as well. But that review is still under way, and it is being considered by Minister Bishop and the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey).

talk.start.para: âThat is reassuring.

âI notice that in the Senate you also got up a review, an all encompassing review, on military compensation, on military discipline. I also note that most of the eventualities that are coming before that committee, with the exception of one or two, are things that happened during your time.

speech.para: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIf you want me to go through them, there are the submarines, Mr Mackelmann and a few other things like that. We are trying to make sure that, when you have a military discipline panel, not only is it expert, not only are the people on the panel people who have not had anything to do with the circumstances that gave rise to that tribunalâwhich was a difficulty, as you well know, in the Black Hawk matter, because we do not have an enormous army like the US, so somebody in the hierarchy has had things to do with keeping Black Hawks going and so onâbut also that we give the perception to the people out there that fairness is being done. That is why I made the Black Hawk matter an open inquiry, and in the Westralia inquiry we have not only made it open but also introduced a couple of outsiders for reasons of added expertise but also for reasons of public perception so that in 10 years time somebody cannot come back here and say that whatever we did back in 1998, 1997 or 1996 was not reasonable. Some of these inquiries and reviews that you are complaining about are necessary, but they are necessary because of deficiencies that came up in earlier times, and a number of those times were when you were in control.

âI am waiting for the response by the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) to the problem that has been raised by the shadow minister for defence science and personnel, the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson)âthat is, the withdrawal of employment services for defence personnel.

speech.para: I believe that this is a fairly significant issue. Defence personnel and their families make a lot of sacrifices for the Australian community. They are often moved around the country, which causes considerable disruption to their lives. With their being moved from one centre to another, one of the issues with which we must contend is the attempt to create opportunities for their families to integrate into the surrounding community. I think that is fairly important, because it is about developing opportunities to make family contacts and, in doing so, making it easier for the family to become part of the local community.

In that context, I am seriously concerned about the creation, through the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, of two classes of people amongst those who are looking for a job at the moment. Defence Force personnel not only make a contribution to Australia's defences but also actively pay their way through the PAYE tax system. As from 1 May, when they are moved from one centre to another, because one member of their family is employed by the defence forces, if their spouse or partner is unemployed and looking for a jobâand the careers of these spouses or partners, one must understand, are disrupted on a regular basisâas a result of changes to employment services, those spouses and partners are no longer entitled to free employment services to assist them in obtaining casual, part-time or full-time work which will help them and their families to settle in the local community.

But it is worse than that. In some states and territories, because of that denialâand it is a blatant denial in the creation of two classes of unemployed in this country as at 1 Mayâthose partners and spouses, who are making considerable sacrifices for the Australian community, can be required to actually pay for employment services, those states and territories being South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, the ACT and the Northern Territory. And with those states, for example, just think of the development of the Tindal base over the last decade; think of the defence personnel in the ACT or Victoria. In those states and territories now, those partners and spouses, having been deemed ineligible for a free employment service by this government, can be required to put their hands in their pockets and pay employment agents for assistance to get jobs in local communities. Not only is that discriminatory; it is unhelpful to Australian Defence Force personnel and their families.

I would have thought that a real, practical and decent Minister for Defence would have fought tooth and nail in the recent budget process. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), in his own dogged, ideological way, has been unwilling to help those Defence Force personnel and their families by actually announcing some measure to assist those people in this budget.

Therefore, I suggest that Defence Force personnel would find the budget papers relating to the Department of Defence more interesting for what they do not say about that problem than for what they do say. The Minister for Defence ought to take up this fight; he ought to take it up with the cabinet and make sure that this government does something on a comprehensive basis to assist, through free employment services, all Defence Force personnel, as they are moved from town to town, to get access to work on a casual, part-time or permanent basis.

talk.start.para: âThe matter that has been raised by the shadow minister for employment and training, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), really would be better raised during the consideration of the employment estimates, which are to follow these defence estimates. But if I may just say a few words at this timeâ
âOrder! I accepted that on the basis of the defence personnel.
âI will address this issue in the employment estimates.

âI am quite happy to address this matter. As the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) has said in the House on a number of occasions, `No job seeker, whether or not on benefits, will be charged a fee.' As I understand it, that still stands.

speech.para: The matter of defence personnel and their wives has been raised, quite properly. We have this problem all the time: somebody has a job, they move from Sydney to Darwin or wherever, and it is a very difficult problem. But we have something called the Defence Jobs Club, which is where these people are specifically catered for. These jobs clubs also have practical courses to enable job seekers to improve their search skills and so on.

Members opposite were very critical that I, as the minister, had not done anything about making sure that there was a facility for these people, when moving around, to be looked after in some way. But you might rememberâat least the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) will rememberâthat, prior to the last election, in our policy platform, we promised to save $125 million a year and redirect that into various other aspects. One of the areas into which we redirected it in 1997-98 and 1998-99, with a total coming to $4.1 million, was spouse employment. That saysâand let me read it to you:
. . . an enhanced spouse employment assistance program particularly targeting remote localities and development of a spouse employment database.

In other words, we know we have a problem; of course, there is a problem. I worry about this, but in some areas historically we have moved people around about every two years. That is to give the ADF employee a tick in this category and that category, and so forth, so he or she can move on up the ladder. But the spouse is obviously left in the circumstance that you have described. We have been well aware of that matter.

You cannot tell me that you were well aware of that matter 2Â¼ years ago and that we have done lessâbecause actually we have just done more. So you cannot say that for 13 years you had it all organised, because that was the arrangement before: every couple of years, you moved people around to new jobs. I suggest that the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) go back and have a look at what arrangements were in place prior to March 1996, and then have a look to see whether they have got worse or better since. I think he will find that the circumstances are still the same; that is, people are still moving around, although I do have some reservations about the number of times that we ought to move people around.

We have just had an example come up in acquisition in recent times. If you get somebody who has expertise in a very difficult and technical area, such as in the acquisition area, and who is not going to become the chief of the Defence Force some time in the future, then it is crazy to move that person on. So we are looking at some areas of expertise where people should stay much longer and where some people may stay for life because they are so good at it, they like doing it and so on. I say to the member for Batman that that was a good political statement just now, but the facts of the matter would seem to be different.

talk.start.para: âI understand the reservations that the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) has with respect to moving people aroundâthe potential disruption it causes to defence forces in some circumstances, and, more importantly, the disruption it causes to families, especially young families, with respect to the partner or spouse having to give up a career opportunity. I am of the view that we all have room to improve our performance. The truth of the matter is that 2Â¼ years ago the situation was entirely different. There were not two classes of unemployed in Australiaâthose classified as eligible job seekers and those classified as ineligible job seekers.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the member for Batman is perfectly entitled to make these points in the DEETYA estimates, and I really think he should be required to do so. The points he wishes to raise are general points about the employment market and employment services. They are not specific to defence at all.
âI will allow the honourable member for Batman to continue, but he should direct the comments to the defence area, if that is his concern.

âIn context, I think this is very relevant to the defence area. The minister has appropriately referred to the defence jobs clubs. The reality is that that is a short-term solution against a far more comprehensive system that existed previously of a widespread commitment to jobs clubs all around Australia for all Australia's unemployed. With respect to those unemployed people, since March 1996 $1.5 billion has been cut out of programs that were used to assist people, including defence personnel, with activities to get a job. As I said, a lot of those unemployed people were related to defence personnel. I turn to the issue of access to employment program assistance to try to get a job.
âOn defence personnel only.

âI am speaking about defence personnel. Unlike some, I cannot separate them from the rest of the Australian community because they are all Australians, all trying to do their best for the nation. I am very proud of the job that the defence personnelâ

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: these points are perfectly reasonable ones for the member for Batman to make but at the right time, and this is not the right time. He will have plenty of time to make these points. We need not further detain the Minister for Defence on this subject.
âThe member for Batman must return to the subject of the matter before the chair, which is the Department of Defence.

âI very much agree, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am not going to be bludgeoned into submission and I am not going to walk away from the fact that I think we ought to stand up for defence personnel and their families. No-one should walk away from the need to look after defence personnel and their families. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not shut up, as the Parliamentary Secretary (Mr Abbott) is endeavouring to force you to get me to do with respect to these issues.
âOrder! You will comply with the standing orders, and I will give the ruling on the standing orders.

âI will comply with the standing orders, Mr Deputy Speaker, and raise these issues because they are issues of major importance. I request that you continue to protect my right to raise these issues in the Main Committee.

speech.para: The truth of the matter is that defence personnel are worse off today with respect to their capacity to get a job because of the changes that have been made. It is a very telling point. Defence personnel and their spouses have lost the capacity to move around Australia and have access to a comprehensive free employment service. That is exceptionally important. Time and time again defence personnel and their families are contacting our office with examples of their being charged for employment services that were free prior to 1 May. It is legal to charge defence personnel and their families in some states and territories but it is illegal in other states and territories.

I make this point: there is room to improve as a result of the changes that have been made from 1 May. I ask the Minister for Defence to take this very, very serious problem on board. Yes, there are defence jobs clubs, but they are a drop in the ocean compared with the system that existed prior to 1 May. Defence personnel and their families are entitled to better than the system that now exists around Australia post 1 May. They are being denied a comprehensive opportunity to get a job, be it part time, casual or full time, to integrate into the local community, and to make a major contribution to those local communities. For the sake of their families, defence personnel need to have that opportunity.

I will not be silenced by the parliamentary secretary with respect to these very telling issues. If you want defence personnel in Australia, then you look after them and make sure that they have a comprehensive employment service. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âJust before the minister commences, I welcome the distinguished visitors from Kenya to the Main Committee.

âWhen I was farming I used to send my kelpie around the mob of sheep I wanted to muster. Now my well-trained son does that instead.
