But the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) has sent his dog not around the outside of the paddock where the sheep are but around the outside of the boundary fence of the property and, in fact, around the boundary of the state in which the property is in. His all-encompassing claim, as you pointed out quite rightly, is quite outside this debate. You thought this was very serious when you were on your feetâ

speech.para: Mr Martin Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIf it is so serious, I put it to you: why do you not send, and why have you not sent, those complaints to my office? You have said that this has been happening since 1 May. I will be delighted to deal with those problems. You should have sent them around, as my colleagues would have done and do to other ministers every day of the week.
âI have been raising these problems in the parliament.

âNo. You are making a public statement in the parliament, but if you want the problems of these individual people, who you are so concerned about, to be dealt with, then send them around to my office.

âI am going to talk about veterans' affairs. I appreciate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) being present as I want to raise a number of specific matters. In a contribution I made here last week on the veterans' entitlement amendment bill, I raised a number of issues. He took the opportunity when he responded to insult me or to patronise me. I was listening to the broadcast of the proceedings as I was not in the chamber at the time, but I wanted to take him to task on that.

speech.para: I made a number of remarks in my contribution about the appropriation for the veterans' affairs budget. I said that there had been reductions in some programs within the veterans' budget. He either did not hear meâhe was not here when I spokeâor he was advised that I said that there had been a reduction in the budget. He quite correctly pointed out that there had been an overall increase in the appropriation of 7.2 per cent, although I think in fact it was 7.6 per cent. That was my understanding, anyway. As the minister said, that does not indicate a cut in the funding for veterans; in fact, it is an increase over the 12 months of something like $500 million.

That was one of the matters that I wanted to raise. Yes, there is $500 million there. I assume that at least some of that will be the $500 million the government has allocated towards the gold card initiative, or at least some part of it. I just wanted a clarification that the veterans appropriation did include some money for that initiative. I understand that the minister introduced that bill into the parliament this morning, so I assume that some of that money will be in the 1998-99 budget.

I do want to defend myself on the basis that there wereâand you would only have to look at the appropriationâsignificant cuts in a number of different services. I readily admit that there are also increases in a number of other services, so the overall picture is that there is an increase. I could ask the minister why there is a decrease in health and medical research in relation to veterans' health care. I could ask him why there is a decrease in the Australian War Memorial veterans' commemorative activities. I could ask him why there is a decrease in residential and community care grants. I could ask him why there is a decrease in the refurbishment, reconstruction and relocation of war graves and related facilities. I could ask him why there is a decrease in payments to ex-service organisations to facilitate claims by eligible veterans.

The point I was making before the minister's patronising comments that I had said that there was a decrease when there was in fact an increase related to my concerns about some particular programs. I ask those questions. There are other programs he can point to where there have been increases. I welcome, and the veterans community welcomes, the gold card initiative, but if that is the reason for the increase, one does not have to be too clever to work out that there must be reductions in the budget to fund that particular increase. I do not think the minister is that fast on his feet, but he might get a bit of advice to make it all add up for me.

talk.start.para: âHe's no Reg Gasnier.

âHe is no Reg Gasnier. You got it right, Martin. In fact, I do not think he is even a Martin Bella. We accept that. I actually asked for a departmental briefing on this and they hedged around that a little bit.
âHe said you never go to his door.
âHe said in his speech that I never went through his door. The fact is that I did not have to grovel to the minister to get help in veterans areas. I have a lot of friends who are veterans.
âYou know more about it than he does.

âI do know a lot more about it than he doesâor, indeed, ever will know about it. But the fact is that I have asked for a briefing. It will be too late now; they will probably offer it next week some time when I am back in my electorate. (Time expired)

âObviously, the dominant aspect of this budget is the gold card. I think it was unfortunate that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), through essentially genuine motives, in his first phraseology, conveyed to the Australian electorate and more particularly the Australian veterans community that essentially a wider group of people were getting this card than turned out to be the case in the end. As I say, I do not think that he attempted to mislead at all. I think it was just that he probably did feel that all Second World War veterans were to be granted the card.

speech.para: Obviously, whenever any of these extensions occur, there are vast numbers of individuals and other groups who feel that they should have an entitlement. By that, let us say, unfortunate and accidental phraseology, expectations have been increased considerably. I appreciate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) and the department, by contrast, have clearly made it evident from the beginning that this applies only to those people who saw active duty against hostile forces. As I say, there has been no blame on the part of the minister or the department, but, unfortunately, the Prime Minister probably just rushed, got a briefing and used terminology which led to people perhaps thinking that they were going to get it.

Since then we have had a wide variety of groups feeling that they have a claim. Both the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) and I are consistently approached by these groups. One very impassioned group is the allied service men and women; people who say they have been here for 50 years, that they are Australian citizens and that they have worked all their lives, et cetera. We then have people who were in groups such as the Women's Auxiliary Air Force saying they volunteered and were willing to serve overseas and it was only unfortunate for them that they never got the opportunity. It goes on and on.

Quite frankly, as is clear from the budget papersâI do not know whether the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) is correct in his inference that perhaps the gold card has come at the expense of other programsâthe fact of life is that $500 million over a four-year period is a very significant expenditure. Any extensions beyond this have to be looked at fairly seriously and after great consideration by either side of politics.

However, of the many groups that are out there clamouring for extensions, one oversight by the parties is Korea. When we made the First World War decision, we could be fairly confident in saying that everyone who was 70 years of age should get the gold card. There were not going to be many people that were overlooked; Australia did not participate in the Spanish Civil War or in any of the other interwar conflicts around the world. There was no international dispute.

The Prime Minister did say that he thought that the extension to Korea and Vietnam should be on the same basis as the precedents set by the First World War and Second World War extensions. And, on the surface, that sounds very logical. But the fact is that, in the post-Second World War period, the onset of the Korean War was not too distant from the conclusion of hostilities in the Second World Warâand the Korean War dragged on until 1956. So, on the Prime Minister's implied commitment that he thought that what Labor did in 1973 was correct and that the government was now doing the same thing essentially 53 to 55 years after the conflict, what we are talking about in regard to Korean veterans is that they should get this benefit in 2009 or 2011.

Because we did not face this problem in the interwar yearsâwe did not have people who were 70 years of age involved in other conflicts that I am aware of, because there were no interwar disputesâwe had no people who fell between the cracks. We really do have to look at this problem because there is a distinct possibility that significant numbers of people who were in Korea have reached 70 years of age and, by the time that either side of politics says that on the past precedents they will get the gold card, they are going to be well in their 80s. I do not think this has really been thought through because, obviously, the focus has been on the Second World War people. They are the mass; they are the large numbers; and they are the dominant personalities in the service organisations that have had this as their first priority.

It is also worth notingâgiven the kind of hullabaloo about this thing being from left fieldâthat the Prime Minister has made it constantly obvious to the Australian electorate that the 1973 precedent was a good indicator. (Extension of time granted) He has consistently said that 1973 was a good precedent as to how we should extend the gold card. That is an important point because, for all the rhetoric about how glorious this decision was and how it broke new ground, the Prime Minister has said that 53 to 55 years is a reasonable time period after a conflict to grant this card. He also went on to say that, when we dealt with Korea and Vietnam down the track, he felt, as a person, as an individual and as a dominant player in our political system, that after 53 to 55 years they should get the gold card.
Mr Forrest interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe are well aware of that. The member for Mallee obviously got a newsletter last night that told him that people who have disabilities get the gold card. Everyone else in the room is aware of that. That is not groundbreaking information. In case the member is not aware of this yet, what we are talking about is the extension to those people who do not have war related disabilities. The vast mass of people who were in Korea, Vietnam, the Second World War and the First World War received the gold card regardless of the absence of war related injuries. That is what we are talking about today.

speech.para: The point I am trying to make is that both sides of politics need to have a look at the Korean veterans and face the reality that large numbers of them are already over 70 years of age. A significant number of them were career servicemen, some of whom had been in the Second World War and some of whom had been long-term enlisted people. It has to be looked at down the track by both sides.

The other point I am making is that, for all the rhetoric, for all the hullabaloo and for all the gala performances from the minister and the Prime Minister, the Prime Minister has essentially said that the 1973 extension was a good precedent and that 53 to 55 years afterwards is roughly when we should do it. That is what this government has done now. That precedent was created in 1973.

The other matter concerns the reference made by the member for McPherson to a reduction in assistance to service organisations in regard to helping clients. The minister looks a bit bedazzled by this. The member for McPherson made this claim. If that were the case, there must be grave concerns, because one of the serious problems in this department at the moment is legal aid. One does not see any new allocation, any new devotion of resources, to a very fundamental problem confronting the service community in this country.

I refer to a letter from the Law Society of New South Wales, which is certainly not affiliated to the Labor Party. In the actual contemporary debates of politics in New South Wales, they very strongly attacked the Premier of the state this week over his treatment of a judge who has been before the parliament in regard to his services. But the Law Societyâthat responsible, conservative, respected organisationâmade this point in correspondence dated 22 April to members of this parliament:

In the 1997/98 budget the Commonwealth Government reduced its contribution to legal aid by 21%. Funding for legal aid ranks amongst the Government's lowest funding priorities. The Attorney-General's portfolio of which legal aid is part received only 2.4% of the Commonwealth appropriation (ranking 11th of 20 Departments).
They went on to contrast defence, et cetera. They term this a significant and rapid reduction. They make the point that legal aid funding for criminal casesâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This point relating to legal aid does not fall within the defence and veterans' affairs portfolios. The member should bring his contribution back relative to the bill before the committee.
âOrder! Give me a chance to rule on the matter. It has been a fairly wide-ranging debate, but the member for Reid should bring his comments back to the rather narrow specifications of this bill.
âWith respect, there is an allocation in this portfolio to assist people to launch cases; is that correct?

speech.para: Mr Bruce Scott interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSorry, it is in respect of mounting cases. The degree to which that is valuable and effective assistance relates to the overall picture of how people launch and fight veterans cases. Quite clearly, it is of substantial importance that veterans are able to launch cases. I know the minister is a bit embarrassed by his failure to do something about this matter in the Attorney-General's portfolio. I am quite surprised that the severe hurt to veterans in launching cases has occurred. I was quite amazed that the minister actually allowed this to go through to the keeper. This very substantial downturn, this very serious reduction in resources, has meant a series of decisions by state governments which directly affect veterans.

speech.para: It is not going to be answered by some technical attempt to say that legal aid is totally separate from and unrelated to this portfolio. As we know, in the first year of his reign in this portfolio, the minister made much of how he was helping various groups launch cases, how he was giving assistance to this and that RSL to do this and that and how many grants there were around the place. So it is intrinsically connected with the question of legal aid. What we have seen, as I said, is a serious reduction by the government, and the veterans community is not interested in this fight between the various coalition state governments around Australia and their federal counterparts.

talk.start.para: âWhat have you got in New South Wales?

âI am glad the minister asked that question because, as he is well aware, New South Wales did have one facility that no other state in this country had. Until last year, veterans in New South Wales were able to receive help for VRB cases from the Veterans Advocacy Service, a part of the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission. The minister raised New South Wales, and he is very correct. The New South Wales Labor government had a superior system of legal aid for veterans which was over and above that of every other state in this country. So I am very glad he raised that. But what happened to that specific service which was superior to the rest of the services in the country? The federal Attorney-General's Department insisted that it go. So I am very glad the minister raised New South Wales.

speech.para: As the minister is well aware, that is not the total picture, because changes to legal aid in this country have essentially had very major impacts around the country. In his own state of Queensland, we are seeing perhaps the greatest number of letters from advocacy groups, lawyers and RSLs of any state in the country in regard to the way legal aid is being undermined in that state by the various limits. The Courier-Mail of 4 May certainly hit home on that issue. In Queensland, they are saying there will be a tougher merits test and an arbitrary lump sum various stage limit on veterans cases which will come into effect this month.

As the minister very correctly pointed out, whilst the New South Wales Labor government had the most superior legal aid assistance to veterans in this countryâand that is a very important point he has compelled me to makeâthe downturn in regard to legal aid around the country for veterans is very pronounced. In Victoria, they also introduced lump sum limits and tighter merit tests last year. For younger veterans with multiple series of medical complaints, the number of medical reports they can receive assistance for has also been limited. That is a very obvious concern to veterans.

On the question of veterans and their ability to launch cases, in last year's budget there was a reference to the government's proposal for panel diagnosis of Vietnam veterans. In this year's budget papers, there is a bit of a question mark over what is going on, because last year there were estimated savings to bring in this proposal. Like most of the interest groups, which are the Vietnam veterans associations, I was under the impression that this attempt to doctor shop on behalf of the departmentâthat is, to run around town until you got a doctor who was basically in line with what the department wantedâhad been abandoned. It seemed to have disappeared into the ether.

In these budget papers, there is no indication of a reversal of that. If there were to be savings last year and the idea had been abandoned and basically put further back, one would have thought it would have had to come into consideration in the estimates in this budget, but there is no mention of it. There is a figure in there which is roughly the same as what they were going to save last year for this proposal, so it seems they are going ahead with this system or a variation of it. It seems that despite assurances and winks and nods to service organisations in this field that they were not going to proceed, all the indications are that panel diagnosis or a variation of such, which is aimed in the end to save the government money, is going ahead. So that is a matter that does cause us concern.

talk.start.para: âDespite the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) saying that I have not darkened his door since he has been the minister, I ought to say that I have had cooperation from his office, staff and advisersâwhich I appreciateâas I have had from the department. So I regret that he took the opportunity to make the remarks that he did, so as to in some way cast aspersions on my credibility and my commitment to veterans causes. Saying that I had not grovelled around to his office since the coalition has been in government was an insulting remark and, in insulting me, I think he insulted a number of others as well. I did not think it was necessary to take up the minister's personal time. In fact, I am not sure that he would have been able to tell me anything that I did not already know.
âIn fact you might have been able to teach him.

âI am not saying whether that is the case or not. The fact is that I was able to get plenty of help and I am still able to get plenty of help without seeing the minister personally. I took that as a serious reflection on my integrity and my commitment to this cause.

speech.para: I do not want to make veterans in this place a political football. Although I have frequently spoken about veterans issues in this place, I have not done so on the basis of attempting to make them some sort of political football. I do, nevertheless, feel free to say on behalf of the veterans community that they do get a bit tired of platitudes. It is all right for successive governments to get up and say, `We're doing great things for veterans. Look at `Their ServiceâOur Heritage'. That is a great idea.' Some of the things in that program are worth while, but I was concerned at the time it was done that it was some sort of an attemptâand I am prepared to accept that it was notâto build up the momentum that the previous government had quite correctly built with Australia Remembers.

I said in my contribution last week that Australia Remembers was a great program. It stood alone; it was appropriate. I was concerned when we went with `Their ServiceâOur Heritage' that it was something of an attempt to carry on the momentum. Nevertheless, I accept that, within that program, there are some very worthwhile initiatives.

In my new capacity as the Leader of the Christian Democratic Party in this place, I want to say what I said last week: I will be uncompromisingly in here to speak for veterans. Perhaps I was not able to do that in the past as a member of a political party that I thought, and still essentially believe, is committed to the veterans community.

Like the minister said last week, all of us in this place ought to be, and hopefully are, committed to our veterans, but it needs to be demonstrated in action rather than words. That is why I feel, without having the minister insult me, quite entitled to ask questions and to make statements about matters of concern to veterans. Let me start now with a number of particular matters.

talk.start.para: âWe are running out of time.

âYou might be running out of your time, but I am not running out of mine. We have quite a bit of time to go, and I want to go through this line by line. I have not had the benefit of the departmental briefing, but maybe they can take my questions on notice.

speech.para: I want to take up the matter of the gold card. I think the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) is right. There was an impression given, and it may have been a mistake, that somehow the gold card was going to go to all Second World War veterans. I am not decrying what has been done, but I am saying that I think an impression was given that the gold card was going to go to all Second World War veterans. When the fine print came down, that was not the case. What we have done here is create a class of second-class veterans. They have always been, and they continue to be, a whole group of second-class veterans in respect of not only this matter but also, for instance, the disability pension, which the member for Reid also mentioned.

Because they do not get a service pension, their disability pension is treated as income. I have given up on the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) on this matter. I made a speech in 1996 when I said, with some pride, `Look, the government has set up a review into that.' As I said in my speech last week, I wrote to the minister on a number of occasions and said, `What's happening to the review?' and she said, `The review is almost complete.' Finally, the review was completed, and the advice I got then was that it is all too hard and it is going to cost the government a lot of money. Obviously, it has now been put in the too-hard basket. There is a serious element of discrimination here against a group of veterans who have their disability pension treated differently. (Extension of time granted)

When is the government going to correct the discrimination against those veterans who are getting disability pensions treated as income vis-a-vis those who have service pensions who are obviously getting them on top of their pensions? What is the government going to do about that? They have carried out the review. They have admitted it is a problem. They have said it is in the too-hard basket. I want to know what is going to happen.

In respect of the gold card, there is a case, in my view, for extending the gold card to all Second World War veterans. A number of them have been to see me and have said, `I don't have the so-called qualifying service. I was not posted on active service, but I volunteered. I could have gone anywhere in the world as a volunteer, but I ended up in Townsville, outside the period where qualifying service might have applied,' or `I ended up in Brisbane.' `Nevertheless, I gave up two or three years of my life.' I think they are now entitled to ask whether at some point they will get the gold card.

I also raise the issue of the Korean veterans, and I think the member for Reid mentioned that matter. A large number of them are over 70 years old. They actually saw active service in Korea. Is the government at some stage going to contemplate extending the gold card to them? I think there are even some Vietnam veteransânot the ones in this room because they are too youngâwho are in their seventies, probably not a large number, who would also be entitled to ask the same question about whether the government is contemplating giving the gold card to them.

I was going to raise the question of legal aid because it obviously is a matter of great concern to veterans at the moment. The fact is that their rights to pursue their entitlements to the ultimate extent are being taken away from them. They cannot do it, obviously, if they do not have legal aid, yet in Queensland, as the member for Reid quite correctly says, there is a serious problem about access to legal aid.

Finally, I wanted to raise the question of the Vietnam veterans morbidity study. I asked a question of the minister about this in the parliament the other day. I did a naughty thing and actually told the minister's office that I was going to ask him the question.

talk.start.para: âIt was very evident, too.

âIt was evident because he happened to have the report in there with him. Despite all of that, he did not answer my question. I thought, next time I tell him I am going to ask him a question, I had better give him the question, not just tell him I am going to ask him a question. I said to the minister's office, `I'm going to ask the minister a question about the Vietnam veterans morbidity study.' The actual question I asked him was: if the results are validated, what action is the government going to take, particularly having regard to the children of veteransâand one of the key concerns that came out of this report is that it is actually the children of veterans who are suffering from a large range of illnesses and effects from their fathers' service.

speech.para: I want to know why there is nothing in the budget. There was a program floating around, the name of which escapes me now, that the Vietnam veterans thought was for that purposeâ to provide some advance fundingâbecause, hopefully, the findings in that report will be validated quickly. I assume it is a priority for that to be completed. So I want the minister to tell us that if the results are validated the government will act in the interests of the children and families. The veterans are more or less taken care of within the existing system, but the real concern is with the children.

I pointed out to the minister in my question that in the United States there was a precedent with the recognition that spina bifida in the children of Vietnam veterans was caused by their fathers' war service. There was an acceptance by the United States government. The minister is shaking his head. He can answer the question because I think the United States government has set a precedent.

I apologise to the minister if I have overstated it. But I was offended by the remarks I heard him say in respect of my contribution last week because I think he did attempt to patronise me and I will not be patronised in this area. That speech was in the context of a bill to do with war widows. My mother is a war widow. To put aside my own involvement in this, I had a deep emotional commitment to that issue, as I do to veterans' affairs, and I will not hesitate to stand in this place and speak strongly on behalf of veterans.

talk.start.para: âWe have had a range of comments from the opposition on this, the anniversary of the Battle of Midway back in 1942 and also the 201st anniversary of the first arrival of merino sheep in Australia, so it is a very important day. I had hoped that we would see some members on the other side of the House wearing their wool today in support of our Australian wool industry.

speech.para: I certainly want to answer some of the questions raised by those on the other side of the House. I say to the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) I do acknowledge that he is a Vietnam veteran himself. I acknowledged that in the parliament last week, I acknowledge it here again today, and I acknowledge his service to our nation. I want to say, as he said todayâit is a line I have used since becoming ministerâthat veterans are not a political football. His comment today suggests that he is using that same line. I welcome that and I think every member of this parliament should remember that when they make comments in relation to our veterans and war widows.

I will comment on some of the questions raised. Firstly, I will deal with the issue of a briefing. I understand that the member for McPherson requested a briefing on Monday. Today is Wednesday. Obviously, in a ministerial office, with a full diary every day from early in the morning until late in the evening, it is not always possible to respond immediately. The same would apply to the department. But you are welcome to a briefing and there is no need to write. The shadow minister and I work extremely well on issues in relation to veterans because I try to make sure that the shadow ministerâand anyone else in this parliament who wants information in relation to programsâhas access to that information.

In relation to the budget, the member for McPherson suggested that we had cut fundingâand that is what I took offence at last week. He suggests today that they are programs. There is an increase of $500 million this year. I will run through some of those issues. There is $96 million in the forward estimates for the coming 12 months for the gold card; for the direct purchase of health care for veterans, there is an increase of $150 million in the forward estimates for the coming financial year.

For the Australian War Memorial, there is an extra $2 million in the forward estimates to make sure that they can maintain an adequate base in their funding for the maintenance of the Australian War Memorial. That is a real commitment that we have given. In our first budget, we gave something like $7 million for the much needed restoration of our great national treasure, the Australian War Memorial, and our government has made a commitment that there will be no entry feesâwhich were being considered by the past administrationâto go to see our Australian War Memorial, and we have committed extra funds there.

There is also the extension of $194 million in the current 12 months forward estimates for the growth that is expected in the cost of health care for our veterans. So the $500 million is for the next 12 months increase, based on just those four or five programs. Of course, that was reflected in the forward estimates.

You also suggested in relation to the War Memorial that there have been some reductions. Can I explain for the benefit of the member that there are one-off appropriationsâfor instance, for the women's service memorial, $70,000 in 1997-98. It is not going to appear in 1998-99 because the money has been drawn down for that memorial. For the merchant navy memorial, there is $100,000 in 1997-98 which is not going to appear again this year. So sometimes programs like that are specific programs that are not ongoing. With those two memorials, I think you should understand that once the memorial is constructed or the money drawn down, there is no need to go back and do it again; it is a one-off.

I touch on the issue of the gold card. There seems to be some confusion relating to what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said. I have got the Prime Minister's press release here. (Extension of time granted) If you have got any doubt in your mind, you should always read the press release. Sometimes the media might not give the full context. We all know in this place that the media sometimes can cut short someone's response, whether it is a voice or whether it is even a press release. I will read the first paragraph:

All World War II veterans who served in the Australian Armed Forces and faced danger from hostile forces during that conflict will now qualify for comprehensive health care under an extension of the Gold Card benefits, worth $508 million.

That is a net figure of $508 million. So that should answer that question. I hope it is answered once and for all. That is quite clear. The Prime Minister did not mislead anyone. I think members should look at that.

I want to further touch on the issue of the gold card and any further extension. I am interested in any further extension. I am not quite sure whether the opposition is committing to an extension to other areas of service. Obviously, it is an issue that would be a priority for ex-service organisations. I am interested in whether the shadow minister is suggesting this as their promise. They had 13 years in government and we await more than your seven dot points that came out of Hobart in relation to your policy for the veteran community.

The member for McPherson raised the issue of the disability pension and the eligibility for service pension and how it is counted as income by the Department of Social Security. There is a very comprehensive review being done by government right now.

talk.start.para: âIt is completed.
âIt is not completed.
âYou got it wrong again.
âI told you he was slow on his feet.

âI am giving you the information. It is an interdepartmental review, and it is not finished. You sought the information, and I am giving you the information. In response to the remarks of the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) about being my slow on my feet, I think his patronising comments never change, and I guess he never learns.

speech.para: Obviously, we are taking the issue seriously. I want the member for McPherson to be aware that a service pension is all about persons who have qualifying service. The whole repatriation system, which is 80 years old this year, was based on those who faced the hostile forces of the enemy. If you move away from that fundamental plank, you diminish the service of all those who have qualifying service. That will say to them, `We are not going to treat you as anything special.' That is what that will do.

The member for McPherson, who is a returned serviceman himself, I think understands that the repatriation system was built around those principles. I have a father who also served, but he did not serve outside of Australia. I also have a younger brother, who was conscripted in the Vietnam conflict. So do not come to me and say that I might not know anything about this issue.

talk.start.para: âI didn't say that.

âYou inferred it. I take the issue very seriously. In relation to the validation process for Vietnam veterans, it is this government that conducted this health study. It is a self-assessment study. I take the issue of the health of Vietnam veterans and all veterans very seriously. We have already said that the health of Vietnam veterans is a major concern to the government. I will not leave any stone unturned until we get to the bottom of it. We have committed $750,000 to research, particularly in relation to genetic disorders and the effects of agent white, or agent orange, as many people would more commonly know it. So we are taking it very seriously.

speech.para: You asked what action the government will take. The government cannot respond until that validation process is completed. We have gone to great lengths to complete this study. We want the validation. I think it is one of the most significant studies of the health of any serviceman or woman who has served in any war anywhere in the world from any nation. So the rest of the world is watching this validation process and its results. (Extension of time granted)

In relation to the US government's decision to extend the benefits of their system of support to children of Vietnam veterans with spina bifida, prior to that decision, their welfare system did not pick up those children, as I understand it. Our system did. Our welfare system will pick up those children with disabilities. So to say that the American government has done something that we have not is incorrect. Our system already picks them up within the welfare system, not under the Veterans' Entitlement Act. That is why we do have a very good welfare system in this country.

The American government acknowledged that those children of Vietnam veterans who have spina bifida, and they said that the causal link was not necessarily established, would be supported by a government program. We pick up our spina bifida children here in Australia through our welfare system. Once again, I think that underpins the fact that we in Australia have the best repatriation system in the world. We also have a very good welfare systemâamongst the best in the world.

What we are trying to do now is get to the bottom of the health related issues, as they may have affected the veterans whom we have already acknowledged. All those conditions that were identified in that study are, in fact, covered under the Veterans' Entitlement Act today. We are seriously looking at and awaiting the final validation process in relation to that health study.

talk.start.para: âWhen will that be?

âWe hopeâand as I said when I addressed the Vietnam Veterans Association in Darwin a couple of weekends agoâthat it will be by the end of this year. It is a process that you cannot rush, because to get it right, to get it validated properly, is the most important thing. That is what we are doing. We will continue to monitor any situation relating to the health of our veterans.

speech.para: I want to touch on the issue of panel diagnosis. I think when I first became minister what I discovered as I travelled around was the fact that many veterans, particularly Vietnam veterans, were not happy with the system as it was at the time in relation to diagnosis of PTSD. The veterans were not happy with the system. Therefore, I was not happy.

talk.start.para: âI wasn't happy either.

âNo-one was happy. They said that there needs to be some change. We needed to get a system that everyone had confidence in. The veterans have to have confidence in the process of diagnosis. What we are dealing with in relation to PTSD is something you cannot see. I often describe it this way: you can go and have a look at a new car, which is all polished up and looks great, but when you lift the bonnet and look at the engine you still cannot see inside the workings of that machine. That is what PTSD is like. It is a psychological disorder. You cannot see it. It is a very difficult assessment, as I think many would acknowledge.

speech.para: Whilst the veterans were not happy and the department was not happy, we have to come up with a system that everyone has confidence in. That is what we are seeking to achieve as part of the process of getting a regime in place that, importantly, our veterans will have confidence in.
Mr Laurie Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo. I think it is about getting confidence in the system. The department is working with the Vietnam veterans organisations. It is a partnership arrangement. That is very important. Everyone at the end of the day, from the person at the front door of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in the main office, in one of the state offices or working through an agency arrangement, are all committed to our veteran community. I know that in Mildura, in the electorate of the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), we have recently established a contractual arrangement so that the local council office is the provider. That is working extremely well out there. It is an invaluable service in a rural area. Wherever the department people are, they are committed, as this government is committed, to delivering the best possible health service to those who gave service to this nation of ours of which we are all so proud.

speech.para: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

para.inline: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

speech.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,394,960,000

talk.start.para: âBefore we move into a more comprehensive consideration of these issues, I pose a question to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) concerning one outstanding issue that was raised in these proceedings last year. I must say I join with him in expressing some concern about a former employee of his, a Mr Oldfield. During those proceedings in the Main Committee, the parliamentary secretary undertook to conduct a full, comprehensive and exhaustive investigation as to Mr Oldfield's activities whilst in his employ as a parliamentary secretary.

speech.para: A serious issue was then raised by the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not Mr Oldfield, whilst in the employ of the parliamentary secretary, had conducted himself in a bona fide way with respect to accountability on the use of his travel entitlements, the use of his time and other facilities such as mobile telephones, telecards, et cetera.

I cannot find, since that undertaking was given by the parliamentary secretary, a full and proper report back to the parliament, nor do I find any reference to it in the department's papers, because perhaps in the overall consideration of these issues, expenditure wise, it might be a minuscule issue. But I think the parliamentary secretary had a right to express his concerns in the Main Committee when these matters were last considered. Before moving on to other issues, I pose that question at the outset, so as to enable the parliamentary secretary to get that issue off the agenda. Then we can move on to new issues.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) for raising that matter. Yes, I am conscious of the discussion we had last year on this self-same subject. I am also conscious of the way I felt at the time, and still feel, about the treachery of my former staff member.

speech.para: As I indicated to the Main Committee then, I believed that my former staff member had made inappropriate phone calls using departmental equipment and that he had made trips as a governmental staffer that were completely and utterly inappropriate. I referred those matters to the departmental secretary for departmental investigation.

As a result of those investigations, I believe that some moneyâI seem to recollect from memory that it was some hundreds of dollarsâwas repaid by Mr Oldfield for phone calls which he agreed were not within the entitlement. The matter was then referred to the police for further investigation. I believe that that police investigation went on for quite a few months. I received advice probably about a month ago that the police had declined to take the matter further.

That is where things are. I do not know that there is much more that really can be done except for me to put on the record yet again that I believe that former staffer of mine behaved contemptibly. I only hope for the sake of the people of Australia that he is behaving better in his current employ.

talk.start.para: âFollowing on from the answer of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott), as I understand it, Mr Oldfield, formerly an employee of the parliamentary secretary, is now in the employ of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). He mentioned the recovery of moneys owed to the department with respect to telephone accounts. Was there any full and proper investigation with respect to his time and also the use of travel entitlements? Could he also enlighten the Australian public as to why the Federal Police, unlike what is the case with members on both sides of the House who are currently being pursued through the courts, chose not to prosecute one Mr Oldfield, an employee of Ms Pauline Hanson, the member for Oxley.
âBefore I call the parliamentary secretary, I understand that members' staff are paid out of the appropriation of the Department of Finance and Administration.

âI do not like to darken these proceedings by mentioning him by name, but Mr Oldfield was on my ministerial staff entitlement. I am not sure precisely what that means in terms of where his salary comes from, but certainly travel and other entitlements were provided for out of the departmental budget. The departmental investigation was into his use of departmental entitlements and, as I said, he repaid some hundreds of dollars.
âDid it include travel?

âYes, it included travel. From memory, he repaid some hundreds of dollars relating to inappropriate, out-of-entitlement phone calls. There were no repayments for travel because he claimed, with some justification, that he had also done legitimate businessâwhatever else he might have doneâon these trips. At that point the department referred the matter on to the police. The police, after what was certainly a lengthy and I can only assume a thorough investigation, decided that they could not take the matter further.

speech.para: I understand the concerns of the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). Certainly in the weeks and months following my former staffer's defection, I was absolutely appalled, flabbergasted and, I have to say, ashamed of the sorts of things which it turned out he had been doing. I took the only appropriate action under the circumstances.

The member for Batman asked about my former staffer's time. What he does in his own spare time outside of hours, as it were, is really his own business. Obviously there is an expectation that out of a sense of fitnessânot to mention loyaltyâthat staff of politicians will act in ways which are consistent with the loyalties and allegiances of their employer, and plainly in this case my former staffer did not do that.

As the member for Batman says, my former staffer is now in the employ of the member for Oxley and has, I believe, been on her staff ever since he left me. Certainly he was acting informally as an adviser to her for some months before leaving me. I was never aware of that. As I said, I regard it as contemptible behaviour on his part. But he is now, in his capacity as an assistant to or a staff member of the member of Oxley, apparently acting as the One Nation campaign director in Queensland. How that squares with his employment and his payment by the Commonwealth is a very interesting question but beyond the scope of these estimates.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I think we should leave this particular aspect of this topic because, as I understand it, staff salary, travel and entitlements, et cetera come out of the Department of Finance and Administration and we have already earlier today dealt with the estimates for that department. If the honourable member for Batman or anyone else wishes to pursue this issue, they should exercise other avenues. I think we should now move on to a more detailed examination of the expenditure proposed for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

âI understand your concerns and your suggestion, but there is one final issue that does not go to the use of entitlements. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) referred to the fact that he is now convinced that, whilst this person was in his employ, he was secretly carrying out work for another political party.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I think you have half ruled on it, but I am sitting here wondering what possible relevance this has to do with the budget appropriation that we are currently dealing with. Can you instruct the member to please get on with it.
âI thought I had done that.
âEnforce it, if you like, but let us be relevant.

âIf the member for Batman wishes to raise this issue, he has to somehow relate it to the expenditure for the department that we are considering. If he is just going to ask about the salary and so forth of a former employee, that should have been dealt with earlier today under the Department of Finance and Administration. Like him, I am bound by the standing orders and I have ruled that we should now move on. There are other avenues available in the parliament if he wishes to raise these issues. But the member must relate it to the expenditure for the department of employment, otherwise it will be out of order.

âThe issue relates to carrying out the duties for and on behalf of the parliamentary secretary. The parliamentary secretary, if anything, made a suggestion that coat-hanger activities were conducted by a member of his staff on the basis of perhaps justifying movements around Australia to carry out activities for other people. Is it his view personally that, when he examined the justification for some of that travel, the actual work carried out on behalf of the parliamentary secretary and the department itself was, if anything, very minor and merely a means to justify other activities? I suggest that it might have been.

âI must rule that we as a committee are not interested in personal views. If the honourable member for Batman wishes to obtain a personal view from the parliamentary secretary, he should either put it in writing or maybe put it on the Notice Paper . But, as I have said on three occasions, I think we have canvassed this issue fairly thoroughlyâin fact, maybe too thoroughlyâbearing in mind that the matter of staff salary, travel and other entitlements is a matter for the Department of Finance and Administration which we have already dealt with earlier today.

interjection.para: What we are dealing with now is the proposed expenditure for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Regardless of what the parliamentary secretary's personal view on present, former or prospective staff may or may not be, I hardly think it is relevant to this expenditure. We should move on now with the consideration of the proposed expenditure for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The honourable member for Batman is making my job quite difficult this morning.

talk.start.para: âBecause you are so highly respected, Mr Deputy Speaker and a very close personal friend of mine who, I hope, is going to vote for me in the future, I will now move on to some other issues. I understand that the question I have raised will be responded to by the parliamentary secretary because he would not want it hanging over his activities as parliamentary secretary. This issue does not just relate to budgetary expenditure; it also relates to the problems of unemployment and some of the changes in government policy that were announced not just in this budget but in previous budgets and partly implemented in this budget.

speech.para: At the outset, I want to say that I think the budgetary process with respect to the unemployed has become a painful and unnecessary journey to nowhere. When considering this department in detail, you have to consider the overall problem of unemployment and, in that context, I go to the budget projections for unemployment.

The real problem for the budget process is that it is going nowhere when it comes to doing something about the jobless. Even though the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) might regard parts of the budget as being heroic growth assumptions, my reading of the budget papers leads me to believe that we are still talking about a stubbornly difficult unemployment rate of eight per cent over the next 12 months. On the basis of the budget projections, that effectively means that unemployment is going to increase during that 12 months from the current level of 7.9 per cent.

I would also like to say that, despite the government's endeavours to prompt and change the view of the department, the department still said that, based on the performance of the previous Labor government, we were on target to achieve an unemployment rate of five per cent by the turn of the century. If Labor had remained in governmentâand had continued to grow the whole economy one per cent faster and jobs nearly three times faster than the coalitionâunemployment would now be down to six per cent, with 150,000 more Australians back at work.

I raise that in the context of the budget predictions. When you compare them with the ABS figures on unemployment, it shows that the participation rate has now fallen by over half a per cent since this government was elected. I therefore put to the minister that, if this government had the participation rate that we had at the time of the last election in March 1996, we not only would not have an unemployment rate of 7.9 per cent today based on the last monthly figures; we would have an unemployment rate in the order of 8.8 per cent. Based on the budget projections of growth, if we had the same participation rate, we would be potentially looking at a projected unemployment rate of way over nine per cent today.

That is very important when considering these budget processes, because even Dr Hewson, a former close friend of the parliamentary secretary, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), has suggested there are major problems with the budget projections going to the level of economic growth, the potential impact of the Asian crisis on the Australian economy and the fallout from the jobs front. I think we ought to have a proper discussion today about where we are actually going on the unemployment rate and the fact that the participation rate has fallen by over half a per cent. That suggests that, if the government had maintained a sense of hope and confidence in the economy, the unemployment rate today would be in the order of 8.8 per cent. On the basis of the budget projections and using that participation rate, we would be looking in normal circumstances at an unemployment rate of over nine per cent in the next 12 months. That is not denying the fact that, in these budget papers, the government accepts that unemployment is actually going to increase over the next 12 months.

We have to be honest with the Australian community. This budget suggests that unemployment is going to increase over the next 12 months. We cannot escape the fact that it would get worse if all of a sudden people said, `We're going to go back into the work force.' I know the government has a strategy of actually forcing people out of the work force. I need only refer in passing to the fact that the government has cut assistance to child care by $800 millionâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI have a few queries in relation to some of the accounts of this department. I notice in the accounts that the running costs are $461.5 million and a reference is made to `other services' of $1.871 billion. Firstly, how much of those running costs is going to pay people in the department who are regarded as unattachedâthat is, who do not have a position and who are not engaged in gainful employmentâbut who are drawing a salary from the Commonwealth? If there are a number of people in that position, and I would be interested in both quantum and numbers, why is this occurring and what can be done in a department such as this to prevent it from occurring? Secondly, what do the `other services' refer to? If I could get an answer on that, I would be obliged.

speech.para: In relation to this portfolio, may I say at the outset that I have a warm personal regard for the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp). On all the occasions I have dealt with him, he has given me prompt attention. He is a diligent worker and he is a most intelligent individual. I do, however, draw attention to a number of concerns I have in relation to the operation of the new employment job market scheme.

In particular, many complaints are coming through from, shall I say, people in the underemployed category and people who are not on benefits generallyâthose sorts of peopleâwho are striving to get employment, who are having absolutely no success in doing so and who are being shunted between job placement providers. It is the most depressing thing. Mr Irving, a constituent of mine, came to see me last Saturday with his wife, and he bitterly complained of the system.

talk.start.para: âSo you work on Saturday?

âYes, I work Saturday and Sundayâno double time either. The fact of the matter is that he came to see me most bitterly disappointed with the system. He said that last week was one of the most depressing in his two years of looking for work. He went to a number of places to register. He was told that he was not eligible as he was not on a benefit. He is desperately wanting to get a job. While he is 80 per cent through a design and drafting engineering qualification, unfortunately, he is in that over-45 age group. I could see nothing but genuineness etched all over his face as someone who is desperately trying to get work but who is finding the system basically against him.

speech.para: The interest of the providers diminishes immediately when he cannot quote a number or he cannot say that he is registered as unemployed. Basically, out of a number of providers he went to see, only one showed a smidgen of interest in trying to place him somewhere. So the frustration and the disappointment were, as I say, etched all over his face. That is one person, but that one really sticks in my mind amongst many others who have told me similar stories. We must look at the situation that has occurred that is denying people these particular benefits.

Also I mentionâand I would like to develop this furtherâthat employers were used to a situation with the old CES where they were able to get assistance in finding employees, but one very irate employer rang me up a few weeks ago to tell me that he was going to be charged upwards of $250. I approached the minister's office about this. I did not believe that was true but, to my horror, I was told that it was. We were never told that in the party room, I can assure you. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI might begin by just picking up on the comments of the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) with respect to the ability of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp). There is no doubt that this is a minister with a great mind, a very intelligent man. But the problem is that he is also a man absolutely ideologically driven. Day after day in question time he stands at that dispatch box giving new meaning to the phrase `lies, damned lies and statistics'. He consistently fiddles with the figures to give a false impression about the impact of his employment policies and the impact of his educational policies on the wider community.

speech.para: He is now responsible for this part of the budget which effectively runs up the white flag on unemployment. This was the minister who, when in opposition, travelled the width and breadth of this country bleating about the rates of unemployment in this country, in particular bleating about rates of youth unemployment, yet he is now prepared to accept that, in 12 months time, unemployment in this country will be no better than it is todayâindeed, no better than what it was when he came to office. In particular, he is prepared to concede that youth unemployment will stay higher than it was before he came to office.

I want to turn to the impact that has on my electorate. As you know, the unemployment rate in the Hunter region is hovering still well above 10 per cent. In my own home town of Cessnock, it is around 12 per cent. Cessnock is a community founded on coal. The township and the more than 20 villages that surround the town were founded on the coal that was beneath the surface. We once had almost 30 coalmines in the Cessnock LGA, now we have but one, which is about to close. We used to have a textile and clothing industry. It is no longer with us. Our kids used to travel to Newcastle to manufacturing firms like BHP, Comsteel and Tubemakers for their apprenticeships, but obviously those opportunities are now very limited. The LGA's one great hope, the tourism sector, driven by the local wine industry, now faces new challenges due to the Asian economic crisis.

What is this government's response to all that? It is not an industry assistance package or a labour market adjustment package. I might say too, that while those coalmines are now closed in the immediate area of Cessnock, something like 20 per cent of the work force still works in the coalmining industry. Those men and some women travel down to the lake, but mainly they travel to the Upper Hunter to work in large open cut coalmines like Hunter Valley No. 1 and Mount Thorleyâcoalmines that have been in the news of late due to Rio Tinto's attack on working conditions within those mines.

Coalmining remains a significant employer, and yet there is a range of studies that show that, due to the depressed price of coal, at least another 1,000 jobs will go in the industry in the Upper Hunter over the next 12 monthsâa further impact on the Cessnock local government area. I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on 16 December last year asking him to address this problem, putting forward a significant case for an economic adjustment package in the local area of Cessnock. What was his response? None at all. Not even an acknowledgment of my letter, not even an acknowledgment from the Prime Minister of my representation with respect to the dire economic situation in Cessnock. What has been their response to the unemployment situation in Cessnock? No thought of assistance in terms of economic recovery, none at all.

There was a bit of assistance for Newcastle when BHP announced the closure of the steel industry. But an Upper Hunter BEC study shows that the downturn in the coal industry in the Upper Hunter in comparative terms will have a greater impact on that community and the communities which rely upon it than, indeed, the BHP steelwork's closure will have on Newcastle and its surrounds. I do not see the Prime Minister coming to the Cessnock local government area or, indeed, the Upper Hunter. I know it took him a long time to come to Newcastle. (Extension of time granted) I will keep pushing to ensure that the Prime Minister comes to Cessnock, and so he should.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We are currently discussing a question about appropriations for employment, education, training and youth affairs. I know there is wide scope in a debate on appropriations. But the member is talking specifically about the situation in his electorate. I am wondering what possible relationship there is with the appropriation we are considering. I would like him to be a little more consistent with the issue under discussion.
âOrder! The appropriation expenditure is to do with Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I think the honourable member is dealing with that area.

âIt hurts when I expose the Prime Minister's incompetence, and it hurts when I expose the Prime Minister's lack of care and concern for Labor electorates, basicallyâfor those working Australians who live in relatively safe Labor electorates. But I thank the honourable member for his contribution because I am about to come to that very point.

speech.para: I will speak about the one thing that the Prime Minister has done in the Cessnock LGA; that is, he has imposed significant changes in employment services. Cessnock used to have a Commonwealth Employment Service that once upon a time employed about 20 peopleâ

talk.start.para: âIt was a very good one.

âWhen it closed, it was employing 10 peopleâand it was a very good service, as the honourable member interjects. Cessnock also had a great community infrastructure. It comprised organisations like Northumberland Network, the Samaritans Foundation, the skillshare that was based in Kurri Kurri, for exampleâall very good organisations with a great track record which had for years provided very good employment services for the unemployed in Cessnock.

speech.para: But what do we have now as a result of the new Job Network? We have an office of Employment National with five staff, and nothing elseâno contracts for Northumberland Network, no contracts for the Samaritans and, of course, Kurri Kurri skillshare cannot be given contracts because it went out the window earlier with one of the other ideologically driven approaches; and that is it. We were to have two sites in Cessnock: we were to have Employment National doing both FLEX 1 and FLEX 3 services; we were also supposed to have Hospitality Horizons providing FLEX 1 services only. Of course, as we know, due to the farcical situation, Hospitality Horizons has fallen over, leaving Cessnock with one site only.
Let us look at Maitland, next door in the government held marginal seat of Paterson: six sitesâand I thank the parliamentary secretary for his smile, which just says it all.

talk.start.para: âHe's embarrassed.

âAs the honourable member for Batman interjects, he is embarrassed by this situation. There are six sites in Maitland, where the unemployment rate is lower than in Cessnock; and one in Cessnock, where the unemployment rate is in excess of 12 per cent. There are eight service providers in Maitland with its six sites. The government will argue that some of those service providers based in Maitland have contracts to provide services in Cessnock. But what a farce that is. Mission Australia have just rented an office from the Samaritans Foundation for one day a week; that will be that organisation's contribution. I support Mission Australia; I hope that they will do a great job, and I will do all I can to assist them because we need some help.

speech.para: The parliamentary secretary will say, `These allocations of contracts have all been done independently, and all prudential scrutiny has been exercised.' But how can anyone possibly explain how Maitland, with a lower unemployment rate than Cessnock, could possibly have six sites compared with Cessnock's one or two, as was intended? There is just no logic in that at all.

Today, during this debate, I challenge the parliamentary secretary to explain to me and my constituents, including the almost 4,000 people who are unemployed in the Cessnock LGA, why it is that now they have two choices: to line up at the office of National Employment, with five staff down from the 10 which the CES had; or catch a private bus to Maitland or Newcastle at a cost of between $6 and $16.

talk.start.para: âAnd that's before the GST.

âYes, that is before the GST, as the member for Batman says; that bus fare is about to rise. So I challenge the parliamentary secretary today not to give me the general waffle about how many providers and sites there are in the DEETYA region or the area but to explain to me why it is that there is only one site for the almost 4,000 unemployed living in the town of Cessnock.

âFor a discussion of this portfolio's appropriations, one really has to go to the statistics, because Minister Kemp is renowned for the way in which he manipulates figures to do with his portfolio. He is renowned for his ability to be the great propagandist of the government.

speech.para: I want to go to a study, released on Sunday by the Brotherhood of St Laurence, which looked at the new Job Networkâthe brave new world of employment services. There are a few themes in this paper that was prepared by Dr Paul Pickering of the Research School of Social Sciences at the Australian National University, one of which has been touched on by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon)âand that is the disproportionate way in which tenders have been allocated throughout Australia.

If you look at the local area that I represent and, say, the program now known as jobsearch training, in the dormitory municipalities of Nillumbik, Banyule and Whittlesea, which are in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, we find that no jobsearch training tenders have been let. In fact, for the whole north-east region of Melbourne, there are only five, with four of those in Preston within the seat of Batman. That is just an example of the lack of access that has been provided to certain regions under this new program.

I go to the funding and the problem that is isolated in this paper which was released on Sunday. The fact is that there is a gross underfunding of the programs, on the basis of the figures that the minister and the department have released. If we go to the budget papers, for the term of the tendersâthat is, from 1 May 1998 to 30 November 1999âand taking intensive assistance, which in the build-up to the letting of the tenders was known as FLEX 3, the department says that there will be 550,000 commencements and the maximum number of 247,500 job seekers at any one time.

Dr Pickering did some sums on this in his paper on the basis of the initial payment. He indicated that of the $1.1 billion, which previous papers have indicated would be available for that 18-month period, 89.6 per cent of the intensive assistance budget would be taken up by the initial commencement payments, allowing just over 10 per cent for the larger outcome fees. In response to this, a spokesman for the minister is quoted in today's Age saying that the paper was flawed because it had not taken into account the fact that 100,000 people had transferred from intensive assistance from the old employment market to the Job Network.

That statement from the spokesperson on behalf of the minister does not allow for the fact that in Dr Pickering's paper he went on to say that, after doing those calculations indicating that nearly 90 per cent of the budget would be taken up by commencement fees, even allowing for a percentage of roll-over clients, those who are already receiving assistance and who attract smaller commencement fees, and clients who complete their outcome in a subsequent contract period, there is still a big financial hole.

If we take 110,000 transitional clients and we spread them proportionately over the three levels under intensive assistance, which have different gradings of commencement feesâFLEX 3.1 has $1,500, FLEX 3.2 has $2,250 or FLEX 3.3 has $3,000âthat adds up to $806 million. If we take 100,000 transitional clients at a minimum transfer fee of $1,100, that adds up to a total of $916 million. That is 83.3 per cent of the total budget for intensive assistance, leaving only 16.7 per cent of that budget for the higher outcome fees.

How does it work? Yet again, Minister Kemp or Minister Kemp's department is coming up with figures that are put in place to totally confuse, either that or, if we take it on the balance of the evidence before us, it is a great con. Perhaps the great con is that the minister knew that, even though he is ideologically driven, he was putting in place something that just will not work. This is a tragic con because it is a con on the unemployed people of Australia. That is the real thing that sticks in people's craws. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn this debate on the appropriation bills dealing with the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, I am going to concentrate very much on youth affairs. There is a sleeper issue out there in the electorate which will bite this government like you would not believe. The reaction from the electorate will be similar to that greeting the futile nursing home changes which panicked the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) so much that his government changed its position at least 14 times and cost a minister her job. I refer to the introduction of the common youth allowance on 1 July 1998.

speech.para: The government thought that it had tucked this measure into the back of a huge budget paper pile that we all get lumbered with and that somehow people would not notice it until it was too late. Well, they have noticed it. The electorate is beginning to stir. They can smell something that is not right with this measure, and they are starting to make their voices heard. My office has already been receiving a steady flow of inquiries from worried, outraged parents.
The government is so secretly concerned that it devised a youth allowance media strategy, which said:

We can expect more vocal opposition from families after July 1 when families of young unemployed people start to feel the effect of the parental income test. We can expect disaffected families to air their grievances through the media.

Has there ever been more of an understatement than this? Families earning as little as $23,500 will be forced to pay as the Howard family government withdraws income support for unemployed children. Young people in families earning over $42,000 will be cut off from any unemployment assistance at all. They will not get 1c. Let us not forget that on top of this those families will also cop a goods and services tax.

A mother of a young person in my electorate came into my office last week. She had just discovered the entire devil in the detail in the proposal the Prime Minister had been widely applauded for in this place. Her 18-year-old son will not receive a single cent in income support because this family earns over $42,000. Never mind that this family must also support three other children. Never mind the financial stress and strain of having to pay increased child care, medical and other costs. Never mind any of these things because it is your responsibility to support your own children. This is the family friendly advice the Howard government provides to battling families in the Illawarra.

This mother is absolutely ropeable. I understand that she is trying to make an appointment with the member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash). I tried to explain to her that it would be very unlikely that the member for Gilmore would see her because she lived in Throsby, but this mother is determined. I do not expect this mother to be to fobbed off by the member for Gilmore. I expect the member for Gilmore to actually meet this mother. I expect her to defend her vote in this place to introduce the common youth allowance.

I might say that this is what members of the government parties are increasingly going to have to do. They are going to have to go out there in the community and defend how they have voted on this budget and on a whole range of issues that have so devastated the Australian community. They are going to have to tell the people and justify how they vote. I expect the member for Gilmore to really listen to the plight of an ordinary family and the effect that this measure, which she supported, as she supports everything else, will have on families after 1 July.

Labor moved amendments to this legislation in the Senate. We sought to protect young unemployed people, who the Prime Minister promised would have a job, and their families. We moved to keep the age of independence at 18 years of age. This would obviously have meant that young unemployed people between the ages of 18 and 21 would not have been affected by the parental income test. This family friendly Howard government voted against these amendments. The bottom line is that this government is making low and middle income families pay the price for this government's unemployment failure. This is a sleeper issue, but it will awake and on 1 July there will be fireworks. There will be plenty more angry mothers, fathers, sons and daughter who will be seeking retribution, and it will be at the ballot box.

I support what the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) has said, and I have heard the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) also say in the chamber about people who are not registered with various agencies trying to get unemployment benefits. I have had people come into my office and see me about this. I have had people ringing me up about it. It is a really discriminatory move that this government is making. Unless you are registered, you cannot get the benefit. I can provide the parliamentary secretary of the minister with a whole range of things. I heard a minister in here earlier today say that no-one was going to have to pay a fee. That is certainly not right. Unless you are registered, you are not going to get the services that are being provided. It is utterly outrageous and it has to be changed.

talk.start.para: âSome 50 years ago George Orwell wrote that famous essay about politics and the English language. I am certain that he had people like the current member for Goldstein, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) in mind when he wrote it. A couple of George Orwell's famous quotes were, in relation to Stalinist Russia, about Stalin referring to the elimination of undesirable elements. We all knew what that meant. The British also referred to the pacification of India, and we knew what that meant too. If you examine the minister's second reading speeches, you find example after example of where he states that less is in fact more.

speech.para: I would like to challenge the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) to get up in a moment and explain an item on page 130 of Budget Paper No. 4. Under section 2, assistance to school education, there is an item 02, entitled `School to workâinitiatives to promote effective and reliable pathways from schooling to employment.' I was under the impression, from the propaganda that went out about the budget, that this was actually built upon and expanded. According to me, and maybe the parliamentary secretary can correct me if I am wrong, it looks as though there is about a 25 per cent reduction in school to work initiatives in this country.
I quote the Canadian writer, David Pecaut, who, in the 1997 edition of Policy Options said:

It has become an economic fact of life that the strongest companies and the strongest nations are those with the strongest work forces. The high skilled, high wage economies that are thriving today can confidently look forward to continued prosperity.

He went on to write about the total system breakdown in Canada; about the deterioration of the school to work transition for young adults. I suspect he could write exactly the same thing for this country.

When young people in secondary schools seek advice in further careers or further training, what are they usually confronted with? There are perhaps 1,200 students in a secondary school and one career adviserâone for 1,200. That is a totally impossible expectation to try to meet. How is that teacher often selected? In fact, the majority are selected by what is called a famous short straw method.
