In other words, you all put your hand in and hope to God you do not get itâand I am wondering if the short straw becomes the career adviser. Of course that teacher has a whole range of other duties as well as career guidance. The expectation is totally ridiculous.

I would like the parliamentary secretary to explain to me why in 1998-99, when we and the government have made such a big deal, and I think rightfully, of school to work transition and you have cut it not by five per cent or two per cent but by 25 per cent. Is this a recognition of what is common in all English speaking countries with right-of-centre governments that there is no attention paid to the resources for five-year-olds to 15-year-olds in particular. I know that most responsibility for schools is in fact a state responsibility, but there is a leadership angle at a federal level.

That leadership at a federal level has gone totally missing. Whether you refer to school to work or enrolment benchmark adjustment, it does not matter. When it comes to the very foundations of education we find that this government and this minister have gone missing. They talk about literacy and numeracy initiativesâbig deal! I was the one who made that reference in this parliament in 1988. In fact, I could not even get my own side to be interested until 1990 when Mary Crawford, the then member for Forde, was chairing the literacy challenge. So it is a recent phenomenon.

For a long time in this country we have taken children at the foundation level of educationâtheir training or further educationâfar too lightly. At a university level we are second to the United States in expenditure. That is a good thing. And we are doing some very positive things in TAFE in terms of training, but we have forgotten about the real levels of education. When a 16-year-old child fronts up with a literacy and a numeracy problem it is because he was a six-year-old child with the same problem that no-one addressed.

talk.start.para: âWhen I spoke earlier I mentioned the cost to employers of using Employment National when previously there was no cost involved. I was contacted in the last few weeks by a produce business employer in my electorate who raised this matter with me in a state of great agitation, and I do not blame him. He had used the old CES for a lot of years and had found a number of good employees through that system without charge. He was then met with the rather stark announcement that he was going to have to pay $250 or more for using a service which once was free. It is no good saying that small business is the engine room of society, that small business is doing well now that interest rates are down, and that small business is now coming out of the trough when, at the same time, we are doing this to small business.

speech.para: This is attacking something that should not be attacked: the capacity of small business to employ people. Small businesses are living on the edge in terms of margins, yet this particular fee of $250âand upwardsâhas now been attached to anyone in business who goes to Employment National. I was horrified to hear that that was the case; I did not know about it. We were not told about it.

I approached the office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) about this matter and was told yes, that is the case. I was told, I think in no uncertain terms, that we are now moving to a more rationalist approach to these thingsâwhich is code for small business having yet another impost on it, and it is a disincentive to employ people. We are trying to get more people into work, yet here is a cost to a small business in my electorate that produces the response I mentioned. Frankly, I do not blame the small business person concerned for delivering it to me and saying, `What the hell is the government doing about it?'

Can we not look at this again? I know that there is an alternative and that small business people can put the information into a computer at Centrelink and that that is freeâbut that is just not good enough. A service that has been there for so long and that has been very useful to employers and small businesses has now been taken away and sacrificed at the feet of economic rationalism.

The other point I want to raise is the question of the outlays for labour and employment issues of $2.771 billion. I have not as yet discovered a breakdown for what part of that figure will be utilised for the job market program. I would like to get some sort of breakdownâin particular localising it to my electorateâwhich would be useful for understanding just what is being spent.

After all, we are spending a lot of money on trying to get people placed into fewer and fewer jobs. Surely there comes a point in time when we should be saying, `Is that money not better spent on some major capital works program? Is it not better to be directing that money to putting people into real jobs rather than finding fewer and fewer jobs and spending an awful lot of money trying to do that?' I know there is the payment when you get the people placed et cetera, but certainly built into all of that is a cost that one could arguably say is dead money. I would ask that that also be looked at in the context of examining philosophically what we are trying to doâwe are trying to get more people into employment ultimately, are we not? I would ask that some consideration be given to reviewing the cost to employers using Employment National and also to re-examining the cost of the new job market program.

talk.start.para: âI have a couple of comments to make today regarding aspects of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and, in particular, on an issue that relates to my local area. It concerns a local organisation by the name of the Springvale Indochinese Mutual Assistance Association, or SICMAA, which operates out of Springvale and covers part of my electorate and also parts of the electorates of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). It is a very valuable organisation in the local area in terms of providing assistance to people of Vietnamese, Cambodian and Chinese backgrounds in particular because the area has a very high number of migrants from those countries. SICMAA recently applied for funding under the community support program. I will read from an article on that issue in one of the local papers, the Dandenong Journal . The article headed `Funding refused for job scheme' reads:

speech.para: The co-ordinator of the Springvale Indo-chinese Mutual Assistance Association (SICMAA) has launched a stinging attack on the Federal Government and its method of allocating funds.
Mr Phong Nguyen made the criticisms after his organisation had been denied money for an employment program.
SICMAA's Community Support Program proposal had been submitted to the Department of Employment, Education and Training.
The association has a smaller scale but successful program in place.
Mr Nguyen said that tender assessments seemed to favour the larger, mainstream organisations over smaller groups such as SICMAA.
"Once again it's a matter of the funds going to the mainstream rather than the organisations who deal with the specific ethnic groups," he said.
"I mean we all know the astronomical unemployment rate in the Indo-chinese community so why not fund a program that can deal directly with the problem."

While he applauded much of the work done by larger organisations such as the Springvale Community Aid and Advice Bureau and the Salvation Army, Mr Nguyen said that SICMAA was often better placed to help its constituents.
"We speak the language and understand the culture which has its obvious advantages," he said.
"It's decisions like this which show that this Government is abandoning multiculturalism."

The Community Support Program proposal involved the provision of services not normally included in an employment schemeâsuch as family and psychiatric counselling as well as rent assistanceâto give participants the best possible chance of finding employment.
Mr Nguyen said the amount requested by SICMAA was modest and open to negotiation.
Despite requests, the Journal had not received comment from the Department of Employment, Education and Training at the time of going to press.

That is an article from a couple of weeks ago. I have not had an update on this particular issue at this time. But it does show a wider question on this government's priorities when it comes to employment assistance.

We know that we have seen massive cuts to labour market programs and we have seen the focus of those programs alter. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) basically uses the line that `these programs were not about jobs, they were mickey mouse programsâprograms that were in existence under the previous governmentâand that what we have got now is something which is much more practically related.' There are a couple of practical points that can be related to what has actually occurred. Practically what has occurred is a major gutting of funding to provide assistance to people who are unemployed. When you look at the question of the size of that cut, you have to ask, `How can you possibly do as much as was done with so little?'

On the question of the nature of the practical results from providing assistance to the unemployed, it misunderstands and it misses the entire point around the question of providing practical assistance. It goes beyond the question of merely pointing people in directions. It basically misunderstands the whole point about the different levels of disadvantage of people who are unemployed. It does not take into account a range of other issues around the question of the programs that were in existence and the nature of what they were designed to deal with. It misses the entire point that when you look at the question of the success ratesâand I use that term looselyâof some of these programs they were aimed at people with varying levels of disadvantage and, in the circumstances of a complex employment market and a complex labour base, you have to take those issues into account.

It is true that, in funding the Job Network, aspects of those issues are being picked up but nowhere near enough to deal with the real issues. The point is that, if you handle unemployment in a simplistic way, as this minister does, and if you endeavour to simplistically distort statistics in order to make some cheap political points, as this minister has done, it will lead to a situation where you misunderstand the nature of the problems you are dealing with. If you misunderstand the nature of the problem you are dealing with, then you will not deal with it. That has been the issue with this government in terms of employment, in terms of providing jobs and in terms of dealing with people who are unemployed. The government is missing the point and it has missed the point entirely on this issue. This issue from my local area shows that point graphically.

talk.start.para: âI would like to continue on the issues that I raised at the outsetâthat is, that I believe the country deserves better on the employment front and that the real problem with this budget strategy is that it will not generate jobs. I also referred to the fact that you cannot separate the issue of employment from other portfolio responsibilitiesâthe impact, for example, on the fall in the participation rate of the cruel cuts to the child-care system of over $800 million since the government was elected.

speech.para: I was, in essence, leading to the fact that the budget also confirms that, in the two years since the government was elected, nearly 800,000 unemployed Australians have seen their job prospects deteriorate alarmingly. The budget strategy also confirms that the $148 million cut in employment services has affected their capacity to get back to work and it is going to make it worse for those workers and their families. They face a fairly daunting situation at the moment and that is because of the projections and the performance of the government as reflected in the budget papers.

Firstly, the budget papers clearly show that the unemployment rate has scarcely fallen in the 26 months since this government was elected. Secondly, we can all recall the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) at the National Press Club just before the last election in March 1996, when he tried to stand tall by saying, `I've got a plan. I'm going to be a very disappointed man if I don't achieve something on the youth unemployment rate.' This budget confirms that the youth unemployment rate has in actual fact risen. He tried to set out in detail that concept and the image that he has a plan to do something about youth unemployment. Despite all the changes to the youth allowance, the so-called work for the dole and the way forward for young people, we are talking about a rise in youth unemployment, which was confirmed in the budget papers, to 29.2 per cent since March 1996.

I also referred to the fact that I think it is fairly important that you look at the issue of jobs growth in the budget papers and compare the current figures with what was achieved in the last 26 months of Labor in government. This budget confirms that total jobs growth has been around one-third of the rate of the Labor government in its last two years in office.

I now go to the issue of full-time jobs. I appreciate the importance of part-time jobs but the government, in more recent months, has got a lot to say about full-time jobs growth. The budget also confirms that the number of full-time jobs created under this government is less than one quarter of the number created under Labor. The minister is pretty good at dodging and fiddling the figures from time to time, but let us put them all on the table today.

I have already referred to the fall in the participation rate but I also raise the issue of the change in the employment services. It is one of the most alarming issues on the employment front today, and it goes to the need to actually offer a helping hand to the long-term unemployed. I am pleased to say that we actually had a plan when we were in government to try to help those long-term unemployed, many of whom are from a non-English speaking background. I note that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) has just walked into the chamber, and I assume that he is also concerned about the withdrawal of employment assistance not just to the people who live in Australia at the moment but also the new arrivals. They are not entitled to benefits. Also, under the employment services program that now exists in Australia, not only are they not entitled to benefits for two years, they are not even entitled to a free and comprehensive employment service to try to get them a job so that they do not have to walk around with the backside out of their pants because they are not entitled to benefits and not entitled to a free and comprehensive employment service.

I go to the issue of long-term unemployment and the figures are interesting. The number of long-term unemployed people in Australia actually shot up by 6,400 in April. More importantly, there are now 33,200 more Australians who have been out of work for 12 months or more than when the Howard government began slashing the skillshare programs and the other job assistance programs, which amounted to cuts of $1.5 million even when you consider the so-called major announcement on the new initiatives on work for the dole. We have to acknowledge that that was announced in January but they tried to make out that it was yet another announcement in this budget. That announcement was actually made in a headland speech in January.

The government is cutting programs and employment assistance services at a time when we have got not only a worsening situation on the employment front but, more importantly, a worsening situation when it comes to the issue of long-term unemployment. They are the people who really need comprehensive assistance case management, not a government that prides itself on a surplus for election purposesâand even, potentially, for tax cuts: the Treasurer (Mr Costello) refused to answer what I thought was a fairly telling question in question time yesterday about whether or not the surplus should be used for tax cuts. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to make some additional comments around aspects of the Job Network and what has occurred in my local area over the last couple of months. I have had a number of constituents contact my office, both in writing and verbally, to raise concerns about access to assistance and their particular circumstances and difficulties they have found in dealing with the new system.

speech.para: One particular example which I would just like to tell the committee relates to a woman in her late 30s who is married and whose husband is unemployed. This person has had extreme difficulty gaining assistance. She is someone who has quite good skill levels and she also understands, if you like, that you need to speak up when you have difficulties dealing with an organisation, so she has not been easily deterred.

Upon initially making contact with a local provider, she was told she was ineligible for any assistance. Having then questioned that and being told that that was the way it was, she made inquiries to a local senator's office. That led to contact from the department later that night, when she was told, `You are eligible for assistance. There's no problem with that. We'll get someone to contact you again tomorrow.' Correspondingly, no contact was made the next day, but some contact was made the day after.

After several phone calls over several days, the circumstances were such that she was then told, `No, you are not eligible for any assistance, but you can still use the facilities.' She subsequently went down to the Centrelink office and endeavoured to access the computer system there, but she does not have a PIN. She then sought to gain a PIN in order to be able to access that system and was told initially that she could get a PIN. Then, after a period of some days, she was eventually told that she could not. As I understand it, in terms of the operation of this computer system, if you do not have a PIN, you cannot get the details. Essentially, you can discover there is a job, but you cannot discover where it is. You are in a situation where you cannot access that sort of assistance.

That poses a real question about people being denied access to the system because they are not seen as being as unemployed as others or are in a situation where their economic viability is arguably better than that of other people who are unemployed. It really raises the question: are we serious about trying to give people proper access to services?

There is no doubt that the old CES was not perfect. It was sometimes a bureaucratic organisation, although I think governments of all persuasions, in order to try to deal with the unemployment problem, probably made too many adjustments over too short a time, which led to an element of organisational fatigue. But it was there, it was accessible, it was available and it was something that people, certainly in my local area, sought to utilise.

With the changes that have been talked about and that are now in operation in terms of the Job Network, we have heard in the parliament and in the media about organisations that do not in fact exist or are in the process of trying to exist. There are some notable examples which show clearly that there are difficulties around the question of the operation of this new system. The argument from some is that that is just part of the process of establishing these things and that there will be bugs in the system. The problem here is whether in fact we are talking about bugs or whether we are talking about a system that is buggered. I have a feeling that we are talking more about the latter than the former.

We are dealing with a situation where, through this process of privatisation, through this process of severely altering the entire raison d'etre of this particular assistance system for unemployed people, we are in fact ensuring that more and more people will drop off the statistics. That might look good in terms of the question of the unemployment statistics from the government's point of view but, in terms of the society we have and the society that we are developing into the next century, it has real implications if we are seeing more and more people drop off the statistics on the basis that they do not think there is any point in looking anymore.

That has always been an issue, and that has always been something which underpins the question of how real the figures are. But we are seeing an institutionalisation of change within the system, which is going to lead to a situation where more and more people take that option of dropping out on the basis that they can see no hope under this government in terms of its new system.

talk.start.para: âI know the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) is getting a little impatient with the issues being raised but, then again, I suppose when you represent the northern beaches of New South Wales, where unemployment as of April this year was 1.4 per cent, you would not see the issue of unemployment as being huge. Then again, if you represented Canterbury-Bankstown, where it is 9.2 per cent, Fairfield, Liverpool, Camden or Campbelltown, where it is 9.9 per cent, or the Fairfield- Liverpool area, where it is 12.1 per cent, or even the electorate of the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), where the latest available figures, from December last year, for the whole of his seat show unemployment at 15.4 per cent, you would understand the importance of this debate.

speech.para: I was going to the issue of the budget forecasts. To reinforce the rubbery nature of those forecasts, I want to compare some figures and put them on the table for discussion. I pose a question to the parliamentary secretary: how are we actually going to achieve a suggested fall in unemployment when you have a look at these figures over the last 26 months?

Let us go to total jobs growth during the Howard government's first 26 monthsâ235,800. During the last 26 months of Labor, the figure was 549,900. Let us go to the issue of full-time jobs growth. With regard to the parliamentary secretary's performance, with his mate the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), the figure is 118,100, as against our performance of 330,100. With regard to part-time jobs growth, the figure is 117,700, as against part-time jobs growth by Labor in government of 219,700 for those 26 months. The trend in unemployment during Labor's last 26 months was down 2.2 per cent. Under the first 26 months of this Howard government, the figure is 0.5 per cent. Youth unemployment has jumped to 27.1 per cent from 26.4 per cent, and the participation rate has fallen by over half a per cent, from 63.8 per cent to 63.2 per cent.

I raise those issues because the budget forecasts suggest that growth will slump. It says it will slump to three per cent in each of the next two years, well below what all economic commentators suggest as a required level of growthâat least four per cent to even start getting unemployment down. So it is a very serious question that I think the parliamentary secretary ought to answer today for the Australian community. On the basis of their performance to date and the projected jobs growth figures, how are they actually going to achieve the suggested fall in unemployment over the next 12 months?

In that context, I also refer to the forecast of 1.75 per cent employment growth for the year, which is even less than the original forecast of two per cent in last year's budget, which itself had to be reducedâyes, reducedâsharply mid-year to 1.25 per cent. In that context, in looking at the overall budget papers, I also note that the government predicts that the total number of unemployment benefit recipients will increase by five per cent from the beginning of the September quarter 1998.

We have a government that is trying to create the impression out there that we are going to get people off benefits, that we are going to reduce unemployment, that we are going to really create all these jobs. Yet the budget papers suggest that the total number of unemployment benefit recipients will increase by five per cent. I know that over 3,000 employees of the department have lost their jobs because of the closure of the CES as a result of this budget, but it is hard to rationalise even that as leading to such an increase in the number of unemployment benefit recipients.

Many participants in this debate have referred to the debacle which currently exists in employment services. We will continue on with that topic because there are major problems associated with it that must be put on the table. We intend to return to these issues when we come back after the suspension for lunch. They are of fundamental concern to the unemployed, especially to the two classes of unemployed currently existing in Australia as a result of this budget process: those who are classified as eligible job seekers; and the hundreds of thousands of Australians who are now classified as ineligible job seekersâand I am not just speaking of the migrants with whom the minister for immigration is concerned but Australians across all walks of life who are now denied a free and comprehensive employment service. In states such as South Australia, the ACT and the Northern Territory, basically they are being told, `You can get out there and beg or, if you have a few bob in your pocket, put your hand in and pay for employment services.' It is an ugly face of Australia with Australians being classified into two groups of unemployed: eligible job seekers and ineligible job seekersâand this being at a time when the employment situation is very difficult. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âObviously members opposite have run out of specific difficulties to raise with the departmental estimates and they now wish, through the shadow minister, to simply reiterate again and again how evil they think the government is. I suppose they are entitled to make those statements, but I would like to begin to answer some of the specific issues which have been raised previously by members opposite.

speech.para: First of all, I go to those matters which have been raised by the member for Bruce (Mr Griffin). I can understand the member's disappointment and I can understand the frustration of the Springvale Indochinese Association at not getting community support program funding. These programs, like all programs in the department, are allocated on a competitive basis. I can only assume that other people put in a bid to provide these services and that their bid was better.

So across the country on a whole range of programs we have seen good programsâin some cases, quite good programsâbeing supplanted by better programs. In saying that, I do not in any way wish to criticise the programs offered by the Springvale Indochinese Association. I am sure it is an excellent organisation and I am sure it is doing great work.

However, I would simply say to all the people of Springvale of Indochinese origin that with this program we are attempting to have the very best serviceâand as a department we are confident that that is exactly what we have. On this whole subject of services to non-English speaking background people here in Australia, I just make this point: in regions where more than 10 per cent of people are from non-English speaking backgrounds, all tenderers for the Job Network were required to demonstrate how they were going to help these groups.

Finally, the member for Bruce (Mr Griffin) talked of the run-around one of his constituents got. Obviously there is nothing more frustrating that getting the run-around from member to senator to department to senator to department, and so on. I would like to say that that has never happened under this government; I would like to think it never happened under the previous government; I would like to think that it will never happen under any government. But the reality is that this kind of thing does happen, even with the best will in the world. I do say though that I am confident there is goodwill all around and, if the honourable member would like to tell me the name of this particular constituent, I will do my best to try to ensure that they get the service they need.

The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) raised the issue of the youth allowance. As the member for Throsby pointed out, the youth allowance is coming in very shortly. The point of the youth allowance is to try to end the previously existing disincentive to study, with people on unemployment benefits receiving rent assistance and not being subject to parental means testing.

The member for Throsby has said that there are losers under the youth allowanceâand he is absolutely right in saying that. But I ought to point out that, of the 560,000 thousand estimated recipients of the youth allowance, 378,000 will receive the same money as they do currently under unemployment assistance or Austudy; 137,000 will receive more money than currently, mostly because they are students who now will be eligible for rent assistance; 33,000 will receive a reduced amount; and 12,800, who are currently on unemployment benefits, will no longer receive those unemployment benefits because of the operation of the parental means test.

Obviously these people will be frustrated, they will be disappointed, they will be angry. But I think it is a good principle for us not to provide or build into the system disincentives for people to studyâand it is disincentives such as those that the youth allowance is designed to prevent.

I now turn to the comments made by the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). He claimed that there had been a 25 per cent budget reduction in funding for school to work programs. One particular item has been reduced by that amount. But, in addition to that particular item, there is $20 million a year in VET funding to cover this very point, and that is $80 million more than previously provided. I believe that we need to look at the budget as a whole rather than simply at one particular line item. (Time expired)

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.29 p.m. to 4.32 p.m.

talk.start.para: âI refer specifically to the question of Centrelink referrals to the Job Network. I note from the budget papers that, as a result of these changes, we are talking about cuts of $147.6 million from employment services over the next four years. It would be interesting to know from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) the referrals for the first month of the operation of the Job Network with respect to all forms of assistance; I refer to the abridged form of FLEX 1, 2 and 3.

speech.para: Can he give advice as to not only the total number of referrals by Centrelink but also the number of referrals with respect to each of the forms of the assistance, FLEX 1, 2 and 3? Can he confirm information supplied in a Senate estimates committee yesterday by the Deputy Chief Executive Officer of Centrelink, Mr Ross Divett, that for June the real figure of potential referrals will be of the order of 30,000, which includes job matching, Jobsearch training and intensive assistanceânamely, FLEX 1, 2 and 3.

I turn to the operation of the Job Network. I note that this represents the end of a 50-year tradition in the form of the closure of the CES. I also noteâand I refer to advice from Centrelink as to how this department's Job Network will operateâthat people are now classified as eligible job seekers and ineligible job seekers. In that context, is it appropriate to conclude that eligible job seekers are basically defined as follows: in essence, the only people entitled to any semblance of a free employment service, as strictly provided for by the government's policy position with respect to access to what is broadly described as FLEX 1, 2 and 3 services.

I suppose the definition of eligible job seekers is Newstart recipients, youth training allowance recipients, special beneficiaries receiving payment under NSA conditions, sole parent pensioners, partner allowance recipients, widow allowance recipients, disability support pensioners, benefit parenting allowance recipients, carer pensioners, some special benefit recipients, CDEP recipient job seekers and all job seeker customers aged 15 to 21 years of age who are not in full-time education or employment, except for customers wishing to register with an outside provider.

With respect to those so-called customers of the Job Network who are eligible for assistance, it is therefore appropriate to conclude that people other than those covered by those definitions strictly are not entitled to a comprehensive employment service by the new Job Network. In essence, they can possibly be charged if they do not fall into those particular definitions for employment services within the various arms of the Job Network.

I also seek advice from the parliamentary secretary that, on the basis of those definitions, the following types of people are ineligible for a comprehensive employment service from this government: firstly, workers who have been retrenched, such as those potentially retrenched workers at Burnie, who under the government's arrangements cannot access social security benefits until the term of their retrenchment, annual leave and long service payments have effectively been worked out; secondly, women returning to work after possibly spending time bringing up children and whose husbands are already in jobs, be it on a part-time, casual or a full-time basis; thirdly, part-time workers who are looking for full-time jobs, or they may even be casual workers looking for full-time jobs; fourthly, students; fifthly, people in the six-week waiting period to be declared eligible for the dole; and, finally, newly arrived migrants banned from any benefits for the first two years after arrival. (Extension of time granted)

I am seeking, through the processes available, a very clear position from the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not only those people defined as being eligible job seekers are automatically and properly entitled in the mind of the government to what is described as a comprehensive employment service, or whether or not the other people I have referred to are ineligible and classified as ineligible job seekers under the new arrangements.

I am seeking confirmation from the parliamentary secretary of the department's view as to whether or not people classified as ineligible job seekers in some states and territories, such as in South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, the ACT and the Northern Territory, under legislation existing in those states and territories, can be asked to pay for employment agent services and that the cost could be, for example, a commencement rate of $250, which is a fee suggested with respect to some of the charges now applicable under the government's user pays principles in the operation of Employment National.

I am also seeking clarification from the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not, as a result of the introduction of the Job Network on 1 May, prior to 1 May a lot of services were provided to employers free of charge, and that since 1 May there has been a change in operation with respect to government activities in relation to employment services aimed at trying to get the unemployed back to work; that, in essence, has resulted in employers having to put their hand in their pocket to pay for these services. Could the parliamentary secretary enlighten me as to the types of charges that Employment National has determined as being appropriate with respect to these services that they now charge employers for?

I am also seeking advice from the parliamentary secretary as to how we could assist employers engaged in areas of seasonal employment, such as in regional Australia and the rural industry, and whether or not under these new arrangements those employers can be required to put their hand in their pocket and pay for services that may have been previously free to employers operating under such employment arrangements.

I also pose a question to the parliamentary secretary that has been suggested to me by a range of employers. Because of these new charges, a number of employers may not use those services now because they are regarded as being beyond their financial capacity, especially small business. I would have thought that this government would seek to continue to portray itself as a friend of small business. Employers might resort to other employment practices, such as the engagement of illegal migrants and backpackers, and, in some instances, it may result in cash in hand and perhaps even further development of the black market in Australia. I wonder whether the department has considered whether or not there ought to be increased attention to inspection with respect to its association with the Australian Taxation Office as to the potential loss of the PAYE tax base as a result of these new charges and the impact on the employment practices of employers.

I am also seeking advice from the department as to the number of organisations that previously helped long-term unemployed today as against what might have existed as at March 1996. I ask that because I clearly asked the parliamentary secretary today about the worsening situation on the long-term unemployment front. My suggestion was that there are over 33,000 more long-term unemployed today than as at March 1996. Is it true that the number of organisations providing help to the long-term unemployed has been more than halved from 321 organisations prior to 1 May to 125 under the new Job Network? (Extension of time granted)

I turn to the issue of some of the expenditure announcements by the government in these budget processes. I note that the government suggests that there is new net spending of $327.8 million on jobs programs, confirmed in the budget. As my examination of the budget papers suggests, that includes $6.4 million extra in the budget to help people gain the skills necessary to begin an apprenticeship. I must say that I welcome the provision of $16 million over two years to increase the number of apprentices in group training. I also note the provision of up to $30 million in loan guarantees to group training companies. But the question I pose to the parliamentary secretary is: does that new spending of $327.8 million represent, unfortunately, less than one-fifth of what has previously been taken away by the government in the previous two budgets with respect to employment programs?

I also refer to group training. What is the reasonâI cannot find one within this budget processâfor the failure to reintroduce commencement payments for apprenticeships in group training companies? I pose that question because, on my examination of the figures, we have a major emerging skills shortage in Australia. I refer to the fact that not only has the growth in traineeships fallen off in more recent times but alsoâand I seek confirmation from the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not this is trueâthe number of apprenticeship commencements since March 1996 has fallen by 5,000.

I now move to the issue of new money for vocational education and training. In the budget paper it is suggested that there is some new expenditure. I also seek confirmation as to whether or not in previous budget announcements of the government since March of 1996 an amount of $269 million has been taken out of vocational education and training. I also understand that potentially those earlier cuts that I have asked for confirmation on reduce the incentive for employers to take on apprentices. I have noted that, for example, the growth in group training apprenticeship numbers has slowed dramatically from 25 per cent annually over the period 1993-96 to just 10 per cent anticipated for 1997-98. What are the parliamentary secretary's views with respect to those suggested projections on group training apprenticeships?

I consider that we have a major problem with respect to the issue of training in Australia at the moment. I also seek information from the parliamentary secretary as to what processes are provided in the budgetary papers for closer consultation between the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs on the problems of emerging skill shortages and the fact that it would seem that the department of immigration is now willy-nilly allowing people to come in from overseas to fill those emerging skill shortages whilst we have a situation in Australia where the number of apprenticeships has actually fallen dramatically by more than 5,000 commencements since Labor's last full year in office. In that context I ask is it true that, in 1994-95, 49,458 people started apprenticeships whilst in 1996-97, following the election of the Howard government, we are talking about a number of 44,127 apprenticeships?

If the figures for those suggested apprenticeship starts are accurate, I would like to know where in these budget papers the parliamentary secretary can point to a very decisive strategy to reverse the falling number of apprentices. (Extension of time granted) I also seek information from the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not, in referring to the issue of apprenticeships in this day and age, the minister for employment also seeks to group not only the old traditional apprenticeships but what were previously called traineeships in which there was quite a considerable growth prior to March 1996. Is it therefore accurate to suggest that, in that context, when you actually separate the issues, not only do we have a fall off in apprenticeship commencements of 5,000 but also the rate of growth in traineeships has slumped from 161 per cent in 1995-96 to just 61 per cent in 1996-97?

I have raised some pertinent issues today that this government ought to be concerned about and it ought to use these processes to give not just the Labor opposition a full explanation but more importantly the Australian public at large. Those issuesâand we are still waiting for answers from the parliamentary secretaryâwent to whether or not he was satisfied firstly with an explanation of one of his former employees, Mr Oldfield, as to how he conducted his work and whether or not his travel was in accordance with his wishes. Secondly, there was the issue of whether or not the budget projections are actually accurate and whether or not they will stand up to producing a major reduction in unemployment.

I have sought information on the Job Network as to who is eligible and who is ineligible. I have asked the question about accurate information on the announced government program expenditure as against cuts over the previous couple of budgets. I have asked a question regarding detailed information on the success of the new jobs network in its first month of operation and a question of referrals by Centrelink and what are the projections and the breakdowns, not just for the first month for each form of assistance but also the projections for the month of June. I have sought information on the falling rate of apprenticeships and traineeships, however they are called.

I raise these issues because I think these processes are about accountability. My own view is that the budget talk in the papers has sought to hide a major problem in Australia at the moment with respect to a worsening situation on unemployment. I seek confirmation from the parliamentary secretary as to whether we expect an increase in unemployment over the next 12 months. I have also sought information from the parliamentary secretary as to the process of consultation between this department and the department of immigration to reverse an emerging trend by which skilled vacancies in Australia are filled by people from overseas whilst apprenticeships and traineeship opportunities in Australia fall off. I await the parliamentary secretary's response to those detailed requests for information.

talk.start.para: âI begin with the matter of David Oldfield about whichâ
âYou want an answer?

âI am very happy to talk about what happened, and I have already spoken earlier today about what happened. I think it should be obvious to the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) that, of course, in my judgment, my former staffer did misuse his entitlements. That is why I referred it to the department and the department, I presume for similar reasons, referred it to the police. Once that happens, it is out of our hands, as it were. It is out of the government's hands. The police made their decision on what they thought were reasonable bases. I really think that any further questions on the subject of that gentleman should be directed towards the Australian Federal Police.

speech.para: I think I have said all I can say on this and I think I have done all I can possibly do on that subject. As I said, he is still in the employ of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). As far as I am aware, he is on the Commonwealth's payroll and acting as the One Nation campaign director in Queensland. That strikes me as a strange kind of activity; nevertheless, that is really something that can be dealt with by other people in other places. The member for Batman might like to pursue that elsewhere.

talk.start.para: âHe's your mate, not mine.

âIt should be pretty clear to the member for Batman that he is not my mate. To come to some of the issues that have been raised by different people in this debate, the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) complained about what he said was the reduction of labour market services in Cessnock to just one. In fact, one person, one entity, Employment National, is providing full FLEX 3 services in Cessnock but there are two providers of what were called FLEX 1 services in Cessnock. The point that the member for Hunter well knows is that contracts to provide labour market services have been allocated on the basis of an open tender process.

speech.para: While it is obviously very disappointing when services which have done well and which have helped many people are no longer funded, the fact is that the funding decisions were made by the department on a blindfolded basis. They were completely removed from the political process as such. The member for Hunter has to accept that good services have been supplanted by better services. As the member for Hunter admitted himself in his contributions, there are services in nearby towns, some of which are available on an extension basis.

The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) spoke at some length about Dr Pickering's paper. I have not seen Dr Pickering's paper, but I am quite happy to ask the department to look at it and make an analysis of that paper and, on the basis of that analysis, I will happily respond to some of the contentions raised by the member for Scullin. I should point out that the vast bulk of funding under the new employment services market is to be paid to the jobs brokers once job seekers have been found jobs and have been kept in those jobs for six months. So it should not surprise the member for Scullin that a great deal of the expenditure would take place in future years.

I should point out while we are talking about the general issue of funding that this government is going to spend more on labour market services generally in the four years from 1996, when unemployment was at eight per cent, than the former government spent in the four years up to the Working Nation statement, when unemployment was nearly 11 per cent. We are spending billions and billions of dollars on services for the unemployed. As I said, we are spending a half a billion dollars more in this current four-year period than the former government spent in the four years prior to Working Nation when unemployment was 11 per cent. This government is certainly not short of effort to help the unemployed. (Extension of time granted)

The member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) raised a number of issues. The first issue he raised was that he wanted an explanation of the $1.8 billion in the budget papers for other services. I am advised that the vast bulk of thatânamely, $1.6 billionâis to be spent funding employment services under the new labour market system. I am advised by people who are better at interpreting budget papers than I amâand better at interpreting them, I suspect, than the member for Dicksonâthat that is all there in the budget papers.

The next question that the member for Dickson raised was: how many unattached staff are there on the public sector payroll as a result of the changes that have been made in labour market services? I am not in possession of a precise figure at present, but I am happy to get that figure. I will write to the member for Dickson to let him know what that figure is. I do want to assure the member for Dickson, who is so interested in all of this that he is not here to hear what is being said in response to him, that there is no-one doing nothing on the public payroll and that any unattached officers are in fact working in the public sector to advance the welfare of our nation, as all public servants do.

The member for Dickson talked about one of his constituents, a Mr Irving, who he said was upset at being given the run-around, so the member for Dickson said, by various job agencies. We all get various people coming into our offices who feel disappointed with the level of service that they have received. For a constituency member of parliament there are few things more frustrating and few things more disappointing. But what a good local member does is make phone calls on behalf of the constituents. Perhaps that is what the member for Dickson is doing now. He may well be ringing some of the job agencies in his electorate on Mr Irving's behalf. There are certainly job agencies out there serving the people in the electorate of the member for Dickson who, I am sure, will only be too happy to help Mr Irving.

I should now turn to the general question of labour market services as they are being provided under the new post 1 May regime. As the member for Batman and others know, labour market services are now being provided by a whole range of people. Labour market services that were once the sole preserve of the Commonwealth Employment Services are now being provided by many providers. As the member for Batman knows, there are now over 300 jobs brokers operating at more than 1,400 sites, whereas the old CES was operating at just 300 sites.

There are all sorts of advantages in this new labour market: for one thing, there is a greater range of providers to choose from; for another thing, there are incentive payments built into the system; there is greater coverage; and there is greater client choice. It is a system which we believe is going to work much better than the old system. But it is a system which has only been in operation for one month, and one would hardly be surprised if there were not some glitches in this early period.

On this question of cost to employers, yes, Employment National has made a decision to charge employers $250 for what it calls its standard service. Other providers, I am pleased to say, have made the decision not to charge potential employers for placing people with them.

talk.start.para: âIs it only $250?

âThat is their standard service. The point I wish to make is that the alternative to using these providers is to put an advertisement in the paper, to have most likely hundredsâcertainly dozensâof applicants and then have to sift through them all yourself. So I think that, at $250, the kind of service that is being provided by Employment National is very good value. (Time expired)

âI refer to the suggested number of outlets mentioned by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott). I would like clarification from the parliamentary secretary as to how many of those Job Network outlets operate on a full-time basis and how many are operated on the same basis as outlets such as, for example, the Employment National office at Katoomba. In Katoomba, up until 1 May, there was a pretty good service provided by the Centrelink office and directly opposite the Centrelink office, on the other corner, was the old CES office. During a recent visit to Katoomba, I found that that CES office had been closed. You could see from the black balloons hanging around the CES office the displeasure of the staff and the local unemployed at the government decision to close that office.

speech.para: How many of these new outlets that the parliamentary secretary refers to now operate on the same basis as the new Employment National outlet in Katoomba and make it hard for a person with disabilities to access it? This Employment National outlet in Katoomba is found in the main street in the Colonial Mutual building, if I remember correctly. To enter the outlet a person is initially required to walk up approximately 20 steps, go down the corridor past the dentist on the left, past the accountants, around the corner, down another flight of about six steps, past the male and female toilets and then find a closed door with a sign on it saying, `This Employment National outlet will be open one day a week for a limited number of hours.' When the parliamentary secretary refers to a specific number of outlets, I think we ought to get a full and proper explanation as to how many of those outlets are operated on a full-time basis and how many are operated on a four-, three-, two- or one-day per week basis.

In that context, I am also seeking detailed information from the parliamentary secretary as to whether or not an article in the Courier-Mail of today relating to South Pacific Cruise Lines is accurate. On page 5 of the Courier-Mail this article refers to the cruise liner training operation falling over last year leaving 300 Queenslanders out of work. It also suggests that South Pacific Cruise Lines owes $550,000 to businesses and former employees. The article then goes on to suggest that an affiliate company of South Pacific Cruise Lines, CGI Financial Services, also owes about $600,000 to 27 companies, including banks in New Zealand and Germany.

Is it true that the government made available $2.2 million in the form of Commonwealth government assistance to that company to train unemployed people? Can the parliamentary secretary also inform me as to what the government is seeking to get that company to pay back to the government. Firstly, what are the actual amounts that are owed by the company to the government for its failure to adequately deliver the services for which it was contracted? Secondly, what action has the department taken to recover that money? Thirdly, what is the view of the departmentâand of the Attorney-General's Department, if it has been consultedâ as to the capacity of government to recover amounts for the taxpayer, and what are the amounts?

talk.start.para: âOn this question of cost to employers of having job seekers referred and put into jobs, as I said, Employment National is charging $250 for what it calls its standard service. If the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) wants to know what it charges for other services, he can quite easily go along to Employment National and they will give him their brochure, as Employment National at Brookvale gave me their brochure a week or so ago.

speech.para: But the important point to make is that there are many other providers in this new market who have pledged to provide services to employers, including small business people in the electorate of the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), for free. I would urge people who are unhappy with the $250 charge of Employment National to shop around and to find another service that is prepared to provide them with job seekers.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThey only have to look up the phone book to see there are Mission Employment, Options and Job Futuresâthere are any number of providers that are providing services to employers for free.

speech.para: The other issue that the member for Batman has raised in various ways today is not the cost to employers but the costs to job seekers. The first point I want to make is that every single job seeker in this country will have access through, at the present moment, 45âbut, by August, 200âJob Network access centres at Centrelink that will give those job seekers access to the on-line computerised job display system. They will also have access to phones, faxes and computers. They will be able to conduct, if you like, their job search business from these Job Network access centres at Centrelink offices. Every single job seeker in the country will have access to this. This is a service that was never offered by the CES. It is a distinct improvement in the services being offered to job seekers by this government. Every single Australian, regardless of whether they are unemployedâ
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Honourable members will have their chance, if they wish to contribute in the proper way.
âIt is not at all restricted. Everyone has access to the Job Network access centres that by August we estimate will be located at 200 Centrelinks around Australia.

speech.para: A further point I want to make is that job seekers on a benefit will pay nothingânever ever. They will not pay anything for the services that they get from Employment National or from any of the other jobs brokers. Those jobs brokers are required to offer their services to those job seekers absolutely for free. Now other job seekers may be required to pay something. For argument's sake, they may be required to pay $20 for the preparation of a CV. They may be required to pay something for those services. It is not an unreasonable requirement.

The other point that needs to be made is that these are private sector organisations; they are not government organisations. Employment National is run on a corporatised basis. It is an independent organisation that is running its own race, as it were. Mission Employmentâthe Salvation Army operationâOptions, Job Futures and all the rest of them are independent organisations that are running their own race. They are setting their own agendas and their own standards. But the point that needs to be made in response to some of the accusations from the member for Batman is that these are organisations with a strong social conscience. These are organisations with a deep sense of commitment.

talk.start.para: âOh, come off it!
âAre you saying that Mission Employment lacks conscience and lacks the commitment? They have a very strong sense of vocation.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of orderâ
âIt is outrageous.
âOrder! The member for Prospect has not got the call.
âMy point of order goes to the question of relevance about Mission Employment. When he refers to reputable organisations, is he referring toâ
âNo, this is not a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

âI will be as brief as I can. I apologise that I was not here earlier but, as an Independent member, you get a lot more calls from constituents than as a member of the government. I wish to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) a bit more about the $250 fee. I was also advised that figures as high as $800, and even in excess of that, could be asked of an employer by Employment National. This is my first question: is the parliamentary secretary able to give a guarantee that no figure higher than $250 is involved?

speech.para: Secondly, in relation to the parliamentary secretary's point about employers shopping around, I am not quite sure whether he realises it but some of these employment providers so-called will keep people waiting on the phone for 20 minutes at a time. If a businessman is going to ring up five employment providers and it takes 20 minutes for each one, there goes an hour and a half of his day, in the context of what is a very difficult day in business these days. I would ask him to be a bit realistic about that and perhaps examine whether or not Employment National can go back to providing the service that was previously offered.

I did not quite understand the point made by the parliamentary secretary in relation to the Job Network access centre. Is he saying that any personâthe underemployedâwill have access to this Job Network access centre some time before the end of the year? I was not quite sure of that point. And is that something over and above what they can get now at Centrelink? At Centrelink now there is apparently a proposal to have an on-line facility available for people not on benefitsâthose who are just underemployed or not employed at all. Is there something more than that? Those are my points.

talk.start.para: âTo put the mind of the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) at rest, yes, Job Network access is available to every single Australian who wants to utilise the service. The service comprises access to the on-line touch screens as well as access to phones, faxes, computers and photocopiers. So a job seeker can conduct job seeking activity from Job Network access centres, which I am advised are currently operational at 45 Centrelinks and which will, by the end of August, be operational at 200 Centrelinks. I am very happy to clarify that for the member of Dickson.

speech.para: The member for Dickson also asked whether I could give a guarantee that Employment National would not charge more than $250 to employers for providing people to fill jobs. The point that I need to stress to the member for Dickson is that Employment National is a corporatised entity.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is a corporatised entity in the way that, under the former government, Telstra, the Commonwealth Bank and so on were corporatised entities.
âSo the answer is no?
âNo, I cannot give that guarantee. But I see the smirks of members opposite. I see the smug look on the face of the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). Is it so outrageous? Is it so appalling?

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

They have a role available to them and that role is to stand in turn and seek the call for five minutes. If they do not want to do that, they should go somewhere else and do some writing or something, but they should not think they are in question time. Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest that they be removed from this place if they do not take the opportunity to speak properly and in turn.
âI thank the member for O'Connor for his point of order. The member for O'Connor makes an appropriate point and I bring it to the attention of all honourable members.
âFor the first time.
âThe member for Batman will withdraw that remark.
âNot you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I meant the member for O'Connor.
âI am asking the member for Batman to withdraw it in any event.
âI will withdraw the suggestion that it is the first time that the member for O'Connor has been in order.
âI asked for nothing more or less than for you to withdraw. I call the parliamentary secretary.

âThis allegedly appalling principleâaccording to the member for Prospectâthat under no circumstances can any job agency charge an employer for services rendered was in fact established and embraced by the CES under the former government. Under the former government, in New South Wales, the CES could charge $400 per placement to employers. In capital cities, the CES could charge between $100 and $300 per placement for the recruitment of temporary workers. In fact, the old CES charged certain employers in Tasmania between $75,000 and $100,000 a year to provide people to fill jobs. So the confected indignation and the spurious self-righteousness emanating from members opposite comes very ill. It is certainly deeply hypocritical of them to carry on in this way.

speech.para: The member for Batman also asked about job referrals from Centrelink. I am advised that there have been 90,000 referrals from Centrelink to job agencies for intensive assistance, or FLEX 3, in this first month of operation of the new market. The target was 95,000 referrals; 90,000 referrals have in fact taken place.

talk.start.para: âWhat about FLEX 1 and FLEX 2?

âFor FLEX 2, I am advised that we are on target. I recall being told this morning that the FLEX 2 places were something like 70,000 for the whole year. Do not hold me to that, please. I will check the figure, but I was certainly told that we are on target for FLEX 2 referrals. FLEX 1 people are not referred at all. Job seekers are told about the various agencies that can provide labour exchange services. If they do not make contact with those within a period of about two months, they can be breached, but there is no referral as such for FLEX 1. (Extension of time granted)

speech.para: I now turn to some of the other specific issues raised by the member for Batman. He asked about group training companies. My understanding is that $1,500 has been added to the payment to most private sector employers. This payment has not been added to the apprenticeship completion payments for group training companies. I understand that the reason for this is that the private sector employers are required to pay tax on these payments and the group training companies, being not-for-profit organisations, are not, so that additional payment is being made to the private sector employers for apprenticeships to try to equalise their position with the group training companies.

The member for Batman made some statements about falls in apprenticeship numbers. I am happy to look at the figures he quoted, but the figures I have suggest that this year we will have something like 200,000 people doing apprenticeships and traineeships, and I am advised that that is a better than 50 per cent increase since 1995. If the member for Batman has additional information, I am happy to look at it, but they are the figures that I have been given and I have more detailed figures somewhere amongst the papers I have been given that disagree with his figures. As I said, I am happy to look at the other figures he has.

I guess I should go back to the comments with which the member for Batman began his remarks. He talked about what the real unemployment rate is, what might happen to the unemployment rate if the participation rate rose and so on. As we know, the official unemployment rate is given to us by the statistician. The statistician works on the basis of surveys. Surveys rely on what people tell the surveyor. I guess all I would like to say is that what we as a government are aiming at is full employment. Full employment as I understand it has always been defined as a situation where everyone who wants a job can get a job. Obviously, we are not at that position. The government has not been at that position, regardless of its political complexion, probably for the best part of three decades. Unemployment is far too high. We all know that. The member for Batman knows that. I know that. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) knows it. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) knows it.

The question is what we should do to bring unemployment down. Obviously, the first thing to be done to bring unemployment down is to get the economy ticking over as well as possible. That is why the fiscal repair job done by this government is so important. That fiscal repair was largely responsible for the fall in interest rates, which in turn was largely responsible for the relatively buoyant economic conditions that we have got. Then we need to have a better educated and trained work force, and that is what our changes to the TAFE sector, our changes to the university sector and the various measures we have taken in the schools sector are designed to achieve.

Finally, we need a better functioning labour market. This government has brought in incentive payments to those who are out there trying to help the unemployed. That is something that the former government, I think, might have liked to have done but did not. Obviously, if you are getting a meaningful incentive to get someone a job and keep them in a job, it stands to reason that you are going to go that extra mile, go that extra yard, and we believe that that is what is going to happen. If we are wrong, then the electorate will no doubt at some appropriate time judge us in the way that only the electorate can. The simple truth is that we have engaged some of the finest organisations in the countryâreligious organisations, charitable organisations and organisations with a deep sense of vocation and a deep commitment to do the right thing by Australia's unemployed.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

talk.start.para: âThere are three issues that I want to cover tonight in the social security area, but I just want to say a few general things first. It is the case, as so many Australians know, that this Howard government has cut billions of dollars out of the social security system in its three budgets. This is money which has come out of the pockets of the unemployed, people with disabilities and low income families. That is where the money has come from. It has not come from some other pot. It has come from some of the poorest people in this country. It came out of the pockets, as I said, of the unemployed, people with disabilities and low income families. They are the people who have borne the brunt of the cuts from this government. That is how this government has created a surplusâon the backs of these people, on the backs of the poorest people in this country.

speech.para: This government has made these individuals and families even poorer. Even worse, it has made it harder for these people to get ahead. It is a government which has indiscriminately cut programs, many of them programs which were aimed at helping people get back into the work force. In this way, the social security cuts have undermined the ability of the system to provide both security and opportunity. It is security and opportunity that the social security system should be providing. This government will increase poverty and it will add to the entrenchment of people further into poverty. It is a government that has not been interested in real reform or how to help people get off benefits and get back into work.

The fact is that, under this Howard government, it is now harder for people to get off social security benefits and back into work. Cuts to child care have made it harder for families to earn an income. Families are, as a result of this government's recent changes to youth payments, now being forced to financially support their young unemployed adult children. People must use their savings before they can get unemployment benefits. Services and support for people with disabilities have been slashed. That is the achievement of this government when it comes to social security: make it harder to get off benefits and get back to work; increase the price of child care, so make it harder for families to earn an income; make families support their young unemployed adult offspring for longer; make people use their savings before they get any help to get back to work: and make it harder for those who have disabilities to get decent support.

On the first and what I consider to be a very important issue, it is now harder for those Australians who are unemployed to get back to work. The government has made it even more difficult for those on social security to move off benefits and get employment. It has failed to create new jobs, to reduce unemployment or to help those who are unemployed. Most critically, the government has failed to provide the incentives that are necessary for people on benefits to take up work. We know that the unemployment rate is stuck at around eight per cent and that there are around 800,000 people on unemployment benefits. Most critically, more than half of these people have been registered as unemployed for more than a year. Long-term unemployment has risen under the Howard government, while at the same time, as we saw in the last debate, special labour market assistance programs for the long-term unemployed have been abolished.

In fact, in March 1998, there were more than 13,000 additional Australians on unemployment benefits and related payments than when the Howard government came to power. So an additional 13,000 people are receiving benefits compared with when this government came into office. Just listen to what this mother of three had to say:

People like me are put off returning to work if they are to be treated like this by the very people that want to reduce the amount of unemployment in the country. All I want to do is get ahead financially. I just want to make it known that there are people in the community, like me, who are in a catch 22 situation about returning to work.

(Extension of time granted) The unemployment rate for sole parent pensions and people with a disability remains unacceptably high. The government has abolished the disability reform panels which helped people on the disability support pension get back to work. It is not at all clear to us how people with disabilities will be helped to find work under the new labour market arrangements.

Of course, cuts to child care have made it harder for sole parents to find work. A recent report to the government says that sole parents will find it harder to get jobsearch help under the new arrangements, and they may now also have to pay for training. This evaluation report of the JET program done by the Department of Social Security says, in part:

In the new labour market assistance environment, most JET participants will not receive intensive employment assistance, and . . . courses will be available only on a user pays basis. For income support customers, the cost will be prohibitive, and unless JET can offer an alternative, employment outcomes and subsequent savings to the Government will diminish.

This is yet another example of the government reducing the incentive to work. The earnings credit scheme, of course, which allowed a person to save up some of their earnings before they lost their unemployment benefit, was abolished in the 1996-97 budget. In this budget, we have had another payment cut, an extra payment cut, that went to sole parents who are studying. Unemployed people say that it just does not pay them to work, they lose too much of their benefits. This is what one sole parent said:

As a sole parent, the federal Government has directly cut my income as follows. First, as one of their public service cuts, I lost my professional job. My childcare fees have doubled. The poverty traps I face in attempting to do a small amount of part-time casual work have increased as a result of the abolition of the Earnings Credit.

Can the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), who is at the table, explain to us why it is in fact the case that the government has reduced what was already only a very small and tightly targeted payment, this payment that was made to social security recipients and pensioner recipients who are seeking to improve their education, who are going back to school, TAFE or university and doing some more study. What do they get from this government? They get a reduction in their pensioner education supplement.

I would be interested if the minister could actually inform us as to how many people, how many sole parents, will in fact have their benefit reduced by this change. Of course, the government is taking a saving, once again, at the expense of one of the poorest groups in our community. It is people on sole parent pensions who are going to have their pensioner education supplement reduced when they are trying to get out there, earn a little bit of money as a result of casual employment and do some study so that they can get ahead and get a better job. I would like to know how many people have been affected.

Why is it the case that the government has seen fit to exempt those on the disability support pension from this rate change but, for some reason, take a saving at the expense of those on sole parent pensions? Once again, it seems that they really are singling out some of those who are the worst off in our community who are trying to make the best of a difficult situation and get back into the work force.

The second issue I want to talk about is what this government has done to the young unemployed. As we now know, young unemployed adults who are living at home in families with incomes as low as $23Â½ thousand are now, from 1 July, going to start losing their unemployment benefits as a result of this government's introduction of the youth allowance. The budget papers were very helpful because, for the first time, we discovered how much this government is saving on the backs of the young unemployed and their low and middle income familiesâ$428 million to be precise. Some $428 million is going to come out of the pockets of families with incomes as low as $23Â½ thousand. (Extension of time granted)

If you are in a family on, say, average earnings of $35,000, the unemployed young person in that situation will find themselves, from 1 Julyâthat is, of course, if they get the paperwork in time and get it inâ$55 a week worse off. That is the approach that this government has taken to those unemployed young people and their families. If the young person is living in a family where the family income is $42,000, they will have to find $87 a week because their young unemployed person will not get any unemployment benefitânothing.

Effectively, the government is transferring responsibility for unacceptably high rates of youth unemployment to families. That is basically what has happened with the changes to the youth allowance. They have completely failed to reduce youth unemployment, so they are handing the responsibility back to the nation's parents.

On this matter, I would like to know from the minister: in the process of taking $428 million out of the pockets of young people and their families, why is the Department of Social Security being given $70 million to do it? What is that $70 million going to be spent on? Why is it that it is going to cost so much moneyâ$70 millionâto take all of those payments off young people and their families? I have another example from a young person, who says:

I am 18 years old, live with my parents, and currently unemployed . . . As of December my family has lived off one income of just under $28,000 per annum . . . Under the new legislation my family is now means tested on past income, despite the fact that for the last 6 months, we have been a single income family. I am now no longer eligible for any payment of any kind, Health Care Card etc.

This is the reality of what this government is doing to the young unemployed.
