It is saying to them, `If your family has an income above $23Â½ thousand you will not be entitled to full unemployment benefits.' It is from that level of family income that, in fact, we will see a reduction in unemployment benefits. To repeat, once again, there is no question that this is yet another example of the government putting the responsibility for youth unemployment back onto families.

A further issue that I wanted to raise tonight is another way in which this government has, over its three budgets, attacked the savings of different groups in our community. The government has, as a result of a number of different changes, forced people to now use up most of their savings before they get access to unemployment benefits. This was a 1996-97 budget measure, and I will go on to draw out how this theme has been repeated again in this year's budget.

When the workers in Burnie find themselves unemployed because of this government's actions, just like those in Cobar, they will find that they have to use up their savings down to their last $2,500 before they get unemployment benefits. As a young unemployed fellow said to me:
This was not the way I had wanted to spend my life savings . . . The whole experience has made me feel as though someone has stolen a large part of my savings.

That was a young unemployed person who was hit by the liquid assets test and, basically, had his redundancy payments affected. For those who are over 55 but below age pension age, there is now the additional hurdle. Those workers are having their superannuation assets counted under the pension income and assets test. They are being forced to rely on their superannuation and, effectively, retire early. These two measures are hitting those workers who have been made redundant hardest. The government, I would have to say, just seems to want to get these people out of the work force entirely, and certainly off the unemployment queues. (Extension of time granted)
We have had so many responses from people in the community about this change because they do believe that they are being punished by this government for saving. As an older man said to me:

During these days of high unemployment workers will be forced to use these funds for living and searching for work instead of keeping them for their retirement. I myself have been retrenched three times now, and have kept my savings and Superannuating Payments in Approved Deposit Funds, instead of frittering them away, and now I am about to be penalised for being careful in trying to provide for my old age.

That is the effect of this government's change on those who are over 55. What do we see in this budget when it comes to those who have been badly affected, once again, by this government? In this budget, those who have received lump sum compensation payments for pain and suffering, not for income loss, will be affected by one of the worst changes in this year's budget.

Previously, if you had received a lump sum payment for pain and suffering, it was not treated as income for social security purposes. From July next year, people who receive lump sums above $10,000 will have their age pension, unemployment benefit or disability pension cut for up to 12 months.

For example, an unemployed person who loses his leg in an accident and gets a lump sum payout of $25,000 for pain and suffering will lose all of his unemployment benefit, all of it, for 12 months. An old age pensioner who might fall over and, say, gets a lump sum of $15,000âand these are realistic amounts that people have received in compensation for pain and sufferingâwill lose $46 a fortnight out of her age pension every fortnight for a year. As an injured person said to us:
To the people who designed this legislationâ
so I say this directly to the minister who is at the tableâ

I would expect that they would sing a different tune if it happened to them. If I were to win money at the races, I would not be removed from the pension that I am on because of my injury . . . I always believed that Australia was about fair play. No more. It is about kick them when they are down.

So, if you put all of these measures together, consider what the message is that the government is sending to people who are unemployed, to sole parents who are trying to further their education and get ahead, to people who have saved for their retirement or who have been paid a redundancy payment because they have lost their jobs, or to people who have had accidents, through no fault of their own, and have received payouts for pain and suffering.

What is the government's message to these people? The government is saying to the unemployed, `Don't try to work your way off benefits because we're going to make sure it's not worth your while to do so.' It is saying to families, `Don't earn more than $23Â½ thousand because, if you do and you have an unemployed person living at home, we're going to cut their unemployment benefits.' It is saying to accident victims, `Don't use your lump sum to get a fresh start because we're going to take away your social security payments, if you do.' The Howard government says to older Australians, `Don't invest in superannuation because, if you are retrenched and over 55, we'll make you use it up before you get unemployment benefits.

The next message, of course, coming from this government to social security recipients is just as perverse, and that is going to be the goods and services tax. Make no mistake about it, the goods and services tax will undermine people's chances of getting ahead. Not only will those items like food and clothing rise in price, but it will be equivalent to a cut in benefits. Also, the cost of getting a job will rise. People will have to pay more to get job help, more for getting their resumes together, more for child care and more to travel to work.

I just want to finish with a quote from a mother, which I think expresses the way many Australians are feeling at the moment as the direct result of three rounds of deep cuts to services and support in social security. She said:
(Extension of time granted)

Many people from all walks of life that I speak to generally have been `hit' in some way by the Howard Government. It seems to range from loss of jobs, incomes and job security, cutting of basic community services (health, education, welfare) to higher costs for all basic necessities in life, leaving people caught in the middle and uncertain of the future . . . The nation is going backwards.
I think that summarises what this government has done as far as social security is concerned.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Through you to the minister at the chair: I understand that my colleagues and I are all touching on immigration. Perhaps the minister might like to answer some of these social security questions before we move into the next sector of immigration. I am easy; it might be appropriate.

âLet me first just thank the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) for her comments in relation to the social security issues. I will deal with them fairly shortly, primarily because I think the speech was one which canvassed issues quite widely. From listening to the honourable member's comments, I conclude that I could well have engaged her as my speech writer for those speeches I made about the many decisions which at that time were taken by the former government when it was in office. I will not delay the chamber long; I will use the balance of the time and then resume my place.

speech.para: As I was listening to the honourable member's concerns about some of the changes we had made to the social security systemâchanges which I see largely as being designed to maintain the integrity of that systemâan interesting point occurred to me. We have made these changes to address the sorts of issues that need to be addressed if you are intent upon ensuring that the scheme is one which is fair, remembering that it is not an universal scheme in terms of pension eligibility and that it has maintained assets and income testing, the introduction of which the Labor Party, in part, was responsible forâparticularly the testing in relation to assets.

I found the honourable member's comments a very interesting set, especially when she made the suggestion that a number of initiatives which have been designed to maintain the integrity of that system, particularly in relation to the assets area, should be opposed. I take it that, having raised the criticisms, that is what the honourable member was intending. Yet you have to marry that up with the sorts of commitments that the Labor Party is making.

Is the Labor Party about taking each of these matters through in a budget context and restoring each of them? That would have implications for a budget that a Labor government, if one were to come into power, would be obliged to implement. It also would have an impact upon the budget surplus. It would be interesting to know whether the honourable member is adhering to the line that you can make these sorts of criticisms but they are not matters which you would seek to address in office.

Another interesting point that occurred to me as I listened to the honourable member's observations was the reference to the impact of our measures in cutting millions out of the system for the unemployed. First, she disclosed in her own comments that the unemployed are down, at the moment under eight per cent, and then she suggests that there are additional people on benefits. That seems to me to be mutually inconsistent with the proposition that you are advancingâthat we are stripping benefits away from the unemployed, and yet at the same time the number of people on benefits allegedly is going up.

As for comments that have been made in relation to JET and the other matters pertaining to compensation and also to young unemployed, I will pick those up if time permits. But, if not, if the honourable member wishes, I will give a more detailed response.

talk.start.para: âI rise today in my first opportunity on the occasion of the National Day of Italy to pay tribute to the great contribution that the Italian people have made, and continue to make, to the growth and development of Australia. This year marks the 50th anniversary since the formation of the Republic of Italy in 1948. I want to pay tribute to the Consul General of Italy, Dottore Francesco Catania, and the Italian National Day Committee.
âOrder! I do not want to interrupt the honourable member, but we are dealing with the expenditure of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

âYes, I thought I was in order. They worked very hard to organise a most successful `festa' in Sydney on Sunday at which the minister was in attendance. I would also pay tribute to His Excellency Ambassador Giovanni and Signora Castellaneta for the warm hospitality they extended to their guests at a reception held at the Italian Embassy. The embassy reception was a particularly grand occasion because of the presence of the `Bersaglieri Band'. The Bersaglieri Corps, an elite forceâ

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Whilst I do not want to unnecessarily interrupt the honourable member, I just ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether this is not more appropriate to an adjournment debate in the other chamber.

âI drew that to the attention of the chamber. I am sure the honourable member for Lowe will bring it into the portfolio of immigration. However, although there is a wide latitude here, he should bring it back to that portfolio. I think there is some validity in what the honourable member for Groom says, but I do not want to be hard line here. If the honourable member could perhaps throw in immigration and multicultural affairs every so often, we could get over this technical difficulty.

âThe federal government has provided funds for the function that I refer to, and I will come to more specifics in a moment. As long as the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) keeps taking points of order, I might not be able to get through what I want to say.
âIt was a very short point of order.

âThe Bersaglieri Corps, an elite force of the Italian Army, founded on 18 June 1836, performed some impressive trumpet pieces, including the ever popular O Sole Mio âwhich, of course, they repeated today in the national parliament. The baptism of fire of the Bersaglieri came in 1848 during the first Italian War of Independence. They later distinguished themselves in all the wars of the Italian Risorgimento of the 19th century and, in particular, they took part in the takeover of Rome as the capital of Italy in September 1870.

speech.para: The Bersaglieri continued to distinguished themselves on many occasions and their outstanding achievements and bravery were recognised even by their enemies on the battlefields. Today, the Bersaglieri are mainly involved in historical re-enactments and official ceremonies. They frequently provide concerts at public celebrations, military parades and tours.

On the occasion of the National Day of Italy, it is fitting to thank the many Australians of Italian background, my wife included, for their contribution to many facets of our way of life in Australia through their language, culture, heritage, values, music, architecture, commercial and business links.

Migration is always a traumatic experience, even when it is to a country that has solicited people to come and has accepted them as citizens. It is often an agonising experience because migrants leave not only their country, city, friends, traditions, customs and values, but also because they leave behind a part of themselves. They become strangers in a different, and often indifferent, environment. They feel isolated, defenceless, vulnerable, with a desperate need to acquire a new sense of identity. They need security not only in material things but also, and especially, in their cultural life. They need to feel accepted as human beings and not dehumanised by being told to `assimilate' as if they were non-persons.

Migration represents a moral and political challenge both for the migrant and for the host country. Although mass emigration to Australia did not commence until after World War II, Italians have always had a presence here. When the First Fleet arrived in 1788, there were two Italian born people on board. From the 1850s, Italians came to settle in our country in increasing numbers.

Today, Italians are Australia's largest non-English speaking group. Italian-Australians have made a rich contribution to Australia's history and culture. Without doubt, Italian culture generally and immigrant Italians in particular have exercised a major influence on Australian life. The origins of this influence can be traced back to the period even before the First World War.
I must leave it at this point. I was going to seek leave to continue, if I could.

talk.start.para: âThe honourable member will have to make some reference to the expenditure before the committee. As the member for Groom says, you really are making an adjournment speech and it might be more appropriate to do that tomorrow. You have the call but, unless you are going to finish shortly, if you do not refer in your remarks to the relevant expenditure, I will have to rule you out of order.

âI will make reference to it because, as I said, there has been a cut in the budget and it is a shame that so many people of Australian-Italian background will feel that they are not getting as fair a shake as has occurred in the past. However, I will continue.

speech.para: Unlike many other immigrant groupsâand I am speaking in support of people of Australian-Italian background, whose very special national day was yesterdayâItalians were geographically dispersed throughout the Australian colonies and they worked in a wide variety of occupations, such as land clearing, road building, cane-cutting, tunnelling, mining and quarrying, and agriculture.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member is really straining the line.
âI take the point put by the honourable member for Groom. I think the honourable member for Lowe is almost finished. Am I right?
âYes, I am almost finished. I am down to my last two paragraphs.
âYou have taken one five-minute allocation and you are halfway through the next five minutes in a speech in which you have not really related to the portfolio, so you should really wind it up now.

âYes, I am winding up. Australia today is what it is because of the momentous and historic contribution of the Australian-Italian community. I want to express thanks to Gianfranco Cresciani, Stephen Castles, Caroline Alcorso, Gaetano Rando, Elli Vasta and Helen Ware whose documents I have pursued for this information and also to the Parliamentary Library staff for their assistance. I conclude by saluting the one million Australians of Italian background and by wishing them a happy 50th anniversary of the founding of the Italian Republic, their ancestral homeland.

âI rise to speak in the limited time available to meâand I hope it is for more than three minutes; I hope the clock will be put back five minutes, as I was generously giving up my time to listen to a rendition by the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) who spoke previously. I must admit that, in one respect, I have to congratulate the member for Lowe on his remarks in respect of the Italians and how they have settled in this country and made Australia, I believe, the wonderful country that it is.

speech.para: I would like to touch more on the budget documents we have before us, particularly those dealing with, as I said, immigration. I would like first to touch on the family reunion program under the immigration portfolioâand I am glad the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) is present in the chamber. I would like to reiterate the coalition's policy document of 1996. In fact, it was on 9 February that this statement was made, containing in part:
The family is the foundation of our society and must be at the core of immigration and settlement policy. Our goal wherever possible is to reunite dislocated families.

I have brought that up in relation to the budget documents particularly because, rather than achieving that goal, I believe the coalition now has effectively ended the preferential category and slashed the numbers, both in absolute and in proportional terms.

I turn now to look at what the budget and the budget documents have told us. The total migrant intake has fallen in real termsâthe proportion, in other words, constituted by the family reunion program. In 1995-96, we saw an intake of 82,500, 68 per cent of which was family reunion. In the next budgetâthe first coalition budget of 1996-97âwe saw that drop to 60 per cent. We then saw the intake go to 47 per centâor a population of 32,000âof the planned intake for the 1997-98 year. I believe, from reading through the documents and some of the statements made by the minister, that we are going to see that fall again.

When one looks at the documents one will see that measures taken to reduce the number of permanent resident visas granted in the preferential family category have included sponsorship, which is now limited to Australian citizens. That was a decision made by this government in October 1996. We have seen the introduction of a tougher new test for parent entry.

talk.start.para: âThe Senate knocked it out.

âI will come to that also. Whereas the pre-existing test required that half or more of the children be resident, the new test required that the majority of the children reside in Australia. That was another decision made by the minister in December 1996. We saw the introduction of the mandatory requirement that family sponsors sign an assurance of support agreement, secured by a bond refundable in the event that no claim is made on social security.

speech.para: We then saw an introduction of a requirement that a de facto spouse prove a one-year pre-existing relationship with the sponsoring spouse. Again, that was a decision made in March 1997 by the minister. We then saw the introduction of `cap and queue' limitations on the number of visas issued to aged parents and working age parents. This extended the categories capped but did not cap the spouse or the dependent children. That was also a decision made in March 1997. In the 1996-97 budget, the program target was reduced from 48,720 to 36,700. The outcome ultimately being that 36,700 visas were issued.

These changes occurred as a result of legislation and regulations. What I would like to point out, as the minister has brought to my notice, is that where the Senate rejected the government's amending legislation or disallowed a regulation these policies were then implemented by ministerial policy directive. The government introduced policy changes in the field of immigration by administrative action, despite the parliament's rejection of those policy changes. As we know, the processing priorities, which also determined the order in which we view applications, will be considered to give priority to applications where the sponsor is an Australian citizen, the applicant is the child of a permanent resident or citizen, and, in the case of the parent visa applications, the majority of the person's children are Australian residents.

I would also like to briefly touch on exactly what the government has done in the 1998 budget. Not surprisingly, as we are aware that in the Queensland election coming up on 13 June preferences have been given to the One Nation Party, this budget again fails to deliver the funds for the $10 million anti-racism campaign it promised Australians prior to the last election. There is no commitment from this government for multiculturalism in this budget. In this budget the government has also completely ignored the need to provide help to get newly arrived migrants into jobs.

No initiative has been taken to improve the prospects of migrants who no longer get unemployment benefits to receive any active assistance to find work in their first two years in Australia. There have been no specific targeted allocations to restore any funding to assist ethnic communities to set up ethno-specific nursing homes and hostels, which is a subject I touched on again last night. I mentioned the fact that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs had recently been at a Croatian village to turn over the first sod for the nursing home part of their application. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI wanted to say a few words in relation to the appropriation concerning social security. I wanted to concentrate on the 18- and 19-year-olds who have lost their unemployment benefits. I would like to address the issue of the withdrawal of unemployment benefits for 18- and 19-year-olds living with their parents who earn more than $23,400. The government describes these families as relatively well off. However, the effect of this decision is to force some 27,000 unwilling unemployed young people back into the school system without any examination as to why these young people left school in the first place.

speech.para: This decision shows a complete lack of understanding by the government as to why young people leave school prior to completing their higher school certificate. In most cases, this is because they have lost interest in the school environment. This attitude may have come about because of a range of issues, such as a change of school, emotional problems and difficulties at home. This decision continues the pattern that has permeated the whole government in its short history of winding back its involvement in assistance to those people in the Australian community who have been worst affected by this government's inability to distribute the wealth of the country evenly among its citizens.

I would like to address one issue in particular relating to the students income test, which enables applicants to qualify for Austudy. The government's legislation considered the effect of other payments such as termination payments, lump sum leave payments and other leave payments. The legislation set out provisions to apply the income maintenance period to Austudy recipients. This income maintenance period is a new provision as far as Austudy is concerned and means that if a young retrenched worker has accumulated, say, four weeks annual leave that period of leave must be used up before the worker becomes entitled to Austudy. This is a principle which I strongly disagree with.

Leave entitlement at the point of termination is money belonging to the worker to use as he or she sees fit. If a worker realises that his employment is in jeopardy, he may accumulate leave entitlements with the view of meeting some financial commitment that he will be unable to fulfil due to a lack of income if he is retrenched. It is morally wrong to ask a worker to live on his accumulated leave entitlement until it is exhausted. That money could well be used to help pay off a home or other debts and enable that worker and his family to have a little less stress than has already been inflicted by retrenchment. However, this whole provision is rather a penny-pinching exercise when you are dealing with low income people with irregular work patterns and is another example of this government reducing entitlements to battling Australians to the lowest common denominator.

Against the background of the government's policy of forcing families to support young people in the transitional period between school and work, you have a situation of falling income for both full-time and part-time workers. I refer to an excellent paper, Australia's youth, reality and risk produced by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum, which states on page 16:
Many 15-19 year olds have no income at all and are dependent on their parents. This proportion increased significantly between 1982 and 1994-95.
The average income of these 15 to 19 year olds receiving some income was $150 a week in 1994-95 and had fallen significantly in real terms since 1987.

Incomes of all part time workers in the 15 to 19 population (including students) fell by nearly 30% between 1982 and 1994. The income of full time workers also fell but by much less than part time workers. There was a big drop in the number of 15 to 19 year olds working full time.
Teenage unemployment has increased and the proportion of teenagers with no income has also increased, as the eligibility criteria for government payments have become more stringent.
For those unemployed 15 to 19 year olds receiving an income, real income levels have fallen slightly since 1982.

Rather than a belt-tightening exercise, the government should be increasing the demand for employment opportunities for our young people rather than cutting their benefits. It should also, at the same time, be implementing policies that reverse the fall in school retention rates.

talk.start.para: âI want to briefly respond to the comments of the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield). I note that this is a further opportunity for addressing comments to a matter that has been extensively debated in the House of Representatives and the Senate in relation to legislation that has been before the parliament. The issues have been well canvassed there.

speech.para: The youth allowance arrangements involve the Commonwealth in very significant additional payments. While some have faced reduced benefits, a system was put in place which the former government, I think, recognised was appropriate but never was able to come to grips with. It is one in which a range of benefits paid to people who are participating in education and training should be comparable with those who are on benefits and unemployed.

If you have a system in which young people will absent themselves from school and from further training in order to be able to access more generous benefits, which was the case previously, then you have a system in place which in the longer term is going to disadvantage Australia as a country. Young people who ought to be able to receive training and education would elect not to do so and would be therefore, in the longer term, significantly disadvantaged in terms of future employment opportunities.

We do not resile from the fact that these changes have been undertaken, but they were undertaken in the context in which there were very significant additional expenditures assumed in order to raise the benefits that were available to those who were in education.

In relation to the leave issue, I think it is just a question of a philosophical approach. I am surprised that, having come from a party that introduced assets testing, you would take the view that leave payments, which essentially are payments in the nature of salary at a time when a person is away from work. Leave payments, which may have accumulated over time, should not be treated as income in the hands of the person for the time in which the leave accrued. To suggest that the money should be then used to pay off debts or to spend in perhaps more frivolous ways in order to provide a benefit to my way of thinking flies in the face of the nature of the payments that are being made. To the extent that the honourable member has raised any other matters that require more detailed elaboration, I will ask my colleague in the other place to write to him directly.

talk.start.para: âI indicate to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) that the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), as the shadow minister, sends his apologies. He is in the chamber on chamber duty, although I suspect that if this continues until after the dinner break that, like Macarthur, he might return.

speech.para: Unfortunately, when discussing budgets over the last couple of years there has been one hardy perennial that has come up in discussing this portfolio. In the area of multicultural affairs that, of course, is the anti-racism campaign which was promised to Australians before the last election. I think it is appropriate to put this matter in the context of the events of this week and the decision of the coalition in the Queensland election to give preferences to Pauline Hanson's One Nation.

I think there is a mood out there in which people are questioning whether there is a diminishing commitment to multiculturalism from this government. One of the best ways that the government could illustrate that it is not walking away from multiculturalism would be to put in place this oft promised anti-racism campaign. The only mention of it in the portfolio budget statements is that there has been a carryover of funding, and under the performance forecasts for 1998-99 there is a dot point which states:
an anti-racism campaign to promote community harmony will be developed and implemented.

But, really, we need it and we need it tomorrow. In my electorate of Scullin something like over 40 per cent of the people were born overseas. They are from diverse backgrounds. Some nine per cent were born in Italy. I commend the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) on his comments about the 50th anniversary. Also, in an electorate like Scullin we have many people from the new wave of migration coming to live in the area, including Indochinese and refugees from the Horn of Africa or Iraq. These people are doing it hard enough without racial tension.

On Saturday morning I had a young Iraqi refugee come up to a mobile office I was conducting to indicate that she has been here in Australia for three years, and she and her sister are still unemployed. They have enough settlement problems without extraneous pressures being placed upon them because of what they perceive to be a growing tendency within the Australian community to not necessarily welcome them with open arms. I think the majority would like to welcome them with open arms but, unfortunately, there has been a sense that minority views within the Australian public are getting prominence.

I urge the ministerâI do not know under what difficulties he is operating to get this campaign off the groundâto act in the knowledge that the opposition supports him in getting this campaign off the ground. I believe that a campaign such as this, which illustrates that multiculturalism has been a very positive thing for the Australian community, is very important. Deep down, we would all agree with that. I am not sure what the messages are. I am not sure whether a different definition of multiculturalism is developing that portrays it negatively. If so, I believe that is wrong. At Melbourne airport, the state government has a sign stating `Multicultural skills build your business'. The Victorian government is pushing multiculturalism as an asset of the state of Victoria. We really need to look at whatever the impediments are or have been to getting this campaign off the ground and to ensure that it does get off the ground.

There are several items within the budget that, if I get the opportunity, I shall return to. I note that one major item in the area of ethnic affairs that is contained in the budget is a social security related matter. It is the cut of $42.5 million over the next four years by the extension of the two-year waiting list to especially New Zealand citizens under a reciprocal agreement. If you characterise the other sorts of expenditure items, there is really not much in this budget for immigration and multicultural affairs related matters. There is one particular revenue matter that I will return to when I get the opportunity soon.

talk.start.para: âI commence by supporting the comments of the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) about multiculturalism. If the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) needs any further help in getting his arguments through cabinet, let us remind the coalition of its multicultural affairs and settlement policy statement of 9 February 1996. Under the heading of `Racial Vilification', it states:

speech.para: All Australians have a responsibility to stamp out racism wherever it occurs. Australians recognise overwhelmingly that education is the only long-term viable approach to the eradication of racism.

As the member for Scullin said, the $10 million that was promised was rolled over from one budget to another. It has now been rolled over again. The minister set up a committee in August 1997, when he announced that market research was to be conducted to assist with the development of that campaign. Progress certainly has not been very public or, if it has, I am not aware of it. I have not seen or heard a lot about it. I particularly ask what progress has been made with that campaign.

Whether we like it or not, we are seeing overt and covert racism increasing. Even though all of us stand up very proudly and say that we are against it, I again reiterate, as I said earlier, the position of the Queensland coalition government colleagues of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to direct their preferences to the One Nation party. They certainly do not seem to be flying the flag and saying, either individually or collectively, that they disagree with the statements coming out from the individuals in that party.

The communities that I and the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace) represent are certainly very proud of our multicultural identity. The logo at the entrance of Fairfield city states that we are here celebrating diversity. All of us, both as Australians and particularly as parliamentarians, should be making sure that we get the message across to not only those people we represent but also other members of government so that at least some of the promised programs of the great election campaign of March 1996 will start being delivered. In all due respects, we have waited for three budgets. We have seen, as I said, two budgets roll over that money. As my colleague the honourable member for Scullin has said, it is now going to come into effect next year. Can we be so sure?

While talking about what has been cut, I also mention the $166.9 million in revenue that will now be taken on as income by the government with the introduction of the $50 levy for non-electronic travel authority countries. I was rather disturbed when that was first mooted and spoken about. One reason we were given at the time was that we now need to look at these countries where a lot of people are coming in as visa overstayers. We are bringing in this $50 levy on visas so that inbound tourists to this country meet their commitment. At the same time, it will allow usâI will quote the minister, but not verbatimâto use that money to have officers watch our shores.

If you look at the statistics the minister circulates around to us on a regular basis, you will find that those at the top of the list of overstayers in this country come from the UK. The next highest, if my memory serves me correctlyâI have not brought the papers with meâare people from the United States, and it goes down from there. The people we are going to charge visas to are certainly not from any of those countries. They average two to three per cent of overstayers. That is where we are introducing that visa levy. It will be interesting to see how that eventuates and whether that income will be used as the minister has directedâI have no problem in thinking he is very sincere in saying what he hasâor whether it will end up in consolidated revenue. Perhaps we will have to read next year's budget papers to make sure where we go from there.

This year's budget shows an $11.8 million cut to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which is a decrease of 33.7 per cent. We also see that $2.8 million will be saved by discontinuing the Australian assessment of community English skills or, in other words, the ACCESS test. We also see that $2.1 million will be cut to legal aid funding, which means further limited representation for migrants and refugees. Further, $2 million will be saved by the government over four years through the closure of loan funds operated by the International Organisation for Migration. That is certainly another cut in this budget. We then look at the 1998 budget increases. I will touch on some of the increases that have been there from the 1997-98 financial year. An amount of $51.6 million will be spent over four years on the enhancement of visa processing and the board of monitoring. An unspecified amount will be spent on the redevelopment of the Villawood detention centre, and I ask for a further explanation for that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will take this opportunity to deal with one topic raised by both the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) and the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), and it concerns the government's commitment to implement education programs to deal with issues relating to race. It is a very serious matter. I have made it abundantly clear over time that, when this is done, I want to get it right. As a threshold to initiating our consideration of this matter, we did undertake very extensive research to ascertain what benchmarks there were around the world for programs to deal with these sorts of issues which had been successful in changing attitudes. We found thatâ
âNot like the push polling survey in Canberra recently.

âI will deal with that, too, if I may. The search was unsuccessful in terms of producing research that was able to demonstrate that results of that sort were obtainable. The second aspect of our inquiries was to undertake very extensive consultations with ethnic communities and people interested in these questions. The view was that if you are going to go out, regale people and say, `You are a naughty person. You are a racist', such a program would not work. Those comments came back to us over and again. It needed to be something positive that built up our self-esteem about what we have been able to achieve and how we can go further.

speech.para: That prompted us to undertake very comprehensive research, first of a qualitative type followed by quantitative surveying.

talk.start.para: âYes, I read the Canberra Times .

âThe honourable member said that she was not aware that we were doing anything. She was aware of the report of one person who was surveyed about some statements that had been developed in focus groups. I read it too. Those statements were not statements of the government. It was not push polling, as the honourable member put it.

speech.para: What comes out of quantitative research testing qualitative statements is some knowledge of the extent to which particular views are held by segments of the community. It provides a basis upon which we can benchmark for future inquiries the extent to which those sorts of issues have been addressed by what we are going to do. We are intent in putting in place those arrangements. I look forward to cooperation from the opposition in implementing that program. I will be keen to do it as quickly as possible.

We are and remain committed to multicultural Australia. Do not believe me; take the Prime Minister's statement from the launch of the discussion paper by the National Multicultural Advisory Council. We have endorsedâit was a bipartisan position that is in the policy documents you are readingâthe `National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia'. The various elements of it have our support, and that support remains.

I am about implementing programs to enhance our cultural diversity and the extent to which people are accepted as Australians within the Australian community as a whole as part of our Australian family. I do that through all my public comments and statements and do so very deliberately on behalf of the government. I would not in any way countenance a view that there is a lack of commitment that can be demonstrated by anything this government has done for multicultural Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe largest figure in this portfolio's estimates of the budget is $166.9 million in revenue, which relates to the change to visa application charges for non-electronic travel authority visitor visas. That is $166.9 million over four years. The outlays relating to that under the enhancement of visa processing and border monitoring contained in budget paper No. 2 over the same four years show an increase of only $51.6 million. This answers a question by the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) about this measure really being a cash cow. The money is just being returned to consolidated revenue.

speech.para: Over $110 million is much greater than anything else contained in this year's budget for this portfolio. This concerns us in the context of a $2.7 billion surplus. We would have hoped there was a more generous spirit and not continued displays of mean spiritedness in addressing some still very important issues regarding the way in which we provide services for migrant Australians.

I return to the Iraqi refugee issue. Being unemployed, very little assistance is given to those people, and that is wrong. I believe that they deserve, as part of our commitment to them, to get assistance and, to a degree, special assistance. We have a great concern that the $50 charge for non-electronic travel authority visitor visas is just being used as a revenue raising measure.

I want to briefly mention the Villawood detention centre. I will allow the honourable member for Prospect to have a bigger go at it. My only interest in it is the way in which there is transparency in budget papers. Opening one where, under the financial implications, it says `NFP', which I gather means `not for publication', is a problem. If government is going to say that they have this charter of budget honesty, we hope to not see too many of these type of items creeping in.

I add that this is one difficulty when going down the privatisation track. I note that this is something under a BOOT concept. In other contexts, I have had some difficulty with that concept. Sometimes we lose transparency in not only the financial implications but also a whole host of operating matters. I would hate to see this creep in under this guise. I know that the honourable member for Prospect has indicated her concern about it. It struck me in perusing the budget papers that it did not seem to really help proper discussion and debate about important issues, such as handing over to private concerns such a migrant centre.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âBefore the break we were talking about immigration. I had started to touch on the redevelopment as indicated in the budget papers for the Villawood detention centre. The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) also touched on this by making reference to the fact that I would be returning to it, and how right he was. Having witnessed the growth and non-growth of the Villawood detention centre for quite some time, as it is at the periphery of my electorate, I can understand and appreciate that certain changes need to be made to it. What I cannot understand is that, even though it has been indicated in the budget papers that changes are about to take place on it, we see continually written here, `Not for publication'.

speech.para: I do not believe that is the way to go. I think it is going to create mistrust in the community at large as to what this means. It is all very well to say that we are looking for private investors to build it, own it, operate it and we will pay rent for it, but I think that peopleâand it is the taxpayers I mean when I refer to the peopleâare going to demand a lot more than that. They are also going to demand from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) that, if there is an indication in the budget papers that certain building programs need to be adhered to and certain changes need to be accommodated, surely a lot more information has to come in, rather than having `NFP'.

I would like the minister to answer that question in his reply as well. I do not believe that in the eight or nine budgets I have seen since I have been a federal member that I have ever seen that before. Perhaps I could be enlightened if this has occurred beforeâthat budget papers have indicated `Not for publication'. I do not know that that is the normal practice, but perhaps I could have that explanation given by the minister when he replies to some of the objections we are raising to the proposed budget expenditure that is before us.

There are other areas I would like to very quickly cover. We touched on some of the obligations that have not been met. I do not want to repeat those, but I do feel that I have to reiterate, as we have done in the past, the service reductions that have happened in the minister's area of responsibility since he has become the minister and since the Howard government was elected in March 1996. In that time, and we have seen it through budget paper after budget paper, we have seen something like five Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs offices closed. These are offices that were in suburban and regional centres. We are all aware of the one in Townsville, but as well as that there are Chatswood and Wollongong, and Sunshine and Geelong in Victoria. I wonder whether this is an indication that there will be more and more closures.

The other area of concern I have relates to what we have not provided in English language programs and settlement programs. I remind the minister of the reference I made to the policy statement of the then opposition, which is now the Howard government, of 9 February 1996. A particular statement regarding English language programs was made in that document. I would like to again quote from the document, for the minister's benefit. It states:
A common language is the glue of a cohesive nation.
There is certainly no disagreement from me on that. It continues:
The coalition is committed to ensuring that all migrants have the opportunity to gain the essential means of communication. We will give greater emphasis to English language and literacy services.

They are not my words; they are the words of the coalition during the campaign in February 1996. What have we seen since then? Since they have come to government, we have seen over that time the fees that were paid by those people who were participating in the adult migrant education program, other than those entering Australia under the humanitarian or refugee program, increase from $2,205 to $4,405. That occurred in October 1996. From January 1997 we saw that go up again to $5,500. I believe that is a tremendous increase. I also feel that a lot more consideration should be given to those settlement programs.

I have another concern. I have written to the minister on this and I thank him for his reply. I might add, by the way, as the minister is at the tableâI would say it anywayâthat he is probably one of the few ministers to answer all of his mail and sign it himself, so at least we know when we have made written representations to him that not only has he read them but that he is well aware of the answer that is going out. I dare to say that that is certainly not applicable to a number of other ministers I could mention in this chamber. My mail is continuing to go out, and I can tell you that there is a lot of it. But, Minister, I thank you for that.

You wrote a letter to me after I voiced my concern over what had happened with the contracts for the adult migrant education classes or teachers in my area and where we were going to see changes occur with that particular group. (Extension of time granted) The group I was representing have been doing a wonderful job in migrant education as far as the English language is concerned, and the minister has visited that particular office in Fairfield on a number of occasions. However, there was a lot of concern and a lot of angst that, after what had happened when they missed out on receiving that program, perhaps the job they had done for many years would not continue to be done.

I have been assured by the minister in his reply to written correspondence that I am not to worry at this stage and that those programs will continue. I can assure you, Minister, I certainly will be watching very keenly to see that the programs not only continue but also the quality of the program continues. As I said, our teachers in the English language, particularly in the Fairfield area, virtually wrote the book. As I understood it, the contracts were given out for private enterprise to participate in that and also become the director of the programs for the English language. I understand that the program that was written by those teachers in that adult migrant education service in my area and other areas like that was used as a term of a particular provision of a contract, although I do not mean a contract as such.

When you are looking to privatise a service, you must have a plan against which you expect certain contracts to be able to be measured. I understand that their particular program was measured as to what can be achieved. If we are using a program that is working so efficiently and so well that we have to use that as the style in which we want private enterprise to follow, why would we give away the one that is running so well in the first place? I find that very difficult to understand. I can assure you that people in my community who are using that service on a continual basis also find it very difficult to understand.

I reiterate that I am very concerned to see that our migrant people, our first arrivals, have access to legal aid. We know that that is not forthcoming anymore. With the cutbacks that I referred to earlier we have seen alterations in the power of the tribunals and the government has introduced legislation to prevent the Federal Court intervening to overturn or vary the department's decisions. Be that as it may, it leaves an extra layer which new settlers in our country, or people who wish or choose to come here, or others who have fled here, have to go through to put their case forward. It certainly takes away another level at which they can be granted assistance. How much more pressure are we going to put on people who are trying to settle in this country?

Without taking up a great deal more time, I reiterate that I am still very concerned about the changes that have been made over the last year or two to the concessional family program. I am not concerned about our skilled migration program because I support what the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is doing in that area, but I am concerned about the family reunion program.

In one of my earlier speeches tonight, I mentioned a comment that was made on 9 February 1996 about how family is the core. If we have people settling in this country, yet we divide them from their family when they are able to show that they can provide for their family, that comment does not ring true. I know we cannot accept everybody who applies under the family reunion programâI understand and appreciate that. But, in electorates like mine, time and time again people meet the criteria, have their medicals and are ready to have a visa issued when all of a sudden there is a cap.

Again, I have written to the minister about this matter because such cases are becoming very prevalent. Families come into our office and say, `But, wait a minute, my Mum and Dad have been approved. All the family are here. We're ready to go. They have covered everything they had to. They have covered their criminal investigations and they have had their medicals. I've spent a lot of money in paying for them. I'm supporting them and I intend to keep on supporting them. But now they're telling me it is capped. When is our approval going to be given?'

Of course, we have to say, `I am sorry but that is a decision of the government. You now have to reapply next year but you will still have that application pending.' Unfortunately, you also have to tell them that that particular medical check is only valid for six months. Because of the capping, because of the waits, because of what has to happen, those people have to go for further tests later on before they can come out here. That has caused a lot of discontent in that family reunion category.

I have particularly been asked to express this concern because I have a large Assyrian population in my area. One of the criteria for either the humanitarian program or the refugee program is that they have to be displaced persons. Of course, the Assyrians tell me repeatedly that they have been displaced persons for 2,000 years because they have not had their country to themselves for that time. They have often wondered why they have not been given a special category. They tell me how difficult they find it to come to this country because they are in a holding patternâwhether it is in Lebanon or in Jordan. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAt this stage I will take the opportunity to reply to some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) who spoke earlier. I will try to deal with the issues that I can clarify. Some of the other issues are matters of debate on which the government has taken certain positions. In relation to those matters, differences are obviously emerging and I think some of that came out today in question time.

speech.para: It seems that there is a view amongst the opposition that family reunion should be increased at the expense of skilled migration. That is the only conclusion that can be reached from a statement which says, `The program will be the same size but family reunion will be increased.' It is at the expense of skilled migration.

The fact that we have a commitment to the family as the foundation of our society in no way detracts from the argument that I know the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) disputes but which holds; that is, that the great bulk of family reunion applicants who have been removed from the programâand I am talking about reduced application rates in the mainâhave been removed in relation to spouse and de facto partners and to parents.

We made decisionsâand I will pick up this pointâthrough regulatory change and the Senate disallowed it, but we have implemented the measures in ways which the law authorises. I assertâand I have asserted it over the years, and the opposition used to assert itâthat it is a matter for the government of the day to determine the size and composition of the immigration program. In fact, this was the first time we had seen regulations disallowed, with the Senate saying, `We don't think it is a matter for the government. We think it's a matter that will be dealt with on the floor of the Senate.'

I encourage the honourable member for Prospect to read the discussion paper on parents that was prepared by my department, particularly in relation to the costs. I was interested in her comments about people who have shown that they are able to provide for their family. The fact is that the system was not one in which people provided for their parents. Most of the parents who were entering Australia came from countries where no welfare systems were in placeâsome 75 per centâand within six months, while your provisions were in place, they were either on special benefits or on unemployment benefits. That is that case.
Mrs Crosio interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat will have occurred from the preclusion period. Ultimately, people were asking their neighbours to meet the costs. That is why the dependency issue is such a crucial issue. I can understand why, if people could bring their parents into Australia and have them on a pension or benefit, they would do so. Bear in mind that, as a matter of policy over a long period of time, we have generally taken the view that in relation to a pension eligibility there was a 10-year preclusion period. However, it was undone by the access to special benefits and the access to unemployment benefits. Those matters are brought out in the discussion paper. That is one of the reasons why we have put further changes in place. There are other points that I would like to make.

speech.para: Mrs Crosio interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI will. Let me just say that, if you turn to some of the budget documents, you will see that the term NFP can be found on page 132 and 133 in relation to the sale of National Rail Corporation, proceeds of ANLâ

speech.para: Mrs Crosio interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âLet me just make the point that, where matters are commercial-in-confidenceâ
âSo are we selling it?

âNo, commercial-in-confidence. Where contracts have yet to be finalised, there are appropriate reasons for not putting out the totality of those arrangements in the budget papers at this time. That is the reason. The nature of the scheme as it is proposed has been made clear. This is a situation in which contractors will be building a detention centre which we will lease. That is the nature of it. Over a period of time, it makes the proposal more affordable and it spreads, ultimately, the cost. The fact is that the detention centre is something that needed urgent upgrading. (Time expired)

âIn the last couple of weeks, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) has unfortunately undermined his own reputation, and I go specifically to the issues which are raised within the budget context. He has undermined his own reputation by attempting to misrepresent the position of the Australian Labor Party in relation to matters of immigration and multicultural affairs.

speech.para: We all know that the minister disagrees with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on a range of fundamental issues. For that he is respected, even though he does not always publicly state those matters. The minister has kept quiet about the Hanson phenomenon and about the distribution of preferences, even though it is an area which is fundamentally important to multiculturalism. He has said nothing about it because he has decided not to rock the boat within the government, even though we know that he obviously has strong disagreements with the views and approaches of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

I was surprised to see the minister quoting the other day from Among the barbarians by Paul Sheehan. I found it amazing to see the minister quoting from that bookâa book which he knows is an intellectually bankrupt book based on the peddling of prejudices in relation to immigration policy and multicultural policy. And that has come at a time when, in the last six months, we have had more people coming out of the woodwork pronouncing against multiculturalism and pronouncing racist statements of all sorts. In fact, it has almost become fashionable to pronounce all sorts of things against immigration and multiculturalism. You can get on the radio programs and you can get in the newspapers. All you have to do is get up and make a story. It does not matter where the truth lies.

This gentleman, Mr Sheehan, has written a book which is fundamentally flawed in every respect, and I challenge him to produce facts and figures to back up most of the things he has said. He has the cheek to attack me in the book. With what? With the fact of my having been the one who implemented the access and equity program? I understood that the minister was supposed to be supportive of the access and equity program. What has happened to the access and equity program, Minister? It has disappeared under your regime. Nothing is happening. In fact, you are allowing people who are against the access and equity program to attack the ethnic communities and to attack the program and you are saying nothing about it. That is appalling.

Then we come to the question of the campaign against racism. Two years ago, $5 million was put aside in the budget, and that was repeated again in the next budget. What has happened to that money, Minister? Why has that campaign against racism not got going? We have a situation now where we have, as I have already indicated, some of the worst levels of racism and public expression of racism, opposition to multiculturalism, attacks on multiculturalismâtotally unfair attacksâand attacks on individual ethnic communities. Where is the minister's campaign against racism? It has disappeared. It was supposed to have got going two years ago.

We are going to have a federal election and we will not even have had the campaign against racism. That is surely a shameful thing. The minister comes in here all self-congratulatory about everything that he has doneâas if there is nothing wrong with what has happened in this area. In fact, we have got a society in which multiculturalism is being attacked from every cornerâwhen we left government, society believed in multiculturalismâand Australia is being discredited internationally for allowing these sorts of things to persist. It is not just the Hanson phenomenon. It is all of the other attacks on multiculturalism that are occurring and all of the other attacks aimed at dividing us in terms of the differences between the ethnic communities and the differences between the Aboriginal people and other Australians.

The minister has a responsibility in these matters and he has not been fulfilling his responsibility. It is all very well to say that the Prime Minister's position determines this, but the minister has a responsibility. He had money allocated to be used in a campaign against racism and he has not used it. We now have a situation which is extremely serious for this country and it will continue to be so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLet me just pick up some of the points made by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). If he had been here earlier, he would have heard what I had to say about the commitment this government gave in relation to dealing with racism. He might care to read the Hansard in relation to that tomorrow. I would dispute very much that we have been discredited internationally. I travel a little and I can say that Australia's reputation in these matters is undiminished in relationâ
âOh!
âIn relation to what is happeningâ
âDo you close your eyes and ears? You are the only person who can maintain this in the whole of this parliament.

âMy eyes and ears are open. Let me add further that, if the honourable member had listened to the interesting comments in the Attorney-General's estimates in another placeâand perhaps he might care to read themâhe would have heard Professor Alice Tay, who is now the chair of HREOC, reporting that this year the complaints arising out of racist issues have fallen. They were at an unacceptably high level last year, and I do not in any way diminish that, but I think one needs to be careful to talk about these issues in a factual way.
âI challenge you on this, Minister. I challenge you to have a look at the media over the last six months and to maintain what you are saying.
âI am simply going by the comments given in the Senate.
âOrder!
âWe are having a debate on the estimates.

âOrder! The member for Calwell knows that he does not have the call at this stage. We will conduct these proceedings in a civilised manner. If he wants to speak again, he will get the opportunity to do so.

âI will leave those matters there. Let me just say, in relation to the access and equity issue, that we have been intent on implementing that through the charter for a culturally diverse society, which is the government's statement on these matters, which has been endorsed by all ministers for application within their portfolio areas.

speech.para: Some other matters were raised, which I would like to pick up, if I may. The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) raised a concern about the issue of access to benefits. The extension of the two-year preclusion period to New Zealanders ought to, in my view, be seen as a matter of ensuring that the arrangements that we put in place are non-discriminatory. It was always the government's intention to negotiate where there were agreements that arranged for other entitlements to be reviewed, but that had to be done in concert with other governments. For that reason, it took a little time.

I will just take up issues in relation to the importance that we attach to programs. We have made some program changes. The access test is no longer required, and it was appropriate in those circumstances to make adjustment. The loan funds arrangements which were in my portfolio areaâagain, fairly modest amounts involvedâfor today's migration program were not suitable, which meant that it was inappropriate to continue them. But last year we did make available very substantial increases in funding for settlement programs. We put in place arrangements to enhance, through the grants program in particular, support for refugees and humanitarian entrants, and those moneys were committed again this year. We had additional funding for the teaching of English, particularly to refugees and humanitarian entrants, recognising that for people who had been tortured and traumatised there were enormous difficulties in accessing the normal teaching programs. For that reason, it was seen to be beneficial to have some pre-enrolment courses to prepare people who had come through the refugee and humanitarian programs for a structured learning course, which we saw as being most appropriate.

I notice the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has gone, but I will pick up later her comments in relation to the AME program, because I want to assure her that there is certainly no intention on the government's part through the tendering arrangements to see the program diminished. We see greater flexibility and opportunities for improvement. We were faced with significant cost increases if we had gone on with the existing arrangements, and some changes needed to be made.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), in his comments on the access and equity program, said, `We've got this charter for a culturally diverse society and we're doing something about access and equity.' Let me put the facts before the House. When we were in government, there was the Office of Multicultural Affairs, and 50 per cent of its duties, roughly, were engaged in access and equity issues. The Office of Multicultural Affairs was abolished in the very first budget of this government, and all of the programs related to access and equity were abolished with it.

speech.para: There was then the creation of this so-called charter for a culturally diverse society in which it was said to each department of the government, `You go and implement something in terms of access and equity.' The reality is that when I was the parliamentary secretary in this area there was report after report which showed that, if departments are left to themselves to implement these strategies, they never implement them. The whole point of having the Office of Multicultural Affairs overseeing this matter was that they could report independently and objectively on this issue of whether or not access and equity was being achieved for people from non-English speaking backgrounds.

Let me explain two aspects of this. The first is this question of whether, in fact, people from a non-English speaking background and from an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background are able to access programs that are available or whether they are failing to do so because perhaps they do not have a sufficient level of English, they do not have enough understanding of the programs or because the department has not made sufficient efforts to get those messages across.

I remember that, when the minister was in opposition, he actually referred to the fact that one of our reports criticised us. We as a government criticised ourselves during that period because we said that we had not achieved enough, given our goals in relation to this matter. That was how much was needed to be done. Instead of that, we have the abolition of OMA and we then have a situation where the minister feels that it is sufficient to allow each department to do whatever they wish with this charter for a culturally diverse society, and that is it; that is access and equity. So each department can choose to do whatever it wishes, and the departments are not doing the job in terms of access and equity. People are not getting access and equity in the proper way, and there is no monitoring of this. There is a little unit in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

As I said, 50 per cent of OMA was concerned with this matter. That has been abolished and we have a couple of people, maybe three or four people at the most, in the department of immigration supposedly looking at this whole matter when whole departments, including, I might say, senior public servants, had to be pushed to actually implement this.

I even got into trouble with quite a few heads of departments because, on the instructions of Prime Minister Keating, we had to push this matter with the departments because a lot of the departments were saying, `Why should we bother with this? We have other priorities.' The fact is that you simply cannot put down a charter, like the minister has done, and say, `That's it. We'll leave it at that and we'll have mickey mouse monitoring of this situation.' How many programs has your department actually pushed through in other departments on access and equity, Minister? How many?

Minister, you think that you can simply dismiss this issue with one comment. But the reality is that multicultural programs have been significantly cut back in a whole range of areas by this government, with one of the worst examples being in the area of access and equity. It is a shameful situation because people are missing out on entitlements from government departmentsâand not just from the Department of Social Security but from a whole range of other government departmentsâin relation to this matter.

Let me conclude with another issue to which the minister referred, and that concerns aged people. Two years after this government was elected, we are still in the process of trying to negotiate social security agreements with a number of key countries. I have written to the minister and raised this issue, but nothing is happening with the social security agreements. They are not proceeding with Greece, Croatia, Turkey or Germanyâand they are just four countries I happen to have come across because I have an association with themânot to mention a number of others that are complaining, Slovenia being one, that Australia is dragging its feet in terms of social security agreements. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are a couple of matters I would like to pick up for the benefit of honourable members present. The member for prospect (Mrs Crosio) was anxious about Villawood. I reassure her that I have been quite conscious of the need to keep people informed. I did make certain arrangements for the Mayor of the City of Bankstown, the local member of parliament and one other member of parliament from an adjoining electorateâand I am sorry I did not include youâ
âIt's actually in his electorate; it's on the border.

âYes. I arranged for senior officials to brief the two members whom I thought were the most closely affected, along with the shadow minister, on the nature of the development; to take them through the plans and show them what was intended. If it would be useful for you to see those plans, I would certainly be happy to facilitate a briefing.

speech.para: My second pointâand I think it is important to understand this point because the principles were the same when you were in officeâis that high risk posts, about which I have spoken in the context of the new charge in relation to the issuance of paper visas, require additional resources. The only way in which I could get additional resources was if I had some way of paying for them. The United Kingdom, the United States of America, Japan and the countries that you have mentioned do not pose a risk. The risk factors have always been determined asâ

talk.start.para: âThey have the largest number of overstayers.
âNo, they have the largest number in absolute terms; but they also have by far and away the largest number of people who enter Australia.
âThey have the largest number of overstayers, too.

âThey have the largest number of overstayers, but they do not have a high overstay rate. The rate is determined by looking at the total number of people who enter Australia and the percentage who actually leave; that is what we look at. If you have a country where the overstay rate is, say, 0.3 per cent, that is significantly higher than the overstay rates that you get for the United States or the United Kingdom, most of Europe and Japan, where you are talking about 0.001 or 0.002. They are the equivalents. You have to look at those things.

speech.para: We have seen a fallâand I acknowledge that this has happened over time; it was happening with increasing data matching and increasing efforts in trying to locate overstayersâin the numbers of people who are overstaying in Australia; that has happened. Also, there has been an increase in the number of people who are here unlawfully who apply to stay on. But that does not alter the fact that overall the numbers have come down through efforts that have been undertaken over timeâ

talk.start.para: âSo why do you need this other provision?
âBecause there are desires to expand Australia's tourist potential in places like China and India where you have veryâ

speech.para: Dr Theophanous interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo, let us understand that the sorts of people you want to come are people for whom $50 will be quite irrelevant.

speech.para: Dr Theophanous interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo, it applies in relation to the paper visa processing and, unless the electronic travel authority is available because it is assessed as being low risk, then the way in which it operates will ensure that our interests as a nation are protected while expanding the range of opportunities that exist.
âYou've lost the plot.

âIf you look at China or India, you are looking at countries where there is enormous potential for overstay. If you look at the numbers of people who make protection claims, if you look at the nature of other applications that are lodged in Australia, it is an issue of very considerable dimension. I have not lost the plot at all, Andrew.
âYou've lost the plot on this issue. This is completely wrong.

âBecause of the time that you have spent looking at these sorts of matters, you would know the enormity of the problems that we face and the costs that are imposed on the Australian community as a result of significant overstay and of abusive claims. These are matters that are best addressed at source by ensuring that we assess people's bona fides before they come. Those bona fides are assessed by Australian based officers. And it is important that we are not put at risk as we were in India recently where we had a student with TB who was able to be visaed by a local basedâ(Time expired)

âMy remarks relate to the appropriation before us of $1,500,324,000 to the Department of Social Security across a range of proposed expenditures. Specifically they relate to the application conditions attaching to youth allowance. I raise these matters on behalf of constituents who see themselves as being severely affected by the provisions of the youth allowance.

speech.para: I have here the letter that goes out to families likely to be affected by these provisions. It is utterly impersonal. It begins with the words `Dear customer'. I do not know where the word `customer' was coinedâhow somebody who is needy of income support suddenly becomes a `customer' of a department. This letter originates in Brisbane, Queensland. Some of the euphemistic jargon in this is as follows:
By introducing the youth allowance, the government is making financial support for students and job seekers simpler and more flexible.
It goes on to say in the next paragraph:
. . . to simplify the transition to youth allowance . . .

This is about denying youth allowance or income support to adults 18 years of age up to 21 years of age. In this whole measure is a deal of social engineering, in the minds of some of those who sit opposite, about forcing parents to be responsible for their adult children. They are no longer children. They are over 18 years of age. They can stand for the office of Prime Minister. They can go to war. They can engage in any activity in their own right as citizens. But for purposes of income support from government when they search for work and work is unavailable they are to be denied assistance, and it is to be loaded back on to their parents.

My constituent, who I have been talking with again this afternoon, is absolutely irate. This is a family with two young adults, both aged over 18 years. As a result of the stepfather earning just over $40,000, the level of income support for his two daughters will drop back to about $15.20 per fortnight.
