This family has a mortgage to pay and all the ordinary expenses of a family and home to keep, and then they are suddenly told, `You have to support your two adult children. They are yours.'

What this is doing is punishing these young people for being unemployed. The younger one is a year 12 student, who has worked her insides out trying to find employment, taking training. These people are adults. On public transport they pay adult fare. Wherever they go they pay adult prices for everything. They get no concessions, no benefits, no support, and they are being loaded back on to their parents. The father said to me this afternoon, `We have to pay full price for everything. I'm 44 years of age. I'm a fitter by trade. I'm supposed to support four adults.'

We all know as parents that young adults eat a hell of a lot more than older adults. The younger lass he referred to finished year 12 and could not get assistance to do child care. They told her to come back in a year and she could try then, but it is placing pressure on that young person. He is saying to me, `I've done the hard yards. I'm 44 years of age. I can't work physically and manually as long and as hard as I used to be able to do. My reward for that as a battler now is to be told, "Thank you, you have to support these two young adults".' Under the government's means test that applies for the youth allowance, they are no longer eligible for assistance other than for $15.20 per fortnight.

I want to raise that in the parliament to express my disgust. Here are young adult Australians, old enough to carry a gun and be conscripted and sent to war, old enough to stand for public office, old enough to vote, but they are not old enough to be entitled to any level of support for genuine circumstances which are beyond their control. They are not responsible for unemployment. They are not responsible for jobs not being available.

In regional areas where I come from, like the Hunter and the central coast where my colleague the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) comes from, our level of unemployment is considerably higher than the level in metropolitan areas of Australia. We have that burden. These young Australians are being punished by this government for being unemployed. The victims are being punished rather than those who are responsible for creating the circumstances being punished. I appeal to the government and to you, Minister, to take this message back to your colleagues. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will not respond at length, but I do thank the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) for his contribution. We had dealt with the principal issue raised by the honourable member earlier in the debate this afternoon. The general comments I made then, I think, pick up most of the contribution that the honourable member has made, save for the correspondence he has received. I would obviously like to provide that to my colleague in another place, and I will get you a written response in relation to the appropriateness of it.

âI want to raise another matter in relation to the immigration program. This concerns the issue of what is happening with business migration. I have raised this matter with the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) privately. I must say that when I raise these sorts of concerns with him he sends his officers around to explain things to me. I was concerned about what was happening with the business migration program from China, so the minister sent around his top officials to talk to me about what was happening in that program. That was two months ago, and I remain totally unsatisfied with what they said to me at the meeting and with subsequent matters.

speech.para: Let me explain the situation. All business migration applications from China are processed in Hong Kong. Leaving aside why that is the case for the moment, what has happened is that the applications received in the last 18 months or so from Hong Kong have all been held up because the department decided that, even though they had filled in the same forms as everyone else around the world, all those applicants would be sent a second letter, and they would be asked to provide a hell of a lot more detail than people are required to provide in other places.

Why did this happen? The reason this happened was that the department was not satisfied with its own procedures for determining who was and who was not genuine on the basis of the information supplied on the forms. Therefore, they sent everybody a form. There was no discrimination, mind you. It was not a matter of saying, `This one is clearly a case that goes through.' Every single person was sent a form, requiring additional information.

The result is that people who want to invest in Australia and genuinely want to come to Australia are all being held up. Why? Because the department in Hong Kong decided to send everybody the letter, irrespective of who they were, and required them to supply additional information. In cases that have come to my attention, some people have supplied reams of information in relation to their business investments and all the rest of it. People are not required to do that if they come from the United Kingdom or some other place.

When I asked the officers of the department why we were requiring people from China to do this, the responses were amazing. They mentioned examples of managing directors of Chinese companies that may be partly owned by the state or local government. As they are not private companies, the rules that normally apply in other places and which apply primarily to private companies cannot be applied to these Chinese companies.

There is a problem with this. The vast majority of companies in China are in part publicly owned, be it by local, state or federal government or semi-government organisations. Hardly anybody from China is a managing director of a company that is totally privately owned. Given this situation, you might have thought that we might try to fix this in some way by having some special or additional rules that would give some concessions to these people, many of whom are excellent and who want to come to Australia.

There are investors with a lot of money, and they want to contribute their very significant managerial skills. We are talking about, in some cases, people who are running companies worth more than $15 million. Do you know what the department said? They said, `It is so hard doing it the other way. What you should really do is get them to apply not for permanent residence or the business migration visa but for the new three-year business temporary visa. Let them come here and then they can do something after that.' That was the department's reply to this situation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe are coming to the end of the debate, but I will endeavour to clarify the issue. There are several new matters that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) introduced. The first relates to social security agreements. The government is anxious to press these matters, but not to press them at Australia's disadvantage. We want to ensure that there is a system in place in relation to social security agreements that benefits not only those people who leave Australia to live abroad but also those people who have lived in Australia who, for some of their life, earned their income and paid taxes in the country with which we are making an agreement.

speech.para: Dr Theophanous interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI was recently in Greece. I was participating with a number of ministers in explaining the sorts of issues that have to be effectively addressed.
âWell, will you tell us what happened?

âI will tell you that the task is one for the Minister for Social Security. You make the point that there is no activity on this front. I am simply saying that there has been activity. There was correspondence from the Minister for Social Security before the ministers in Greece that had endeavoured to press the matter further.

speech.para: Dr Theophanous interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI do not know, but I can find out. I took the opportunity while I was there to progress these matters as far as I could do so reasonably.

speech.para: In relation to the business migration scheme, let me make it abundantly clear that we want additional business migrants. We want people who are going to meet essentially the criteria that flowed from the review that was put in place by the honourable member's Melbourne lord mayor. The Deveson inquiry took place after a public accounts inquiry, where the business migration scheme was brought into very considerable disrepute. There certainly are requirements that people have to have demonstrated performance in running a business. They have to have capital. They have to be able to demonstrate that the money they have has been lawfully achieved; in other words, that they have been taxpayers.

talk.start.para: âWe know all that. What about China?

âThat is the very point. China has a system that is developing today out of a communist system in which they did not have established accounting procedures and the sorts of taxation arrangements that we have normally worked with. They do not necessarily have in placeâthe honourable member for Calwell has made this point himselfâcorporations in which the capital is owned by the people purporting to be the proprietors.

speech.para: We have to have in place arrangements, which we have been developing specifically, for China. We are anxious to get Chinese business migrants. We are conscious that we need to get people who are successful businessmen with their own capital. A review is being undertaken by the Roach committeeâthat is, the business advisory panelâin relation to these matters. I am certainly happy to have my officers continue a dialogue with the honourable member for Calwell about the difficulties that we have in relation to these matters. I am certainly happy for him to put any further submissions to the business advisory panel.

I do not intend to see a very important national interest program undermined, as it could well be if I degrade the criteria simply on the basis that poor China has not yet been able to develop the sorts of arrangements in which they can prove to some external party that the funds they have are their own, that they were lawfully made, that they have been taxpayers and that they have the relevant business experience. I will take advice from the experts in relation to those matters to maintain the integrity of the scheme but to maximise the numbers of people who might be able to come here.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

para.inline: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

speech.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,172,328,000

talk.start.para: âI will not keep the committee very long, but I did want to take the opportunity briefly to raise three points and to congratulate the government on all three of those. The first two come under the purview of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mrs Sullivan) at the table, so I am delighted that she is here to hear what I have to say. The first one relates to the $1Â½ billion or thereabouts in overseas development assistance which I think is a very responsible approach to our aid program. It is a modest increase on 1997-98. We now as a nation exceed the OECD average and are expending something in excess of 0.27 per cent of GNP. For that, the parliamentary secretary and the government deserve congratulations for taking a very responsible approach.

speech.para: The second point is a subset of that and is a new program which again comes under the parliamentary secretary, and that is the youth ambassadors for development program. It is a relatively small expenditure of $10 million of which a little over $8 million is in fact a new program, the balance coming out of the overall ODA funding to which I have just referred. That will give us an opportunity, as has been indicated, to develop a pool of young Australians with knowledge of the Asia-Pacific, an understanding and appreciation of the diversity within the region and a range of lifelong contacts with friends within the region.

The third point I wanted to raise is in relation to treaty making processes. As members will recall, that was the subject of the first ministerial statement from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) after he became the minister in which we announced reforms to that whole treaty making process. I was appalled, I have to say, to read the speech by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in this place last evening.

talk.start.para: âDisgraceful.

âI agree. It was a disgraceful speech. It was offensive. I think we should all condemn her for what she said in that. She talked about the draft declaration on indigenous rights. She referred to that as a treaty. It is not a treaty. It is a draft. It is a declaration. She talked about all sorts of things like dividing this country racially, et cetera. She is wrong. She is misinformed. I think we should all condemn her for that.

speech.para: She also referred to the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. In fact, several months ago I invited her to appear before the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties to hear the facts rather than the fiction she was generating at the time in relation to the proposed Multilateral Agreement on Investment. It is now on the record that last Monday we tabled an interim report on the MAI which I think has put to bed her arguments of shadowy figures in the darkened corridors of the OECD in Paris making laws for Australia.

Australians make laws for Australia. When the honourable member for OxleyâI am reluctant to use the word `honourable'; she is the member for Oxley as far as I am concernedâraises these things, she needs to be a little more informed. I agree entirely with what the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) has said. She is uninformed. She is divisive. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said that, in relation to that speech last night, it is `dishonest' and she is `deranged', and they are the words that were used. I also agree with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) when he said that there were shadowy people choreographing her movements.

The honourable member for Oxley reminds me of the little wooden wind up toy with Mr Oldfield sitting there twiddling away with the wind up. I would like to see the spring run down and the Australian people reject her for what she isâa rhetorical person with no substance.

talk.start.para: âI shall respond extremely briefly, and I am sure everyone is very pleased to know that. I acknowledge the contribution of the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and thank him for it. The increase in overseas development assistance of $50 million is, as he said, modestâbut, nevertheless, it is welcome. These are rather difficult times in which to budget. I think the government has done well in the budget that it has brought forward for AusAID.

speech.para: I particularly wanted to acknowledge his comments on the youth ambassadors for development. I have been in this parliament for a very long time and in that time have been involved in a number of foreign affairs capacities. Tourism has also always been an issue in my electorate, whether I was a senator for Queensland or the member for Moncrieff. My experiences throughout have long since convinced me that the best way to build good relations between countries is to have good relations between the people of those countries.

In relation to the scholarships that have long since been extended to people in our region to study in Australia, we have for some time been aware that they have paid off very handsomely in terms of relationships between Australia and the countries from which those scholarship holders came. As those people grew older and passed through the ranks of their jobs, whether in private enterprise or government, and rose to positions of some influence, the very positive feelings they had for Australia have been expressed. They have led to very good relationships, whether in trade or diplomacy, government to government.

The youth ambassadors for development is a quite different venture and a very exciting one. It will give a challenge to the young people of Australiaâa challenge which I am sure they will rise toâto be part of that bridge-building process between our country and our neighbours. I am convinced that the young people of today are every bit as idealistic and altruistic as ever they were. The challenge that the youth ambassadors for development program offers is one that I am sure our young people will rise to with some excitement.

This program brings in a new dimension, and that is the involvement of business and institutions in a very direct way both in identifying places in countries in our region for those young Australians and in identifying suitable young people for those placements. The profundity of the linkages, in addition to those that are being built through our education programs, will I am sure stand us in very good stead.

The third point raised by the honourable member for Groom concerned the contribution made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson)âif one could call it a contributionâin the House of Representatives last night. I will not speak at any length on this matter but I acknowledge what he says. The member for Groom is, of course, an expert on the subject of the treaty making process. He is the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties which the Howard government established to handle treaties on behalf of the parliament. He has a great deal of expertise in this matter and he speaks with great authority. It has given me no end of pleasure to refer to his committee the numerous enquiries I have received on the subject of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment, although all the letters seemed to bear an uncanny similarity to one another. Nevertheless, I am confident they are being well dealt with.

It is sad that we have in our midst members who will trade on the ignorance of others. But it is a fact of life. I happen to be an optimist. I believe that, in the end in human endeavour, reason triumphs. That is how one has to deal with ignorance. I hope that my faith in that rather exalted notion is not betrayed in this instance. It does not always triumph. Sometimes it takes days, weeks, yearsâsometimes even centuries, I am sorry to sayâfor reason to triumph but it does ultimately triumph. I thank the member for his contribution and commend the appropriations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: âI wanted to raise a couple of points. One thing that is not very popular out there in the community is foreign aid. I am a great supporter of increasing the level of foreign aid to the rate recommended, which I think is 0.33 per cent of GDP.
âNo, 0.7 per cent.

âI thank the honourable member for Groom. We are a long way from that. I do not know where I got 0.33 per cent from. The fact is the modest increase that we have had this time came off a fairly low base, the first budget of the Howard government having decreased the level of foreign aid. At the time I was very disappointed with that decrease, because if there is one area in which we have to show concern, it is in the area of helping those in third- and fourth-world conditions. We can demonstrate that by both the level of aid that we give and alsoâand I add this as a direction that I think the department has taken with expenditureâby especially directing aid projects to try to get the people to help themselves.

speech.para: It is not a case of just giving money and walking away; it is a case of establishing infrastructure, using the considerable expertise we have to establish things and then giving the people who are in these disadvantaged conditions the opportunity to reconstruct their infrastructure, to help improve their water and to plant such things as crops, seeds and so forth. Little things can go a long way. I think the NGO, World Vision, with which I have been associated for more than 25 years in one way or another, has shown the way in that. It has actually led governments to directing aid in a far wiser way and to making the dollar stretch further.

It is very hard, in my view, to somehow compare our situation with the situation of those in third- and fourth-world countries. We hear this argument broadcast a lot: `Well, we've got to look after our own first.' It goes down; it is very easy off the tongue; and people get attracted to it. But, when you get down to the nitty-gritty and explain to people the conditions that women haveâwomen who are working right until the last weeks of their pregnancy, who are having babies in the field, the umbilical cord is tied with a bit of grass that has tetanus spores on it, the baby is infected and often the baby diesâI have found that in my electorate, with people who initially burn up about foreign aid, when you explain those sorts of things they shrink back from the horror of those sorts of conditions. I think it is incumbent on us all to get that message across. But we do need to improve the level of aid.

The other area I want to mention briefly is the failure of the policy of the department of foreign affairs in relation to Timor over a long period of time. The failure of the policy towards the Indonesian government has been brought out. The harvest is now being collected from the failure over a long time to deal properly with Indonesia. We have a situation where Suharto has finally been overthrown after a long time in power. The corruption that is being uncovered is absolutely horrendous. In my own electorate, a constituent approached me about how a hotel in Dili had been filched from his family by people related to the Suharto family. I had been making some representations in relation to that matter over some period of time.

We have got to turn around the sort of endemic corruption that this government and previous governments have propped up one way or another by lending comfort to the Indonesian government in their horrendous takeover of East Timor and the abuse of those people. We have a real opportunity to influence policy in that area, and the department of foreign affairs have got to realise that they made a mistake over a long period of time. They have to draw back and now look positively to help the people of East Timor and advance their cause of self-determination. With those few remarks, I endorse these estimates.

talk.start.para: âThe Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mrs Sullivan) spoke about how she was optimistic and idealistic. That is to be welcomed in a discussion of foreign affairs. Yesterday when I was talking about the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Bill 1998 , I referred to the fact that a couple of views of the world have been emerging after the Cold War. One is the thesis of Professor Huntington, which says that we are all going to fall away because we will have a situation where the world will be divided and these different civilisations, as he calls them, will conflict with each other. There will be these terrible new conflicts arising in the 21st century between civilisations that are based on culture and ethnicity.

speech.para: In that respect, you could take the situation of India and Pakistan. You would have to say that a phenomenon like what has happened there in the last two or three weeksânot only the actual testing of the bombs but the follow-up to that, where the people were celebrating in the streetsâindicates the extent to which nationalistic chauvinism is occurring. There is that negative view but, in contrast to that, there is an optimistic view that the human race will be able to come together, that we will be able to get our international affairs together, and that we will be able to build a better 21st century.

In regard to what is happening with globalisationânot just of the international economy but of technology, communications, cultural traditions and all the rest of itâwe have all these dramatic changes taking place in the world at the moment and I think it is very important that foreign affairs policy keeps pace with these changes. I would like to suggest to the government that one of the things we need to do in Australia is to try to bring together more knowledge and understanding of these matters. We need a think-tank of some kind to advise the government of developments and changes in the world and the implications for foreign affairs and trade policy. The universities do a good job, but there are bits and pieces being done all over the place.

What we need is a good advisory unit which can give us advice about foreign policy and the directions of foreign policy into the future to tackle these issuesâissues such as whether we are going to see the clash of civilisations, whether we are going to see some multicultural, multi-ethnic world, what the consequences are of globalisation and how they can be dealt with. Those sorts of issues need to be addressed, in my opinion, and I think it would be very positive if we could bring that together.

There is one other matter which stems from the comments of the member for Groom (Mr Taylor). Obviously, the vast majority of members of this House condemned the comments made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) yesterday and their implications in terms of the damage that those sorts of comments make to our international standing.

One of the things we can do by taking the opposite position to the member for Oxley is to reaffirm the importance of our multicultural society in both foreign policy and trade policy. In the area of trade policy, we can do a lot more by using people who have come from different cultural backgrounds and different countries to help to establish links with those original countries, especially trade links. I know there are examples around the world where we have tried this from time to time, but I think we should do a lot more of this. If we do, I think we will be able to achieve much better outcomes in trade policy. If we used, for example, a Hungarian Australian, a Turkish Australian or a Chinese Australian to help smooth the way in the dealings with those countries, then I believe we would be able to actually increase our trade both within the bureaucracy of foreign affairs and more broadly within the community through the chambers of commerce and so on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTalk about famous last words. In my last contribution, I said that I thought this was going to be a very brief debate. I thank the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) for his contribution, which was a thoughtful and, I know, a very sincere one. I should like to very briefly respond to a couple of the points he made.

speech.para: As he pointed out, in percentage terms a 0.5 per cent increase in the foreign aid budget is modest, but that does not tell the whole story. It was $50 million, but that does not mean we have just added $50 million to what we were already spending money on, because each year's funding is a new program in itself. There are certain individual programs that will have ended in the previous financial year that we do not renew, because generally our programs are finite. When they end, their funding ends. So we have been able to initiate a lot of new things with money no longer needed because of programs being completed.

There were some things we were locked into when we came to governmentâsome long-term agreementsâand that has taken some flexibility out of the aid program. In terms of cutsâand there has been reference to previous cutsâno greater cut has been taken than in any other area. Foreign Affairs and Trade took their share and AusAID took its share. The department had to find those cuts because of the budgetary situation when we were elected to government in 1996. I will not prolong that particular debate, though. That is one for the Treasury estimates and I might be being a little too provocative.

I should would like to point out that, whilst it was, as he said, a modest increase, it was 0.5 per cent in real terms. There is $10 million for a new youth ambassadors for development program. There is a new $6 million East Asia crisis fund. Emergency funds have been trebled to $34 million. There is a $14 millionâ18 per centâincrease in the sector of governance and human rights, and a fivefold increase in funding for human rights activities, which I know is an area that the member for Dickson would be interested in.

As time goes on, the coalition government will be able to shift the emphasis of spending into those areas to which we give priority, and I think they are areas that the honourable member would support. I also point out that we very much value the role that non-government organisations play in the matter of delivery of overseas development assistance. This year the core funding for the non-government organisation program has been increased by 13 per cent, which means that it has been increased by 47 per centânearly 50 per centâsince the coalition government was elected in 1996.

I acknowledge the difficulties that the member referred to that can be encountered, in concept, in the community in relation to overseas aid, and there are some people you will never persuade. Heaven knows, of all the people in this parliament, I am probably the one who is out there the most, talking on it and inviting the sorts of questions and objections that the member referred to. There are some people you will never convince.

But I very strongly believe that the answer to criticism of our overseas aid program is to go out and debate it, to make information available, to tell people about it, to invite their comment and their criticism and to let the Australian public feel that this is something that they are involved in. Therefore, the emphasis that we have given to non-government organisations and to that particular program is, I think, entirely appropriate. Most members could be very surprised if they realised the penetration of the issue of foreign aid in the community, and I mean this in a very positive way.

Most of the churches are involved, care about it and have comments to make about it from time to time. All of the significant service groups are involvedâmany of them in a hands-on wayâand so on. Suburban housewives are involved through local Red Cross branches. It is very broad and inclusive. The more information that we can put out about our program the better. As I said earlier, I believe reason triumphs. If you give the facts, that is the answer to it.

My time is running out, although I know I can talk again later. I just want to make a very quick response to the reference the member made to East Timor. Maybe I shall wait until later. I have a feeling someone else has another contribution to make.

talk.start.para: âCould I make a comment on the East Timor issue in relation to what the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) said. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) have said that our emphasis is on bilateralism, and we have strengthened that bilateral approach. Within the strength of those bilateral arrangements, it is a warts and all approach. In the case of Indonesia, the pinprick, if that is the right phrase, has always been the conditions and what has happened, albeit over 20 years ago, in East Timor.

speech.para: Both the Prime Minister and the foreign minister have said that we should not be afraid to objectively criticise the Republic of Indonesia in relation to human rights infringements within East Timor. So I do not agree with you that, in fact, it is something that we have left unsaid. I think on both sides of the House we have taken a similar approach. I do not think any of us support what happened over 20 years ago, but it is regarded by most people these days as part of the sovereign state of Indonesia, like it or not. If there are human rights infringements, we should criticise those human rights infringements, and they are the points that the foreign minister has made over and over again.

talk.start.para: âI would like to make a very brief contribution. I commend the government for the increase in aid, even though it may only be modest. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mrs Sullivan) says, it is not so much the size of the increase but the degree of focus that makes it effective. I did notice that $6 million was put aside for the Asian crisis.

speech.para: In my electorate, there are a number of building supply companies, and they have put the point to me that, in the aftermath of the riots in Indonesia, an interesting way of providing aid might be to use Australian building supplies as a form of aid. I know, generally speaking, governments frown upon supplying aid in kind or supplying actual food products, for example. I suppose this would come into a similar category, but they make a very interesting point.

There will be a great need for building supplies. It is a time of civil and political unrest. Australia could make a very significant contribution to the rebuilding of those cities that have been damaged, some superficially, some more deeply. At the end of that period of reconstruction, those Australian building supplies and the companies that supply them, their engineers and the other people who might go across to see to their installation, place in that economy, and in the new administration of Indonesia, a good image of Australian building supplies and what they might do on a long-term basis for Indonesia. To be shameless about it, there is an element of promotion in it, but it could be a practical way to not so much take advantage but build on an unfortunate situation, see it fixed quickly and, at the same time, give Australian companies a promotional boost.

talk.start.para: âI will respond just briefly in relation to certain remarks made by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), but first I will just to add to the East Timor issue. As far as Australia is concerned, apart from our concerns about the people of East Timor and their autonomy, there is a major unresolved problem that we have in this area: the death of those five journalists.

speech.para: Last year I met the mother of one of those journalists. The only inquiry occurring that could even approach some form of substance was the Sherman inquiry, and the Sherman inquiry failed to interview very relevant witnesses. So that particular inquiry was insufficient to clear this matter up once and for all.

In my view, we now have a golden opportunity to have a proper inquiry; to send to that country a team of people who, in cooperation with the Indonesian government, could properly investigate the deaths of those journalists. I know that the matter is perhaps considered now to be old, but it is unresolved as far as Australia is concerned. In my view, those deaths have not been properly investigated. The Sherman report was inadequate, witnesses were not interviewed and the inquiry, leading to the Sherman report, was not done in the context of a proper inquest-type inquiry and investigation.

So let us take this opportunity. I urge the government to make approaches to Indonesia about this issue because, as far as Australia is concerned, a gesture by Indonesia in this direction would, in my view, have a great and profound effect on the people of Australia who have long memories, and, as I say, the mother of one of those journalists who were killed. I do point to that as a significant matter in the whole scenario.

But I would add also to the remarks about East Timor made by the honourable member for Groom. It has to be acknowledged, with great respect, that within the Department of Foreign Affairsâand this was said by former diplomat Jim Dunnâthere has been a failure of policy advice in that area. I think it is about time that the department of foreign affairs stopped fudging on this issue and acknowledged for once that there has been a failure to give proper advice to successive governments on what occurred in East Timor. Once that acknowledgment is given, we can go forward and develop a relationship where there will be respect on both sides and one which at the same time will benefit the people of East Timor.

talk.start.para: âI shall be brief. A wide range of subjects has now been raised, and I do not think it desirable to get into a general debate on foreign affairs here. I shall respond to a number of things in the appropriation bill context.

speech.para: I refer the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) to the book Australia's Overseas Aid Program 1998-99, in particular page 81 on which there is a section called `Types of Contracts let by AusAID'. The honourable member made a suggestion about building supplies in consequence of the riots in Indonesia. This type of suggestion is commonly made and it is not a bad suggestion; it just does not fit in with the way we run our aid program.

Our aid program is run in response to requests from partner countries. That is not to say that because a country asks for something we give it to them. We have a structure in our program. It has identified priority areas, and we have a way of going about them. What I am trying to say is that aid projects are not initiated from within Australia.

That said, the point the honourable member makes is correct: one of the benefits to Australia of its aid program is that, in the process of Australian concerns getting contracts to carry out that aid, naturally commercial opportunities often follow. That is different from using your aid program as a subsidy for Australian business or commercial concerns. Our aid program is about helping poor people; it is not a subsidy for Australian industry. We identify the poor people and their needs within our priority sectors, and that is the area in which we operate. We also identify the areas in which Australia does its aid best and has particular expertise.

So that is the general rationale. But it does follow quite often that, when Australian companies are successful in getting contracts in the competitive tendering process, they gain expertise and get contacts in that country which can lead to other commercial opportunities quite independent of the aid program. That is to be welcomed.

I believe that one of the very good things about our aid program is the number of Australians who are overseas implementing it. Whilst there is a very major component of training in our aidâand we do try to maximise the amount of training given to locals so that they have the relevant skills after the project is finished, so far as we are concerned, to continue on in similar areasâAustralians nevertheless are personally heavily involved overseas. I think one of the greatest assets we have going for us in our aid program is the Australians who go and work overseas, the sorts of relationships they build up and the image they give.

I will refer to East Timor fairly briefly. I am not unsympathetic to the point of view that the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) put, and I do not think anyone here is. But in the world of international politics one has to be a realist: there are things you can do and there are things you cannot do. We are a major funder of the Human Rights Commission in Indonesia. It has been very courageous in relation to the East Timor situation. For example, it was that body which investigated and brought out a public report on the Dili massacre; it has been a report from which much has flowed and on which much is based. The Indonesian government has accepted that funding by agreement with us. It is not something we have gone in and foisted on them. We have been able to establish a relationship whereby it has been possible for us to do that.

We also give very substantial amounts of aid to East Timorâone of the reasons being that over time the Indonesian government, because of our good relationship with it, has known that we are not going to go in and stir up trouble.

We are quite fearless in what we say and have said to the Indonesian governmentâthe present one and the previous oneâabout East Timor. Indonesia knows that a factor in our relationship is that we are going to keep on pushing the envelope on the subject of human rights and democratic rights in East Timor. There are a lot of countries that could not do that with Indonesia. It is because there is substance to the overall relationship that they will accept it from us, and on that basis we are able to help people in need in East Timor. It is not a perfect situation; that I would acknowledge. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

para.inline: Department of Transport and Regional Development

speech.para: Proposed expenditure, $231,784,000.

talk.start.para: âMy remarks relate to proposed expenditure on roads through the Department of Transport and Regional Development. I am looking at the table that shows proposed expenditure in 1998-99 of $1,563.6 million. I bear in mind the comments of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) in the House of Representatives a few days ago about expenditure on roads and about the level of fuel excise being collected.

speech.para: I want to say at the outset that when one looks at the estimates and looks through the documents associated with the budget one sees that there has not been an increase in expenditure on roads but rather a decrease of $28 million from last year to this year. That cut is made up of a $12 million cut in the national highway funding program, $7 million cut from grants to the states, $9 million cut from grants to local government, and, in total, expenditure on road maintenance and construction has been cut from last year's forward estimate of $1,628 million to $1,601 million.

But the great casualty in road expenditure since this government came to office has been the national highway category. In the national highway category we see that in 1997-98 there was $680.1 million. Expenditure was to rise to $687 million in 1998-99. In fact, what is provided in the budget is expenditure of $675.5 million. I want to compare that with the expenditure on the national highway program in Labor's last year of office, and that was $834 million. What we have seen with this government is more gatherings from fuel excise but less money being spent on roads.

The minister made great play in the House the other day of our having increased the excise on fuel from 7c per litre to 34.97c per litre. What the minister probably was not told by his advisers, or did not want to listen to if he was told, was that with the introduction of import parity pricing by a former Country Party transport ministerâat that time, in 1978-79, the Leader of the Country Partyâthe excise on crude oil was raised from $3 per barrel, which is equivalent to 18.9c per kilolitre, to 64.53c per kilolitre in one fell strike. That was a major increase. We then had a fuel excise and a crude oil levy under the program of import parity pricing. That was done by a National Party minister. It was an exercise that was paraded for the best part of two years and promoted by the then Leader of the National Party, the then member for Richmond, who made great play of that.

Subsequently, in 1986-87 the two levels of collection were combined into one and levied as an excise on petrol at the consumer end. That was the major change. One can go through the amounts being collected. They were actually indexed between 1988 and 1993. In 1993, they were increased as a result of the differential introduced between unleaded and leaded fuel. I do not think anyone would disagree with that and with the necessity to go to unleaded fuel.

But in this budget we have reached an all-time low in the share of fuel excise being spent on roads. We are now in the situation where 35c per litre is collected by this government every time fuel is purchased at the fuel pump. A mere 5c of that 35c goes back to road expenditure. This was an issue on which the now minister had a great deal to say when in opposition. Now that he is the minister I would like him to do something about increasing that share of excise that is spent on road expenditure, road construction and road maintenance. This minister is the one who had so much to say about the share of fuel excise being directed to road construction and maintenance. There is no better person than him to do something about it. What we are seeing here now is an abysmal performance and an abysmal share of revenue collected from motorists being directed back to road construction and road maintenance. (Extension of time granted)

The other point I want to raise under the estimates of this department deals with aviation safety. On 14 December 1995, we released the Plane Safe report, which was a unanimous report into aviation safety by the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. There were 17 recommendations in that report. I just want to touch on two major recommendations this evening. The first was:
(a) the Civil Aviation Safety Authority publish serious deficiency reports on a monthly basis, initially for charter operators, commencing March 1996;

That was 2Â¼ years ago. Paragraphs 5.30, 5.31 and those prior to 5.30 cover the background to that recommendation. But, essentially, the background is this: the charter section of the general aviation industry is the area where we, as a committee of inquiry, perceived the greatest danger to be. The market needs to know about the information that is gathered each month by Civil Aviation Safety Authority surveyors or inspectors as they do their rounds and make their inspections of various aircraft, workshops and hangars. There is an abundance of information. Some of it is of minor import, but some of it is very serious, and the public are entitled to know.

It is not good enough to say that passenger aircraft are operated at a high level of safety. Whenever a person steps on board a general aviation aircraft, be it a private charter or a charter aircraft leased out to operators of business, they are entitled to expect that that aircraft is being maintained in accordance with civil aviation safety regulations. They are entitled to expect that the aircraft has been maintained within set times and that the person operating the aircraft has the appropriate credentials and endorsements to operate that aircraft.

We recommended taking a very minor step forward, but what has happened in the 2Â¼ years since this was covered? The people who railed against general aviation safety at the time are now mute. What has happened now is that the poacher has become the game keeper. This is an extremely serious issue. In this context, I want to ask the minister about the electronic locating transmitters on board the aircraft that was involved in the recent tragedy where six residents of Albury died. A campaign was run to block the installation of fixed ELTs on aircraft. I saw nothing in the public reports that ELT signals were received from that missing aircraft. I mentioned it to somebody. They said that it did not matter because the passengers were all deceased, but that is not an answer. We are entitled to know. I want to know. I want to see action to have this recommendation implemented as soon as possible, because it tells the industry, `If you are operating your aircraft unsafely and out of time, and if your maintenance release sheet is not dotted, the public is entitled to know before they set one foot on that aircraft.' Many of us travel on charter aircraft at times.
The other matter relates to recommendation (d), which reads:

air operators and ticketing agents be required to provide information, at the point of sale and in a prominent place on all tickets, on (i) the name of the operator (ii) the type of operation, (iii) the aircraft type, and (iv) an explanation of the different levels of regulated safety for the different types of operation.

This followed from the Seaview disaster. People are entitled to know, when they buy the ticket at point of sale, what type of aircraft they are travelling on and what standard of safety is likely to be available on that aircraft. When tickets are sold, the public may think they are travelling on a 747, a Boeing 737 or a frontline regular higher safety standard aircraft, but, ultimately, they can finish up, in some cases, on a cross-chartered private aircraft. The standard of safety on that aircraft can be much lower. I would like the ministerâI do not expect it tonightâto give to the House or to me in writing a written explanation of what is happening with these two recommendations. They should have been implemented two years ago. They were capable of being implemented two years ago. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI refer to the comments of the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on road funding. I am sure he is aware that the overall level of federal road funding in this year's budget was considerably higher than the one in the last Labor budget. I think he perhaps mistakenly indicated to the chamber that that is not the situation. I can assure the chamber that it is indeed right. This year's funding is up on last year's. Again, it is one of the largest road funding budgets on record. The government has said quite clearly that road funding is extremely important to this country.

speech.para: We would like to see a reduction in fuel excise charges and a greater increase in the level of road funding than exists at the moment. However, the realities are that we have been placed in an extraordinarily tight financial situation by the actions of the former Labor government. We have quite clearly said that we want to see a reduction in those fuel excise charges and that we would like to see an increase in the level of federal road funding. Let us make it quite clear what our desires are, but let us make it equally clear the reasons why they cannot be fulfilled at this stage.

The interesting part about this process that we are going through today, and indeed through Senate estimates and other areas, is that the true impact of what we inheritedâleaving the government aside and, even more importantly, what the people of Australia inherited and the impacts of thatâis just starting to flow through now. People are starting to realise just how dramatic it was. It was not a deficit in isolation. It was a deficit that required remedial action in portfolios right across the board. The real issue here tonight is that budget deficits are more than just figures in budget documents. They affect real portfolios and real decisions.

I also wanted to briefly talk about the excise question again raised by the honourable member. In the period 1983-84 to 1995-96 the former Labor government increased excise on petrol from around 7c per litre to the current level of approximately 34c per litre for unleaded petrol.
Mr Cadman interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou may well ask. Do you want me to go through those again?
âYes.

âIt went from 7c in 1983-84 to 34c for unleaded petrol and 36c for leaded petrol in 1995-96. That is extraordinary. Over the same period federal spending on roads did not keep pace with the increase in excise revenue. In fact, in 1982-83, in the period of the former federal coalition government, federal road funding represented about 60 per cent of federal fuel excise revenue collections. By 1995-96 this figure had fallen under Labor to around eight per cent. I saw the honourable member for Shortland with his calculator going madly before this started. I have worked out what it was.
âNo, you're wrong.
âNo, it was not what I said to you before. (Time expired)

âI only have one matter I wish to raise in transport, and I appreciate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, coming to the chair to allow me to take the floor to do it. I bring it to the notice of the member for Ballarat and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson) so it can go back to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) for investigation.

speech.para: What I am concerned about is that, if he has a look at budget paper No. 2, tucked away under `Transport and regional development' is the seemingly innocuous planned expenditure of $300,000 in the coming financial year for a public awareness campaign concerning Sydney's second airport. This is on top of the $200,000 the government has already spent this financial year on the same project. I would like to read from that budget paper. It states:

The Commonwealth has provided an additional $0.5 million over 1997-98 1998-99 to complement and broaden the existing community consultation programme that was established to raise the levels of awareness, knowledge and understanding of the proposed second Sydney airport and its related environmental and economic implications.
What does the government actually mean by `complementing and broadening the existing community consultation program'? That is the question I ask.

It seems to me that it sounds like an advertising or a PR campaign, and I think I would be right. Recently the Department of Transport and Regional Development contracted the services of a well-known Sydney PR firm, Cosway, to put together a campaign to sell Badgerys Creek airport to western Sydney residents. Cosway has a long history of association with the Liberal Party.

In 1993 Cosway was hired by the then coalition New South Wales state government to repackage its budget documents in a simpler and more easily understood form. That was the first time that a PR company had been used by the New South Wales government to sell its budget. Well may we ask the now Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) because the services were paid for with $160,000. Cosway has hired again in 1994 for the same purpose, only the pickings were a little richer this time. Cosway reaped the benefits of its close association with the Liberal Party to the tune of $600,000.

It is no crime that an advertising or a PR company with a long history of association with a political party is hired by that party when in government. I would of course question the morality of conducting a snow job on the people of western Sydney teaching them how to learn to love the idea of having jumbo jets flying over their houses 24 hours a day, but that is an argument for another time. What is important is that any company hired by this government, especially a company with a long history of association with the senior party of this government, like Cosway, has competed for the contract with other firms. It must be transparent to all that the company in question has gone through the same rigorous channels as everyone else in tendering their application. In relation to Cosway, I now have my doubts.

According now to my information, Cosway has enjoyed a longstanding and close association with the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey). The member for North Sydney has in the past shared a strong friendship with an ex-principal of Cosway, Mr Greg Barnes. As I understand it, Cosway has also done some work for the member in the past, work that was carried out, I understand, at a very affordable price. We also know that the member for North Sydney is the chair of Sydney airport community forum which is heavily relied upon by the minister for transport to advise him on all matters regarding airports in Sydney. He is also a strong proponent of Badgerys Creek airport.

I am not accusing the member for North Sydney of acting inappropriately. I am not accusing him of any impropriety. However, I do suggest that there remains a question of whether he may have acted unsuitably. I do suggest that the member for North Sydney needs to come into the House at some time, or the parliamentary secretary, to answer these questions. He must outline his relationship with Cosway and tell us whether he played any part in its receiving this government's latest contract. He must come clean on whether he smoothed the waters for Cosway all the way to the minister's front door. He also must come clean on whether he helped organise this contract for Cosway as his quid pro quo for the work it had done for him in the past.

I also suggest that the minister for transport release all details regarding the tendering process for this PR campaign. We need to know what other companies tendered for the contract, what prices they quoted for the job and on what grounds they were judged unsuccessful. Until the minister for transport and the member for North Sydney clarify their role in Cosway receiving this contract and until the minister for transport allows public scrutiny of the tendering process involved, doubts will remain over whether this money has gone to the company best suited for the job, however debatable that job may be, or to the company which was lucky enough to have mates in all the right places. Until they do, we are faced, I believe, with another unwelcome opportunity to question the standards and the credibility of this government.

I reiterate that $300,000 is there for a campaign I believe is quite unsuitable in the first place to try to tell the people of western Sydney that they need an airport there, but most particularly, and that is what concerns me, is how this contract was furnished, how this contract was tendered for and how this contract now appears in the budget papers with the $300,000 and with the fact that Cosway already has the contract. These are questions that I believe must be answered. I understand the position the parliamentary secretary has been placed in. If he cannot answer them, I certainly would welcome answers in writing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am concerned in that I rather suspect that the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has not advised the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) that she would be making these comments tonight. The convention of the House in my eight years here has always been that, if you are going to make those sorts of allegations against another member, that person be notified.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We are talking on the budget papers. We are talking about a $300,000 amount that is included in these budgets papers. I have bought in the member, which I clearly stated in my remarks. I am not accusing him of any impropriety.
âThere is no point of order.

âThe member for Prospect may want to back off at a million miles an hour in relation to the comment that she made, but may I remind her that the conventions of the House are that, if you are going to make those sorts of allegations against another member, you have the decency to advise them that you are going to do so. Some pat excuse such as, `I wasn't going to make these comments but decided to do it,' is not a reasonable excuse. I know that my colleague is keen for workplace relations to be debated tonight but I hope that the member for Prospect will leave the Main Committee chamber and reflect on her role as a senior member of this House and whether tonight she has lived up to the responsibilities that that brings with it. I will leave that be.

speech.para: I was going talk very briefly in relation to the question of Badgerys Creek. I quote from the Aviation Press Club on 17 February 1998 where this comment was made, `We remain committed to building an airport at Badgerys Creek, subject to the current EIS process.' The speaker at the time was Mr Lindsay Tanner, the member for Melbourne, the opposition spokesman on transport.

Just very quickly in the one minute that I have left, I mentioned earlier that I saw the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) madly tapping away on his calculator. I have worked out what he was doing. He was actually adding up the extraordinary amount that the coalition is putting in to regional Australia in this budget. I am not surprised that he would need a calculator because it is a sensational contribution to non-metropolitan Australia. Unfortunately, his calculator is unable to tell the chamber that there is $1.25 billion in the Natural Heritage Trust, $1 billion in the Federation Fund, $250 million in the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, more than $700 million on federal road funding and a $525 million AgricultureâAdvancing Australia package. It must be a very advanced calculator to start adding up quite extraordinary figures like that.

This is a budget for regional Australia. It is an important budget; it is a budget that sets in place the ability of this country to start delivering to the young people, to small business, to families and to farmers. They are the ones who, at the end of the day, deserve a go. This budget is putting them in a position where they can maximise the opportunities that will be delivered to them over the forthcoming years.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

para.inline: Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business

speech.para: Proposed expenditure, $197,511,000

talk.start.para: âMy remarks relate to proposed expenditure by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business which in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) comes to $197,511,000. I am particularly concerned about running costs which are estimated at $75,735,000. The performance of some officers within that department has led to the appalling spectacle that we saw over recent months of what is the government's idea of security. We have seen uniformed thugs, balaclavas, guard dogs, mace sprays, midnight raids on law-abiding citizens in their workplaces and vilification of members of unions, their wives and their children.

speech.para: Amongst all of this Australians are coming to realise that, with a government applauding, aiding and abetting Mr Christopher Corrigan to contrive the bankruptcies of his own companies so as to avoid his obligation to his employees, no working man or womanâno matter whether union members or notâare safe in their jobs. It is an ugly Australia they do not want a part of, we do not want a part of and, increasingly, the people in the electorate are coming to recognise that.

What we are seeing in this action is a minister out of control and a government that has lost control. What we are seeing is a malice, a malevolence and a hatred of union maritime workers at sea or ashore that subsume their commonsense and fair judgment. I have referred to what happened at Webb Dock but, most scandalous of all, is that this government has joined with Mr Christopher Corrigan and endorsed his action of contriving the bankruptcies of his own companies in an attempt to avoid their obligations towards his own employees. The government, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), officers of this department and their colleagues endorsed the expenditure of over $1 million from the taxpayer to prepare what effectively was Christopher Corrigan's battle plan.

Months before the event of the night of 7 April 1998, cabinet had rushed through approval for the $240 million financing of the redundancy package that was to be utilised by Mr Christopher Corrigan. Straight through cabinet with no notice and no written submissionâjust a straight verbal submission. It is almost unprecedented. We know the whole operation was engineered and orchestrated from this building, even to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business announcing at 11 p.m. on 7 April 1998 the eviction of 1,400 Patrick Stevedores workers from their jobs. It was obvious on the television interviews that were broadcast the next morning that he exulted in doing it.

We know that the office of the minister for workplace relations has been the major operations centre for this infamous political exercise. It is a political exercise that has cost Australian taxpayers, Australian importers, exporters and our international trade dearly. It has damaged waterfront employees and their families not only financially but also in community and social terms. We know that the former minister, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), and his staff are now being blamed for this fiasco. But we also know that, when Minister Sharp resigned, the operation was grabbed by the minister for workplace relations and his office. They ran that operation even though I know they are trying to blame Mr John Wallis and Mr Greg Bondar, former members of Minister Sharp's office.

But I believe the culprits, the zealots responsible for the fiasco, rest in the office of the minister for workplace relations. Among those are Derren Gillespie, formerly of the Department of Industrial Relations; Dr Stephen Webster, of Dubai fame; and Mr Paul Houlihan, of Mudginberri notoriety. David Trebeck has been credited with responsibility for the mad Dubai mercenary plan, but I do not think he would be involved. I have known David for a number of years and I do not think he would be involved in something like that.

Let me say that corporate Australia has observed these goings on and there is no corporate leader or contact that I have across industry who has endorsed `doing a Corrigan'âthat is, the contriving of the bankruptcy of one's own businesses to avoid one's obligations to one's own employees. In fact, it is quite the opposite. The corporate leaders and executives I have spoken toâand there are quite a number of themâhave declared that what Christopher Corrigan did is wrong. We know it is wrong. The public knows it is wrong. The government knows it is wrong, but it supports it lock, stock and barrel. If `doing a Corrigan' was to be legitimate, then no working man or womanâunion member or not, private employee or whatever situation they are inâwould be safe in respect of their employment or entitlements.

I have placed a number of questions to the minister for workplace relations and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) on the Notice Paper seeking information on the individual cost components of moving product from origin to final destination. I will come to those a little later. What they show me is that neither minister has the information that is needed to justify or to explain the action they have taken. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would also like to touch on a very similar matter to the one the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) has just raised. As honourable members would know, in March of this year, I brought in a private member's bill in which it was proposed that certain steps could be taken to protect workers. I have always said that I have never believed that the private member's bill I introduced was a be-all and end-all.

speech.para: What did concern me, and this is what I believe is the industrial relations aspect of this particular budget paper, is the fact that the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) had actually confirmed in a press release that he was going to take particular steps regarding the protection of workers' rights and that he was going to take that to the forthcoming meeting of the Labour Ministers Council on 1 May 1998. I have a copy of the agenda paper of 1 May 1998. All of those labour ministers met at the 59th meeting in Wellington, New Zealand. You had to go to agenda item 4 to see what the minister had to say on this. He is the minister for workplace relations, the minister who was proclaiming that he had the be-all and end-all solution to the protection of workers' rights.

When the Cobar miners were down here, they had to park on the lawn of Parliament House before they even got a five-minute interview with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this country. When they got that five-minute interview, besides all the other promises that were made to them about that $7.9 million that they were owed in wages, one of the things the Prime Minister promised that Cobar delegation and Steven Roach of the Shearers and Rural Workers Union was, `At the very least, I will keep you up-to-date on what is happening about your claims.' Three months later, Mr Roach and those people still have not heard a thing from the PM's office.

But Minister Reith said, `No, I will take certain action and when I sit down with all the labour ministers of this country, we will discuss the item.' I was very pleased to see that the protection of entitlements of employees on insolvency went to that particular meeting. When I went to find out what actually happened, I was hoping to God that we were going to get something moving in this country. I am not the first one to raise this. It has been raised in the past and nothing has been done about it, and I was hoping something would be done in the future. We go to the recommendation and it states:

Because an employee's entitlements are often found in State legislation or a State award (as is the case for the Cobar and Woodlawn miners), the issue of how best to protect these entitlements is in part the responsibility of State Governments.
It then states:
It is therefore recommended thatâ
and this is from all of the years when we were going to get the wonderful solutionâ
(i) LMC recognise a joint Commonwealth/State responsibility to determine the best national approach in this area; and
(ii) the matter be referred to DOLAC for detailed consideration, including consultation with all affected parties, and the preparation of a report to LMC.

It is the greatest whitewash I have ever heard in my life. At least the minister, with all the support he would have Australia wide now, and surely with the support he would have from his government colleagues, should stand up and say, `It's about time we did something to protect the workers of this country. It's about time we stop'â
Mr Cadman interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWhat you are saying to me is that two wrongs make one right. Well, they do not. If we were wrong in the past, you are wrong in the present. For God's sake, the workers of Australia do not want to see people and governments wrong in the future and this is what you are hiding under. The bushel you are hiding behind is not the 13 years; it is your own incompetency. The bushel you are hiding under and trying to go to for cover is that you are saying now with one breath that we can preach to the workers of Australia, `Don't worry we'll look after you,' and what you are doing is sweet nothing.

speech.para: I believe that it is the greatest let-down to the workers of Australia who had high confidence that this federal minister would have at least gone to that Labour Ministers Council in Wellington, New Zealand, on this issue, following his press release and saying that my bill was not going to be the cure-all so let us pull it apart. I am not saying it ever was going to be the cure-all, but at least it could have been a beginning and we could have built from it. It was not a bill that I put together. It was a bill that this parliament paid to have a parliamentarian draftsman put together with the ideas that we needed to put in it.

So I am really saying how disappointed the workers of Australia are. We saw on our TVs tonight the workers of the paper mill in Burnie, Tasmania. I hope they have got means to make the redundancy payments and pay the outstanding wages to their employees, because that has not happened with the rest of these companies that have gone broke around this country. That insolvency has brought trial and tribulation to the families affected. You only have to speak to some of the women still in Cobar. Their men have left their homes because they are shearing, they are doing anything, to bring a bit of money back to the family so they can keep paying their mortgage hoping that, in the future, there will be some work in that town because that is where they have established their life and their families.

They were promised a lot by this government. They were promised a lot by this Prime Minister, and this Prime Minister and this government did not even have the decency to inform them three months later as to what is happening. There is nothing happening. There is nothing happening that is going to protect workers in the future. Regardless of what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Cadman) thinks about what we did or did not do, we did not do enough either. I am saying that it is about time a government stood up and took the bit between the teeth and did something for the workers of Australia.

talk.start.para: âI referred earlier to the cost components of moving a container of product from land side origin to final land side destination. I asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) question No. 2843, which was:

speech.para: What are the schedule charge rates for (a) loading on ship and (b) unloading from ship (i) 20 foot and (ii) 40 foot containers by type on offer by (A) P&O and (B) Patrick Stevedores at the port of Brisbane.

This is a minister who has railed and ranted frenetically and abusively and who has vilified and abused workers and their families on the waterfront for month after month after month. When you ask him, `What is the cost of stevedoring a container of goods across a wharf in Melbourne or Sydney?' what is the answer? `Commercial-in-confidence in Adelaideâthat is, don't know. In Botany, commercial-in-confidenceâdon't know. In Brisbane, don't know. Fremantle, don't know. Melbourne, don't know.'

I asked further, `What are the similar costs in respect of Antwerp?', because these are ports we are trading to. He said, `Commercial-in-confidence.' That is, I do not know. For Felixstoweâthe one he raves about so oftenâthe unloading cost is $179 to $205. Port Klang, $80 to $120 for unloading. Rotterdam, don't know; commercial-in-confidence. Singapore, $111 and $168 to unload. Yokahama, don't know.

All of those ports are ports with which we deal, and one would have to know the cost. I know the cost in Japan is about $250 to $280 per TEU. In Long Beach, the one he did provide, an average of $113. I then asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) what the sea freight charge was of moving from our major ports to ports of destination a TEU or a 20-foot equivalent container. To China, it is $1,300; to France, $1,970 and $2,155; to Germany and the European ports, around $2,000. USA west coast, $2,995. The east coast of the United States, $1,975; Boston, $2,550.

I went through all of those ports. I then asked questions of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What was the stevedoring cost and the land transport cost at the other end? All of those costs are absolutely relevant to this national debate about export freight costs, not picking one item and abusing the people involved there. I have done all of these figures, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I will read them to you. The road transport cost in Australia, we know from published sources, to Sydney is $288; ship based charges, $29; cargo based charges, $45; customs brokers, $110.

We will take the published figure from the BTCE for stevedoring, which is an average across Australia of $188. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, you know, because you know a bit about ports, and I know, that the published rate is not the paid rate. Depending on who you are as a customer and the number of ports you are using, your rate is a special rate. So it is something less than that figure. In some cases, it is as low as $70 for stevedoring a container.

If it was $200, that would mean 1c per kilo of wool or 1.1 cents per kilo of meat. With stevedoring, I am taking the published figure of $188. The total is $660 Australian land side; sea freight to the US west coast, $2,995; stevedoring at Long Beach, $113. And with land transport, let us round the figures off to $232âsomething less than the Australian land transport cost, but obviously it would be more. That gives a round figure of $4,000. So the stevedoring charge in Australia is 4.7 per cent of the $4,000 cost.

So what does the government and this minister zero in on? Hundreds of millions of dollars worth of damage done to our trade on the 4.7 per cent. Even in the government's own bible, the Productivity Commission report, it refers to lift charges for stevedoring as being 0.4 per cent of the total cost of moving a container to an export destination. That is 0.4 per cent in respect of an export reefer container out of Australia.

Let us say the container is going to Europe and the freight charge there is about $2,000 and the other land transport charges on the waterfront in Australia are $660, as I mentioned. Felixstowe Port, I know, has a $200 stevedoring charge. Let us say the land transport is $140. The total figure is $3,000. In that case, Australian stevedoring is 6.3 per cent. We can do better in Australia, but we will do better by leadership, by cooperation, by working together, not by vilifying a segment, one of the smaller segments, of the total cost. I put these figures on the record. Some are the government's, some are published, and some the government makes policy without knowing the facts. (Extension of time granted)

Let us put an end to this cant from the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. He cannot produce the figures. He is on the public record of this parliament. He does not know what the costs are of stevedoring in Australia. It is not enough to say they are commercial-in-confidence. He is responsible for providing advice to government, to the nation, on waterfront costs.

The most important thing in waterfront costs, in transport costs, is the total cost. As the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) knows very well, the total cost from origin to ship side, other side, unloading and delivering finally to the customer, is not the 1c of cost in stevedoring a kilo of wool that is important. Yes, any reduction in cost is important. We all wholeheartedly want to achieve that. Reliability is a factor, but there are no costings about this because this never was an exercise in productivity. This is an exercise that has emanated out of the vile hatred of the minister for workplace relationsâand anyone can see it in his frenetic behaviour in his chamber. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may not see it because you sit behind him. We see it, but let us get back to the real issue.

How do we make our transport services as efficient as possible? How do we make our products as competitive as possible in world markets? Reliability is a factor. Let us sit down and work that out because all disputes finish in a solution. The magic is to get to that solution as quickly as possible, not to polarise. This government-created, government-engineered dispute and fiasco has cost this country dearly in international image. I never want to see the ugly image of dogs, uniformed thugs, balaclavas, mace sprays and police raids with batons in this country's workplaces again. That is not part of the Australia that we were born into. It is not part of your Australiaâany of you in Australia. It is not part of my Australia. That must be put to an end.

Let us get all of the parties involved back to sitting round the table sorting out the best way of doing things. Let us deal with the facts of the matter. I have given you the facts of the matter.
