In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is what I borrowed the calculator for earlier, to calculate the percentages. It was not for that other foul exercise that the parliamentary secretary, the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), was referring to. I know he meant to be nice by it.

I also want to say also in defence of former Minister Sharp that I know what is going on around this building. I know that he and two members of his staff are being loaded with the responsibility and blame for this fiasco. I do not believe that. I know the minister well. We have served together on committees. I do not think he is the person responsible for this. This emanated out of the minister for workplace relations and the zealotsâthe Paul Houlihans, the Dr Stephen Websters and the Derren Gillespiesâwho have had to correct evidence that was given to the Senate estimates committee only yesterday. I think the blame lies there. But, whatever it is, let us try to get this country back to normal. Let us try to get back to re-establishing our image and improving the quality and efficiency of our service as quickly as we possibly can.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Remainder of billâby leaveâtaken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the midyear economic review released on 18 December 1997 contain a forecast growth in employment in 1997-98 of 1.25 per cent revised from the 2 per cent stated in the 1997-98 Budget but retain the forecast for the unemployment rate of 8 per cent; if so, how can the figures be reconciled.
(2) Does the review contain forecasts that the unemployment rate will fall below 8 per cent in 1998-99 and that economic growth will fall from 3.75 per cent in 1997-98 to 3.25 per cent in 1998-99.
(3) Is it a fact that economic growth of 4 per cent or more is needed to reduce unemployment; if so, how can the forecasts referred to in part (2) be reconciled.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO), the Budget forecast for year average employment growth in 1997-98 was revised from 2 per cent to 1Â¼ per cent, reflecting the weaker than anticipated outcome in the June quarter 1997. Forecast employment growth over the year to June 1998 was unchanged from the Budget at 2Â¼ per cent. Given monthly unemployment outcomes and no change in the forecast for employment growth during 1997-98, there was no change to the Budget forecast for an 8 per cent unemployment rate in the June quarter 1998.
(2) The MYEFO did not publish a forecast for the unemployment rate in 1998-99. A full set of forecasts for 1998-99 is contained in the May 1998 Budget.

(3) There is no unique rate of economic growth required to produce falls in the unemployment rate, since movements in the latter will be equally dependent on population growth and labour force participation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) How many persons are affected by changes associated with the introduction of the residential care allowance and the removal of rent assistance for nursing home residents consequently no longer able to claim the payment as a taxation rebate for medical expenses.
(2) What is the estimated saving to the Commonwealth from the measure for 1997-98.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) From 1 January 1997 until 30 September 1997, pensioners living in nursing homes were eligible for Residential Care Allowance (RCA), with the rates and eligibility the same as for rent assistance.

From 1 October 1997, RCA was replaced with the pensioner supplement, paid directly to service providers. This change affected all nursing home pensioner residents. The total number of nursing home residents for September 1997 averaged 71,326, of which around 90 per cent are estimated to be pensioners.

Also, from 1 October 1997, the basic daily care fee for pensioner nursing home residents was reduced (from 87.5 per cent of basic age pension plus RCA to 85 per cent of basic age pension) to compensate for the loss of RCA.

As income, RCA was not an expense, and as such the RCA payment itself could not be claimed under the medical expenses rebate. Only qualifying expenses can be claimed under the medical expenses rebate.
It is not possible to estimate resident numbers who used their RCA to pay their fees and who claimed their nursing home expenses under the medical expenses rebate.
However, this number would be small. Most residents who previously received RCA are full rate pensioners, and therefore have no tax liability from which to offset the medical expenses rebate.
(2) RCA was abolished from 1 October 1997, with both the basic daily care fee for nursing home residents reduced, and the replacement pensioner supplement introduced, as compensation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Will ex-servicemen with 30 days continuous service in an operational area be eligible to receive the Australian Service Medal 1945-75.

(2) Has Naval Personnel Services advised a number of ex-servicemen that they would be eligible for the Austral ian Service Medal 1945-75 Clasp Minesweeping; if so, how many veterans received the advice.
(1) Has the clasp been formally gazetted; if so, when; if not, how will the veterans be recognised.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. If the area is prescribed for the purpose of an award of the Australian Service Medal 1945-75.

(2) Yes. Some 40 veterans were advised that the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp `Minesweeping' would be awarded. This included the then President of the Returned and Services League of Australia, Major General James, in December 1996.

(3) A Clasp `Minesweeping' will not be formally gazetted. However, eligibility for the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp `S W Pacific' to include minesweeping activities and bomb and mine clearance duties has been extended to include those eligible personnel. A formal Instrument of declaration and determination was approved by the Governor-General on 16 April 1998.
I refer the honourable member to my Media Release of 24 April 1998 which states, quote:

"Approval to extend the provisions for eligibility of the award of the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp `S W Pacific' was announced by the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, Bronwyn Bishop MP.

"I am delighted to announce that recognition can now be given to those Australian Defence personnel who undertook minesweeping and bomb and mine clearance duties after World War II and missed out on an Imperial Naval General Service Medal or General Service Medal at the time," said Mrs Bishop.

"These Imperial awards which provided recognition could only be earned if 180 days qualifying service was rendered. It is this Government's policy that certain service of 30 days or more should attract the Australian Service Medal 1945-75. Those who did qualify for an Imperial award for minesweeping and bomb and mine clearance duties, however, will not be entitled to the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 in recognition of those duties."

Mrs Bishop said that the extension of eligibility resulted from a review carried out by the Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Honours and Awards, which consists of representatives from Government House, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The review identified that duties carried out in the South West Pacific were comparable to those of the British Occupation Forces in Japan which consisted of a wide range of duties, including minesweeping and bomb and mine clearance. Accordingly, those Service personnel who served in the Netherlands Indies, Portuguese Timor, Moratai Island, Sarawak, Brunei, British Borneo, Philippine Islands, Solomon Islands, Nauru and Ocean Islands, Burma, Malaya, Singapore, the Queensland coast and waters off the coast of China and the South West Pacific, for varying periods between from 3 September 1945 to 10 November 1956, will be eligible.
The medal will be awarded for 30 days continuous service during the eligibility periods." unquote.

subdebateinfo.title: Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2795)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Does his Department cooperate with other Commonwealth departments in deciding whether Australia is to become a party to the Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague 1954).

(2) Does his Department have to consult with State and Territory governments and agencies in deciding whether Australia is to become a party to the protocol; if so, with which State and Territory governments and agencies has his Department consulted and on what dates, in what form and with what outcomes.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. A number of Departments have a continuing interest in Australia ratifying the Protocol to the 1954 Hague Convention on the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict. These Departments include the Department of Defence; the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the Department of Communications and the Arts; and the Attorney-General's Department.

(2) Yes. Before Australia ratifies any treaty or related instrument, consultation with all State and Territory governments is required at various stages in the treaty-making process. Such consultations are yet to take place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2524 (Hansard , 10 March 1998, page 651) regarding a contract with Sirway Asia Pacific, has purchase order 2580040AC for the supply of crockery been completed as required by the due date of 20 January 1998; if so, what remains to be supplied.
(2) Do penalties apply to late delivery; if so, (a) what are they and (b) have they been applied.
(3) Have officers of his Department visited Sirway Asia Pacific's sites in Australia; if so, (a) which sites, (b) on what dates and (c) what reports were made to his Department.
(4) Is his Department able to supply documentary evidence of its monitoring of Sirway Asia Pacific's compliance with quality assurance clauses in the standing offer; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is:

answer.para: (1) The crockery against Purchase Order 2580040AC was delivered on 8 May 1998. Contract samples were approved on 16 January 1998 and the contractor had until 15 May 1998 to finalise the initial order.
(2) Yes.

(a) Clause 8.1 of the contract states "If the contractor is responsible for delivery being delayed more than 10 working days beyond the due date specified in the Contract he should contact the Ordering Authority for approval otherwise the Commonwealth is, without prejudice to any rights that would otherwise accrue under the Contract, entitled to recover from the Contractor a discount of 2% per week in respect of the period by which the delivery of conforming supplies exceeds the specified due date of the contract".

(b) The penalty for late delivery was waived for the inital order as it was agreed to give the contractor additional time for tooling up, ie to 15 May 1998. The contractor has been advised there will be no such extension for future orders.
(3) Yes.
(a) Clifton Hill Victoria; (b) April 1997; (c) It was reported that the storage facilities were suitable for storage of crockery.

(4) The Department has documentary evidence of its monitoring of the contract's compliance with Quality Assurance clauses in the standing offer. This information is considered to be Commercial-In-Confidence and, as such, cannot be released.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2663 (Hansard , 31 March 1998, page 1441), to what countries has the Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) been introduced.
(2) How does his Department define low risk nationalities and what criteria are used.
(3) How often is the decision to grant an ETA reviewed by his Department and what criteria are used.

(4) Does his Department undertake checking of boarding passes and passport matching in countries where the ETA has been introduced; if so, what are the details; if not, what is the nature of monitoring passengers boarding flights to Australia.
(5) From which countries did the (a) 202 and (b) 351 persons referred to in part (3) of the answer to question No. 2663 come.
(6) Has his Department discerned a changing pattern between the two program years referred to in the answer to part (3) of question No. 2663.
(7) In what year did Singapore Air Terminal Services (SATS) take over checking boarding passes and passport matching for flights to Australia.
(8) Why was the role transferred to SATS.
(9) How many persons travelling by air from Singapore have been refused entry at Australian airports since SATS took over the role and from what countries did they come.
(10) Has his Department discerned a changing pattern in arrivals since SATS took over the role.

(11) Have officers of his Department commented on problems since SATS took over the role; if so, (a) on how many occasions, (b) with what frequency, (c) what was the nature of the comments and (d) what action did he or the Secretary of his Department take in response.
(12) How many persons have been refused entry at Australian airports in the current program year and from what countries did they come.
(13) To what countries do the arrangements involving the authorised travel agents referred to in the answer to part (1) of question No. 2663 apply.

(14) Have the arrangements been cancelled in respect of an authorised travel agent; if so, in each case, (a) in what year were the arrangements (i) established and (ii) cancelled and (b) why were they cancelled.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Electronic Travel Authority is available to Citizens of the following 26 countries: Andorra; Austria; Belgium; Brunei; Canada; Denmark; Finland; Germany; Greece; Iceland; Ireland; Italy; Japan; Liechtenstein; Luxemburg; Malaysia; Malta; Monaco; Netherlands; Norway; Singapore; South Korea; Sweden; Switzerland; United Kingdom; United States of America
(2) In determining if a nationality is of `low risk' established indicators which are able to provide a measurable risk assessment are assessed in each instance. These are:
. rates of overstay
. rejection rates covering visitor and Temporary Business Entrant applications
. rate of change of class applications following entry to Australia
. refused entry rates
. application rates for bridging visas
. application rates for protection visas.

(3) The issue of an ETA is an automated process which involves the computer matching of biodata of an applicant against immigration data bases containing lists of persons adversely known to the Department. If the biodata matches with a record held in an immigration data base then the ETA is not issued by this automatic process.

A further matching procedure is carried out when the record of the ETA issue is loaded into the immigration visa data base for future use at the time the ETA holder undergoes boarding procedures overseas and again during arrival procedures in Australia.

(4) No. It is the airlines' responsibility to ensure that only passengers carrying proper travel documentation are uplifted. Failure to comply is a breach of Section 229 of the Migration Act for which the airline as an alternative to prosecution may pay a fine. The details of passengers who claim to have been granted an ETA are checked by the airlines through a computerised checking system to ensure that a visa has been granted.

(5) (a) The 202 persons travelling by air from Singapore who were refused entry at Australian airports this financial year (as at 28 February 1998) came from 40 countries: Sri Lanka (43), People's Republic of China (17), Thailand and Iraq (16 each), Somalia (15), Kuwait (14), India (12), Malaysia (6), Bangladesh,Turkey and Iran (5), Algeria (4), Hong Kong (3), Afghanistan, Albania, Austria, Ghana, Lebanon, Nepal, Pakistan, Romania, Singapore, Syria, Taiwan, United Kingdom, Zaire (2), France, Egypt, Indonesia, Ireland, Japan, Lithuania, Netherlands, New Zealand, Nigeria, Philippines, Slovenia, South Africa, Sudan, Yugoslavia, Stateless (1).

(b) The 351 persons travelling by air from Singapore in 1996/97 who were refused entry at Australian airports came from 37 countries: Sri Lanka (112), People's Republic of China (46), Somalia (28), Thailand (25), Iraq (22), Indonesia (20), Kuwait (11), India (10), Bangladesh (8), United Kingdom (6), Algeria, Iran, South Africa (5), Nigeria and South Korea (4), Malaysia (3), Bulgaria, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, Morocco, Nigeria, Syria, Turkey (2), Albania, Dominican Republic, Ghana, Kenya, Lebanon, Myanmar, Philippines, South Africa, Sudan, Vietnam, Yugoslavia (1), Stateless (8).

(6) The latest figures available (as at 30/4/98) confirm that the number of inadmissible passengers arriving from Singapore is continuing to decline. The total number of inadmissible passengers refused entry at Australian airports is however increasing.
(7) It is not known when SATS started checking boarding passes and passport matching for some airlines' flights to Australia.

(8) It is a matter for the commercial judgement of airlines as to whether they use their own employees to conduct checking of boarding passes and passport matching for flights to Australia or whether they contract the services of SATS for this purpose.
(9) Figures are not kept which would enable the question to be answered.

(10) Although it is not known when SATS started checking some flights to Australia, over the last two years the figures would indicate that there has been a downward trend in movements of inadmissible passengers from major source countries.

(11) My Department's Airline Liaison Officer in Singapore noted in May last year that a small number of passengers had recently passed through SATS checks undetected. This was brought to the attention of SATS management by our Airline Liaison Officer.

(12) As at 30 April 1998, this financial year 1272 persons were refused entry at Australian airports. They came from the following countries: People's Republic of China (220), Indonesia (118), Iraq (114), Sri Lanka (108), Somalia (72), Thailand (61), New Zealand (48), Algeria, Kuwait (46), Iran, United Kingdom (39), South Korea (31), Philippines (28), India (21), Malaysia (19), Hong Kong (17), Colombia (16), Pakistan (13), USA (11), Bangladesh (10), Germany (8), Afghanistan,Ghana, Sudan (7), Ireland, Lebanon, Netherlands, Singapore, South Africa, Tonga, Turkey (6), Albania, Cambodia, Canada, France, Israel, Japan, Taiwan (5), Fiji, Kyrgyzstan, Nepal, Romania, Syria, Vietnam (4), Brazil, Chad, Denmark, Kazakhstan, Liberia, Russia (3), Angola, Austria, Ecuador, Nigeria, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Sweden, Switzerland, Tunisia, Uganda, Yugoslavia, Zaire, (2) Argentina, Croatia, Czech Republic, Egypt, Eritrea, Greece, Italy, Ivory Coast, Libya, Lithuania, Macedonia, Mexico, Micronesia, Morocco, Norway, Portugal, Samoa, Sierra Leone, Slovenia, Spain, Uruguay, Stateless, Unknown (1).

(13) Arrangements for authorised travel agents have been or are operating in 32 countries. Since the implementation of ETA many of the agency arrangements have been made redundant in those countries. The 32 countries are: Austria; Canada; Czech Republic; Denmark; Finland; Former Yugoslavia; Germany; Greece; Gulf States (6 countries); Hong Kong; Indonesia; Italy; Japan; Malaysia; Netherlands; Norway; Singapore; Slovenia; South Africa; South Korea; Sweden; Switzerland; Taiwan; Tahiti; Thailand; United Kingdom; USA.

In the case of Hong Kong, in addition to normal agency arrangements for Hong Kong residents and other approved nationalities, special arrangements exist with one office of the China Travel Service (CTS) located in Hong Kong to process a limited number of visitor applications (usually for tour groups) from Chines residents of the Guangdong Province. These visas and the travel of the recipients are monitored by the Australian Consulate-General Hong Kong.
(b) The agency in Greece had issued a visa in direct contravention to instructions given by the Migration Office of the Australian Embassy, Athens.
